review: This is my first book by Lisa Jewell, but it won't be my last. While there was no great twist at the end, this is a well-told, gripping suspense novelThis is my first book by Lisa Jewell, but it won't be my last. While there was no great twist at the end, this is a well-told, gripping suspense novel about two women who randomly meet in a restaurant while celebrating their birthdays with their respective husbands. They are "birthday twins." One seems sane; the other not so much. I believe the original premise must have been, How can two people born on the same day in the same hospital end up with such different lives? I like that question.I listened to the audiobook, which was fantastically narrated and edited. FOUR disquieting STARS ...more

review: This was my third Claire Keegan book, and whoa, I did not expect this to be so disturbing. SO LATE IN THE DAY is three short stories about disenfranchThis was my third Claire Keegan book, and whoa, I did not expect this to be so disturbing. SO LATE IN THE DAY is three short stories about disenfranchised lovers, progressing from sad, to worrisome, to seriously creepy. It's Keegan's powerful use of dramatic irony that makes this book difficult to put down. She puts her characters in increasingly dangerous situations that we can sense will turn out badly, like a human train wreck. Keegan's writing is spare and beautiful, but I have to say I enjoyed FOSTER and SMALL THINGS LIKE THESE much more than this book. THREE icy STARS...more

title: Yellowface
author: Kuang, R.F.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's easy to know why the NYT, et al., liked this book so much; it's about the book industry. Agents and publishers are known to love books about bookIt's easy to know why the NYT, et al., liked this book so much; it's about the book industry. Agents and publishers are known to love books about books and writing. But this book, IMO, is unoriginal. What about Ladder to the Sky, by John Boyne? What about the movie called The Words? They are both stories (and I'm sure there are more) about young writers who steal manuscripts by known writers and publish them as their own. Enter YELLOWFACE, by R.F. Kuang. Same story. Same guilty complex. Same ending. Basically. This book brings racism to the mix. Maybe that's why it did so well. It's not just white men stealing from white men. Kuang is an Ivy League-educated writer/insider. She knows how the game (oops, I meant system) works. She makes fun of it, which I imagine the industry got a real kick out of. I kept reading this book (even though it was unoriginal) only to see if it had a redeeming twist at the end. What it does is spiral in on itself. TWO boring STARS...more

title: The Giver        (The Giver, #1)
author: Lowry, Lois*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Author Philip Pullman once said: "There are some themes, some subjects, too large for adult fiction; they can only be dealt with adequately in a childAuthor Philip Pullman once said: "There are some themes, some subjects, too large for adult fiction; they can only be dealt with adequately in a children's book." Pullman may have had THE GIVER, by Lois Lowry, in mind when he said that. Written in 1993, of course I had heard of this book, but it wasn't until an 11-year-old recently told me how much she loved it that I decided I was overdue to read it. Plus it's really short and I needed one more book to complete my GR challenge. Whatever the reason, if you haven't read The Giver, do it. Dystopian fiction? Science fiction? Magical realism? This story has elements of unreality that thrust the world of Jonas and his family into a vivid and shocking reality. Part The Handmaid's Tale, part The Stepford Wives, the community in which Jonas lives has a lot of rules but no freedom. Jonas is the perfect character to shatter the illusions that the Committee has created for its inhabitants. But at a cost, naturally. FIVE tragic STARS...more

title: The Vulnerables
author: Nunez, Sigrid
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was my first book by Sigrid Nunez. What a unique voice she has! Nunez is a writers' writer: she quotes and references other great writers (ProustThis was my first book by Sigrid Nunez. What a unique voice she has! Nunez is a writers' writer: she quotes and references other great writers (Proust, Woolf, Didion, et al) and their styles and methods of writing. I found this interesting, but not sure everyone would.The Vulnerables is a pandemic book. It chronicles the unnamed narrator through lockdown in NYC. For me, just enough time has passed that I was able to appreciate (and to an extent smile at) the reminders of that hell. (Remember wiping down our delivered groceries because we thought they might have the coronavirus germs?) When the narrator has to share an apartment in the city with a troubled young man as they both take on the task of caring for a mutual friend's parrot, Nunez touches on humanity and people's idiosyncrasies in full color. This book would be a good one to reread someday.Four Stars...more

Fortunately, the story is lightened a bit by minor characters who add comic relief.I found this book overly long, going off on unnecessary tangents and details. review: Such a sweet and touching story. I loved it. It's especially amazing considering it's a debut novel by Laura Spence-Ash. Her writing is clean and lyriSuch a sweet and touching story. I loved it. It's especially amazing considering it's a debut novel by Laura Spence-Ash. Her writing is clean and lyrical, truly lovely. There is just enough atmosphere and description to make you feel like you're living in the novel with out any "boring parts."BEYOND THAT, THE SEA is the story of Beatrix, a young British girl who is sent to America by her parents at the start of WWII. Apparently that wasn't uncommon, though I didn't know anyone did that. Eleven-year-old Beatrix, soon known as Bea, lives with the Gregorys: mother, father, and two boys: William, 13, and Gerald, 9. We can see immediately there might be feelings between Bea and the boys; that is just one storyline that kept me turning the pages. After the war, Bea returns to London, a strange and different world. I recommend this to anyone who loves historical fiction. FIVE wavy STARS...more

title: Hare with Amber Eyes
author: de Waal, Edmund
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book wasn't what I expected. It's billed as a memoir about a man's collection of small, Japanese netsuke: tiny sculptures that attached to obis tThis book wasn't what I expected. It's billed as a memoir about a man's collection of small, Japanese netsuke: tiny sculptures that attached to obis to counterbalance a small packet. They were gorgeous, delicate objects made of ivory or wood. But the book is also about Edmund de Waal's illustrious Jewish family, the Ephrussis, from the late 1800s in Paris through WWII and into the 70s and beyond, ending in Japan and England. Their family, previously unknown to me, were contemporaries with the Rothschilds and friends of Manet, Proust, Renoir, etc. This is an amazing, sad story of one family's survival and the surprising way that their collection of nearly 300 netsukes survived as their only possession. It is beautifully written and certain editions have lovely color photos. Look for one of those editions if you want to read this.FOUR delicate STARS...more

review: Anthony McCarten is more famous for being a filmmaker (The Theory of Everything, The Darkest Hour, The Two Popes ... ) but whether film or books, boy Anthony McCarten is more famous for being a filmmaker (The Theory of Everything, The Darkest Hour, The Two Popes ... ) but whether film or books, boy is he a storyteller! GOING ZERO is about ten people (5 lay people, 5 professionals) who attempt to go off the grid for 30 days for the chance to win $3,000,000. A big tech company run by the cocky Cy Baxter teams up with the CIA to test their ability to find anyone. We know from the description that librarian Kaitlin Day is assumed to be an easy person to catch. I thought that would ruin the ending, but it doesn't. There are enough twists and turns here to keep you turning the pages as fast as you can. This book brings up enough controversy (pros and cons) of surveillance, facial recognition, and national security to keep readers engaged in that debate for a long time to come....more

title: Tom Lake
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Kurt Vonnegut once said no book should have a prologue. I think TOM LAKE, by Ann Patchett, needs a prologue. It has a good premise: during the Covid-1Kurt Vonnegut once said no book should have a prologue. I think TOM LAKE, by Ann Patchett, needs a prologue. It has a good premise: during the Covid-19 lockdown a mother of three grown daughters tells them about the summer she dated a famous movie star—before he was famous. But it doesn't start there at all. It starts with the mother as a teenager, the first time she auditioned for Emily in the play of Our Town. The mother, Lara, was "discovered" by a Hollywood agent in the play and flown out to California to star in a movie. While waiting for the movie to premiere, she finds herself in Tom Lake, Michigan, doing summer stock, with Peter Duke, an actor who later became an A List movie star. It's a sweet story, very character driven, but it's slow and quiet. Meryl Streep narrated the audiobook, which was both a plus and a minus. I mean, it's Meryl Streep, but you never lost yourself in the story because it's Meryl Streep. Then at the very end, there's a strong political message. That surprised me.I am a big fan of Ann Patchett, but this wasn't my favorite book of hers.THREE STARS...more

title: Legends of the Fall
author: Harrison, Jim
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: LEGENDS OF THE FALL, by Jim Harrison, was chosen for my book club as a simple summer read. Written in 1979, it tells the story of the Ludlow family, aLEGENDS OF THE FALL, by Jim Harrison, was chosen for my book club as a simple summer read. Written in 1979, it tells the story of the Ludlow family, a Civil War Colonel and his three sons who have moved to Montana to avoid the government after seeing what they did to Native American Indians. It's a majestic, tragic story mixed with love and loss. It'll rip your heart out, reader.And here's where I go rogue. I saw the movie from 1994, starring Anthony Hopkins, Brad Pitt, and a stellar supporting cast, most notably Julia Ormand who plays Susannah, the woman who changes every Ludlow man's life. I read the book for my book club, then watched the movie again. I have to say this is a rare instance where I liked the movie better than the book. The book jumps around the globe (Montana, Boston, the oceans wild ...) but the movie stays more centered on Montana. I found it more cohesive and focused. Harrison is said to have written this book in under two weeks, changing only one word for his second and final draft. Hmm. Anyway, it's a powerful family tragedy, but I recommend the movie over the book....more

Oprah chose this for her book club and said she ranks it iOne thing has become perfectly clear: I have a different taste in books from Oprah Winfrey. Oprah chose this for her book club and said she ranks it in her Top Five Favorite Books of all time. Well, not me. THE COVENANT OF WATER, by Abraham Verghese, is a 700-page family saga/medical drama/love story. Verghese's writing never got in the way of the story, except when it came to the medical scenes. As a doctor, I understand he had to write those parts accurately, but only other doctors likely appreciated that. The novel takes place in India from 1900-1977, and I enjoyed learning about India's rich history and culture, but overall I found the book slow and overly long. It has a nice message, but I was eager to finish it.TWO soggy STARS...more

This book is obviously popular within its target audience, but it doesn't deserve such a high overall rating, IMO. EVERY SUMMER AFTER is the story of a 30-something magazine editor who goes "home" for the funeral of her ex-boyfriend's mother. It easily could have been a "women's fiction" beach read, but much of the story was told in flashbacks to their teenage years. That part of the story felt like YA. But some scenes (flashback and present-day) were fairly graphic for YA, to the point of being Romance. I'm okay with Romance ("sex on the page") but I've never known anyone as obsessed with "sucking his bottom lip" as this author. I might have liked it better if it had had a different editor.TWO sucky STARS...more

You have to buy into the premise, but McAllister does a very good job of makingWRONG PLACE WRONG TIME, by Gillian McAllister, is a time-loop mystery. You have to buy into the premise, but McAllister does a very good job of making it believable. The story was engaging and exciting. I listened to it, and really couldn't wait to get back to the story any time I had to break away. After her son commits a murder (no spoiler there), Jenn keeps waking up on days in the past, days before the murder. She realizes she's being given the chance to relive her life, in hopes—she thinks—of being able to stop the murder. You'll have to read it yourself to find out if she does!This is a good story, and I recommend it. FOUR timeless STARS...more

title: Hello Beautiful
author: Napolitano, Ann*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am in the minority here, but HELLO, BEAUTIFUL, by Ann Napolitano, really fell flat for me. I loved her previous book, DEAR EDWARD, so I had been looI am in the minority here, but HELLO, BEAUTIFUL, by Ann Napolitano, really fell flat for me. I loved her previous book, DEAR EDWARD, so I had been looking forward to this one. Plus Oprah raved about it. But not me. I never got drawn into it, emotionally.Hello Beautiful follows four sisters in Chicago, from their teenage years through their 40s. They are extremely close—until they're not. And then of course something brings them back together. This story was mostly Telling, not Showing. Isn't "show, don't tell" one of the first rules of good writing? Even the title is an example: At one point, the sisters mentioned that their father always greeted them with "Hello, beautiful," but I'm pretty sure he said that only once. Napolitano had to tell us that he always said it; she could have just included that in the father's scenes. Regardless, I felt the characters reactions to the (multiple) rifts in this family were overblown. TWO windy STARS...more

review: THE GUEST LIST, by Lucy Foley, is pitched as an Agatha Christie-like mystery. That's pretty bold, but it's easy to see why. THE GUEST LIST takes placeTHE GUEST LIST, by Lucy Foley, is pitched as an Agatha Christie-like mystery. That's pretty bold, but it's easy to see why. THE GUEST LIST takes place on a remote island off the coast of Ireland, and Foley casts shade on multiple characters (two common features of AG). But this is more suspense novel than mystery novel because we don't know until almost the end who ends up dead. Plus there is no detective. The killer admits guilt in the end.It's a good story and strong cautionary tale: If you wrong people, it just may come back to haunt you.THREE and-a-half stormy STARS, rounded down because of too many coincidences...more

review: When I discover a great book by an author new to me, I often look for other books he/she has written. But usually it turns out the first book I read bWhen I discover a great book by an author new to me, I often look for other books he/she has written. But usually it turns out the first book I read by an author is my favorite, whether it was their first or fifth published book. It other words, writers have a style, often a theme that runs through their work. Publishers love that continuity, and so do most readers, apparently. I am usually left slightly disappointed in the cookie cutter aspect.Claire Keegan defied that norm for me. I read SMALL THINGS LIKE THESE for my book club (gave it 5 Stars), and then immediately read FOSTER, which was written years before. Turns out I like this book just as much, possibly more. Another sweet stand-alone short story, Foster is the story of a young Irish girl whose parents send her to her aunt and uncles to stay because they are overwhelmed by all their children and expecting a new baby, too. The aunt and uncle show the young girl a life foreign to her. I won't say more.FIVE bright STARS...more

review: I was looking for a light-hearted audiobook recently, and this fit the bill perfectly. If you're not familiar with Julia Whelan, you are missing out oI was looking for a light-hearted audiobook recently, and this fit the bill perfectly. If you're not familiar with Julia Whelan, you are missing out on a real talent. She is amazing.THANK YOU FOR LISTENING is the story of Swanee and Nick, two audiobook narrators who are brought together by Nick's romance-writing aunt to narrate her final book. Swanee, who had sworn off any more romance books agrees only because she needs the money. Romance ensues. The story is deeper than one might expect, but still light enough—and laugh-out-loud funny enough—to happily distract the reader/listener from the real-life world we have to face everyday. It's predictable as one might expect, but has a lot of layers to keep the story interesting. I really wish goodreads would allow us to rate books by category; this doesn't have the gravitas to rank up there with literary award winners, but it is an easy book to recommend. FOUR sweet STARS...more

title: As I Lay Dying: The Corrected Text
author: Faulkner, William
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is my first Faulkner book, so I don't know if they are all this dense and enigmatic. Written in 1930 but probably taking place earlier than that,This is my first Faulkner book, so I don't know if they are all this dense and enigmatic. Written in 1930 but probably taking place earlier than that, the language of rural Mississippi is beautiful but almost foreign. On top of that, Faulkner uses innuendo, stream-of-consciousness thought, rotating POV, and so many oblique references that I'm not sure I fully understand the entire storyline after just one reading. I even have questions about the title.AS I LAY DYING is about the impoverished Bundren family. As the matriarch is dying, her family tries to cope. Then they set off on an arduous journey through a rainstorm to bury her in her family plot (not her husband's family, but her own). The story is farcical! I don't know if this was ever made into a movie, but if the storyline weren't so sad it would be laughable. Most of the story (80%) happens after the mother dies, so why did Faulkner choose a present-tense title from the period before her death? The beginning is so enigmatic that I barely knew who was whom by that point. I am glad to have read Faulkner, but I hope my book club discussion can explain some of the finer points of this novel.THREE sopping-wet STARS...more

title: Small Things Like These
author: Keegan, Claire
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: SMALL THINGS LIKE THESE, by Claire Keegan, is a gem. She is a genius writer of short stories. The first thing I did when I finished this sweet little SMALL THINGS LIKE THESE, by Claire Keegan, is a gem. She is a genius writer of short stories. The first thing I did when I finished this sweet little book was to start it over again. This is a book that can easily be read in one sitting, or at least one day.Set in 1985 in a small Irish town, Small Things Like These is the story of Bill Furlong, owner of a small business that delivers coal and wood to homes and businesses. He is also a happily married father of five girls. One of Furlong's customers is the secretive abbey/convent at the top of the hill. When he goes one evening to deliver their coal, he sees something that at first troubles him and ultimately changes his life. The best part of this book is the ending. Furlong takes an action that leaves the reader wondering what will happen next, something so big that one might beg for a sequel ... but that would lessen its power. She ended the story at just the right moment.FIVE amazing STARS...more

review: There is a lot to like about THE MAID, by Nita Prose, but its biggest attribute, IMHO, is light entertainment. As the winner of Goodreads 2022 MysteryThere is a lot to like about THE MAID, by Nita Prose, but its biggest attribute, IMHO, is light entertainment. As the winner of Goodreads 2022 Mystery & Thriller category, I expected a much more complicated plot. It doesn't even read like a whodunit. It reads more like a character-driven story of an autistic maid (although they never use the word autistic).The maid, cutely named Molly, is a 25-year-old woman who lives with her grandmother and works at the Regency Grand. She is meticulous and regimented, but struggles to understand human nuances. When she discovers the body of a frequent hotel guest, we quickly learn who is legitimately her friend and who uses and takes advantage of her. I am happy to have read this book, but don't think it deserved to win the top mystery choice of last year. (Read THE PARIS APARTMENT for a better mystery.)THREE tidy STARS...more

title: The Family Chao
author: Chang, Lan Samantha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I chose THE FAMILY CHAO to lead for my book club, and so I reread it. I liked it even more the second time. (Amazing how much more detail we absorb onI chose THE FAMILY CHAO to lead for my book club, and so I reread it. I liked it even more the second time. (Amazing how much more detail we absorb on a second reading, isn't it?) While I can't say The Family Chao is a favorite of mine, in many ways it feels like a "perfect book," one I would be thrilled to have written. It's a literary mystery, but also a love story, a revenge story, and a dysfunctional family story. (Is there any other kind of family?)(Certainly not in literature; that would be boring.) The characters are distinct and introspective; in other words, they face and admit their faults. While not autobiographical, Chang is the daughter of Chinese immigrants. She addresses racial identity head on. While other members of my book club didn't like it as much as I did, we did agree it was entertaining. Again, I highly recommend this book. FIRST REVIEW:THE FAMILY CHAO, by Lan Samantha Chang, was a delightful surprise. As a modern re-telling of The Brothers Karamazov, by Dostoevsky, Chang sets her story in a small, fictional town in Wisconsin. The parents, Big Leo and Winnie, were immigrants to America, pursuing the American dream. They started a Chinese restaurant and had 3 sons: Dagou, Ming, and James. Big Leo had a larger-than-life personality and made plenty of enemies. When he is killed, many people had a potential motive, but one of his sons is arrested and put on trial. That's when the family secrets are revealed.Chang, the director of the Iowa Writers Workshop, is naturally a gifted writer and storyteller. In an interview, I heard her say she gave herself permission to let loose a little bit, not be so serious this time. This book sparks with humor and contains "419 exclamation points." That's more than a few. Though she weaves in many serious themes, there is also a sweetness and lightness to her story. I highly recommend it. FOUR delicious STARS...more

title: Demon Copperhead
author: Kingsolver, Barbara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had heard this was a great book, and wow, yes. Too often if I hear great things about a book I go in with super high expectations that are hard to rI had heard this was a great book, and wow, yes. Too often if I hear great things about a book I go in with super high expectations that are hard to reach. It's the "voice" of DEMON COPPERHEAD that really blew me away. I read several of Barbara Kingsolver's books in the 90s, but didn't know she had the ability to get this deep into her character and story. Well done, Ms. Kingsolver! As a mashup of David Copperfield's plot and Holden Caufield's voice (from Catcher in the Rye), Demon Copperhead tells the story of a teenage boy growing up in very rural Virginia, that southwest tip that abuts Kentucky and Tennessee; not a place that has much going for it. In fact a place that more often devours its own. Born to a drug addicted mother and an already dead father, Damon (aka Demon) faces every worst-case scenario anyone could imagine for a child. The single positive influence in his life is the Peggot family who lives next door to Demon and his mother. Though also highly dysfunctional on their own, the Peggots are the only solid foundation Demon can cling to in times of trouble. And the book is basically 500+ pages of trouble. But don't let that deter you! This is a well-told, gripping story with just enough heart and humor to keep it from being too emotionally heavy. I could barely put it down. This would be an excellent book club book, and I may even choose it for my own so I can reread it. It's that good. Four-and-a-half stars rounded up to FIVE heartbreaking STARS...more

The final quarter of this book was much more exciting than the beginning.HORSE is based on the true story of Lexington, the greatest American racehorse and stud sire of all time. I doubt it's a stretch to guess that Brooks hoped to do for this horse what Laura Hillenbrand did for Seabiscuit, and the horse is indeed worthy of her efforts. Though, because Lexington lived from 1850 - 1875, Brooks had very few facts to go on. It's clear she researched this horse and era incredibly well, but parts of the story felt forced to me, especially where it seemed she felt obliged to include all those facts. THREE racing STARS...more

title: Austerlitz
author: Sebald, W.G.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: AUSTERLITZ, by W.G. Sebald is a layered, dense, heavily-disguised story about the Holocaust. Sebald must have been a genius to pull this off. It is saAUSTERLITZ, by W.G. Sebald is a layered, dense, heavily-disguised story about the Holocaust. Sebald must have been a genius to pull this off. It is said that the heaviest subjects cannot be written about directly; the author must tell an oblique story to get a serious message across. That is this book. With three hundred pages and only 7 paragraphs, we can barely come up for a breath in this story—much in the same way those who lived through WWII and the Holocaust did not get to step away or have a reprieve. As the title character relates dozens of anecdotes about his life (in a search to find out who he really is once he discovers he was adopted by an English family), each scene felt analogous to many of the horrors we now know about. So many scenes contain long lists ... I imagined as I was reading it the lists of names of those who had been killed or went missing during the war. This is a book that benefits from deep discussions. Read it with others, if possible. It's tough to get into, but there is a reason for that. It's not meant to be a beach read.THREE overwhelming STARS...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: SECOND READ: I believe how much we like a particular book is based on where we are in life when we read it. When I reread LUCY BY THE SEA for my book SECOND READ: I believe how much we like a particular book is based on where we are in life when we read it. When I reread LUCY BY THE SEA for my book club, I was shocked by how much more it spoke to me. Perhaps the pandemic was too fresh in my mind the first time (hard to read about it because the scars were still fresh), or perhaps I had grown enough emotionally that I was more open to Strout's message. I identified so closely with Lucy Barton this time. In fact, this book jumped to the forefront of my favorite Elizabeth Strout books. FOUR and a half touching STARSFIRST READ: I feel like I should shelve LUCY BY THE SEA as a memoir because that's how it reads. I imagine that's what Elizabeth Strout is shooting for, but I'm not a fan of memoirs. Strout is decidedly unsentimental: Just the facts, Lucy. She is candidly straightforward in telling us about her beloved character Lucy Barton's experience through Covid and the lockdown. Maybe it's just me, but I wasn't ready to relive it, especially from a New Yorker's point of view. It was bad enough in the Midwest. Regardless, I did related to Lucy as a mother of grown children. It's hard! Grown children vacillate wildly between needing their parents and needing to draw boundaries in order to become fully independent adults themselves. Late in the novel Lucy says: "And there they were, my beautiful daughters. By the duck pond were my two girls. But they were never really mine, I thought as I walked toward them, any more than New York City was ever really mine." FOUR realistic STARS...more

author: McEwan, Ian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: LESSONS, by Ian McEwan, has a great question at its core: How far would you go to fulfill your creative destiny? Does that answer change if the creatiLESSONS, by Ian McEwan, has a great question at its core: How far would you go to fulfill your creative destiny? Does that answer change if the creative is a mother? The problem is McEwan makes the reader work way too hard to get the message, IMHO. In fact, this book seems to have two plots that barely intertwine. First, as you can see by the cover and title, is a young boy's experience with piano lessons at a private boarding school. The second is found on the front jacket flap: "Twenty-five years later, Roland's wife mysteriously vanishes, and he finds himself alone with their baby son." In between the two storylines, we get the husband and wife's entire backstories, and even their parents' backstories. This borders on info dump to me. One er said that instead of "going deep" into the characters, McEwan chooses to "go wide," meaning he encompasses too much history to tell his story. I agree with that. I had to skip huge chunks of this book just to finish it. All that being said, McEwan does have many beautiful sentences and thoughts about life. Also his message about a wife's desire to fulfill her creative drive (acknowledging men get to do it all the time; the problem is when women try it) is well-taken. I just wish he could have left out a bunch of the backstory.TWO boring STARS...more

title: The Ink Black Heart        (Cormoran Strike, #6)
author: Galbraith, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: REVIEW UPDATE: I read/listened to THE INK BLACK HEART for a second time to listen for more clues about who I knew to be the killer that Strike and EllREVIEW UPDATE: I read/listened to THE INK BLACK HEART for a second time to listen for more clues about who I knew to be the killer that Strike and Ellacott are looking for. Even when I knew what to listen for, I still say the culprit was a bit obscure. But, I loved the parts between Robin and Strike even more than in the first read. By the way, Robert Glenister, the narrator of the audio book is phenomenal! Still 5 Stars.ORIGINAL REVIEW: Robert Galbraith (aka JK Rowling) is a phenomenal storyteller. In this, the 6th installment of the Cormoran Strike & Robin Ellacott series), "Galbraith" has created a storyline that closely mirrors her own life story—to an extent. My biggest knock of this book is its length (over 1000 pages). Really? It seems pretty easy to keep the reader guessing when you can throw in a dozen potential killers (and all the inherent red herrings) when you're looking for only one. In other words, no, I didn't guess the killer until it was obvious because Galbraith expertly teases us with so many possibilities. In this story, Edie Ledwell and her boyfriend, Josh Blay, create a YouTube cartoon called the Ink Black Heart. Then a fan creates an online fan-fiction game with the same characters. When the original cartoon gets so popular and Netflix comes calling, the gamers get angry about the creators selling out—so someone kills Edie and almost kills Josh. Strike and Ellacott are hired to find the anonymous person who started the online game—a person who may or may not be the actual killer. One of the best parts of this series is the romantic tension between Cormoran and Robin, a la "Moonlighting," if anyone remembers that TV show. I can't wait for the next (and final?) installment to get more of their story.FOUR and a half inky STARS, rounded up...more

title: Our Missing Hearts
author: Ng, Celeste*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: OUR MISSING HEARTS, by Celeste Ng, is vastly different from her two previous books. Yes, there's a family at the center of the story, but this book isOUR MISSING HEARTS, by Celeste Ng, is vastly different from her two previous books. Yes, there's a family at the center of the story, but this book is considerably more political. As it should be, in some regards. With the real-life anti-Asian sentiment that increased significantly during the pandemic (not to mention atrocities that go back to WWII and beyond), Ng practically is the perfect person to write a story like this. Set in a dystopian near-future, Our Missing Hearts is the story of a Chinese American mother who must abandon her husband and child after her poetry is used in protests to defy the US government. In this version of the future, the Chinese are blamed for "the crisis," (not a viral pandemic, but a financial crisis) and the US government institutes PACT, the Preserving American Culture and Traditions Act. This allows (encourages) Americans to spy on their friends, family, and neighbors. If anyone engages in anything subversive to our then-ultra-conservative government, the authorities will step in and remove the children from their families and "re-place" them in "better" homes. Thus, the protagonist, Margaret Mia, had to leave her home and family before the government could take their only son from her and her husband. When she can't stand it anymore, Margaret leaves a clue for her 11-year old son to come find her in New York City. It's a touching cautionary tale, but the least favorite of Ng's books for me.THREE scary STARS...more

review: This book was recommended to me by my yogi after I mentioned shoulder pain one too many times. Though Dr. John Sarno's "prescription" is controversial—or at least not accepted by mainstream medicine (how's that system working?)—his premise in this book makes complete sense to me. His method of addressing chronic pain is basically free (just the cost of the book for most), which might be one reason the medical world that is quick to recommend surgery or drugs looks down on Sarno's theory. It would be easy to cite his premise here, but that would be the equivalent of a spoiler for a good book. A person who has suffered long-term pain really owes it to him- or herself to read this book and decide if the idea holds merit.(My shoulder pain is gone, by the way.)FOUR painless STARS...more

review: Of all the 19th century books/authors I've read (Eliot, Austen, Brontë, Dostoevsky, etc.), I have to say Thomas Hardy's TESS OF THE D'URBERVILLES was Of all the 19th century books/authors I've read (Eliot, Austen, Brontë, Dostoevsky, etc.), I have to say Thomas Hardy's TESS OF THE D'URBERVILLES was the hardest to get into and had the most archaic language of all. That said, the second half really picked up; I was eager to reach the end of the story.First published in 1891, Tess of the D'Ubervilles illuminates how sexist and unfair the morals and mores were in 19th century England. What a shame that women were treated so harshly.While I was glad to have read this modern classic, it will be hard to recommend. review: The title of this book should have been: Tennis, Everyone?, because it's ALL ABOUT TENNIS, down to point-by-point descriptions of a ton of matches. CaThe title of this book should have been: Tennis, Everyone?, because it's ALL ABOUT TENNIS, down to point-by-point descriptions of a ton of matches. Carrie Soto was the greatest women's tennis player of all time, and by some metrics the greatest player period, male or female. Now, seven years after retirement, Nicki Chan has tied Carrie's record, so Carrie comes out of retirement to attempt to win at least one more Slam title. We aren't supposed to like Carrie Soto, not really, not for most of the book. Her new nickname in the press is "the bitch," because "the battle-ax," her nickname before retirement, just wasn't accurate enough. Carrie Soto has no filter, no compassion, and no sense of humor. She cares about two things: tennis and her father, a retired tennis player from Argentina who becomes her coach—until she fires him because he doesn't want her to win as badly as she does. About 2/3 through this book, Taylor Jenkins Reid, whose other books I thoroughly enjoyed, broadens the storyline to touch on the father/daughter relationship. That added one star to my , but I seriously ached for more of a subplot most of the way through. THREE single-minded STARS...more

Set in California the 1950s and 60s, LESSONS IN CHEMISTRY, the debut novel of Bonnie Garmus, is the story of Elizabeth Zott, a fiercely independent, brilliant, and outspoken chemist who suffers from the intense sexism of her era. Elizabeth Zott is a hoot, though she's never funny. She had an extremely dysfunctional childhood and has had to claw her way through her career. I love how she is true to herself and not ashamed of her life or choices, despite all the judgement and prejudices of the time. Plus, for much of the book, she uses her chemistry knowledge and skills to host an afternoon TV program called "Supper at Six." I even learned a few cooking tips along the way.Though it's not flawless, I highly recommend it. FOUR bubbly STARS...more

Pulitzer Prize winning author Jennifer Egan intentionally gives this book dozens of characters.I don't even know where to begin with THE CANDY HOUSE. Pulitzer Prize winning author Jennifer Egan intentionally gives this book dozens of characters. I started out writing down their names to keep them straight, but gave up after a few chapters. Egan gives us an analogy on page 323 (not a spoiler) that maybe justifies why she used so many characters, but that's not the point of the book. And, since it's not the point, I wonder if it was extreme. The point of THE CANDY HOUSE is the slippery slope of technology, specifically how dangerous it might become if you upload too much personal information to social media companies. While reading certain chapters of this book (specifically about Lulu as a grown-up), I could barely put the book down. Other times, I was frustrated by trying to remember the early details about characters she brought back late in the book. Bottom line: It's a good book if you're willing to do the work to keep the characters straight.FOUR sweet STARS...more

It's the simple story of an 85-year-old woman who goes for a walk on New Year's Eve, 1984. Except it's not really simple at all. Kathleen Rooney, a poet and storyteller, wove love, sadness, feminism, motherhood, friendship, and melancholy into a funny and touching story. Inspired by a real woman, Lillian Boxfish was a trailblazer in the NYC advertising world in the 1920s - 1950s. Now, Lillian walks the city streets and talks to strangers, much to her grown son's chagrin. Along the way she spreads her wit and wisdom with a truly colorful cast of characters. I read this book in 4 days and truly adored it.FOUR peripatetic STARS...more

review: Rom-com is not a genre I typically read so this may be a little harsh, but ... Emily Henry's books (this is my 2nd of hers) are entirely predictable. Rom-com is not a genre I typically read so this may be a little harsh, but ... Emily Henry's books (this is my 2nd of hers) are entirely predictable. Is that why they are so popular? Boy meets girl, they resist falling in love, then boom they realize they are soulmates. I decided these books are like life: We have good days and bad days, we suffer mass confusion and then find a little clarity, and in the end we die. Predictable, yet we still love life. PEOPLE WE MEET ON VACATION was a light, fun story, and that is precisely the reason I read it. Escapism at its finest. I preferred Emily Henry's BOOK LOVERS to this one, but it was genre-appropriately cute. Henry is a good storyteller, and the audio recording was really good. Bonus: Poppy, the protagonist, is a travel writer, so the book whisks you off to some fantastic locales. THREE sunny STARS...more

title: Black Cake
author: Wilkerson, Charmaine
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: BLACK CAKE, by Charmaine Wilkerson, starts with a good premise: A mother reveals her life's secrets only after she has passed away in an attempt to reBLACK CAKE, by Charmaine Wilkerson, starts with a good premise: A mother reveals her life's secrets only after she has passed away in an attempt to reunite her estranged children. However, the story is told in mostly very short chapters—essentially just random scenes—told by one of a dozen POV characters. In other words, there was no flow. The "chapters" jump from "Now" to "Then" and bounce around all the 50+ years between Now and Then. Hemingway had an "Iceberg theory": A writer should include only the tip of the iceberg (10%) in the final draft of a book. The writer should hold back up to 90% of the story, and let the reader figure it out. Wilkerson didn't do that. She wanted us to have all the backstory of way too many characters. IMHO, she should have worked the pertinent facts into the story and left out the fluff. I also wish she had made the timeline more fluid. That said, I like the idea that a recipe can link people to their heritage and family. That seems very special to me.TWO bouncy STARS...more

It defines "unputdownable." Not only is the story powerful, but it carries an anxious gravitas that hits hard—as it should, as everyone should wake up to. What starts out as a subtle story with intrigue builds slowly until it takes your breath away. At least it did mine. But what is it about, you ask? Kind of time travel, or at least you have to accept that premise. The novel spans 5 centuries (1900s to 2400s) with different sets of characters, some who are able to visit the others who lived in the earlier eras. The way Mandel links the stories is brilliant, a true puzzle to solve. FIVE non-tranquil STARSSECOND READ: A few holes pop up with a second reading, but I was still captivated by this story and message. review: TRUST, by Hernan Diaz, was a huge disappointment for me. Diaz's last book was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. In this, I felt he had an interesting (if notTRUST, by Hernan Diaz, was a huge disappointment for me. Diaz's last book was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. In this, I felt he had an interesting (if not original) story idea, then tried much too hard to elevate it. It was a swing and a miss, IMO.Set in the early 1900s and told in four parts, each a novel or memoir from a different character, TRUST is essentially the story of a woman named Mildred Bevel, but primarily in relation to her husband, Andrew, a very successful financier. My biggest knock is that each of the four stories has the same "voice." The second part sounded like/was a retelling of the first part, so much so it made me want to give up on the book. I did like the third part, but before that, it was all "telling," no "showing." The final part could have turned my opinion on its head, but it, too, was a fail. The crucial reveals were in the same voice, from a character who absolutely shouldn't have had the same voice. TWO fallen STARS...more

review: HOW HIGH WE GO IN THE DARK, by Sequoia Nagamatsu, was my third book in a short period of time where at least part of the novel was set in the future. HOW HIGH WE GO IN THE DARK, by Sequoia Nagamatsu, was my third book in a short period of time where at least part of the novel was set in the future. The other two (Sea of Tranquility and Cloud Cuckoo Land) I loved. They allowed general fears to enter the storyline, but always balanced them with hope. This book ... oh my. It should have been in the Horror section of a bookstore. It's pitched to lovers of Cloud Atlas (one of my all-time favorites) and The Glass Hotel. Yeah, no. Well maybe only in that the authors link disparate storylines with a common occurrence, but not in the eloquence of writing. [In the first chapter, Nagamatsu weaves in a scene of backstory, but he uses past tense instead of past perfect tense, so I was really confused until I figured that out.]To be fair, I only made it to page 73. And that was after I set it aside early on to take a break from the tragic yet realistic scenes that Nagamatsu presented as our possible future. He may have offered glimmers of hope later in the book, but this is the stuff of my nightmares, and ... no thank you. I would like to say more, but maybe someone out there wants to read about the worst end-case scenarios of more pandemics and viruses and how exactly they kill our children. Be my guest.ONE horrific STAR...more

review: This is a sweet little gem of a book. Written in 1953, Herrigel, a German professor of Philosophy in Tokyo, recounts his arduous, multi-year journey tThis is a sweet little gem of a book. Written in 1953, Herrigel, a German professor of Philosophy in Tokyo, recounts his arduous, multi-year journey to becoming a Master in Archery. Archery, one of the "artless arts" that can lead to a state of Zen, is the path Herrigel takes to understand what "It" is that masters achieve at the height of their field. Indeed, mastery of swordsmanship, flower arranging, dance, ink painting (i.e. calligraphy), along with "all other arts," share a similar path and lessons in reaching this state of being. In fact, this book was recommended to me by my Yogi, who has read it many times, and I love the link from the ancient arts to the yoga I practice daily. FIVE Zen-like STARS...more

title: The Diary of a Young Girl
author: Frank, Anne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not sure how I made it to 2022 without having read THE DIARY OF A YOUNG GIRL, by Anne Frank, but better late than never. Everyone should read thisI'm not sure how I made it to 2022 without having read THE DIARY OF A YOUNG GIRL, by Anne Frank, but better late than never. Everyone should read this book. The intelligence and deep personal insight that Anne Frank possessed as a teenager is astounding. She was more self-aware than most adults I know today. The power of this book comes from the extremes. In some entries, Anne Frank moons over the boys she "loved" before they went into hiding, or moans about her parents' rules—typical teenage girl stuff. In others, she writes of the kind of mother she wants to be when she grows up. Still other entries recount what they have heard on the BBC radio, about Jews (and anyone who assists them) being arrested and sent off to "work camps." They had heard that many Jews were being gassed, and she wonders if that, in the end, isn't such a bad way to go. You owe it to yourself to read (or re-read) this book, especially in light of the current atrocities being committed by Putin against Ukraine. War is not the answer.FIVE heart-breaking STARS...more

review: Kate Quinn is an excellent storyteller, and I love that she writes about lesser-known but real women throughout history (mostly WWII, as of late). THEKate Quinn is an excellent storyteller, and I love that she writes about lesser-known but real women throughout history (mostly WWII, as of late). THE DIAMOND EYE is about a Ukrainian mother and scholar, Lyudmila Pavlichenko, who becomes Lady Death, a sniper for the Russian army after Hitler invades the country in the late 1930s. The first half of this novel goes into great detail about how the young mother and student became a sniper, and then takes us into the trenches as she stalks and kills Hitlerites. Quinn did her research for this one, vividly describing rifles, tactics, and the horrors of war. It was a bit much for me, but clearly necessary for this story. For the second half of the book, Quinn follows Mila on her tour of the United States in 1942 to ask the US for more aid for the Russians to fight the Nazis. There, the hunter becomes the hunted, and the story ramps up. FOUR shiny STARS...more

It's hard for me to give it 5 stars though, when that would put it right up there with the literary giants. The storyline of THE PARIS APARTMENT is fresh and clever. Foley withholds just the right amount of facts and clues until the last possible moment. In essence, Jess, a young Brit who has had nothing but bad luck, goes to Paris to visit her brother, who seems to have done well for himself. But when she arrives at his apartment, he's not there, and something bad has definitely happened. Scrappy young Jess has to both make her way in a strange city where she doesn't speak the language and figure out what has happened to her brother. The two weren't close, so there's a lot she doesn't know. The other residents of the apartment building are shady and each one is less helpful than the next. The ending does not disappoint! Set in rural Ireland sometime in the early 20th Century, This Is Happiness is the tale of Noel Crowe, a seminary dropout, who goes to live with his grandparents while trying to find a new direction for his life. Then "Christy" comes to town. Christy, a boarder also staying with Noel's grandparents, is here to help erect the new light poles, but he has an ulterior motive. As the light poles are erected and Christy searches out his childhood sweetheart, we learn about faith and families, love and loss, and moving on. review: I am a big fan of John Boyne's work. He is a top-notch storyteller. Whether he's writing plot-based or character-based novels, his stories are grippinI am a big fan of John Boyne's work. He is a top-notch storyteller. Whether he's writing plot-based or character-based novels, his stories are gripping. Born in Ireland in 1950, Boyne, a gay man, has made no secret that growing up gay in Catholic Ireland was the most difficult part of his life. Many of his novels include the horrors and atrocities Catholic priests have committed on young boys. If Boyne doesn't personally hate the Catholic Church, many of his characters do. In other words, it's difficult to talk about THE HEART'S INVISIBLE FURIES, his 2017 novel, without mentioning the hatred of the Catholic Church and the entire county of Ireland (which is/was essentially ruled by the Church) that seeps through his words.THE HEART'S INVISIBLE FURIES is the story of Cyril Avery, a boy adopted by Charles and Maude Avery in 1945. Spanning 70 years, the novel follows Cyril, also gay, through his life and chronicles the laws, prejudices, and attitudes that shape the lives and behaviors of homosexuals, both in Europe and New York City. Hatred of the Catholic Church aside, this is a deep, emotional, sweeping novel full of pain and survival, loss and love. It was difficult to put down, and I think this story will stay with me for a long, long time. FOUR tender STARS...more

title: The Victim
author: Bellow, Saul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I randomly read (listened to) this book because it was suggested just before I took a road trip. I had never read anything by Saul Bellow before, so II randomly read (listened to) this book because it was suggested just before I took a road trip. I had never read anything by Saul Bellow before, so I was curious. Written in 1947, it's easy to see I was not Bellow's intended audience, as this novel didn't really speak to me, despite its top-notch writing.THE VICTIM is the story of Asa Leventhal, a twenty-something married Jewish man, but the novel came off like a long short story. "Listen to what happened to me that time my wife went down to help her mother move." In other words, it didn't have much of a plot other than getting inside Leventhal's head during a difficult month in his life while his wife was away. In fact, it's not even clear who "the victim" is/was. It might have been one of several—or multiple—characters. While his wife is away, Leventhal is being trailed by and is then accosted by an old acquaintance, Kirby Albee. Albee blames his recent downfall in life on Leventhal for extremely bizarre circumstances. Albee is cunning and manipulative, so he convinces Leventhal of his guilt. This really messes with Leventhal's head when his wife (his rock) is out of town and also while his nephew is dying. As Leventhal sinks deeper into frustration and confusion, he worries that he's losing his mind like his mother did when he was a child. In the end, Leventhal stands up to Albee, though barely. They go their separate ways, then meet up again in the denouement. Though I enjoyed reading a work by Saul Bellow, who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in the 70s, I can't say this book held up, at least not for me. There are a lot of Biblical references as well as middle-aged working-man references. I'm glad to have read it, but can't say I liked it.THREE dusty STARS...more

BEAUTIFUL WORLD, WHERE ARE YOU is the story of two friends, Alice, the protagonist—a successful novelist who strongly resembles Rooney herself—and Eileen, her college friend whose boyfriend just broke up with her. Soon Alice meets Felix, a good-for-nothing, attractive man whom Alice quickly falls in love with, and Eileen reconnects with her childhood crush, Simon. As the two girls struggle to keep their friendship alive after life pulls them in different directions, both couples struggle to figure out where they are going and what they want from each other. Maybe the angst of this story speaks volumes to Millennials, but to me it came off as self-indulgent and tiresome. Yes, the world today is in turmoil, and I understand thirty-somethings have a lot of questions about Life—I can appreciate that—but this book was definitely not my favorite novel of 2021.TWO yawning STARS...more

title: The Push
author: Audrain, Ashley*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The plot of THE PUSH, by Ashley Audrain, definitely pushes the envelope. Is it me, or is literature headed toward Extremism? Apparently storylines havThe plot of THE PUSH, by Ashley Audrain, definitely pushes the envelope. Is it me, or is literature headed toward Extremism? Apparently storylines have to be over-the-top these days to get an agent/editor/publisher's attention. THE PUSH is the story of Blythe, a woman whose mother left her as a child. When Blythe marries Fox, she decides she will be the opposite of her mother. Except she isn't. She doesn't take to motherhood, at least not with her first child. She does better with her second child, a son. And then something happens, multiple "things" happen, which lead to the end of Blythe & Fox's marriage. Though Fox tries to convince Blythe she is the problem, Blythe is convinced the blame lies with someone else. Beyond this extreme storyline (to elaborate on why it's extreme would be a spoiler), Audrain's writing-style choices are also unusual. The story is told mostly in the second person as Blythe, in retrospect, tells Fox her side of the story about what happened and why from her point of view. "Your house glows at night like everything inside is on fire." "You slid your chair over and tapped my text book with your pencil ..." It's cumbersome. As a mother who loved her children, I couldn't relate to nor did I enjoy the first half of this book. I had to skip forward because it was painful to hear how Blythe ignored her crying baby over and over and over. The second half was easier to listen to but did not redeem the book in my opinion.TWO sad STARS...more

The mother, Beverly, is a "very popular" author who we learn uses a ghostwriter. George, the father, is a BBC personality who is "not racist!" They have three GenZ children, Nelson, Elizabeth, and Achilles, who are seriously messed up in their own right. Each character is a caricature and their behavior is extreme, but with the point of making a statement about today's culture, specifically how a certain segment of the population is ruled by social media. Inevitably, each of the Cleverlys screws up royally, and we watch them crash and burn. If you appreciate satire, this is a great book, even more so if you're on Twitter or at least aware of the Twitterverse culture.FOUR and a half hilarious STARS, rounded down...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I already want to read SULA again; it was that good. But mostly I want to read it again because I didn't expect it to be so touching. It's a slim bookI already want to read SULA again; it was that good. But mostly I want to read it again because I didn't expect it to be so touching. It's a slim book, 174 pages, and was written early in Morrison's career. The power in this novel from 1973 hits about two-thirds of the way through. It turns really sad. Sula and Nel are childhood friends, growing up in a small Ohio town, beginning just after WWI. Their families are poor and the girls have basically nothing but each other. Then tragedy strikes, someone dies. The girls' reactions to the death shape their futures, and eventually Sula moves away for ten years. When she comes back, things go from bad to worse between the two women. They both survive the only way they each know how, until one of them doesn't. SULA is teeming with colorful characters, characters no one but Toni Morrison could create. They made me laugh, they shocked me, and they touched my heart. FIVE surprising STARS...more

title: We Do This 'til We Free Us: Abolitionist Organizing and Transforming Justice
author: Kaba, Mariame
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It would be nearly impossible to summarize a book like WE DO THIS TILL WE FREE US, by Mariame Kaba, in a couple paragraphs. This is a collection of esIt would be nearly impossible to summarize a book like WE DO THIS TILL WE FREE US, by Mariame Kaba, in a couple paragraphs. This is a collection of essays and interviews collected from the past several years on a monumental subject and national/global movement. The primary message and intent of Ms. Kaba is abolishing the prison-industrial complex. But wait! If those words alone make you want to dismiss Kaba, her ideas, or even this , give me just one minute. I read this book in order to understand how the hell we, in 21st century America (and globally), could possibly accomplish that. Shut down the prisons? No, thank you! But that is an unfair dismissal of her ideas. Kaba wants to eliminate harm from society. Who can argue with that? She knows it is a very complicated idea, especially considering that the idea of "an eye for an eye" is one of the fundamental tenets of many/most religions. Beyond that, it's how we Americans were raised. If we were naughty, we got a spanking. Two brilliant observations: "No one enters violence for the first time by committing it." and, to paraphrase: Hurt people, hurt people. Therefore, Kaba's basic premise is to stop punishing/hurting/abusing young people so they don't learn violence as a way of life. And prisons make offenders worse, ergo they cannot be the answer to our dysfunctional society.My primary reaction to her ideas and proposals (abolishing prisons) is that they are excellent as an ultimate goal, but they should not be presented or taken as a starting point. If that is an end goal, then Square One has to focus on 1) Maternity care and paid leave, plus paid paternity leave. 2) Nurturing and affordable childcare. 3) Early childhood education and equal access to the Internet and devices. 4) Equal education for all. 5) New non-violent methods and responses to youths and teens who will inevitably make mistakes. To build a new society, we have to start with a solid, level foundation for all. Then, ideally, in twenty years or so our prison system would be vastly abolished or minimized on their own accord. That, in my opinion, should be the first step to restorative justice. Two last thoughts. We are now proud of Abolitionists like John Brown and Frederick Douglass for helping to end slavery, so if someone identifies today as an abolitionist, do not dismiss them. Also, educate yourself on the unfortunate soundbite/hashtag #DefundthePolice. What that movement really means is #IfwewantabetterworldweneedtotakesomefundingawayfromPolicebudgetsandRefundCommunities. But that didn't fit in most tweets. Defunding police forces would allow cities to fund mental health organizations that could help a huge number of the people who are now handled (often poorly) by police officers that were never trained to be mental health providers. We need an alternative to 911, a 3-digit number that would ring trained responders for a person in crisis. THREE brilliant STARS...more

review: Let me start by saying I love Louise Penny's Three Pines/Armand Gamache series. I've read them all. This, THE MADNESS OF CROWDS, her latest, does not Let me start by saying I love Louise Penny's Three Pines/Armand Gamache series. I've read them all. This, THE MADNESS OF CROWDS, her latest, does not disappoint. It did make me a little nervous, though, as I started reading.In THE MADNESS OF CROWDS, the newcomer to the frigid fictional town of Three Pines, Quebec, is Abagail Robinson, a statistician who has run the post-pandemic numbers and has developed a highly controversial way to undo the economic damage that COVID has done to our planet—specifically, Canada, where the novel is set. I believe the premise of her theory might be accurate, but it's so horrific I'd wondered if Penny had gone too far. Luckily, the story focuses mainly on the characters and their actions and motivations. Like most mystery writers, Penny makes sure multiple characters have a potential motive and possible opportunity to commit the expected murder. In this, I did not guess who the guilty party was before she revealed him/her. I do wish Penny would write longer paragraphs, fewer one-sentence declarations, but I still love her snowy, yet cozy murder mysteries.FOUR blizzardy STARS...more

THE WAR FOR GLORIA, by Atticus Lish, is a tough story that pits a 15-year-old boy against his estranged father when the boy's mother is diagnosed with ALS. author: Clinton, Hillary Rodham
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: STATE OF TERROR was the opposite of what I was hoping for. I was hoping it would be a Louise Penny mystery with insider tips and ideas from Hillary ClSTATE OF TERROR was the opposite of what I was hoping for. I was hoping it would be a Louise Penny mystery with insider tips and ideas from Hillary Clinton. Nope. This is Hillary Clinton's stab at a novel with, I'm guessing here, no more than guidance from Louise Penny. The story follows a fictitious Secretary of State, Ellen Adams, through a potential "worst case scenario" in American History. From the epilog we know that means nuclear war. Hillary Clinton, it appears, felt no need to cage her politics and opinions, because it takes direct aim at the man who beat her in the 2016 election. Anyone who dislikes it solely because of its politics has the right to go there because the author did first.Sadly, the plot is elementary, the dialogue is stiff and trite, and the ending is very predictable. Worse yet, I'm sorry to say, is the narration of the audio version. Though I assume actress Joan Allen is a lovely person, the narration was possibly the worst I've ever listened to. ONE sad STAR (raised to TWO because there's a brief stop in Three Pines, with a cameo appearance by Chief Inspector Armand Gamache!)...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read IN THE COUNTRY OF OTHERS, by Leila Slimani, for my book club. It's not a book I would have picked up on my own, but it was interesting to see pI read IN THE COUNTRY OF OTHERS, by Leila Slimani, for my book club. It's not a book I would have picked up on my own, but it was interesting to see part of the world at a time in history that I knew very little about—aside from the movie CASABLANCA, which happened a few years before this in the same area. Set in the late 1940s - early 1950s in central Morocco, this story is about a Frenchwoman's life after she marries a Moroccan WWII hero who helped fight for the resistance in France. The racial discrimination was as bad then as anything we see in our world today, probably worse, directed primarily at the French Colonists who lay claim to vast regions of Morocco after the war. The husband, Amine, takes Mathilde to his hometown so he can take over the family farm after his father dies. They struggle desperately with their crops, the discrimination, and the social morés women faced in Muslim countries. It was a brutal existence for many. My biggest knock on this book is that the plot didn't flow. It was written with 9 Parts, which felt like short stories. Maybe if it had been sold as short stories instead of a novel, I might have appreciated it more. I also might appreciate it more after I hear the discussion of my book club. TWO dusty STARS...more

review: Ursula K. Le Guin's rendition of TAO TE CHING isn't a book you read, then shelve and forget about. It's a little treasure to pick up often to remind uUrsula K. Le Guin's rendition of TAO TE CHING isn't a book you read, then shelve and forget about. It's a little treasure to pick up often to remind us of a simpler, yet more powerful way to live. Lao Tzu wrote the original Tao Te Ching thousands of years ago. Many scholars have translated and attempted to simplify and define Lao Tzu's enigmatic "poems" about The Way and Power. It referred often to Emperors and Kings and princes. After studying his writings for years, Le Guin intentionally created this rendition as "a Book of the Way accessible to a present-day, unwise, and perhaps un-male reader, not seeking esoteric secrets, but listening for a voice that speaks to the soul." This book definitely spoke to my soul. It's deep and lovely.FIVE powerful STARS...more

review: APPLES NEVER FALL, by Liane Moriarty, is pitched as a murder mystery. When Joy, wife of Stan and mother to four grown children, goes missing, her husbAPPLES NEVER FALL, by Liane Moriarty, is pitched as a murder mystery. When Joy, wife of Stan and mother to four grown children, goes missing, her husband becomes the primary suspect. But it's difficult after reading this book to put it in any single category. I can't say too much without spoilers, but the plot is kind of all over the place. In fact, it's so character-driven, that it could almost be called a fun work of literary fiction, if that's even a thing.At age 69, Joy and Stan Delaney are newly retired empty-nesters. Once owners of a thriving tennis academy, they are now bored and unsettled. Then one night a girl named Savannah knocks on their door with blood dripping down her face. She said her boyfriend hit her so she left ran out and randomly knocked on the Delany's door for help because their home looked friendly. Joy is delighted to have something to do, someone to take care of. But Savannah is not what she seems, and Joy's four grown children are not happy about the situation. When Joy goes missing, the key to her disappearance is centered around Savannah, as well as Stan. So that's the basic plot, but as I said, this book is entertaining, but not a straight whodunit. THREE juicy STARS...more

title: The Sweetness of Water
author: Harris, Nathan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE SWEETNESS OF WATER, Nathan Harris's debut novel, kind of snuck up on me. I probably wouldn't have picked it up on my own, but it was chosen for myTHE SWEETNESS OF WATER, Nathan Harris's debut novel, kind of snuck up on me. I probably wouldn't have picked it up on my own, but it was chosen for my book club. And I'm so glad it was! Harris's writing style is lyrical, with long, vivid sentences. (I doubt he would cite Hemingway as an influence.) But by the time I got into the groove of his rhythm, I fell deep into his story. The novel is about hope, the importance of hope for everyone.Set in Georgia just days after the Emancipation Proclamation, The Sweetness of Water follows two brothers, Prentiss and Landry, who have just been freed. They soon meet George and Isabelle Walker whose son Caleb is a Confederate soldier, away at war. The Walkers, originally from Baltimore, are outsiders even in their adopted hometown of Old Ox. When they hire the brothers to help work on their land, it causes trouble with the lifelong Southerners who don't believe the freedmen should be paid as much as George wants to pay them. Not long after Caleb returns from the war, someone commits a murder. That's where the story really takes off.The characters in this novel are well-written and feel very real. Their personal histories are raw and often tragic. As the book nears the end, the "profluence" escalates, and it's difficult to put down. There's no Hollywood ending to this one, but I loved it.FOUR and a half sweet STARS...more

title: The Magician
author: Tóibín, Colm
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am amazed by how compelling I found this book when it is essentially a glorified Wikipedia entry about the Nobel Prize winning writer Thomas Mann. II am amazed by how compelling I found this book when it is essentially a glorified Wikipedia entry about the Nobel Prize winning writer Thomas Mann. I both listened to the audiobook and read along with a hard copy (something I love to do!) and could scarcely put it down. Colm Tóibín somehow made Mann's story urgent and gripping. The life story of Thomas Mann, a closeted homosexual who was married to a woman and fathered six children, had a difficult and dramatic life, most definitely worthy of a book. A German who became famous as Hitler was rising into power (he won the Nobel Prize in 1929), Mann was a powerful voice against Hitler. He emigrated first to various European cities, and then Princeton, NJ, just before the war broke out, and eventually Los Angeles before returning to Switzerland for the final stage of his life. He lost multiple family members to suicide, and at least three of his children were also gay or bisexual, one also a drug addict. What amazed me most from this book is learning how powerful Mann was considered at the time ("the most important living German after Einstein,") and also how nonchalant Mann and his wife were about their children's colorful lives. They spoke openly about their partners and affairs. I have owned a copy of Mann's THE MAGIC MOUNTAIN for ten years (and still have every intention of reading one day), but I read this book for my book club. I am eager to hear what others say about it. FOUR illuminating STARS...more

review: The first time I read this book, I thought it felt like the outline of a saga. In roughly 250 pages, Groff tells the fictionalized story of Marie of FThe first time I read this book, I thought it felt like the outline of a saga. In roughly 250 pages, Groff tells the fictionalized story of Marie of France, a real-life woman who lived from 1141 into the early 1200s. Several paragraphs are simply a few sentences from various years of her life, in chronological order. It felt unfinished. More common now is for an author to choose one chunk of time, usually mid- to end-life, and tell about the protagonist's young life in backstory. The second time I read this book—for my book club—I caught much more of Groff's beautiful writing and the necessary struggles people/women (for there are no men in this book) had to endure just to survive. I appreciated it much more for what it is.FOUR matriarchal STARS...more

review: The title of this book isn't random. Richard Powers wants the reader to feel bewildered—as is he, I imagine. BEWILDERMENT is the story of Theo Byrne, The title of this book isn't random. Richard Powers wants the reader to feel bewildered—as is he, I imagine. BEWILDERMENT is the story of Theo Byrne, a widower, astrobiologist, and father of a young boy who is "on the spectrum." The story is teeming with science, astronomy, and the insanity of humans who fail to see how beautiful and lucky we are to be on this incredible planet. Because of the aforementioned science (science-fiction nerds will love it!), it took me a while to get into the story. I was a bit put-off by Powers' seeming need to show off ... and then I understood it was likely purposeful. There is a mid-point shift where the story becomes more personal, and that changed my perception. And the ending, well, the ending is a punch in the gut.FOUR bright STARS (and if I read this again, I will probably raise it to Five Stars)...more

author: Auster, Paul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Want to know how to take a book from great to meh? Make it twice as long as it should be! 4 3 2 1, by Paul Auster, clocks in at approximately 1000 pagWant to know how to take a book from great to meh? Make it twice as long as it should be! 4 3 2 1, by Paul Auster, clocks in at approximately 1000 pages; by page 700ish, I was so ready to be done with this book. 4 3 2 1 is four iterations about a boy named Archie Ferguson. Born to the same parents on the same day, each chapter (Archie 1.1, Archie 1.2, etc.) takes us further into each life. While it's crazy to think "What would my life be like if I had ... gone to this college instead of that college, or not gone to that party, or moved into this apartment instead of that apartment?" taking it to the extreme that Auster did in this novel was just too much. Ernest Hemingway has an "Iceberg theory" about writing: A writer should leave out 90% of what he knows about his characters and their backstories; the reader should be able to intuit the rest. Yeah, Paul Auster gave us the entire iceberg with this novel. His writing is superb, but the story was too long.THREE tiresome STARS...more

Again,Taylor Jenkins Reid is an excellent storyteller. MALIBU RISING is my second of her novels, and I enjoyed it as much as DAISY JONES and the SIX. Again, I listened to the audio version, and was treated to an excellent performance by Julia Whelan. Set in 1983 with flashbacks to the 60s and 70s, Malibu Rising is the story of four siblings whose father is a famous singer on par with Frank Sinatra. Naturally, he's not a great father. When their mother dies, the oldest child, Nina, takes over running the family. They manage—barely—until the father returns. Reid peppers her stories with acute observations on each of her round characters, as well as the relationships between siblings, giving the novel more weight than an average beach read. Plus, her scenes are very cinematic; they seemed destined to become movies. (But don't wait for that, read the book first!)FOUR Malibu-beachy STARS ...more

This is my first Marc Levy book, and I thoroughly enjoyed his storytelling. Set in 1950 England and Istanbul, the writing was evocative and detailed. I will look for more of his books.Alice Pendelbury, a 30-something orphan and perfume maker, and her friends take a Christmas Eve trip to a fair, where her friends convince her to have her fortune told by an old woman in a booth. The woman contradicts everything Alice knows about herself, and this eventually sets Alice on a journey to Istanbul. Alice's neighbor, Daldry, agrees to escort her there and pay her way thanks to an inheritance that he is trying to burn through. He returns early, and Alice stays on to find "the man who will change her life," according to the fortune teller. She finds this and more.This book isn't likely to blow anyone's mind, but it's a lovely, engaging story. I had never heard of Laura Dave before, but when I read the premise and first few pages of THE LAST THING HE TOLD ME, I was hooked. I never wanted to put this book down, and when I had to, I couldn't wait to get back to it. Hannah Hall is a furniture maker in NYC. When Owen Michaels, a Silicon Valley tech genius, walks into her store with one of her best customers, the two cautiously hit it off. Hannah was raised mostly by her grandfather and has trouble opening up to people. Owen's first wife was killed tragically, and he is raising their daughter, Bailey, by himself in Sausalito. When Hannah and Owen get married (not a spoiler), Hannah works very hard to win over her 16-year-old stepdaughter. One day, both Hannah and Bailey get cryptic, scribbled notes from Owen. His company has been raided, and he has disappeared. As Hannah and Bailey follow the very few clues they have as to what's really going on, they discover an unknown past, and also a way forward. title: Orphan Train
author: Kline, Christina Baker*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read ORPHAN TRAIN, by Christina Baker Kline, because my children's 2nd great-grandfather came to the Midwest on an orphan train. The idea of orphan I read ORPHAN TRAIN, by Christina Baker Kline, because my children's 2nd great-grandfather came to the Midwest on an orphan train. The idea of orphan trains—taking orphans and unwanted children from the East Coast in the late 1800s and early 1900s and sending them to "farm country"—is both heart-warming and heart-breaking. Often, young babies were adopted quickly by families that couldn't have children, but older boys and girls were often "taken" by families that needed extra help on the family farm or in the family business. Not all orphans ended up in loving homes. Kline centers her novel around a troubled teenage girl in 2011 and a 91-year-old woman who was sent on one such train from New York to Minnesota after the rest of her family died in an apartment fire. When Molly, the teenager, is assigned service hours for a misdeed, she commits to helping Vivian, the elderly woman, clean out her attic. This takes them down memory lane, unraveling both of their life stories. One  I read called this book "predictable," so I thought I knew where it was going. Let's just say it did not end as I expected it to, so I wouldn't call it predictable. That being said, this book ended in a flash. Because I was listening to the audio version, I was unaware of how close to the end I was when suddenly it was over. I wish it had ended the way I had predicted. THREE lonely STARS...more
