Hannah did an excellent job of making me feel I was living through every phase of Elsa's life. I even cried real tears near the end. I struggled a bit with the book because it seems really drawn out. However, that may have been intentional so the reader fully understands the gravitas of the characters' struggles. Based on real life, it was heartbreaking to read about the day-to-day realities that Americans had to face during those unprecedented times, including what they faced when they migrated to California and how they had to live to survive. In fact, this book feels like two stories in one: first, surviving as farmers in Texas during the drought; second, being migrant workers during a depression. FOUR dusty STARS...more

All of Louise Penny's crime novels are excellent, but often in a more literary way than a whodunit way. This one kept me guessing until the last page, but it's strength is in the development and backstory of the characters. While I like the literary tilt, someone looking for a true murder mystery may not. Like a good Agatha Christie mystery, everyone is guilty of something, even if not the murder.In A BETTER MAN, a young, pregnant woman has gone missing, then is presumed dead, then her body is found in a flooded river. In many of Penny's novels, she weaves an obscure historical fact into the story. In this, the overriding theme is domestic abuse. Not only is the woman's husband a suspect, but so is basically everyone in the story (except for our hero, Armand Gamache).THREE and a half STARS rounded to FOUR...more

author: Penny, Louise*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: GLASS HOUSES, by Louise Penny, shakes up the format of her Armand Gamache series. In this, Gamache is testifying in court about the death of a person GLASS HOUSES, by Louise Penny, shakes up the format of her Armand Gamache series. In this, Gamache is testifying in court about the death of a person found in the church basement in Three Pines. We don't know who the deceased is or even who the defendant is until late in the book—after many flashbacks to how the murder happened. In this, the 13th installment of the series, Penny probes the nature of conscience and how far people will go to justify their actions. Turns out it's pretty far, depending on the potential payback of those actions. As she is known for, Penny always weaves a bit of history into her stories. In this, we learn what a cobrador is: a cloaked figure from ancient Spain who would stalk a person with unpaid debts until he was shamed into paying up. In GLASS HOUSES, Penny ups the ante by making it not just a financial debt, but a moral one. When a cobrador arrives in Three Pines, the townspeople and four returning visitors contemplate whom he is stalking. It seems everyone has something in their closet. FOUR revealing STARS...more

I have great respect for THE NIGHT WATCHMAN, a story based on the life of Erdrich's grandfather, but I can't say I loved this novel.THE NIGHT WATCHMAN is the tale of Thomas Wazhashk, a member of the Turtle Mountain band of the Chippewa Indians in North Dakota. When the government proposes that the US Government "terminate" their life-long treaty with the tribe because they are "so prosperous," Thomas takes the lead among his fellow tribe members to testify in front of congress that they should not be terminated. A subplot involves Thomas's niece, Pixie/Patrice, a fiery young girl who is struggling to know what love is. Chock-full of anecdotes and tales of other members of their family and tribe, the story becomes choppy and difficult to follow. It is colorful and detailed, but as a novel it lacks flow, in my opinion.THREE colorful STARS...more

review: Immediately after reading the last line of A GREAT RECKONING, by Louise Penny, I said aloud, "Oh, wow!" I absolutely didn't expect that piece of this Immediately after reading the last line of A GREAT RECKONING, by Louise Penny, I said aloud, "Oh, wow!" I absolutely didn't expect that piece of this puzzle. Bravo to Ms. Penny. In this installment of the Armand Gamache series—and trust me, these are so much more than just detective novels; Penny does an amazing job of creating realistic, well-rounded, flawed characters—Gamache becomes the Commander of the Sûrete Academy of Quebec. In the previous 11 books, we have learned there are some bad apples in the Quebecois police force, and those bad apples have been grooming the young cadets to carry on their dirty work. Gamache intends to stop that. A few chapters in, one of the professors is found dead of a single gunshot wound to the temple. It wasn't suicide.My one frustration with this story is a "lucky break" that helps solve the case. Argh. It could have been so easy to eliminate that coincidence. title: A Swim in a Pond in the Rain: In Which Four Russians Give a Master Class on Writing, Reading, and Life
author: Saunders, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A SWIM IN A POND IN THE RAIN, by George Saunders, is a phenomenal must-read—for writers and extremely curious readers. Reading ASIAPITR is probably asA SWIM IN A POND IN THE RAIN, by George Saunders, is a phenomenal must-read—for writers and extremely curious readers. Reading ASIAPITR is probably as close to an MFA-level Creative Writing class that I will ever get. Here, Saunders gives us 7 short stories from 4 Russian greats. One by one he breaks the stories down and shows us why these writers and stories remain important standouts more than 100 years after they were written. But more than that, Saunders *explains* what the hell the story is really about and how to read between the lines, i.e. what we learn by what the authors didn't say/write. I've never been a big fan of Russian short stories, as a whole, and can name only a few (mostly by Checkov) that I actually liked. Saunders opened my eyes and taught me how to appreciate (if not like) even the oddest of all 7 stories (The Nose, by Nikolai Gogol). Saunders is brilliant. Every English teacher, IMHO, and every writer would benefit from reading this book. It's that good. FIVE swimmingly brilliant STARS...more

title: Klara and the Sun
author: Ishiguro, Kazuo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: UPDATE ON REVIEW BELOW: I reread KLARA AND THE SUN because I chose it for my book club. This book holds so many subtle, nuanced subplots that came thrUPDATE ON REVIEW BELOW: I reread KLARA AND THE SUN because I chose it for my book club. This book holds so many subtle, nuanced subplots that came through only on the second reading. Ishiguro poses Big Questions, starting with "What does it mean to be human?" and "How far will parents go to help their children for the future?" Again, I love this book.KLARA AND THE SUN, by Kazou Ishiguro, is a subtle masterpiece. Quiet and quick to read, the layers of plot, subplot, and subtext are brilliantly woven into a story that evokes fear, sympathy, and sadness. Set in the near future, Klara is an "artificial friend," a human-like robot with artificial intelligence. AFs are chosen by parents and their "lifted" children to be the child's constant companion, a way to fend off loneliness. Klara, a chic, French-looking AF, is said to have extraordinary powers of observation. It is through observation that AFs learn human behaviors and emotions. The child in this story—Josie, who is "fourteen and a half" and walks with a limp—and Klara bond at first sight. Eventually Josie convinces her mother that Klara is the only AF for her ... It's difficult to elaborate further without spoilers, but Ishiguro weaves in issues ranging from religion to science to climate change and beyond. I loved this book. Read it, and then read NEVER LET ME GO, Ishiguro's brilliant book from 2005, if you haven't already.FIVE bright STARS...more

In THE NATURE OF THE BEAST, a young boy from Three PAnother great mystery by Louise Penny, and again, a story that sprang from a true Canadian crime. In THE NATURE OF THE BEAST, a young boy from Three Pines finds "a huge gun in the woods, big as a house, with a monster on it!" Of course, no one believes him—until he's found dead. Gamache, who is now retired, mostly sits on the sidelines of this one as Lacoste and Beauvoir take the lead, but, fortunately, Gamache can't quite stay out of it. Louise Penny is an incredible story teller, and I love that we learn a little history along the way. This "supergun" was a real thing, able to launch missiles into outer space, and the man who invented it was Gerald Bull, a Canadian. (I looked it up on Wikipedia to verify and learn more about it.) In this, the 11th installment of the Armand Gamache mysteries, I certainly did not guess who the killer was ... but to the point I felt a little cheated. The clues must have been very subtle. Regardless, the ending was strong, and set up her next story in the best (scariest) way!FOUR beastly STARS...more

In THE LONG WAY HOME, Clara Morrow, one of Penny's beloved Three Pines townspeople, contacts Gamache because Peter, her estranged husband, failed to come home on their agreed upon date. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Louise Penny's Armand Gamache books get better and better throughout the series. While the 8th book (A BEAUTIFUL MYSTERY) is still my favorite so far,Louise Penny's Armand Gamache books get better and better throughout the series. While the 8th book (A BEAUTIFUL MYSTERY) is still my favorite so far, HOW THE LIGHT GETS IN is wonderful, too. This might be the most complex of her stories, making it nearly impossible to put down. In this, Gamache has two mysteries to solve at the same time—one, the case of a woman who has gone missing, and, two, what the hell are his superiors up to? Penny expertly weaves the two storylines together, one as cover for the other.One of the coolest things about this series is that Penny bases a lot of her mysteries on obscure but intriguing events in Canadian history. In this case, the missing woman (who is soon found dead) was Constance Ouellet, the last remaining member of quintuplets born during the Great Depression. The quintuplets were based on the real life Dionne quintuplets, born in Canada in 1934. The real story has many tragic aspects, which Penny touches on in her novel. I love that we can learn a little history while being so entertained. HAMILTON, anyone? Plus the title was taken from a Leonard Cohen song. What's not to love?FOUR and a half light-filled STARS...more

title: Blind Turn
author: Achterberg, Cara Sue*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: BLIND TURN, by Cara Sue Achterberg, is the story of a teenage girl who hits and kills a man while driving and possibly texting. I prepared myself for BLIND TURN, by Cara Sue Achterberg, is the story of a teenage girl who hits and kills a man while driving and possibly texting. I prepared myself for a sad story, but this novel is so much more. What starts as a simple story about one girl's misfortune turns into a cautionary tale. Who among us has not glanced at our phone while driving? This story illuminates how one mistake can change the lives of many people—possibly even end someone's life. But BLIND TURN then grows into a story about forgiveness: how and why to forgive others, and the importance of forgiving one's self, because we have all made mistakes, we are all human. Set in a small Texas town where football is practically a religion, Jessica Johnson has killed the town's beloved football coach. Everyone, especially Jessica, is devastated. Her divorced parents knew and loved Coach Mitchell. The characters are well-drawn, relatable people with personal, familial, and financial troubles. As each character struggles through his/her own circumstances, it becomes nearly impossible to put the book down as the girl's trial approaches. Will she or won't she go to prison? But there's another interesting social dynamic that Achterberg may or may not have intended. In BLIND TURN, Jessica is a "good teenager" and the victim is a town hero. Both of those factors up the intensity of the story, but this is a sad reality in America that has only recently come to light. If the driver were a young black male, for example, would the reaction of the small town and the outcome have been the same? If the victim had been a homeless person or unknown neighbor would the reaction and outcome have been the same? Research has shown that attractive blond children who have gone missing are more likely to receive national attention than poor or disadvantaged children. That is so sad. We should care for everyone as if he or she were a good, beloved, attractive friend. Because, we are all human. BLIND TURN shines a light on the power of humanity. FIVE intense STARS...more

review: THE BEAUTIFUL MYSTERY, by Louise Penny, stands out among her Armand Gamache mysteries, earning it five stars. I am a big (late-to-the-party) fan of PeTHE BEAUTIFUL MYSTERY, by Louise Penny, stands out among her Armand Gamache mysteries, earning it five stars. I am a big (late-to-the-party) fan of Penny's work, this being my 9th of her books to read. I'm now more eager to read the rest to see if this one becomes my favorite of all.Set in a real monastery in remote Quebec, though with a fictional order of monks, this novel puts Gamache and his right hand man, Jean Guy Beauvoir, on the trail of a killer inside the abbey. One monk, the prior, leader of their renowned choir, has been killed by one of the other monks. But there is also a parallel and deeply personal storyline concerning Beauvoir. In a previous novel, Gamache and Beauvoir nearly died in pursuit of a killer. Gamache has mostly recovered from that, but Beauvoir still struggles with PTSD—and now addiction to pain killers. The closer the detectives get to solving the case at the abbey, the deeper Beauvoir falls into his troubles. Like icing on a cake to the excellent story, Penny makes the reader fall in love with her settings. Her descriptions of the abbey and the music of the monks are so vivid and reverential that I'm tempted to find recordings of both Gregorian and Plain Chants so I can experience them first hand. FIVE beautiful STARS...more

title: Everything Lost Is Found Again: Four Seasons in Lesotho
author: McGrath, Will*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Will McGrath paints multiple picturesque scenes in these essays on his year in Lesotho, and this book is alive with beautiful sentences ... but it doeWill McGrath paints multiple picturesque scenes in these essays on his year in Lesotho, and this book is alive with beautiful sentences ... but it does not make me want to visit this poor, landlocked, desperate African country. The stories are tragic, but peppered with love and humanity as a means of survival.McGrath's wife, Ellen, initially suggests they spend a year in Lesotho so she can further her anthropological studies on AIDS and orphan care. AIDS is rampant in Lesotho, and one quarter of all their children have lost one or both parents to AIDS. While Ellen travels the country on her motorcycle to visit families in remote areas, Will becomes a teacher at a local school. The two make friends and dive into seemingly every native experience they can—save for beating a thieving shepherd to death. They learn to love the country and its people. I say more power to them, but this is not an adventure I want to add to my bucket list. My eyes were opened to an entirely different world from my own, and I'm glad to have read it, though I would not have picked this book up if not for my book club.THREE impoverished STARS...more

review: Apparently I'm in the minority on THE VANISHING HALF, by Brit Bennett. Chosen as one of the top five novels of 2020 by the New York Times, this book nApparently I'm in the minority on THE VANISHING HALF, by Brit Bennett. Chosen as one of the top five novels of 2020 by the New York Times, this book never took off for me. However, I listened to the audio version and struggled with the narration. Often times the narrator's tone for dialog seemed off to my ear; for instance, one character's comments often sounded snotty when they might have come off as inquisitive if I'd been reading it. Perhaps I'd have had a different opinion if I had read a hard copy.THE VANISHING HALF is the story of two fair-skinned black sisters, fair enough to pass for white girls. And that's exactly what one does. At 16, they run away from home. One choses to live her life as a white girl, even marries a man who doesn't know the truth. The other finds the darkest man she can. Each sister has a daughter. Eventually, the sisters, who lost track of each other for over a decade, are brought back together by certain events. I like the premise there, I just felt the story dragged, chapter after chapter. I wish their "reunion" would have happened at the mid-point of the story. That's where the power of the story was, yet it comes very near the end then drifts away.TWO vanishing STARS for this one...more

review: Here's another book I would like to rate 4.5 Stars. While some authors famously tackle big subjects like WAR AND PEACE, Fredrick Backman has mastered Here's another book I would like to rate 4.5 Stars. While some authors famously tackle big subjects like WAR AND PEACE, Fredrick Backman has mastered ordinary life. And frankly, that's a lot more relatable. ANXIOUS PEOPLE is a delightful story about deeply personal subjects. Like love, lost love, and death. Sooner or later each of us will experience every emotion in this book. ANXIOUS PEOPLE never takes itself too seriously. Backman repeatedly "jokes" about what this book is about. It starts out as a story about a bank robbery gone afoul, then turns into a hostage drama, then veers off and becomes a story about, possibly, a bridge. When a father and son team of police officers take turns interviewing the hostages after their released, they end up learning more about their own relationship than they do about the elusive bank robber-turned-hostage taker. Indeed, each of the "idiotic" hostages develop into endearing souls, each just trying to do the best they can to get through each day. FOUR and a half heart-warming STARS...more

title: Hamnet
author: O'Farrell, Maggie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: HAMNET, by Maggie O'Farrell, is a brave and ambitious book. I say that because O'Farrell took the scant historical facts about the wife and family of HAMNET, by Maggie O'Farrell, is a brave and ambitious book. I say that because O'Farrell took the scant historical facts about the wife and family of William Shakespeare—arguably one of the most famous historical figures ever—and made up a story about his family. She admits in the Author's Notes that the story is entirely from her own imagination. Basically, it appears she created it from nothing more than birth and death dates, plus names and addresses. In other words, she created an entirely fictitious story about real people. I have no problem with that other than the fact that the ers have pitched this book as "the story of how William Shakespeare's son, who died at age 11, influenced the making of "Hamlet," the most famous of all plays." It's not that! It's not even, IMHO, "a Novel of the Plague," as it says on the cover. The plague, or "pestilence," as they call it, also has very little to do with the plot. This is the story of an "eccentric" woman who lived in Stratford, England in the late 1500s-early 1600s, and grieves the loss of her son. And, oh yeah, her husband becomes famous (but that's not much more than a footnote).In HAMNET, O'Farrell never mentions the word "Shakespeare," not even once. She never mentions the name "William" in reference to the father of Hamnet, not even once. He, William Shakespeare, is called "her husband," or "the son of John, the glover," or "his father," throughout the entire book. I have no problem with that, but it was an odd style decision. All that being said, I thoroughly enjoyed HAMNET. It's a well-written, moving story about how Agnes, also known as Ann, met and married "the Latin tutor." They have a daughter and move in next-door to "his family." A few years later, they have twins, Hamnet and Judith. When "the husband" can no longer bear living in the shadow of his father, Agnes encourages him to go to London where he begins writing and performing plays. It isn't until the final 25 pages that O'Farrell mentions the play "Hamlet." I was very curious how this story would end, and was eager to keep reading. I liked the ending; I think O'Farrell pulled it off well. This book isn't for everyone, but I give it FOUR creative STARS...more

SeSHUGGIE BAIN, the debut novel by Douglas Stuart, is a well-written, but emotionally heavy book, heavy to the point of soul crushing. It's that sad. Set in Glasgow in the depressed 1980s, Shuggie is the queer son of Agnes Bain, a funny, caring, beautiful yet alcoholic mother, key word: alcoholic. Her struggle is ugly and tragic, and she drags Shuggie through it all. Stuart makes it clear this is not a memoir, but does say his mother was an alcoholic and he is also queer. In a way that makes the story harder to read because we can assume many of the scenes come from personal experience. This book is a heartbreaker and therefore tough to recommend, but it won the 2020 Booker Prize so you know it's worthy.FOUR STARS...more

review: Jane Harper is an excellent storyteller. THE DRY, her debut novel and the first installment of her Aaron Falk mysteries, is a gripping story about FalJane Harper is an excellent storyteller. THE DRY, her debut novel and the first installment of her Aaron Falk mysteries, is a gripping story about Falk's childhood friend who has presumably shot his wife and young son in a murder-suicide. Falk, a financial forensics police officer based in Melbourne, is asked by his buddy's parents to take another look; they're sure their son didn't do it. THE DRY takes place in Falk's hometown, a fictional ranching community five hours west of Melbourne during a tw0 year drought that has put everyone on edge. Falk fled the town twenty-years before after the mysterious death of a young girl, and must deal with the fallout from that while quietly investigating the death of his friend. While money does play a role in the truth behind the murders, I wish Harper had played up Falk's investigative skills more.FOUR bloody STARS...more

review: DEACON KING KONG, by James McBride, is a romp of a book. McBride manages to tell a story, set in 1969 South Brooklyn, that could have been tragic but DEACON KING KONG, by James McBride, is a romp of a book. McBride manages to tell a story, set in 1969 South Brooklyn, that could have been tragic but instead focuses on the love and kindness of the people living in a difficult era, with writing that is beautiful and memorable. The protagonist is an alcoholic deacon, otherwise known as Sportcoat, who shoots Deems, the local drug dealer, a young man who had a chance to get out of the projects and play major league baseball. However, Sportcoat, drunk on "King Kong," only wounds Deems. This sends the novel on a trajectory worthy of a Shakespearean comedy. With multiple colorful characters, McBride shows us how family, the church, and true love, can lift disadvantaged people and help them survive terrible circumstances and racist politics. Bravo to McBride for exposing these realities in a way that makes the reader laugh out loud. FOUR giant STARS...more

author: Ferrante, Elena
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's a lot to unpack with this book, as they say. THE LYING LIFE OF ADULTS, by Elena Ferrante, is a coming-of-age story about Giovanna, growing up There's a lot to unpack with this book, as they say. THE LYING LIFE OF ADULTS, by Elena Ferrante, is a coming-of-age story about Giovanna, growing up in Naples, Italy, in the early 1990s. As a young girl, Giovanna believes she is beautiful because her father praises her so much. Then, at the age of 12, he says she looks like his estranged sister, Vittoria, whom she knows is considered ugly, at least by her father. That comment sets Giovanna on a mission to meet her aunt. The story happens over four years, coinciding with her puberty. The novel delves into family dynamics, a young girl's insecurities, and her quest to figure out who she is in relation to her parents, her best friends, the boys who are suddenly paying her a lot of attention; it even touches on God and religion. Overriding the story, in my opinion, is the controversy about who Elena Ferrante really is. It's a pen name, and many people believe Ferrante is a man. I'm one of those people. While I related to many of the emotions and struggles that Giovanna experiences, I ultimately felt like this was a man writing as a young girl. I found many passages, most of the sexually charged scenes, to be overwritten and far-fetched, therefore not believable. THREE deceitful STARS...more

THE SEARCHER is the story of Cal, a retired Chicago cop who moves to a remote town in Ireland to get away from murder and mayhem. That is spoiled, of course, when 12-year-old Trey searches him out and asks Cal to find Brenden, Trey's brother who has gone missing. Reluctantly, Cal gets involved.The beauty of this novel isn't the whodunit or the whydunit, it's the personal stories behind the characters. In French's novels, she proves that everyone has a story, and most of us have some degree of pain deep down inside. In Cal's case and Trey's case, the pain isn't so deep. FOUR blustery STARS...more

review: LEAVE THE WORLD BEHIND, by Rumaan Alam, is a high-concept novel. And the concept is a good one: What happens to people on the fringes of a catastrophiLEAVE THE WORLD BEHIND, by Rumaan Alam, is a high-concept novel. And the concept is a good one: What happens to people on the fringes of a catastrophic event? By now we are all familiar with stories (and real life) about people at the epicenter of a catastrophe—from WAR OF THE WORLDS to 9/11—but what about the people who are not immediately affected but still know that somewhere something very bad happened to some people? It's a great question. Plus, LEAVE THE WORLD BEHIND is up for the National Book Award. Naturally, I was eager to read this book which is pitched as dealing with racism and white privilege. But wow, no. With apologies to the author, the writing sunk this story. He made narrative and style choices that didn't work for me.The story is about a white family (mother, father, son, and daughter) who rent an Airbandb house in upstate New York. A few days after they arrive, something happens in the city (never explained) and the owners of the rental house show up on the doorstep. They have fled New York and didn't know where else to go other than their country house. The elderly owners are black. Once the shock of are-they-really-who-they-say-they-are? wears off, race is no longer an issue—and honestly, wouldn't anyone have had that thought no matter what color the people were? Putting that aside, Alam chose to use omniscient POV, but not only does he jump between characters too randomly, about halfway through he starts injecting god-like pronouncements about random Americans who are dying, will die, or who have died in random places from the New York subway to a prison in Georgia to a mother in Philadelphia. Another choice the author made was to eschew (for the most part) dialogue tags. Very few uses of "he said" or "she said." I know those can be obnoxious, but he replaced them with interior thoughts of the character that disrupted the narrative flow. For example, when the family and the owners are gathered around the kitchen island, we get this from the wife: "'I'll do the washing.' Ruth thought restoring her kitchen to order might soothe. Also it was only polite." That really didn't work for me. But this was the kicker for me: The country house has power but no tv or Internet, so they can't get news the traditional way—however, there are two expensive cars in the driveway and they never (even on their two excursions) turn on the radio! Alam makes a quick comment late in the book that no satellites are working, but there are dozens of radio stations outside New York City that would presumably still have some sense of what was happening in the world. Not to mention the idea of driving into town to ask someone or get a newspaper. From there, events get more and more bizarre. I hope I never find out if the world goes as crazy as Alam suggests it might, but he went too far, IMHO, with oddities at the end. The one redeeming factor of this book is that it made me wonder if I should be a little bit prepared for a catastrophic event. I guess it wouldn't hurt to have bottled water and canned goods in my basement.ONE disastrous STAR...more

review: Louise Penny's Armand Gamache/Three Pines mysteries are as addictive as episodes of Law & Order. Penny has built an overarching cast of characters—theLouise Penny's Armand Gamache/Three Pines mysteries are as addictive as episodes of Law & Order. Penny has built an overarching cast of characters—the detectives, the townspeople, and their families—and then she concocts an intriguing mystery for each book. A reader can't help but love the calm, introspective, caring yet aging detective Armand Gamache. He carries huge personal burdens (that Penny subtly weaves in) as he works to solve each crime, so we really root for him to win! These story lines carry on from one book to the next, which is what makes them so addictive.The other interesting element that Penny does adds is her unique murders. So far, there are no run of the mill shootings or stabbings. Each case is intricately planned and only a true sleuth like Gamache can solve them. In A FATAL GRACE, the death of CC de Poitiers by electrocution on a frozen lake is a perfect example. Penny, and therefore Gamache, knows it takes a lot of backstory for an otherwise good person to murder someone. These are as much psychological thrillers as murder mysteries. FOUR shocking STARS...more

title: The Lost Man
author: Harper, Jane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Set on a large cattle ranch deep in the Outback of Queensland, Australia, THE LOST MAN, by Jane Harper, could be used as a primer for anyone who thinkSet on a large cattle ranch deep in the Outback of Queensland, Australia, THE LOST MAN, by Jane Harper, could be used as a primer for anyone who thinks it might be "fun" to visit the brutal lands. Between Harper's descriptions and the excellent narrating on the audiobook by Stephen Shanahan, I got a real sense of the danger and desolation the locals face every day. It's brutal, to say the least.In the opening pages of the book, we learn that a man has died next to "the stockman's grave," hours away from anything, including his car. This man turns out to be Cameron Bright, the middle brother between Bub and Nathan, the protagonist. We quickly learn that this was not one big happy family. The brothers' father was an abusive, angry man, who passed away years before the story opens, yet his legacy lingers, and has affected each member of the family in different ways. The plot centers around how Cameron died. Was it suicide? Did he get lost and disoriented in the heat? Or did someone leave him out there on purpose? While this falls under "mystery" as a genre, it's really the story of a family. It's a story about anger, abuse, survival, and the ways individuals face or deny all of the above. From the boys' mother, Liz, to Cameron's wife, Ilsa; Uncle Harry, the ranch manager; and the "backpackers" who work as hired hands, Harper does an excellent job of casting shade on each of them as possible suspects in Cameron's death. The guilty party was not who I expected. I felt the first third of this story dragged a bit, but once it picked up, it was quite gripping.FOUR broiling STARS...more

title: Utopia Avenue
author: Mitchell, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: UTOPIA AVENUE, by David Mitchell, one of my all-time favorite authors, is proof that even great writers can sell mediocre books. (I feel almost blasphUTOPIA AVENUE, by David Mitchell, one of my all-time favorite authors, is proof that even great writers can sell mediocre books. (I feel almost blasphemous saying that.) His latest creation, which cleverly pulls characters and elements from his previous novels and loops them into a new story, lacks forward momentum. There is no overarching plot or "novel question" to keep the reader turning the pages. I wasn't about to quit reading, but I wasn't excited to read it either.Utopia Avenue is a British rock band, just making a name for themselves in the late 60s. The band consists of four members: Dean Moss, the heartthrob bass guitarist and lead singer; Elf Holloway, the female keyboardist; Jasper de Zoet, the lead guitarist; and Griff, the drummer. In place of a strong plot, Mitchell delves into the private lives of Moss, Elf, and Jasper, leaving Griff as an afterthought. For the first half of the story, Jasper, from THE TEN THOUSAND AUTUMNS OF JACOB de ZOET, might be described as what we know today to be autistic; in the second half he falls into a full-on psychotic breakdown, wherein Mitchell weaves his signature, science-fiction solution. Elf suffers sexist mores and romantic challenges, and Dean battles the dichotomy of a dark past with new-found fame. What's more—the angle so many positive blurbs cite—is that Mitchell surrounds his fictional band members with the most famous, real-life rock stars of their day. What might have been a reality for a band at the time, it comes across as total name dropping in the worst possible way in the book. The list of musicians they encounter is endless: from John Lennon, Keith Richards, Syd Barrett, Dianna Ross, and Cream, to Leonard Cohen, Janis Joplin, and Jerry Garcia, just to name a few. So many it becomes farcical. Then, the ending. Another disappointment to me. It felt like Mitchell didn't know how to end it, so he gave into cliché. While I am glad to have read UTOPIA AVENUE, I will have a hard time recommending it. If you want to read a great book about a fictional band, pick up (or better yet, listen to) DAISY JONES AND THE SIX. That was a great book. Sorry, Mr. Mitchell.THREE flat STARS...more

title: Dear Edward
author: Napolitano, Ann*

review: This is a captivating story. I could scarcely put the book down. DEAR EDWARD, by Ann Napolitano, is the story of Eddie, a 12-year-old boy who is the oThis is a captivating story. I could scarcely put the book down. DEAR EDWARD, by Ann Napolitano, is the story of Eddie, a 12-year-old boy who is the only survivor of a horrific plane crash. All 191 other passengers died, including his brother and both parents. As "Edward," he survives each day with the help of Napolitano's cast of complex, round, flawed characters, including his childless aunt and uncle; Shay, the neighbor girl whose father left home; and his school principal. In alternating chapters, Napolitano tells the story of both the fateful plane flight and Edward's new life. She builds interest in the "before" by singling out a handful of "random" passengers, in addition to Eddie and his family. We come to know and care for each for them, which makes the doomed flight that much more tragic. My only knock against the book is that she tends to whitewash Edward's emotions during his recovery. I wish she had spent more time inside his head. The title, and moral of the story, comes from the letters Edward receives after the crash, mostly from the victims' families. They see him as a savior and hero, and many ask that he fulfill their loved one's truncated dreams. This of course is unreasonable and causes Edward extra grief. How he and Shay navigate a life no one could have predicted is both heartbreaking and heartwarming.FOUR heart-filled STARS...more

review: THE MOST FUN WE EVER HAD, by Claire Lombardo, reminds me of a family-based reality show. I can't be more specific than that because I hate reality shoTHE MOST FUN WE EVER HAD, by Claire Lombardo, reminds me of a family-based reality show. I can't be more specific than that because I hate reality shows. I finished this book only to see if the characters redeem themselves in the end. They don't. At least not enough for my taste. THE MOST FUN WE EVER HAD is the story of Marilyn and David Sorenson and their four daughters. The girls struggle through life because their parents are so madly in love with each other—as if that were an intentional form of child abuse. The sisters are horrible to each other, basically to the degree they are also rich; the oldest daughter, Wendy, being the extreme example. Wendy was a wild, difficult daughter who became a bitter, vindictive woman. Yes, she struggled with issues (bulimia, anorexia, a late-term miscarriage, and an uber-wealthy husband who dies of cancer), but not once does she appreciate anything good in the world, or give anyone, including Violet—her closest sister/best friend—even one ounce of grace. And that's just one daughter. The others aren't much better. Beyond that, the dialogue is choppy and faltering (an attempt to sound more authentic, I'm sure), but it becomes obnoxious and frustrating by the end. I wish I had quit this book after the first fifty pages.ONE clunky STAR...more

title: American Dirt
author: Cummins, Jeanine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's difficult to separate this book from its hype and controversy, but I strongly suggest that everyone do just that and read it. AMERICAN DIRT, by JIt's difficult to separate this book from its hype and controversy, but I strongly suggest that everyone do just that and read it. AMERICAN DIRT, by Jeanine Cummins, is the story of Lydia, a middle class mother and bookstore owner in Acapulco, and her only son, Luca, who are forced to become migrants, on the run from a drug lord and his gang after he murders Lydia's entire family at a party. Sixteen dead, because Lydia's husband, a journalist, wrote an exposé on the drug lord, a man who Lydia knows from her bookstore. Sixteen.The story, in and of itself, is a page turner. Cummins created well-rounded, sympathetic, likable characters, and then put them in a tragic situation with a specific goal. At first, I feared this book might gloss over the horrors many migrants face, but no. Many scenes are brutal, but from what I know, sadly realistic. It's difficult even to read what these people endure. Along their journey, the mother and son meet other fleeing migrants (and possible gang members), many of whom also suffer at the hands of corrupt officials and police along the trek north. Not everyone makes it across the border.After Oprah selected this book for her book club, controversy arose concerning Cummins' "right" to tell this story because she is not a first generation Latina. I understand that logic, but I feel her voice can add to the oeuvre. The more people who read accurate stories about the immigrants the better, I say, because it will open eyes to the reasons most of the migrants want to reach America. Between climate change and terribly divisive politics, the world can be brutal—but AMERICAN DIRT gives us a glimpse at the heart and hope of innocent people just trying to survive and keep their children safe. FOUR and a half devastating STARS...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow. Read this book. Better yet, listen to this audiobook. It's a fantastic story with A+ performances by a stellar cast. DAISY JONES & THE SIX, a novWow. Read this book. Better yet, listen to this audiobook. It's a fantastic story with A+ performances by a stellar cast. DAISY JONES & THE SIX, a novel by Taylor Jenkins Reid, is a fictional biography of a band in the '70s that feels so real I had to check the internet to see if they had existed and I had somehow missed them. Reid excels at voice and dialogue, not to mention setting and emotion. The Six began as a band formed by Billy and Graham Dunn, two brothers with a deadbeat dad. Four other friends join in, including Karen Karen the keyboardist. Billy is the lead singer/rockstar/heartthrob. He gets married early in the story to Camilla. After a decent debut album, they get introduced to Daisy Jones, a wild, sexy, beautiful singer/songwriter. When Daisy and Billy collaborate on the band's second album magic happens. And yes, it causes problems for everyone. With dozens of insightful, powerful lines, Reid has delivered a novel as heartbreaking as the song you and your first love listened to in high school, the one that still tugs at your heart when it comes on the Oldies station in the car. But arguably the best part of this story is how strong the women are. Camilla, Karen, Daisy (while sober), and Daisy's best friend, Simone, each stand their ground, support each other, and make (mostly) good decisions, all while maintaining their femininity, grace, and sense of self. FIVE rockin' STARS...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE ASPERN PAPERS, by Henry James, is a sweet, little Roman à clef that mirrors a tale James heard in the 1880s about a "fanatical" American who learnTHE ASPERN PAPERS, by Henry James, is a sweet, little Roman à clef that mirrors a tale James heard in the 1880s about a "fanatical" American who learns that one of Lord Byron's mistresses, who lived decades beyond him, holds a treasure of love letters between Byron and Mary Shelley. The old woman lived in Italy with her aging niece, so the American decided to weasel his way into the lives of the women in order to get his hands on the papers. James changes the name from Byron to Aspern, but it seems he keeps most of the story the same (though the legend doesn't say what happened to Byron's papers in the end).In this novella, an English man worms his way into the home of these women, promising to do anything, including sleep with the niece, if necessary, in order to get the papers. Not surprisingly, the story is very well written and captivating. We must know whether or not the papers exist, and if so, will the man be successful in getting the papers before the old woman destroys them?!The ending is as poetic as one might hope.FOUR STARS (subtracting one for lack of an original plot)...more

review: This is such a sweet book. I heard reference to it and high praise, enough to entice me into reading it. And I'm glad I did. THE MIRACULOUS JOURNEY OFThis is such a sweet book. I heard reference to it and high praise, enough to entice me into reading it. And I'm glad I did. THE MIRACULOUS JOURNEY OF EDWARD TULANE, by Kate DiCamillo, is a YA story about "a rabbit who was made almost entirely of china," but with ears and a tail made of real rabbit fur. Edward the rabbit was given a most "extraordinary wardrobe, including silk suits, custom shoes ... and a wide array of hats equipped with holes so they could easily fit over Edward's large and expressive ears." He was given to a little girl named Abilene Tulane for her tenth birthday. When the Tulane family goes on a trip, Edward gets lost. His "journey" spans many, many years, some of which he is alternately lost (at the bottom of an ocean or under a heap of garbage at the dump) or found by various adults and children. Some of his owners love him, some badly mistreat him. Through this journey Edward learns the meaning of love, including the pain that comes with it.While this chapter book (with several beautiful illustrations by Bagram Ibatoulline) is intended for grade school children, I can attest that it's a quick page turner that warmed my heart. review: I'd been wanting to read a P.D. James mystery, and chose INNOCENT BLOOD from a list of the Top 10 Mysteries of the 20th Century. It must have made thaI'd been wanting to read a P.D. James mystery, and chose INNOCENT BLOOD from a list of the Top 10 Mysteries of the 20th Century. It must have made that list because it's unique, meaning it holds an odd twist that separates it from a typical mystery. Other than that, I would not put it on my personal list of Top Mysteries of any century.Written in 1980, INNOCENT BLOOD is the story of Philippa Palfrey, an adopted girl who lives in London. Though her adoptive parents are well-to-do, she imagines her birth parents to be star-crossed aristocrats. On her 18th birthday, she can legally learn their true identity and finds that not only are they not aristocrats, they are a rapist and a murderess. Her father died in prison, but her mother is soon to be paroled. Philippa decides she will move out of her cushy home and get an apartment so she and her birth mother can spend time together before Philippa goes off to Cambridge. Meanwhile, the father of the little girl who was raped and murdered by Philippa's parents has vowed to kill the woman who killed his daughter. While Philippa and her mother are exploring London, the man trails them with his single-minded mission. Things don't go as planned. The novel, in and of itself, is about 100 pages too long, in my opinion. While P.D. James is a skilled storyteller and writer, I don't know how this book compares to her others. I'm happy to have read it, but I can't give it a strong endorsement.THREE overly-detailed STARS...more

title: Disappearing Earth
author: Phillips, Julia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Julia Phillips is a name to remember. DISAPPEARING EARTH, Phillips' debut novel is the story of two young Russian girls who go missing in Kamchatka, aJulia Phillips is a name to remember. DISAPPEARING EARTH, Phillips' debut novel is the story of two young Russian girls who go missing in Kamchatka, a remote peninsula that attaches to the far northeastern corner of Russia. The story takes place over twelve months (each chapter = one month). Her writing is clean, evocative, and as sharp as the climate and geography there.Praised as one of the Top 10 Books of 2019 by the New York Times and others, Disappearing Earth gives us glimpses of how the disappearance of two young girls in an insular community reverberates throughout a land as remote as an island, so isolated it is from the mainland. But there in lies the knock, too. Each chapter focused on a different woman (though many lives intersect). Thus each chapter feels like its own short story. The problem is that starting each chapter with new characters robs the novel of momentum. Indeed the cast of characters overwhelms the reader, as we try to keep the women straight while also figuring out how they tie into the story. What's more, Phillips chooses not to tie up the lives/loose ends of all but the primary story. She leaves us in the dark about the characters we tried so hard to care about. While I enjoyed the writing and premise of DISAPPEARING EARTH, I hope she smooths out the structure issues for her next novel.THREE isolated STARS...more

review: THE SECRET PLACE is my least favorite of Tana French's books, though I suppose if you read an author's entire oeuvre, one is bound to be your least faTHE SECRET PLACE is my least favorite of Tana French's books, though I suppose if you read an author's entire oeuvre, one is bound to be your least favorite. The premise of THE SECRET PLACE is that a boy's body is found on the grounds of a girls' school just outside of Dublin. The case goes unsolved for eighteen months, then two detectives get a clue that reopens the case. Together, they solve it in a single day. What I didn't like about this story is that French alternates the POV between the primary detective, Stephen Moran, and Holly Mackey, a student at the girls’ school and the daughter of Frank Mackey, an undercover detective who works with Moran. I enjoyed the psychological insight into and between the two detectives, but I was completely uninterested in the lives of the eight high school girls, one of whom was probably the killer. French gave the girls so much time in this book that it could have been shelved as YA. Turns out I wasn't interested in the criminal intent of a bunch of teenage girls.TWO STARS...more

review: As I listened to THE TURN OF THE KEY, by Ruth Ware, I felt an overwhelming feeling of dread. Not for the characters or the writing, but for the obsessAs I listened to THE TURN OF THE KEY, by Ruth Ware, I felt an overwhelming feeling of dread. Not for the characters or the writing, but for the obsessive detail and length. The bulk of the story takes place over just a few days, so we had a lot of detail from each day. Worse yet, though I didn't predict the ending, I found it implausible. THE TURN OF THE KEY is the story of a twenty-something girl who leaves her job at a London daycare to be the private nanny for a wealthy family in Scotland. The parents, Sandra and Bill Ellincort, are architects who have refurbished an old Victorian estate in the country, turning it into a "smart house." The Ellincorts have four daughters, one of whom is fourteen and away at boarding school for most of the book. The parents are desperate to fill the position of nanny because the previous four have all quit, possibly because the house is haunted. Indeed as Rowan spends her first few nights at the house (while the parents are out of town), she is terrified of creepy noises and moving objects and local lore and their poison garden ... More importantly, the novel is told in a first person account of Rowen writing a letter from prison to a high-powered defense attorney because she has been arrested after one of the daughters is found dead under Rowen's care. She pleads innocence and begins to tell the entire story. In the end, my biggest issue with this book is in the truth about what happened to the child. It was too much of a stretch for me.TWO creaking STARS...more

review: So I finally finished this book. Often cited by other writers as one of their favorites, I undoubtedly went into this book with great expectations. NoSo I finally finished this book. Often cited by other writers as one of their favorites, I undoubtedly went into this book with great expectations. No surprise, I didn't love it. Written in 1981, the year I became a freshman at the University of Iowa, where Marilynne Robinson lives, writes, teaches, and is universally revered, HOUSEKEEPING, is a supreme example of literary fiction. It's about the characters, their personalities, and their choices. Robinson indeed created three distinct, enigmatic women: Sylvie, the itinerant aunt who comes to take care of her nieces after her sister has committed suicide; Ruthie, the older sister; and Lucille, the younger sister. Let's just say it doesn't go well for all three of them.This story is filled with countless gorgeous sentences, but every once in a while there is a long sentence filled with beautiful words ... but I had to stop, reread them, and occasionally ask "What does that sentence even mean?" Perhaps one day I will reread this and appreciate it more. THREE tidy STARS...more

author: Michaelides, Alex*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: But for one flaw, this would be an A+ mystery, worthy of Alex Michaelides' hero, Agatha Christie. Am I the only one who has caught this flaw? I need tBut for one flaw, this would be an A+ mystery, worthy of Alex Michaelides' hero, Agatha Christie. Am I the only one who has caught this flaw? I need to read some s with spoilers to find out. THE SILENT PATIENT was the Goodreads 2019 Winner in the Mystery category. And it's fantastic, except for a flaw in the timeline. I listened to the audio version of this book (twice, in hopes that it was just something I missed), so maybe I need to get my hands on an actual copy, but (obviously) this is something I can't overlook.The story is about Theo Faber, a psychotherapist at The Grove, who very much wants to help one of their "famous, or infamous" patients, Alicia Berenson, an artist who killed her husband (or did she?) and then refused to speak. She was found guilty and committed to The Grove after being found mentally unstable. Theo, who separately discovers his wife is cheating on him, treats Alicia's case like a detective would, trying to learn everything he can about his patient to learn about her history by asking her friends and family about her past. Thus two women have beguiled Theo. In solving one, he ends up solving both mysteries. And it's great—well-written, nuanced, intriguing—except for that one flaw. For that I deduct one star.FOUR shout-them-out STARS ...more

author: King, Lily*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are some books (like people) that come into your life at just the right moment and deliver just the right message. WRITERS & LOVERS, a novel by There are some books (like people) that come into your life at just the right moment and deliver just the right message. WRITERS & LOVERS, a novel by Lily King, is one of those books for me. I adored it. I will reread it many times. I will recommend it and choose it for my book club, just to be sure other people also read this book. Writers & Lovers is the story of Casey, a 31-yo aspiring novelist who has just lost her mother and broken up with her boyfriend. Broke and emotionally shattered, she clings to her dream of selling the novel she's been working on for six years. Through her friends and work as a waitress, she meets two new men, polar opposites, and must navigate those romantic waters as well. Whether or not an individual reader has experienced any of those specific situations, Lily King writes with such a deep, visceral acumen, that I think everyone will feel her pain. And then also her hope. Casey's dream is to be a novelist, but her grit and determination would apply to every dream. The real gem of this novel, though, is how King guides Casey through her journey with enough sparks of laughter and light that the reader's heart will swell by the final page.Believe me, Writers & Lovers should be your next read.FIVE achingly beautiful STARS...more

author: Keane, Mary Beth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The novel ASK AGAIN, YES, by Mary Beth Keane, peeks into the lives of two families, the Gleesons and the Stanhopes, who live next door to each other iThe novel ASK AGAIN, YES, by Mary Beth Keane, peeks into the lives of two families, the Gleesons and the Stanhopes, who live next door to each other in the suburbs of New York City. The fathers, Francis and Brian, were briefly rookie cop partners in the NYPD in the 1970s. Each man is married, and each family has children, though the families are not friends—except for the Gleesons' daughter Kate and the Stanhopes' son, Peter. The two kids "fall in love," but this Mrs. Stanhope cannot abide. She loves her son too much to let him love another female. One night, tragedy strikes, ripping both families apart. The Stanhopes move away. Fast forward a few years. Kate and Peter reconnect, rekindle their love, get married, and have a family of their own. The remainder of the book deals with how the families are healing (or not) from the tragic event of their shared past.ASK AGAIN, YES is a slow-paced, quotidian look into damaged lives. It deals with choices, responsibility, love, and mental illness—very relatable family issues. This novel gained much acclaim in 2019 when it was released, and I had heard a lot about it. A sucker for a good PR spin, I picked it up, but it was a slog to get through. I kept reading mostly to find out if it would redeem itself and live up to its hype. In the end, when Keane reveals the meaning of the title, the book improved enough for me to raise my  from Two Stars to Three. I liked the end message of the novel, but I will be hard pressed to recommend it. It would be a good book club choice because it touches on many issues that families must address in the real world.THREE quiet STARS...more

title: Weather
author: Offill, Jenny*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Jenny Offill has a distinct and unique style of writing. It takes a while to get into her groove. Like her last novel (Dept. of Speculation), WEATHER Jenny Offill has a distinct and unique style of writing. It takes a while to get into her groove. Like her last novel (Dept. of Speculation), WEATHER is the story of Lizzie, a wife/mother/struggling woman, told in snippets. By the time you get most of the way through the short novel, a picture emerges, the full portrait of her characters. In WEATHER, Lizzie is a librarian who also answers emails directed to one of Lizzie's former professors. The professor hosts what is essentially a doomsday podcast. Most of the emails pose questions about the end of the world. Lizzie reminds me a bit of Olive Kitteridge: a depressed, lonely woman struggling through life. Lizze's brother, Henry, is a recovering drug addict and new father. Okay, I'm trying really hard to find something positive to say about this book. When I was about fifty pages in, I was excited about it. But by the end I found it depressing, especially now. As I write this, we are a few weeks into the Coronavirus lockdown. With all the doomsday questions, this book was eerily timely, yet no relief from the anxiety of today's world. I imagine many people love this book, but if you're curious, read DEPT. OF SPECULATION instead. I really liked that one.THREE stormy STARS...more

title: Play It As It Lays
author: Didion, Joan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's difficult to say "I really liked" this book. PLAY IT AS IT LAYS, by Joan Didion, is powerful, devastating, shocking ... like a slow-motion car acIt's difficult to say "I really liked" this book. PLAY IT AS IT LAYS, by Joan Didion, is powerful, devastating, shocking ... like a slow-motion car accident where people die. Some readers have said they didn't like this book because they didn't like the main character, Maria (pronounced Mariah), but they are missing the point. We're not supposed to like Maria; our hearts are supposed to break for her.Written in 1970, PLAY IT AS IT LAYS is the story of a thirty-something actress/wife/divorcee/mother/friend who is falling apart. Nothing in her life is working or happy. Her character starts at a low point and drops from there. People do die. Integral to this story is Didion's writing. It's a blend of stream of consciousness, snippets of life, observations of others, and reflections on the story she's trying to tell. Didion explains nothing, the reader must piece together everything that happened before Page 1. It will be a challenge to recommend this book to very many people because it's raw and bloody. And sad. But if powerful, devastating stories are your thing, then by all means read this book.FOUR brutal STARS...more

review: THE HUNTRESS, by Kate Quinn, is the story of three individuals whose lives intertwine in the years following WWII. Told in chapters alternating betweeTHE HUNTRESS, by Kate Quinn, is the story of three individuals whose lives intertwine in the years following WWII. Told in chapters alternating between their POVs, Jordan McBride, Ian Graham, and Nina Markova, all have a connection to "die Jaergin," German (I think) for "the huntress," a cold-blooded Nazi who escaped after the war. Jordan, a feisty young Bostonian with a new step-mother, wants to be a photojournalist but wrestles with her father's expectations to stay home, run the family business, and marry her childhood sweetheart. Ian, based in Vienna, was a war correspondent who gave up journalism to track escaped Nazis. And Nina Markova, an angry young Russian, flew U-2 bombers in an all-female regiment until she had to "disappear" or risk being denounced and sent to a work camp. I thought Quinn could have included a few more characters as red herrings, but she did a great job with these characters and more.THE HUNTRESS is a well-written, engaging, WWII novel. Quinn did an incredible amount of research for this novel, and wrote detailed descriptions of the locations, weather, and occupations. I enjoyed it and kept turning the pages faster and faster as I read even though it was a little too pat (ie. full of conveniences). At 525 pages, I hoped for more complications.FOUR flying STARS...more

title: Night Boat to Tangier
author: Barry, Kevin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This sweet little book is mighty deceiving. Though NIGHT BOAT TO TANGIER, a novel by Kevin Barry, tallies around 250 pages, they are small, with much This sweet little book is mighty deceiving. Though NIGHT BOAT TO TANGIER, a novel by Kevin Barry, tallies around 250 pages, they are small, with much white space. The white space, I discovered, is crucial as it gives the reader room to contemplate the beautiful, complex sentences. This story has been compared to Samuel Beckett's WAITING FOR GODOT, but I don't remember that play having near the gravitas of this novel. In NIGHT BOAT TO TANGIER, two Irish, former-drug dealers, Maurice Hearne and Charlie Redmond, wait one night at the Spanish port of Algeciras, hoping to find Maurice's daughter who they have been told will be taking the ferry that night. That sounds innocent enough and interesting, but that doesn't prepare the reader for the devastation and heartbreak to come, including the possibility of wether or not "Dilly" really is his daughter. The phrase "If it weren't for bad luck, they'd have no luck at all" most definitely applies to Maurice and Charlie, whose complicated friendship goes back decades. Thick with Irish, Spanish, and drug-dealing slang and customs, this story presumes a lot. Not being Irish, Spanish, or a drug-dealer, I struggled to work through Barry's terse, though often beautiful, writing. But where this story really hits you is with what is implied rather than spoken or written. It's the "near miss" of the father/daughter reunion. It's the heartbreaking realities of survival. It's the pain of love and loss.I found this book very powerful, but I took off one star because ultimately I don't want to work this hard while reading a novel.FOUR moving STARS...more

author: Vuong, Ocean
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ocean Vuong is a young, Vietnamese poet, and it shows. ON EARTH WE'RE BRIEFLY GORGEOUS is his first novel. Throughout this book, there are dozens of pOcean Vuong is a young, Vietnamese poet, and it shows. ON EARTH WE'RE BRIEFLY GORGEOUS is his first novel. Throughout this book, there are dozens of powerful and beautiful passages that truly moved me. And if I could edit out certain chunks of this novel, it would easily merit a five star  and deserve the blurbs on the back cover.However, in writing this sweet "letter to his mother," the protagonist/author becomes tedious if not preachy about certain subjects, for instance the cruelties many Vietnamese women endure to work at nail salons in America. I'm not saying his points aren't valid, it just felt forced and out of place in the book. Also, the narrator is gay and exploring his first sexual encounters with another teenage boy. I've got no problem with that, though those scenes bordered on gratuitous. My knock against that is, again, that it's supposed to be a letter to his mother. No teenage boy I know would ever be that graphic with his mother. The power and language in this novel make me want to read it again. Maybe I will. I just wish Vuong had saved his editorial comments for an essay to make this story sharper all the way through.THREE beautiful STARS...more

review: NOTHING TO SEE HERE, by Kevin Wilson, is a sweet, often laugh-outloud story about two kids who occasionally, spontaneously catch on fire, and also aboNOTHING TO SEE HERE, by Kevin Wilson, is a sweet, often laugh-outloud story about two kids who occasionally, spontaneously catch on fire, and also about families. If you just go with the premise that kids can catch on fire and be perfectly fine (you know, the way you believe the scientists in Jurassic Park bring dinosaurs back to life) then it's simply a story about families. And who can't relate to that?The book opens with Madison, a beautiful rich girl, who becomes roommates at a prep school in Tennessee with a poor scholarship girl named Lillian, the narrator and protagonist in NOTHING TO SEE HERE. Basically, all good things happen for Madison, and all bad things happen for Lillian. Fifteen years later, Madison, now the wife of Jasper Roberts, a senator from Tennessee, turns to Lillian for help. The two "fire children" are Madison's step-children, and she needs someone to care for them after their mother dies. It doesn't take a genius to imagine where this is going.Though the middle of this short book drags a little, the closing chapters redeem it, leaving us with a happy message. I recommend it for a light summer read—on or off the beach.FOUR fiery STARS...more

NOThis book begs to be read in a short period of time, say over a weekend. Unfortunately, I couldn't do that so the book didn't hold together for me. NORMAL PEOPLE, by Sally Rooney, is a story told in scattered scenes over several years about Marianne and Connell, two Irish kids who meet in high school, go to Trinity College together, and navigate their way into adulthood— sometimes as a couple, sometimes as friends. Marianne comes from a wealthy family, though her now-deceased father was abusive. Connell's mother was the housekeeper for Marianne's family. The two kids are star-crossed lovers on a teeter-totter of concern for public opinion; first one cares more, then the other. They also alternately battle huge self-esteem issues.Though likely to be "so spot on" to some (young) people, the characters' reticence to communicate honestly about their feelings drove me crazy. In the end, I felt I had to work too hard for an ambiguous ending.Three average Stars...more

author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The characters in THE DUTCH HOUSE, by Ann Patchett, are arguably the most fleshed out characters of any of her novels. The primary characters—Danny, tThe characters in THE DUTCH HOUSE, by Ann Patchett, are arguably the most fleshed out characters of any of her novels. The primary characters—Danny, the narrator, and Maeve, his big sister—are the children of Cyril and Elna Conroy. Cyril, a contractor and developer, becomes very wealthy (unknown to his wife) and surprises her buy buying an abandoned mansion known as the Dutch House. Elna, who had intended to become a nun, is unsettled by their new life, replete with servants. When Danny is three, Elna leaves her family and travels to India to help then-Sister Teresa. A few years later, Cyril marries a woman named Andrea who has two daughters of her own. Fast forward another four years to when Cyril dies from a heart attack, leaving the house and all his money to Andrea. The bulk of the novel is the interaction between brother and sister as they attempt to make sense of what happened to their lives. Though I'm a big fan of Ann Patchett, I struggled to like this one as much as her others because I didn't like most of the characters. A mother who leaves her children? An emotionally detached (read: clueless) husband? A son who repeats basically every mistake his father made, yet never realizes it? Maeve was my favorite character of the story, yet her motivations and actions surprised me, too. It was difficult to root for anyone here. THREE and a half STARS rounded down...more

review: Patricia Highsmith is underrated. Her name, despite the fact that she died in 1995, is not nearly as well-known as Raymond Chandler, Dashiell Hammett,Patricia Highsmith is underrated. Her name, despite the fact that she died in 1995, is not nearly as well-known as Raymond Chandler, Dashiell Hammett, Flannery O'Connor, et al. Highsmith's writing is on par with any of those names. If not for Hollywood's adaptation of THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY, and later CAROL, adapted from THE PRICE OF SALT, I think Highsmith might end up relegated to the footnotes of twentieth century literature. It's easy to see why Hollywood (director Anthony Minghella, producer Sydney Pollack, etc.) would chose this story for a star-studded big budget film. They upped the ante and the stakes for the conniving, murderous Tom Ripley, but the creation of this antihero is all Highsmith. Written in 1955, TTMR is a nod to Henry James's THE AMBASSADORS, but again, Highsmith takes her characters to new heights. Anyone who likes mysteries or thrillers should spend more time reading Highsmith. She is truly a master writer.FIVE gripping, thrilling STARS...more

title: The Testaments        (The Handmaid's Tale, #2)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE TESTAMENTS, by the esteemed Margaret Atwood, fell way short of my expectations. As Atwood's sequel (35 years later) to THE HANDMAID'S TALE, I expeTHE TESTAMENTS, by the esteemed Margaret Atwood, fell way short of my expectations. As Atwood's sequel (35 years later) to THE HANDMAID'S TALE, I expected superb writing and that I would have to brace myself for horrifying new scenarios for the oppressed women of Gilead. Instead, the book was dull. (Not that I was rooting for female torture!, I had simply braced for more unimaginable scenes, of which there were a couple that I skimmed over.)I read THE HANDMAID'S TALE in the 1990s and could barely make it through what I now know as dystopian fiction. The treatment of the women was more than I could stand. I have since watched the HULU production of THE HANDMAID'S TALE, and while I am still horrified by what happens (it is set in the future, though Atwood never says what decade or even century), the "shock of the new" has evaporated. Intentionally vague in her earlier book, Atwood gives us a few more details in THE TESTAMENTS about how the new country known as Gilead came to be: In primarily the northeast section of the United States, the radical Sons of Jacob terrorist group staged a coup. They "liquidated Congress" and took over control of the US Government, installing Puritan males as their leaders and suppressing all women. During the revolution a nuclear catastrophe occurs, thereby sterilizing most women (and presumably some of the men). The "Commanders" get to choose their young and beautiful wives, and if they are sterile, then the couple gets a Handmaid to act as a surrogate mother for the couple. You can see how this might go badly. Anyone, male or female, who disobeys the strict, puritanical laws (or whom the Commanders want out of the way) gets killed in the most gruesome, public manor you can imagine. Probably worse than you can imagine. In the acknowledgements of THE TESTAMENTS, Atwood says she had been working on The Testaments on and off for much of the past 35 years. That must be true, however this book feels rushed, like an early draft not a final draft of such an accomplished writer. My guess is that because HULU is about to release Season 4 of their version of THE HANDMAID'S TALE, Atwood felt she had to get her version out before them. This book "tells" most of the story in dry, clichéd scenes, alternately narrated by Aunt Lydia, Baby Nicole, and Agnes. (If you know anything about this story, you will know who those women are.) I was eager to learn how Atwood would end her story, but it was exactly as I would have guessed. The final chapter of the book is a scene from the "Thirteenth Symposium on Gileadean Studies," held in 2197. TWO HUNDRED years in the future. Except the lecturers are still doing a slide show and talking about handing out paper versions of their studies. That is NOT how I expect information to be traded two hundred years from now. For someone who's mind could come up with a story like THE HANDMAID'S TALE, I was hugely disappointed that she didn't have a much more creative view of life that far in the future. TWO boring STARS...more

title: Valley of the Dolls
author: Susann, Jacqueline
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Is it possible to read a book like VALLEY OF THE DOLLS, written in 1966 by Jacqueline Susann, without some degree of expectations? As controversial anIs it possible to read a book like VALLEY OF THE DOLLS, written in 1966 by Jacqueline Susann, without some degree of expectations? As controversial and popular as it was in the sixties and seventies (after the movie came out), its reputation and aura seemingly warped, twisted, and gathered steam over the past five decades. Whenever this book came up in conversation, people I know still slightly blushed and giggled about it. I decided to read this “dirty book” for myself to see what all the hype was about. Fifty-three years on, it seems almost tame! Though, obviously, the book stayed the same, and the world changed. This novel tells the sad story of three women (Anne, Neely, and Jennifer) in the entertainment industry over twenty years, from 1945 to 1965. The women meet in New York City through an agent named Henry Bellamy when they are young, gorgeous, naive, and eager. In the closing pages, they are none of those. Money, fame, drugs, men, and time ravage them in different ways and to different degrees. Contrary to what I expected, “dolls” are pills: uppers and downers, mostly; the “valley” is certainly the depth of their destruction. This story is well-written, but very long and overly detailed in some parts. Plus the dialogue is often stiff and formal. I imagine when this book came out, there was a lot of speculation (or knowledge) about who each character was supposed to represent (a roman à clef), because the details were that specific. Today it reads as almost tedious, because it seems Susann tried overly hard to keep it accurate. Three wild not dirty Stars...more
