title: Warlight
author: Ondaatje, Michael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My struggle with this book is different from many of the s I've read. WARLIGHT is the story of two teenage siblings (Rachel and Nathaniel) who aMy struggle with this book is different from many of the s I've read. WARLIGHT is the story of two teenage siblings (Rachel and Nathaniel) who are essentially abandoned by their parents near the end of WWII and left with their mother's colorful, though shady friends. Part I is narrated by Nathaniel in 1945, and Part 2 is told via multiple characters in 1957 as Nathaniel is supposedly trying to unravel what the hell happened. Certainly Michael Ondaatje created colorful characters and wrote picturesque, engaging scenes. The stakes are high for the kids and the setting is exciting. The problem for many people (myself included) is the nearly-impossible-to-follow plot. So, it's "character driven." I can accept that because I love literary fiction. The problem with this book is the loose and fractured POV. The back cover of the novel states, "... A dozen years later, Nathaniel begins to uncover all he didn't know or understand during that time, and it is this journey—through reality, recollection, and imagination—that is told in this magnificent novel." IMAGINATION? Seriously? Here we have a high-level, literary, WWII, coming of age, spy novel, and the protagonist (Nathaniel) gets to IMAGINE what really happened? I don't think that's how high-level, literary, WWII, coming of age spy novels work. Many chapters in Part 2 are written in the POV of various characters from Part 1. However, roughly 150 years ago Mark Twain said, "Truth is stranger than fiction, but it is because fiction is obliged to stick to the possibilities, truth isn't." In other words, maybe in real life we can imagine events we were not privy to, but high-level, literary, WWII, coming of age, spy novels have to follow the rules. Otherwise, the book should be shelved in science fiction. Nathaniel needed to discover the answers to his crazy childhood through legitimate means. If he had, I might have loved this book. Two disappointing Stars...more

title: The Overstory
author: Powers, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE OVERSTORY, by Richard Powers, absolutely deserved the 2019 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction. It's that good. That being said, I think one of the qualifiTHE OVERSTORY, by Richard Powers, absolutely deserved the 2019 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction. It's that good. That being said, I think one of the qualifications for the prize must be that the story educate its readers. Indeed, this book leans pedantic. The Overstory is about trees and their importance to the health and longevity of the Earth, and therefore humans. I loved learning more about the history, gestation, and growth of trees. I have a new appreciation for old trees as I go on walks in my neighborhood. This book made me care about trees in ways I never did before. Thankfully, Powers wrapped the information about trees inside stories about nine unique and diverse characters. Each of them has an entirely different experience with trees. By weaving these characters together over multiple generations, Powers developed a plot and created suspense worth reading. I think the audience for THE OVERSTORY will be small. But people who like nature and deep, elegiac novels with beautiful writing will love this book.FOUR glorious STARS...more

title: The Nickel Boys
author: Whitehead, Colson*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you gave one hundred people the assignment to write a novel based on the real life story of Florida's Dozier (reform) School for Boys, a school nowIf you gave one hundred people the assignment to write a novel based on the real life story of Florida's Dozier (reform) School for Boys, a school now known to have secretly abused and killed young black boys in the 20th century, you would get a hundred wildly different novels. If one of those writers was Colson Whitehead, a Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award winning black author, it's not a stretch to think he might produce the best story of those hundred entries. So maybe my expectations were a tad high.THE NICKEL BOYS, by Whitehead, felt rushed and superficial, like a first draft. For a story based on such a tragic reality, this novel skimmed the life of one boy, Elwood Curtis, who was arrested and sent to the "Nickel Academy" on entirely trumped up charges because he was a black youth in the wrong place in the sixties. Elwood, who Whitehead says is entirely fabricated, was a near-perfect kid, working at every turn to be good and excel under the harshest of conditions. (He was picked up on his way to take college classes as a high school student.) Regardless, Elwood was horrifically punished for his transgressions. The best part of this brief story, IMHO, was Elwood's inner dialogue as he contemplates the preachings of Martin Luther King, Jr, which he heard on a record album his grandmother gave him and read about in news clippings she sent him at Nickel. Elwood struggles with how to follow King's teachings, specifically: "Throw us in jail and we will still love you." Elwood did not love his captors. He tries to follow King's belief that blacks will prevail by holding out hope and love. Instead, this is what leads to his undoing.I found this 200-page novel to be slow and full of TELLING. (Contrary to the adage: Show, don't tell.) For what could have been a book as powerful as Whitehead's THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD, I must say this seriously disappointed me. Two Sad Stars...more

title: The Guest Book
author: Blake, Sarah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am terribly conflicted about THE GUEST BOOK, by Sarah Blake. Normally when I finish a book, I know how I want to rate it and what to say here on GooI am terribly conflicted about THE GUEST BOOK, by Sarah Blake. Normally when I finish a book, I know how I want to rate it and what to say here on Goodreads. Not this time.For starters, I think this story is told backwards. In mysteries, the crime happens at the beginning and the "detective" solves it in the end. In suspense, it's the opposite. We know something bad is going to happen, and we keep turning the pages until it does, followed by the resolution. I think THE GUEST BOOK needed a lot more action up front. On page one, a random boater says, "Somebody drowned there." Yes, that kept me reading near the end, but the missed potential of this book is so much bigger than the action.Though the writing is often evocative and sensory, Blake presents multiple storylines for three generations of the wealthy Milton family, including Nazi sympathizers, racism, homosexuality, pre-marital sex (in the 50s), familial secrets, childhood death, and more—but all the subplots basically fizzle out; the characters don't address the issues they uncover, they just ponder them as they turn up. Blake or her editor might have thought this was more realistic, but there was no climax, no awakening or solution for the youngest generation. The ending was extremely unsatisfying.And the titular guest book? It's barely mentioned throughout and scarcely plays a part in the storyline. (I have no doubt the publishers chose the title from a list based on what would "sell.") Plus, while jumping between the three storylines, Blake does not give us timestamps. At the beginning of each chapter it takes several frustrating sentences to figure out which era we are in. This doesn't add to the story, it slows it down. Additionally, it's told in the omniscient POV, jumping between a handful of characters in a single scene. Again, this slows down the story more than it adds. She could have used third person POV and relayed the same emotion and information via dialogue.I got the sense that Blake was trying to recreate a THORN BIRDS-type book. IMHO, she would have been much more successful if she'd pulled in the story and kept a tighter focus.Two-and-a-half watery Stars (rounded up to three)...more

title: Where the Crawdads Sing
author: Owens, Delia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am sorry to say I was extremely disappointed in WHERE THE CRAWDADS SING, by Delia Owens. When I heard Owens's life story, a sixty-nine-year-old womaI am sorry to say I was extremely disappointed in WHERE THE CRAWDADS SING, by Delia Owens. When I heard Owens's life story, a sixty-nine-year-old woman publishes her first novel which has now been on the NYTimes Best Seller list for 36 weeks, I was thrilled for her. I bought the book as soon as I heard about it in an interview on CBS. Set in North Carolina in the 1950s, 60s, and 70s, WHERE THE CRAWDADS SING is the story of Kya, a young marsh girl, abandoned by her family, who knows just enough to survive on her own. A few years later, when a local boy is murdered, she becomes the town's first and only suspect. She is arrested and tried for his murder. That right there is a decent premise. A story-worthy idea. Unfortunately, this book needed a LOT of editing that it didn't get. The writing goes beyond evocative, quickly becoming flowery to the point of purple prose, yet I never felt I was THERE. There is little to no talk of snakes, bugs, calloused feet, mud between her toes, etc. The dialog (especially that of the white characters: Kya, Tate, Chase) is stilted and too perfect. Kya, a natural beauty, stunning artist, and unparalleled collector of shells, feathers, and grasses who was taught to read by a handsome young boy, becomes an award winning non-fiction author of several books on nature. In other words, her success (leading up to the trial) was farcical to the point of ridiculous. It's a case of an author falling in love with her protagonist. I kind of liked the ending but not enough to elevate my rating. All writers should be as fortunate as Delia Owens, but I wish for her sake that someone along the way had given her honest advice about how unrealistic the story is. It could have been so much better.One marshy Star...more

review: The Queen of Mystery didn't get that moniker by chance. Agatha Christie is a great writer, storyteller, and sleuth, in her own right. There is no doubThe Queen of Mystery didn't get that moniker by chance. Agatha Christie is a great writer, storyteller, and sleuth, in her own right. There is no doubt she was truly a genius. I picked up THE MURDER OF ROGER ACKROYD, written in 1926, after reading a reference to the excellent plotting. The article I read gave away the killer, so even though I knew who the killer was, I was intrigued and baffled by the case as Hercule Poirot worked through it. I haven't read enough Agatha Christie. Full stop. Or, I could continue to say I haven't read enough Agatha Christie to know if the key to all her mysteries is that there are so many characters that it's nearly impossible for a reader (on the first pass) to keep everyone and their actions straight. She plants a lot of needles in the haystack! Like a magician who keeps her audience focused on her right hand while the left is playing a trick, every character—at least in this book—is guilty of or hiding something. That muddies the waters and fuels the confusion about their honesty and motive. Christie's magic is that the answer is always so obvious when Poirot solves the crime in the final pages. FIVE magic STARS...more

title: When Breath Becomes Air
author: Kalanithi, Paul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A lot of people struggle with existential questions like What is the meaning of Life?, and Why am I here? Dr. Paul Kalanithi, author of the memoir WHEA lot of people struggle with existential questions like What is the meaning of Life?, and Why am I here? Dr. Paul Kalanithi, author of the memoir WHEN BREATH BECOMES AIR, struggled with those questions, too, but in my view, he lived the "perfect" life to have the authority to write a book on the subject.Curious as a child, Paul Kalanithi was always looking for answers, turning first to Nature, then to literature and poetry. Kalanithi went to Stanford to study English, where he received both a Bachelor's degree and Master's degree. But studying literature led him to more matters of the mind: How does the brain turn function (like the firing of neurons) into feelings, emotions, and personality? So Kalanithi took a few science and premed classes which led to a second Bachelor's degree in Human Biology. Fast forward a few years, and he also received a Master's of Philosophy from the University of Cambridge, and then his M.D. from Yale. He then returned to Stanford for his residency in neurological surgery, and earned a Ph.D. in neuroscience on the side. Kalanithi, during his decade of medical training, was singularly focused on the quality (and therefore value) of life, especially when confronted with the eminent possibility of death. He had THOUGHT he would study this via his patients in need of the most delicate brain surgeries. Then, at 36, Paul was diagnosed with Stage IV lung cancer.When I say he had a "perfect" life to write this book, what I mean is the pieces of his "pre-diagnosis" life, in the end, seem ideal to create an amazingly beautiful work of art, which he named WHEN BREATH BECOMES AIR. Few authors can organically ask literal questions like "What makes life meaningful enough to go on living?" and "How much neurologic suffering would you let your child endure before saying death is preferable?" These questions segue smoothly into the subject of science vs. God. A quote from page 170: "Science may provide the most useful way to organize empirical, reproducible data, but its power to do so is predicated on its inability to grasp the most central aspects of human life: hope, fear, love, hate, beauty, envy, honor, weakness, striving, suffering, virtue." Not only is Kalanithi able to address the major questions of Life from the medical side (both doctor and patient), but his early studies in literature and poetry gave him the ability to write about them in beautiful, poignant, and powerful prose. His story reads like a novel; I could barely put the book down, though at times I had to because the stories he tells about his patients and his own life are often tragic. It's a tough book to read, emotionally.Shortly after his diagnosis, Paul Kalanithi and his wife, Lucy, also a doctor, got pregnant and gave birth to a little girl. It was something he wanted more than anything. Five months later, Paul passed away, leaving behind this incredible work of literature, including the letter he writes to his daughter in hopes of being remembered. I, for one, know I will never forget this man or his story.FIVE brilliant STARS...more

The author gives descriptive, non-sentimental accounts of realTHE LINE BECOMES A RIVER, by Francisco Cantú, is a well-written and informative memoir. The author gives descriptive, non-sentimental accounts of real people and real events that happened primarily when he was a US Border Patrol agent. They are mostly heartbreaking, occasionally heartwarming. Cantú began this book in roughly 2008 in order to shine a light on the tragedies that were happening then, and in fact, still are happening. The situation has gotten worse, not better as he had hoped. As we should all hope if we care about the individuals who find themselves so desperate for help that they are willing to risk their lives and the lives of their children to reach safety.Immigration, climate change, corruption, and politics, in general, are such complex and important issues that all Americans should be devoting more time and money to. If you don't agree with our immigration policy, then fight for a better situation in Central America. Four tragic Stars...more

title: The Trespasser        (Dublin Murder Squad, #6)
author: French, Tana*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What an unexpected gem! THE TRESPASSER, by Tana French, her sixth installment of her Dublin Murder Squad stories, is more than just a captivating deteWhat an unexpected gem! THE TRESPASSER, by Tana French, her sixth installment of her Dublin Murder Squad stories, is more than just a captivating detective novel. THE TRESPASSER goes deep into the head and heart of its protagonist Detective Antoinette Conway, a young biracial female on the otherwise all-male murder squad. French's series takes on one case at a time, each told from a different detective's point of view. In each of these books, you learn about the inner life of the lead detective. Great idea, that. I haven't read them all, but so far, this is my favorite.The particular case of this detective story is of a young "Barbie doll" who is murdered, allegedly by her new boyfriend, a cookie cutter domestic violence case, at first glance. Except, of course, it might not be, and therein lies the story. The thrilling brilliance of this novel is in the first person mentality of being an outsider. Antoinette is suspicious of everyone of her coworkers, including her choirboy partner, Steve. After years of being bullied, specifically for being female, she doesn't trust any of them. I was as captivated by the subplot about which, if any, of her coworkers was indeed out to get her and trying to force her off the squad. Would this case be her last? THE TRESPASSER is gritty and crude at times, what we have come to expect from detective novels, I think, but it has more to offer than just a good read. The victim and the detective, both women, share a common factor, one that ends in death for one and a hotshot career for the other. It could lead to an interesting discussion on how girls are raised. The other plus for this book might be mainly for writers, but I was really impressed by how French mastered the skill of a first person narrator. I highly recommend this to anyone who writes or wants to write from the first person POV.I hesitate to give a contemporary mystery five stars, but ultimately my ratings are about readability. This novel is unputdownable. The writing is clean, the story is fresh, and the outcome is satisfying. I believe Tana French is the new Agatha Christie. FIVE intense STARS...more

title: The Great Alone
author: Hannah, Kristin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It has been a long time since a book made me stay up late, sobbing as I turned the pages. THE GREAT ALONE, by Kristin Hannah, hit me deeper than any bIt has been a long time since a book made me stay up late, sobbing as I turned the pages. THE GREAT ALONE, by Kristin Hannah, hit me deeper than any book I've read in many years—and that's a lot of books. At 438 pages, it is both epic and a quick read. In that regard, I would compare it to THE THORN BIRDS.Set in 1974 - 1986, the protagonist of THE GREAT ALONE is a girl named Lenora Albright, Leni, for short, whom we meet as a thirteen-year-old, living in Seattle. Her father, Ernt, is a Vietnam veteran, a former POW with PTSD. We would know that now, but they didn't in 1974. Leni's mother, Cora, loves her husband so deeply she forgives his repeated abuse and beatings. The man should be in therapy or prison, instead, the family of three heads to Alaska, aka the Great Alone, after Ernt's war buddy bequeaths him a homestead in the wilds of the harshest state in our country. They manage to survive five years in Alaska before tragedy strikes, then another, then another. By the half-way point in this story, I could not put the book down. The writing isn't perfect. In fact, I found the first fifty pages a bit pedestrian: story, story, story [insert atmospheric paragraph here], story, story. Meh. But when Leni starts school in her tiny new town, everything changed. Maybe I was distracted or maybe Kristin Hannah would have benefitted from one more rewrite, but this book picked up steam and turned into a freight train. The tale is in turns lovely, tragic, horrific, happy, sad, hopeful, and heart-breaking. I've never been to Alaska, but Hannah tells us in her acknowledgments that she (and three generations of her family) lived in the region where this story takes place. When she describes the realities and brutalities of life there, I believe her. I also imagine she has suffered the loss of loved ones. The scenes where she describes death and dying are real and raw. That I do know.FOUR and a half heart-wrenching STARS, rounded up....more

title: Liars' Paradox        (A Jack and Jill Thriller, #1)
author: Stevens, Taylor*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sensational! LIARS' PARADOX, by Taylor Stevens, is a true, nerve-wracking, page-turning thriller. I didn't want to put this book down, and let things Sensational! LIARS' PARADOX, by Taylor Stevens, is a true, nerve-wracking, page-turning thriller. I didn't want to put this book down, and let things slide so I could read it till the end. The writing is terse, yet descriptive and evocative to the point that my heart raced as the characters went from being the hunters to the hunted and back again.Stevens has created remarkable heroes (anti-heroes?) for this "Jack and Jill" thriller. A brother and sister duo, as badass as they come, begin on a mission to find "Clare," their outrageous mother whom they haven't seen in ten years. Clare raised the twins to be assassins to protect themselves from (possibly phantom) bad guys, and then she disappeared from their lives. In this first-of-a-series story, Taylor weaves realistic, complex backstories and personalities for each of the characters, making the storyline as believable as a thriller can be. How Stevens knows the underground as well as she does is a question I don't want to ask! The ending is psychological and literary perfection. She weaves revenge, strategy, and innate human desire into a satisfying but open-ended sequence that leads perfectly to a follow up book. I, for one, cannot wait until it's published. Bravo, Taylor Stevens!Five adrenaline filled Stars...more

title: Breakfast at Tiffany's a short novel and three stories
author: Capote, Truman
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: News flash: BREAKFAST AT TIFFANY'S, the 1958 short story by Truman Capote, is vastly different from the movie. In Capote's version, Holly Golightly isNews flash: BREAKFAST AT TIFFANY'S, the 1958 short story by Truman Capote, is vastly different from the movie. In Capote's version, Holly Golightly is a much more nuanced and gritty female than she is in Blake Edwards' Hollywood version. Both versions are just as they should be.BREAKFAST AT TIFFANY'S, the movie, is possibly my all-time favorite film, so, as a voracious reader, I realized I was long overdue in reading the book. At first, all I could focus on were the differences between the two versions, but by the time I reached the "original" ending, I was completely sold on Capote's version (though I'll never stop loving Edwards' film).To say that Holly is more nuanced and gritty begs also saying that the literary version of Paul Varjak is a ghost of the movie version. In the book, he is an unnamed narrator—a writer, yes, but without a name and without a wealthy benefactor. Capote was such an excellent writer, creating vivid, sensitive characters, that it's easy to see why Blake Edwards wanted to turn this little story into a movie. I'm glad he did, and I'm delighted he gave the film a Hollywood ending—because now we have two versions of a classic story.FIVE sparkly STARS...more

review: I bet AUDACITY, by Melanie Crowder, really threw booksellers for a loop. Should it be shelved under fiction, non-fiction, poetry, or biography? In a sI bet AUDACITY, by Melanie Crowder, really threw booksellers for a loop. Should it be shelved under fiction, non-fiction, poetry, or biography? In a sense, it's all of the above.AUDACITY is a book of poems "inspired by the true events of the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Uprising" of the early 20th century. In other words, it's basically the true story of Clara Lemlich, a Russian Jewish immigrant who inspired the uprising, that the author chose to tell in poetry form. My first question is Why? Apparently Crowder, a poet, felt this story needed to be told again, and as a poet, she wrote her version in her chosen form. There's absolutely nothing wrong with that, but if this book hadn't been chosen for my book club, I wouldn't have ever picked it up let alone read it. C'est la vie, I guess. If this intrigues you, then you'll be delighted to know it's a pretty quick read about an amazing woman.Two-and-a-half bold Stars...more

author: Boyne, John*

review: UPDATED REVIEW: I've just finished reading this for the second time. It definitely holds up. Boyne has created a truly psychopathic character who is "UPDATED REVIEW: I've just finished reading this for the second time. It definitely holds up. Boyne has created a truly psychopathic character who is "hella fun" to read about (to quote another er). This one will get a reaction out of everyone! Can't wait for my book club to read it.Now here's a book worth talking about. A LADDER TO THE SKY, by John Boyne, is a complex, creepy, well-written novel that sticks with you long after you've finished the final pages. The London Times compared it to Patricia Highsmith's Tom Ripley novels, and rightfully so. A LADDER TO THE SKY is the story of Maurice Swift, a handsome, talented but unimaginative novelist who learns early in life that people (both men and women) will open up to him because he's so "beautiful." He uses this knowledge and ability for evil, not good. Told in three parts plus two interludes, each from a different character's POV, we are shown the depths of Swift's depravity—each section darker than the last. His ambition (his ladder to the sky) trumps all. He cajoles, steals, seduces, even kills whoever is necessary to publish his next book, sparing no one in his quest for fame and glory now, and to be remembered forever. Boyne, author of THE BOY IN THE STRIPED PAJAMAS and THE HEART'S INVISIBLE FURIES, makes some bold stylistic choices in this novel. It seems right on the verge of trying too hard, but I feel he succeeded. Especially with the ending. It is poetically perfect. A LADDER TO THE SKY won't become one of the classics of 21st century literature, but I think it will rank high on mystery/psychological thriller lists for decades to come. Four-and-a-half psychotic Stars (rounded up to Five)...more

title: There There
author: Orange, Tommy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THERE THERE, by Tommy Orange, got a lot of well-deserved, national attention. I like to read books that get a lot of attention. It got attention beca THERE THERE, by Tommy Orange, got a lot of well-deserved, national attention. I like to read books that get a lot of attention. It got attention because it brought to light an important subject: how horrifically the early American settlers treated the indigenous people, now known as Native American Indians. However, I can't say this is a great book.THERE THERE has a prologue and an interlude that read like non-fiction. (I have not heard for certain if they are true or imagined to be true.) Those sections are gut-wrenching and shameful. Native American Indians were treated worse than the buffalo and other wildlife. It's sickening to imagine what the "white man" did to other human beings just because their skin was darker and their clothes and language were different from the Europeans'. Again, I'm not sure if those sections are factual or not.The bulk of the novel, however, is made up of short, fictional bits from multiple present-day Native Americans' points of view. Each of the characters Orange creates is working his or her way to a big, present-day Powwow in Oakland, California, where we know "something bad" is going to happen. There's nothing wrong with that premise, except that the characters all blur together to the point that I didn't care who died in the end because I couldn't remember who was who. Though the characters are divergent in sex, age, status, and socio-economic background, their "voices" are mostly interchangeable. Maybe Orange was trying to make the point that the average white American can't differentiate between Indians, but that seems a stretch. A lot of very smart people I know (plus the NYTimes Book Reviewer) couldn't keep the characters straight. That sounds more likely to be the "fault" of the (young) author. In the assorted clips from the dozen or more characters, Orange used present tense, past tense, first person POV, third person POV, even one chapter in second person. They are all well-written, but this books reeks of a "THESIS" compilation, not a well-edited, focused novel. THERE THERE is indeed an important story, and Tommy Orange has great promise. I indeed hope he continues to write and brings to light more truth about Native American Indians. This is a topic America needs to wake up to. I do hope, though, that his next work is more straight-forward.Three enlightening Stars...more

title: Fascism: A Warning
author: Albright, Madeleine K.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: We know Madeleine Albright's intentions for her book FASCISM, A WARNING, simply because of the title, but I think that's unfortunate because, I imaginWe know Madeleine Albright's intentions for her book FASCISM, A WARNING, simply because of the title, but I think that's unfortunate because, I imagine, few supporters of Donald Trump will pick up the book or heed the lessons of such a dire proclamation. Not to mention the flat black cover with bold, red lettering. Maybe her publisher wanted to raise a red flag or embolden the Left to band together in opposition to Trump and the Right, but I wish this book would have been presented as a wake up call to all Republicans. They are the ones who need this information the most.FASCISM, A WARNING, is essentially a summary of (primarily) twentieth century European leaders who are now known as Fascists (they didn't "run" under that political party banner), and the ways in which they each came into power. In other words, it's a cautionary tale to Americans who say, "It can't happen here. We have too many checks and balances." Well, according to Albright and other scholars, yes, it can. Italians and Germans of the early twentieth century were not all horrible people, they were simply frightened, struggling people who fell under the spell of charismatic men who promised to solve all their problems.Beginning with Mussolini, Albright concisely presents the paths that he, Hitler, Milosevic, Chavez, Erdogan, et al, ending with Kim Jong-un, the only "true Fascist," took to become leaders of their countries. She then cites the ways in which Donald Trump is utilizing many tactics these Fascist leaders used, including stealing many lines from their "scripts," right down to "draining the swamp." This book definitely hit me in the gut. It scares the hell out of me to think of how Trump capitalizes on fear and xenophobia to win supporters. America was built on freedom of speech, religion, and welcoming the "huddled masses." Not only that, but America has been a major contributor to Global Warming, hitting the globe in its warmest spot, the Middle East and the Equator. It's no wonder people in those regions are fighting and starving and looking for refuge. I would recommend this book to anyone who asks, "How is it possible, what's happening to our country?" I would also recommend this book to anyone who says, "No, Trump isn't like Mussolini or Hitler or any of those others ..." FOUR red-letter STARS (she lost one star for not making the book more appealing to a wider audience)...more

title: Lethal White        (Cormoran Strike, #4)
author: Galbraith, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Too much of a good thing is not a good thing. Clocking in at 650 pages, LETHAL WHITE, by Robert Galbraith (aka JK Rowling), is the fourth installment Too much of a good thing is not a good thing. Clocking in at 650 pages, LETHAL WHITE, by Robert Galbraith (aka JK Rowling), is the fourth installment of the Cormoran Strike detective series. "Galbraith" is a brilliant storyteller. The characters are fantastically complex and drawn out. The setting descriptions are detailed and picturesque. And the plot ... oh, the plot. The plot is highly complex. Strike and his trusty sidekick, the fiery Robin Ellacott, are hired by Jasper Chiswell, the Minister of Culture for the British Parliament, who is being blackmailed for something he did six years previous that he won't disclose to Strike. "It was legal at the time," is all he'll say. Robin is sent to work undercover in Chiswell's office to gain information from the suspected blackmailer. Meanwhile, a "mentally disturbed man" visits Strike's office at the beginning of the book and tells Strike he saw someone murdered twenty years before. And, as they work the case, Galbraith gives us a several hundred pages of personal (romantic) drama between Strike and his girlfriend (as well as ex-girlfriend), and also Robin, who gets married in the Prologue. Multiple people die (or nearly die) along the way. Somehow, Galbraith weaves all of these threads into a truly captivating story. Ultimately, the first whodunit scene is fifteen pages long as the characters and police "break the case." The second whodunit scene (possibly a why- or how-dunit scene) is another sixteen pages long—because many of the details and clues (which I have no doubt were expertly sprinkled in along the way) are minute and obscure. Bravo to Galbraith, but I would have preferred a five-hundred page novel with fewer red herrings and complications. Then again, I imagine JK Rowling feels enormous pressure to deliver huge, complex books like LETHAL WHITE. Four-and-a-half complicated Stars...more

title: The Witch Elm
author: French, Tana*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am a huge fan of Tana French's Dublin Murder Squad mysteries. Naturally, I thought I would love THE WITCH ELM, her first stand-alone suspense novel.I am a huge fan of Tana French's Dublin Murder Squad mysteries. Naturally, I thought I would love THE WITCH ELM, her first stand-alone suspense novel. However, at over five hundred pages, The Witch Elm is too long.The premise: three Irish cousins, now twenty-eight, return to the family home of their beloved, childless Uncle Hugo who is dying of brain cancer. The story follows these three: Toby (the protagonist and narrator); Leon (who is single and gay); and Susanna (now married with two children), who walk us back through their high school days after the skeleton of a classmate is found inside the family's "wych elm" tree in the back garden. It becomes clear that someone, most likely one of the four people I have mentioned, killed the boy, Dominic, years ago. The question, of course, is which one? Or, was it suicide after all, the way everyone believed at the time of his death?As the book opens, Toby, the narrator, works in PR for an avant-garde art gallery that is preparing for an edgy exhibition. Except things get off track, Toby is reprimanded, and then late one night, Toby's apartment is broken into and the thieves beat Toby to a pulp, causing serious injuries and significant brain trauma. As Toby is healing, he and his lovely girlfriend, Melissa, go to the home of Uncle Hugo to take care of him in his final days. That's when the skeleton is found, that's when the mystery begins. Because of his brain injuries from the robbery, Toby is an unreliable narrator as he works through what might have happened to Dominic.The theme of the book, I believe, is how immensely one person's small actions can affect another person. Tana French doesn't get preachy, but she does explore how seemingly insignificant actions can snowball into tragic events. I fully agree with that idea, and applaud her efforts to inform us via a good story. And yet still, the book drags on a bit too long.Don't get me wrong, French is an excellent storyteller. Her writing and details are focused and clever. This just feels like the publishers told her to take it from, say, 350 pages to 500 to give readers "more." There is too much "navel gazing" (aka pondering of a partial-amnesiac). "Did I do it?" "Could I really have done it?" These aren't spoilers ... it's pretty obvious that we're going to find out one of family members is the guilty party. The ending throws in an unexpected twist, so that's good, but it doesn't save the story.Three-and-a-half shooting Stars rounded to Four ...more

title: A Prayer for Owen Meany
author: Irving, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I first read A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving, a few years after it was published, so maybe 25 years ago. Both readings were for a book club, wI first read A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving, a few years after it was published, so maybe 25 years ago. Both readings were for a book club, which is ideal because this is definitely a book that needs/deserves serious discussion. In short, though, my opinion hasn't really changed: A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY is one of my favorite "really boring" books. A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY is the story of two childhood friends growing up in Gravesend, New Hampshire, in the 1950s and '60s. The narrator, Johnny Wheelwright, is the illegitimate son of a single mother. (One of the driving questions of the novel is who is his father?) Johnny's best friend is Owen Meany, the only child of the town's quarry owner. Owen Meany is one of the most unique and memorable literary characters of all time. He is tiny his entire life and his voice is like "a permanent scream." Not only that, Owen knows things, he is never wrong, and he is very smart. In the summer of '52, the eleven year old boys were playing Little League baseball. Owen's first and only hit struck Johnny's mother in the head and killed her. Because of that moment and several others, Owen Meany believes he is is an Instrument of God. He thinks he was destined to kill her. He thinks everything about him and everything he has done or will do is preordained by God, including his size and his voice. His life quest is to find out why.With that premise (what if a young boy never grew up?—not in the Peter Pan way; in the never went through puberty way), John Irving created a story about WHY that might be. Though Irving states he is not overly religious, this novel is centered around religion, specifically the various differences between the Christian religions. A major point of discussion for this story is: Is a person's life predetermined? Or can a person's thoughts turn their life into a self-fulfilling prophecy? Or is this just a fictional manipulation because everything that happens in the world is random?My paperback copy of this book clocks in at 629 pages, plus the PS. pages of interviews and observations of the author. It FEELS like a bible in my hands. I can't help but believe Irving made the story intentionally long to give it that feeling! John Wheelwright, who narrates the story nearly twenty years after the death of Owen Meany (not a spoiler!), introduces us to nearly every person in the town of Gravesend, NH, or so it seems. I truly don't know why, other than to drag out the story for added emphasis of the final, dramatic pages. There is a lot to like about this book; there is also a lot to not like, eg. Irving's overuse of the semicolon and the exclamation mark! Every word that Owen Meany speaks is written in ALL CAPS. That would be extremely annoying if it weren't a necessary reminder of his high-pitched "wrecked" voice. My biggest struggle with this story is that Johnny Wheelwright never struggles, not even for a second, with anger or resentment toward Owen for killing his mother! That seems implausible to me.The second reading of A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY doesn't hold the same gravitas as the first reading did, but it allows the reader to focus on numerous finer points of the story. It's still a very good boring book.FOUR screaming STARS...more

title: Rabbit Is Rich        (Rabbit Angstrom, #3)
author: Updike, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have not taken the time to look up the phrase "Men are pigs," but I think RABBIT IS RICH, by John Updike, could be entered as supporting evidence: "I have not taken the time to look up the phrase "Men are pigs," but I think RABBIT IS RICH, by John Updike, could be entered as supporting evidence: "Article # 1, your honor."If you've read any of my recent book s, you may remember that I am on a quest to read as many Pulitzer Prize winning novels as I can squeeze into my already towering TBR pile. Because Updike won TWO Pulitzer Prizes for his "Rabbit" series (one for RABBIT IS RICH, and the second for RABBIT AT REST), I thought I would invest my time in the series of four books. I read the first one, RABBIT, RUN, to learn who is who and what is what. Meh. I skipped the second one, RABBIT REDUX, because the summary didn't entice me enough. Now this: RABBIT IS RICH. When I finished this book—astounded it won the Pulitzer Prize in 1982, beating out Marilynn Robinson's HOUSEKEEPING—I literally googled the Pulitzer committee, looking to see who thought this book deserved such an esteemed prize. (It also won the National Book award, so clearly I'm the one who's the idiot, right? Either that or times have changed ...) It came as no surprise to me that the committee consisted of 15 men (13 who appear to be white, two appear to be minorities) and two white women. If Harry "Rabbit" Angstrom, the protagonist, is a "typical" male, which is essentially how the entire series is pitched, then the "typical male" is a low-life, sex-crazed, egomaniacal, disgusting Homosapien. I'm more surprised that the Pulitzer committee not only acknowledged how "typical" men think, but they lauded it. In RABBIT IS RICH, Harry is now forty-something and has inherited a third of his late father-in-law's Toyota dealership, along with his wife and his mother-in-law. He is unforgiving and unloving to his son (despite the fact Harry and his wife Janice lost a baby girl in RABBIT, RUN). He lusts after every young female who comes into his view. He stays with his wife, though wishes she did more to please him. He is racist and judgmental and not terribly bright. Money and sex, sex and money, that's what Harry Angstrom cares about. When, near the end of the book, Harry is told that one of his former girlfriends had to have a mastectomy, his first thought is: ""My God." Breast he had sucked." If I end up reading RABBIT AT REST, which I unfortunately already purchased, it will be only to hope that Harry Angstrom gets his comeuppance. It's no wonder the world is going through the #metoo movement. I only wish it could have started five hundred or five thousand years ago. #PulitzerRedux #MarilynnRobinson1982 Two pathetic Stars...more

I read it (or rather listened to it) as a means to an end: I am on a quest to read Pulitzer Prize winning novels. Since John Updike is one of three writers to win the Pulitzer Prize twice, for the third and fourth books in his "Rabbit" series, I read this just so I would know who Harry "Rabbit" Angstrom is. First published in 1960, RABBIT, RUN, is the story of a typical man. He's a struggling salesman in small-town Pennsylvania with a three-year-old son and an alcoholic pregnant wife. One day he just runs—or rather drives—off. He can't take the pressure and monotony of life anymore. He hooks up with a girl, and only goes home to his wife when she is giving birth to their child. While this book was very well written and certainly interesting enough to keep me listening for twelve hours, I can't say that I identified with the protagonist or his struggles. It's a good book, but I see it as a stepping stone on the path to reading RABBIT IS RICH and RABBIT AT REST. Stay tuned for those s.THREE quick STARS...more

review: If you remove the excess bling and view this novel at arm's length, WHEN LIFE GIVES YOU LULULEMONS, by Lauren Weisberger, is about three thirty-somethIf you remove the excess bling and view this novel at arm's length, WHEN LIFE GIVES YOU LULULEMONS, by Lauren Weisberger, is about three thirty-something women at different stages in their lives who learn to navigate life's common challenges and vagaries. Marriage or divorce, children or no children, friends or frenemies, no life (no matter how rich a person is) is without its struggles. Weisberger, best-known for THE DEVIL WEARS PRADA, is a good writer. She follows the rules and doesn't try too hard. This is "chick lit" at its finest, if that's still a thing and still PC to say. The novel is cinematic and colorful (certain chapters are VERY colorful) and seems destined for the big screen. WLGYL is an easy, fun read—if you can embrace (or ignore) the Maseratis/designer name dropping/gross display of wealth, etc., etc., to focus on the characters' struggles.My biggest knock with this book is not the aforementioned issues some might have. My biggest complaint is how this book skim-coats real problems and never goes deep enough into real emotions. Then again, it may be that I've moved past "chick lit" and prefer more literary reads. After all, I did pick this book up as an antidote to the two previous, very male-oriented books I've recently read.Three-and-a-half lemony Stars (rounded down)...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I once read in a writing-advice blog that prize committees love references to their organization. In LESS, by Andrew Sean Greer, the main character, AI once read in a writing-advice blog that prize committees love references to their organization. In LESS, by Andrew Sean Greer, the main character, Arthur Less, has been dating a poet, an older man of high regard who wins the Pulitzer Prize. Greer goes on (or rather his characters go on) to make fun of winning an award such as a Pulitzer: "You win a prize, and it's all over. You lecture for the rest of your life. But you never write again." In my best estimation, this is why LESS won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 2018.LESS is the story of a tall, blond, lovesick, gay, semi-successful, 49yo writer who goes on a round-the-world trip to make sure he's out of town on the day his former lover (a new, young man; not the older poet) marries someone else. I know nothing about Andrew Sean Greer other than the fact that he is a tall, fair-haired, semi-successful (before this novel), mid-forties writer. In other words, it may not be autobiographical, but it could easily be an amalgamation of Greer's life and experiences. It reads like a mashup of EAT, PRAY, LOVE and THE PRICE OF SALT (aka CAROL), by Patricia Highsmith. It is populated with writers who both support and undermine each other. While LESS walks the high-rope with some seriously funny scenes and self-deprecating humor, I was disappointed and truly shocked that it won the Pulitzer, especially considering the winners over the last few years: THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD, THE SYMPATHIZER, ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, THE GOLDFINCH, etc. Paraphrasing the text of this book, it may simply have been time for a "gay" novel to win, in which case, congratulations to Greer.THREE and a half STARS...more

title: Tangerine
author: Mangan, Christine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Have you ever finished a book and wanted to scream at the author, the agent, and the editor? No? Well I have, especially with this one. TANGERINE is tHave you ever finished a book and wanted to scream at the author, the agent, and the editor? No? Well I have, especially with this one. TANGERINE is the debut novel of Christine Mangan, an American author who received her PhD from University College Dublin, and an MFA from University of Southern Maine. I picked up this book based its cover. The stunning black and white photograph, it turns out, is of the very real Suzy Parker, arguably the world's first supermodel, in Morocco in the fifties. It's gorgeous. Then this blurb from the incomparable Joyce Carol Oates: "As if Donna Tartt, Gillian Flynn, and Patricia Highsmith collaborated on a screenplay to be filmed by Hitchcock." Da dum. Hook, line, and sinker.Then I started reading. I can't say it's not well written, but I can say the first half moved frustratingly slowly. The author/characters refer to "the accident" and "what happened at Bennington" so many times I groaned out loud. The story is of Alice and Lucy, roommates at Bennington College in Vermont in the early 1950s. They develop a close, almost obsessive relationship. When Alice, an orphan with a lot of baggage, meets Tom, a boy from a nearby university, things start to go eerily wrong. The accident happens, Lucy disappears, and Alice drops out of school.Told in alternating points-of-view, first Alice, then Lucy, etc., the book opens (after a dark Prologue) years later with Alice married to John and living in Tangier. Who turns up on her doorstep? None other than Lucy, the suspicious roommate she left behind. They become reacquainted and share bits and pieces of their history. It's not until Part 2, the second half of the book, that this book lives up to its hype. Think Hitchcock all the way to the devastating end. I wish so much I could have weighed in on the editing of this book (naturally, I think my version would have been better!). I would have cut much of the first half and removed every one-sentence paragraph that said: And then I remembered., or And then I saw him., or But there was something more, too. That's what I call "the writing getting in the way of the story." I can't believe I'm saying this, but this is a case where I think I will like the movie version better than the book—and yes, it's already in production with, ooh, ooh, George Clooney as a producer. (Thank you, IMDb.)Three-and-a-half twinkling orange Stars, rounded to Four, for Goodreads' sake....more

title: Crime and Punishment
author: Dostoevsky, Fyodor
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When a book has held up over 150 years of literature, you know it's worthy of reading. Dostoevsky's CRIME AND PUNISHMENT is certainly one of those booWhen a book has held up over 150 years of literature, you know it's worthy of reading. Dostoevsky's CRIME AND PUNISHMENT is certainly one of those books. I chose this book for my book club, which means I also did some research on Fyodor Dostoevsky himself. That research added a significant layer to the story and illuminated many scenes and emotions in the book which were drawn directly from Dostoevsky's life. Most directly, in my opinion, was that FD wrote this book while simultaneously writing another book under dire pressure from a crooked publisher. Perhaps that explains why C&P is filled with adverbs and exclamation points.CRIME AND PUNISHMENT, as most people know, is a novel in six parts about Raskolnikov, a bright young man who has a theory about ordinary and extraordinary people; the extraordinary are able or allowed to do whatever the hell they want, including murder, pillage, and seize land and property. Napoleon, for example, was an extraordinary person according to this theory. When Raskolnikov hits dire straits, he decides to murder an evil old female pawnbroker (and incidentally her innocent sister who walks in at the wrong moment). But much to Raskolnikov's surprise, he is not the extraordinary man he thought he was, and therefore the murders nearly drive him mad because he has a conscience. (A truly extraordinary man would have gone on to kill more people and spend their money until he had acquired great wealth and power.) What follows is Raskolnikov's journey through torment to redemption. [Sorry, but I don't think spoiler alerts apply to a book that's 150 years old. Besides, you learn all that by reading the back cover.]I am fascinated by how guilt, and sometimes lack thereof, weighs on a person. I had wanted to read this book for years for Dostoevsky's insight on the psychology of a criminal. He was highly regarded during his lifetime—and still is—for his keen understanding of humanity under the pressures of poverty, society, and the political atmosphere in 19th century Russia. Two topics were the focus of my book club discussion. First, religion. Dostoevsky was an extremely pious Orthodox Christian. He, more so than his peers, saw Christ as the answer to redemption and the evils of the world. Second was his portrayal of women in this novel. The men in C&P range from hideous (Raskolnikov and Svidrigailov, Raskolnikov's sister's boss) to the kind and hard-working Razumikhin, Raskolnikov's only friend. But the women are almost without exception well-meaning, hard-suffering, supportive and caring people. They—specifically Raskolnikov's mother, sister, and Sonya, the woman he falls in love with—take care of the men in their lives despite their despicable behaviors. CRIME AND PUNISHMENT was a much easier read than I expected it to be. I read the 1992 translation by Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky, which is arguably the most accurate translation, and the 550 pages read very quickly, aside from the aforementioned overuse of adverbs and exclamation points which I can forgive in light of the overall brilliance of this book.FIVE rewarding STARS...more

author: Fridlund, Emily

review: Emily Fridlund has created an enigmatic story in HISTORY OF WOLVES. It's no more about wolves than TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD is about mockingbirds. In othEmily Fridlund has created an enigmatic story in HISTORY OF WOLVES. It's no more about wolves than TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD is about mockingbirds. In other words, it helps the reader find the theme, but doesn't give us a hint to what the story is about. Oddly, ultimately, the novel seems to be a vehicle in which to bash Christian Scientists. Linda (aka Mattie), the fifteen-year-old protagonist in History of Wolves, is the daughter of "hippies," just trying to find her place in the world. They live in a remote house on a remote lake in a remote region of Minnesota. Then a young family moves in across the lake, and soon Linda starts babysitting their young son, Paul. Told as a reflection after the young, Christian Science parents were tried for the death of their son (we learn this in the first paragraph), Linda attempts to piece together her role in the boy's death, and also why people do what they do. The motto of Christian Scientists, "It's not what you do but what you think that matters," becomes her jumping off point from which she develops her own motto: "It's not what you think but what you do that matters." Because she did nothing (or not enough) to save Paul, she struggles with what kind of a person she is deep inside. Mostly we learn she is a girl starved for love.Although I didn't love this book, it made for a good book club discussion. I think Emily Fridlund has a lot of potential, though I hope her next book is more creative story and less a diatribe against the evils of a specific religion (because, this is America and we do have that whole "freedom of religion" thing going for us).THREE curious STARS...more

title: The Widow        (Kate Waters, #1)
author: Barton, Fiona*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE WIDOW, Fiona Barton's debut novel, is a page-turner. Once you start, it's difficult to put down. I fully agree with the comparisons to GONE GIRL aTHE WIDOW, Fiona Barton's debut novel, is a page-turner. Once you start, it's difficult to put down. I fully agree with the comparisons to GONE GIRL and GIRL ON A TRAIN, which is to say that it's a gripping female-oriented mystery. After many years as an accomplished journalist in the UK, it seems Barton decided to turn her investigative journalism into a fictional story. Gene Taylor, the title character in this novel, is the young, submissive wife (now widow) of Glen Taylor who died just before the story opens. Reporter Kate Waters wrangles the first interview with "Genie" who is newsworthy because Glen, a known pedophile (we learn through interviews and subsequent flashbacks), was acquitted for the kidnapping and possible murder of two-year-old Bella Elliott years ago. The haunting case was never solved. Now that Glen is dead, the reporters and detectives are hoping Genie will tell all. The little girl's grieving mother—and the entire UK—still want to find her. Over the course of the book, we begin to wonder if mousy Genie Taylor has a darker side—and possibly a hand in the girl's disappearance. This book came HIGHLY recommended to me as UNPUTDOWNABLE. That usually ruins a book for me. For the "average" reader, or someone who just wants to get lost in a good story, this is a great recommendation. Taking a more critical look, the POV jumps all over the place. Told with alternating POV chapters (the widow, the detective, the reporter, etc.) and a jumbled timeline, the story unfolds well, but Barton does not stick to her chosen POV. Even when we think she's in the head of the detective, for instance, Barton tells us what his partner is thinking. A good editor would have fixed that before publication.THREE and a half dark STARS (for delving into the world of pedophilia) ...more

title: Dept. of Speculation
author: Offill, Jenny*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the first book I have ever read twice in a row. As soon as I finished it the first time, I started it again, partly because it was so moving, This is the first book I have ever read twice in a row. As soon as I finished it the first time, I started it again, partly because it was so moving, partly because the format and style require it. And partly because at 177 pages with a lot of white space, it's doable. DEPT. OF SPECULATION, the second novel of Jenny Offill, reads almost like a poem—think stanzas instead of paragraphs— as opposed to a flowing narrative. The storyline isn't unique, even according to the author in an interview. It took her more than a dozen years to write this book because she was hesitant to tell the tired story of a tired mother and cheating husband. In a literary sense, this book is the result of "necessity is the mother of invention." How can I tell this story in a new way? she asked herself. In fighting against "standard," she lifted her book to "shimmering," "smashing," "startling," "sparkling," and several other blurbed adjectives that don't begin with the letter s. DEPT. OF SPECULATION is a precious, heartrending story of a woman who is struggling with life's challenges. Offill's style is brilliant. Leonard Elmore would give her a standing ovation: It's like she wrote a long novel and took out the parts people normally skip anyway. For example, Offill gives us a paragraph about "the wife" and "the husband" (most of the characters are unnamed), followed by a seemingly random fact from science or literature or history. At first, I thought, What??? Soon I realized the "random" parts aren't random at all. We readers actually have to use our brains to connect the dots. I really really liked this book. FOUR and a half shimmering STARS...more

title: The Age of Innocence
author: Wharton, Edith
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read THE AGE OF INNOCENCE, by Edith Wharton, in my quest to conquer the list of Pulitzer Prize winning novels. Wharton, in 1921, was the first womanI read THE AGE OF INNOCENCE, by Edith Wharton, in my quest to conquer the list of Pulitzer Prize winning novels. Wharton, in 1921, was the first woman to win the prize for fiction. For that reason alone, I would like to give this book Five Stars, unfortunately, I don't think it rises to the level of greatness of earlier novels by women like MIDDLEMARCH and JANE EYRE (both written before the first Pulitzer Prize for fiction was awarded in 1918).THE AGE OF INNOCENCE takes place in New York City in the late 1800s. It was fascinating to hear about New York City at the time, how so few houses were above 14th Street, the early days of the Metropolitan Museum, and other tidbits like restaurants, clothing, transportation, the opera, etc. However I struggled to stay interested in the storyline—how Newland Archer felt torn between his fiancée/wife May Welland, and her cousin, Countess Ellen Olenska, who returns to NYC after leaving her husband, a Polish Count. Archer and Ellen were friends as children, and when they meet again as adults, Archer becomes frantic to marry May Welland before he can get himself in trouble with Ellen, who wants to divorce the Count.  In the late 1800s, her divorce would have brought shame on their entire family. In essence, the story is a love triangle. Will he or won't he leave his wife for her cousin? Perhaps with a second reading I would pick up more subplots and more themes behind the story, but I highly doubt I will ever re-read this book. In fairness, I listened to the audio version, narrated by Lorna Raver. I did not like her reading, so that might have affected my feelings about this book. It's possible I loved MIDDLEMARCH and JANE EYRE because they were narrated so beautifully by the incomparable Juliet Stephenson. Alas, what a shame Ms. Stephenson can't narrate ALL books. THREE (and a half) innocent STARS...more

title: Ordinary Grace
author: Krueger, William Kent*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: MAY 2018ORDINARY GRACE, by William Kent Krueger, is a quietly captivating, beautiful story. Told from the perspective of thirteen-year-old Frank Drum,MAY 2018ORDINARY GRACE, by William Kent Krueger, is a quietly captivating, beautiful story. Told from the perspective of thirteen-year-old Frank Drum, a preacher's son, ORDINARY GRACE is part mystery/part bildungsroman. In the hot summer of 1961, four people die in the Drums' tiny town of New Bremen, Minnesota, one by natural causes, one by accident, one suicide, and one murder—starting with the death of a young boy on the forbidden railroad tracks. Soon another body is found. Then we get the heavy foreshadowing line: "And the next [death] would be the most painful to bear." My thought, as I was reading, was that maybe the accident wasn't an accident, the death by natural causes wasn't natural, etc. If Krueger had done it my way, I might have given the book five stars. It turned out to be pretty straightforward. By making the narrator the son of the town preacher, Frank is privy to a lot of "insider information," though too often the kid is eavesdropping and downright spying on the adults. I'm sure some boys would behave exactly as Frank does, but it felt like more of a literary technique to keep the narrative in the first person POV. This also gives Krueger the opportunity to speak about God, but not too heavily. The passages about "Is there a God or isn't there?" seemed true to character, not forced by the author.This is the first book I've read by William K. Krueger, and I really liked it. It will be easy to recommend. The writing is evocative though occasionally inches ever near purple prose. It starts out strong, then gets a tad tedious, but by half-way through, I couldn't put it down. If you like small-town historical fiction, a bit of mystery, but not gruesome, you will really enjoy this book.FOUR graceful STARS...more

title: Brain Food: The Surprising Science of Eating for Cognitive Power
author: Mosconi, Lisa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If every adult read BRAIN FOOD, by Lisa Mosconi, it might change the course of history. A non-fiction book like this, one that makes bold claims aboutIf every adult read BRAIN FOOD, by Lisa Mosconi, it might change the course of history. A non-fiction book like this, one that makes bold claims about health matters, is entirely dependent on the author's credentials. Lisa Mosconi has the right credentials: She has a duel PhD in neuroscience and Nuclear Medicine, and is a board-certified integrative nutritionist and holistic health-care practitioner; she is the associate director of the Alzheimer's Prevention Clinic at Weill Cornell Medical College/New York-Presbyterian Hospital; she was an associate professor of neuroscience in neurology; she was the director of the Nutrition and Brain Fitness Lab at NYU School of Medicine, et al. If this isn't enough for you, read more about her at lisamosconi.com.Mosconi states on page 11: "What most people don't know is that less than 1 percent of the population develops Alzheimer's because of a rare genetic mutation in their DNA ... for the remaining 99 percent of us, the real risk is not determined by our genes." She claims Alzheimer'sis due primarily to our diet, and I believe her! I will take her advice and do what she says. The following 300 pages of the book give support for her thesis, as well as guidelines for fat, protein and carbohydrate intakes; a questionnaire to help everyone who eats evaluate their diet; recipes and lifestyle choices;and much more. This is a book that could either be shelved on a wise person's book case, or in the kitchen for easy access to the best recipes. Additionally, Mosconi gives us advice backed by science without sounding preachy. The facts speak for themselves. She offers encyclopedic knowledge and holistic direction for every aspect of diet and behaviors on how to avoid one of the most horrific diseases known to man. I know this science will continue to evolve, so I plan to stay on top of it because my mother has Alzheimer's. With the help of Lisa Mosconi and BRAIN FOOD, I am determined to do everything I can to avoid it. FIVE brilliant STARS ...more

title: The Last Anniversary
author: Moriarty, Liane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Australian author Liane Moriarty must be a natural born storyteller. A former advertising copywriter, Moriarty wrote THE LAST ANNIVERSARY, in the earlAustralian author Liane Moriarty must be a natural born storyteller. A former advertising copywriter, Moriarty wrote THE LAST ANNIVERSARY, in the early 2000s. It was her second novel. Now known as the author of THE HUSBAND'S SECRET and BIG LITTLE LIES, the book that became an HBO series, Moriarty creates complicated, believable characters—they're just like us! Her plots are original, too, or at least fresh.THE LAST ANNIVERSARY is a bit complicated, which is my biggest knock on this novel. Plus there are a lot of characters. In other words, this story was entertaining but hard to follow. I had to get a piece of paper and draw a family tree just to keep the players straight. So there's a small island, named Scribbly Gum Island, off the Australian coast near Sydney (Moriarty's hometown), accessible only by boat. The island belongs to the extended family of Connie Doughty. In 1932, 19-year-old Connie rents a house on the island to Alice and Jack Munro to help pay her family's bills. The Munros have a baby girl. One day, the Munros invite Connie and her younger sister Rose over for tea. When the girls arrive, they discover the baby alone, in a bassinet in the kitchen, but Alice and Jack are gone. The tea kettle is boiling, the bread is still warm, and there is blood on the floor. Soon Connie and Rose are giving interviews and tours of the house. It turns into "The Munro Baby Mystery, one of the great unsolved mysteries of the twentieth century in Australia." The family becomes famous and improbably rich.Now jump to the present. Connie has passed away and left her home on Scribbly Gum Island to Sophie Honeywell. Sophie dated Connie's grandson Thomas for one year, then jilted him just as he was about to propose. However, when eightysomething Connie met Sophie, she adored the girl. Sophie reminded Connie of her deceased husband because of her dimples and enthusiasm for life and Scribbly Gum Island. But Sophie hasn't seen Thomas or been to the island in over three years, so this surprises everyone. Sophie meets up with Thomas (who is now married to someone else and father of a baby girl) and learns she has inherited Connie's house which brings her back into the mix of the wealthy, screwed up family. Chaos ensues.See what I mean about complex/complicated/confusing? Add to that, we realize along the way that much of what we've read so far (see above) isn't even true. Figuring out what IS true is what keeps the reader turning the page. The story is fun and lighthearted even as we (and certain family members) begin to wonder if Connie and Rose murder the Munros themselves and kept the baby.I enjoyed this book, but I am happy to know that Moriarty grew as a writer and learned to hone her plots and casts of characters down to a manageable level. I very much enjoyed her later novel THE HUSBAND'S SECRET. This book also reiterates my theory: Novels are like photographs: some are very pretty, but most people like the ones with people they know in them. A writer who can create true-to-life characters can sell a book.Three Stars...more

title: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie
author: Spark, Muriel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was unpleasantly surprised by this book. THE PRIME OF MISS JEAN BRODIE, a 1961 novel by Muriel Spark, is on many Top 100 Novels lists. I've heard reI was unpleasantly surprised by this book. THE PRIME OF MISS JEAN BRODIE, a 1961 novel by Muriel Spark, is on many Top 100 Novels lists. I've heard reference to it by multiple writing teachers, and it's short, so I thought I would give it a go. How this book has withstood the test of time is beyond me. Maybe it was really something in 1961, but it should have dropped off the list long ago, IMHO.Miss Jean Brodie, a woman in the "prime" of her life, is a fascist grade school teacher at a proper girls school in Scotland in the late 1930s. Miss Brodie has chosen six girls (who show promise) to guide in an education of the world. She feels she can teach these girls more about Life and the World—and make them the "crème de la crème"—if she avoids the textbooks and instead tells the girls about what she has seen and whom she has loved. She says often, "Give me a girl at an impressionable age, and she is mine for life." Indeed, as the girls grow up, they remain "the Brodie set," and tend to behave in the self-centered way Miss Brodie taught them until we learn (in a flash forward) that one of the girls has betrayed her by telling her secrets to the headmistress who has been trying to fire her for years for loose morals. Jean Brodie, who was modeled after one of Spark's own teachers, is in a love triangle with two male teachers from the school. She's in with love the married art teacher, but has an affair with the short-legged music teacher because he is single. But then later, when the girls are seventeen, Miss Brodie encourages one of her girls to sleep with the married Catholic teacher while his wife and six kids are away for the summer. It's bizarre.Muriel Spark wrote the book about twenty-five years after the time period in which the story takes place. I assume she was trying to jovially illustrate how some people fell for Hitler, Mussolini, and Franco. That's fine and interesting, in a way. But what turned me off so much about this book is the jumbled timeline (the novel is well-known for its flash forwards) and the repetition. Either Miss Brodie or someone else mentions that she, Miss Brodie, is in her "prime" over fifty times! This woman is an insufferable narcissist. In fact, almost every adjective and point that Spark is trying to illustrate is repeated ad nauseam. Even though the book is short, I could barely slog through the story.Two Boring Stars...more

title: The Alice Network
author: Quinn, Kate*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE ALICE NETWORK, by Kate Quinn, is a remarkable story and an excellent, captivating read. I was so pleasantly surprised by this book, and I have recTHE ALICE NETWORK, by Kate Quinn, is a remarkable story and an excellent, captivating read. I was so pleasantly surprised by this book, and I have recommended it to dozens of people already. This is my first time to read anything by Quinn. She writes primarily non-fiction, which is how she came upon a real-life female spy from WWI who went by the code name Alice Dubois. With further research, Quinn knew she had to tell this woman’s story, but not via non-fiction; she took some historical people, places, and events, then created fictional “friends” and a plot, and wrote this unputdownable novel. The story begins in 1947 with a 17-year-old American girl named Charlotte (Charlie) St. Clair who arrives in London with her French mother. They are on their way to Switzerland to take care of Charlie’s “little problem.” But Charlie is more distressed by the disappearance of her French cousin Rose. Charlie runs away from her mother in order to chase down the only clue she has about her missing cousin who is presumed dead from events surrounding WWII. This clue leads her to the home of Eve Gardiner, an angry, damaged woman who may or may not know something about Rose. The chapters then alternate between Charlie’s story in 1947 to Eve’s story in 1915. It turns out, Eve was a spy in the Alice Network in WWI. Eventually the two stories converge.The Alice Network does not shy away from the realities of war. In other words, Quinn does not gloss over the factual, real horrors that happened to both militants and civilians during the wars. Some chapters are very difficult to read. That being said, Quinn handled it well, and this is an excellent story. Four-and-a-half Stars...more

title: Sense and Sensibility
author: Austen, Jane
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My first Jane Austen book! The fact that I had never read Jane Austen grew to be my big literary secret over the past ten years—the years I've called My first Jane Austen book! The fact that I had never read Jane Austen grew to be my big literary secret over the past ten years—the years I've called myself a writer. But I was not an English major in college and somehow Jane Austen's books escaped my notice. They are long and detailed and well, old, and I always had newer, more exciting books to read. SENSE AND SENSIBILITY, Jane Austen's first novel, published in 1811, came well before George Eliot's MIDDLEMARCH, and Charlotte Brontë's JANE EYRE, both of which I've read and loved. In that context, S&S must be regarded as brilliant. The characters were detailed and delightful or dastardly, and the plot was realistic if somewhat convoluted. Plus, the idea that "women did not write novels" in the early 1800s adds to the celebration and importance of this book.That being said, SENSE AND SENSIBILITY did not rise to one of my favorites. I feel like every one of these nineteenth century British Literature classics could be renamed MONEY AND MORES, I and II and III, etc. Obviously, money and mores (or manners, perhaps) were vital—a woman's reality—but it gets so tedious and disappointing to hear everyone talk about a person's wealth to determine whether or not they are worthy of marriage. Then what women were and were not allowed to say ... well, that adds a comic element, I suppose, but it, too, is frustrating to imagine. I would like to watch a movie version of this book now (I've held off in order to read it first). I'm sure it's a farce with a mostly happy ending. Austen used so many pronouns that I was often confused about who was saying what to whom. So, yes, I'm happy to have read it, but it didn't change my life. Four historical Stars...more

title: Deep Work: Rules for Focused Success in a Distracted World
author: Newport, Cal
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I described bits and pieces of DEEP WORK, by Cal Newport, to my friend, she teased me about skimming a book called DEEP WORK. Guilty as charged! When I described bits and pieces of DEEP WORK, by Cal Newport, to my friend, she teased me about skimming a book called DEEP WORK. Guilty as charged! This intense book outlines Newport's extensive plan for most working adults in the 21st century to reach their highest level of productivity and creativity. It's not a simple process. As a writer with ADHD, I thought this book would be very beneficial to me. Unfortunately, according to Cal Newport, my best plan would be to move to an isolated cabin for weeks, if not months, at a time. That sounds like a dream to me (I'm an introvert) but my husband would not be very happy if I did, nor would my dog, my kids, my friends, or parents. I would probably miss them as well. Newport also wants everyone who cares about reaching this deep state to quit social media. Completely. Could I cut back on social media? Absolutely. But there are benefits to social media from a writer's perspective, not to mention it saves me time, in a way; it's easier to keep up with distant friends and family via Facebook, for instance, than it is to call or write everyone letters. In other words, Newport's advice simply isn't practical for me. He says in his Conclusion, that his "year of extreme depth was perhaps a bit too extreme ..." Even he will "moderate this intensity" going forward. Imagine how the rest of us feel.Newport does give us a multitude of baby steps we can use to help on a stay-at-home basis which I found useful. For example, he advises reframing the work/break pattern. Instead of dragging yourself away from television or social media to work, he advises getting straight to work, and then scheduling breaks for your distractions—almost like recess at school. You can set breaks every hour or twice a day ... whatever works for you. That is doable.There is a lot more to this book but I can't elaborate, because I indeed skimmed most of it. It is highly acclaimed as one of the top business books of 2016. Just be prepared to take his advice with a grain of salt. THREE very deep STARS...more
