title: No One Belongs Here More Than You
author: July, Miranda*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Books like NO ONE BELONGS HERE MORE THAN YOU, by Miranda July, leave me with a stunned feeling. TENTH OF DECEMBER, by George Saunders did the same, buBooks like NO ONE BELONGS HERE MORE THAN YOU, by Miranda July, leave me with a stunned feeling. TENTH OF DECEMBER, by George Saunders did the same, but I loved that book. This one I just admire. The similarity is the brilliant, creative, quirky, probing writing. The difference is the subject matter. Most of July's stories seem near-autobiographical while Saunders' stories are broader, more universal.Published in 2007, NO ONE BELONGS HERE MORE THAN YOU is a collection of 16 short stories, mostly about a young, bisexual girl's tales of discovery. Who am I? What should I be when I grow up? What is sex, what is love? Most of the stories are on the spectrum of quirky—>strange—>freaky—>bizarre. Some are funny, others sad. All are imaginative, powerful and fresh, about survival and growth, including picking oneself up after failure and moving on, somehow. I am not familiar with July's other work, but her writing has a way of mining for deep, deep emotions and translating them into words (much easier said than done). Her ability to find a character's POV is fantastic; they, the confused characters, often speak or think in hyperbole, as a broken-hearted teenager would, for instance. I underlined and starred dozens of lines, even entire paragraphs, in this book, but each story is so unique that pulling out random lines as examples would be like showing you a snippet of just Mona Lisa's mouth; beautiful, sure, but powerless compared to the whole painting. The title (which is not the title of any of the stories) seems like an answer to the questions the characters ask: Who am I? Am I lovable? Do I fit in? And July's answer is Yes, you do. You are good enough. You are good. No one belongs here more than you.Four Probing Stars...more

title: Sing, Unburied, Sing
author: Ward, Jesmyn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As winner of the National Book Award and on multiple Best Books of 2017 lists, SING, UNBURIED, SING, by Jesmyn Ward, is a book I should probably read As winner of the National Book Award and on multiple Best Books of 2017 lists, SING, UNBURIED, SING, by Jesmyn Ward, is a book I should probably read twice. Ward delves so deeply into each character's POV, and the writing is so evocative, that the pace is much slower than most contemporary novels. Perhaps I should have expected that from a title with not one, but two commas. Regardless, I found myself easily distracted.SING, UNBURIED, SING is the story of Leonie, a Black woman in Mississippi, who takes her two biracial children and a friend on a road trip to pick up Leonie's White boyfriend (the father of her children) when he is released from prison. It is told in the alternating voices of Leonie; her thirteen-year-old son, Jojo; and one other character they meet at the prison. Leonie is ... not a good mother. She's a drug addict. Fortunately for the children, they all live with Leonie's parents, Pop and Mam. Pop, though also an ex-con, is a wise and loving grandfather. Mam is dying of cancer. (Yes, it's a difficult story.) Many members of the family are able to hear animals and also the "unburied" souls of people who have passed. One of the blurbs describes this as a "road novel turned on its head." I'm not sure what that means, but the plot is vague. After the family returns from the disastrous trip of picking the father up from prison, the plot centers around Richie, the character they met along the way. His mission becomes the plot, until that is concluded, and then it's about Mam. This isn't a knock, per se, because Ward makes us care about each character so much that we want to know how everyone is doing, but it makes the story seem longer than 285 pages.When I finished this story, I wrote down three words: devastated, exhausted, awed. I think that sums it up well.Four Singing Stars...more

title: Little Fires Everywhere
author: Ng, Celeste*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are many similarities between LITTLE FIRES EVERYWHERE, by Celeste Ng, and EVERYTHING I NEVER TOLD YOU, her first novel. Both stories are about dThere are many similarities between LITTLE FIRES EVERYWHERE, by Celeste Ng, and EVERYTHING I NEVER TOLD YOU, her first novel. Both stories are about dysfunctional families (is that redundant?) in Ohio. Both are set in the near past, this one in the 1990s. Communication, or lack thereof, amongst family members is a strong theme, as well as race relations. In both books, there is also a hint of mystery. However, Ng's first novel is definitely the better book.LITTLE FIRES EVERYWHERE is primarily the story of Mia Warren and her daughter Pearl who rent a home in Shaker Heights, Ohio, from the "perfect" family of Elena and John Richardson and their four children. Mia, an artist, and her daughter have traveled from city to city across the country so that Mia can continually find new inspiration for her photography. But the more Pearl embeds herself in the Richardson family, the more suspicious Elena Richardson becomes about the secrets in Mia's past. Ng is very good at creating characters, and her writing is clean and solid. However, Little Fires Everywhere lacks the focus of Everything I Never Told You. There is too much backstory, too many subplots, and way too many coincidences. What Elena uncovers about Mia links directly to the hottest news story of the year in Shaker Heights, which all began to unravel when a class trip leads the Richardson kids to the museum where they spot a twelve-year-old photograph of young Mia holding baby Pearl. Plus, Elena just happens to be a journalist who knows how to dig up dirt, and her husband happens to be an attorney who takes the big case in the headlines, and Mia happens to work at the restaurant where ... You get the picture.Ng's two novels are so similar, it makes me wonder if her publisher asked for her new novel to be in the same vein as her first novel. Or maybe Ng didn't feel she said all she needed to say about dysfunctional families in her first book. Regardless, Little Fires Everywhere feels derivative. Three-and-a-half Fiery Stars (rounded down to Three)...more

title: Eleanor Oliphant Is Completely Fine
author: Honeyman, Gail
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: JAN 2018I was so pleasantly surprised by ELEANOR OLIPHANT IS COMPLETELY FINE, by Gail Honeyman. It carries much more gravitas than the cover and titleJAN 2018I was so pleasantly surprised by ELEANOR OLIPHANT IS COMPLETELY FINE, by Gail Honeyman. It carries much more gravitas than the cover and title lead one to believe. Yes, the story is about a single thirty-year-old from the UK. Yes, she pines over a handsome man way out of her league. Yes, they use an adverb IN THE TITLE. But, it is not a reboot of the Bridget Jones series, nor is it fan-fiction of Fredrik Backman's books, regardless of the similarities therein.Eleanor Oliphant is a flawed character, inside and out. We find out around page 25 that she has scars on her face, but it takes a while until we learn how she became disfigured. Honeyman does an excellent job of sprinkling hints about her past through the story until the chapter where it all breaks loose. Eleanor is awkward, antisocial, and troubled, yet she is educated, hardworking, and self-sufficient. She works in accounts at a graphic design firm and has no friends and no family. She works, eats, drinks, and drinks some more (to squelch her inner demons), then falls asleep and starts over the next day. One day she is befriended by a scruffy coworker named Raymond. They see an elderly man collapse on a sidewalk, and rush to his rescue. Through their interactions with this man and his family, Eleanor and Raymond start spending a lot of time together. Raymond is compassionate enough to draw out her story and set her on a path toward healing—because the reason she is scarred is a tragedy that she has suppressed. Meanwhile, Eleanor has developed a mad crush on a young rock star. In her efforts to garner his attention, she begins to take better care of herself, which helps others to see her differently.ELEANOR OLIPHANT IS COMPLETELY FINE has many laugh out loud moments, many heart-wrenching moments, and ultimately ... well, I won't say how it ends. This is a deeply touching, well-written book about a memorable character. I highly recommend it.Four-and-a-half Stars...more

title: The Plot Against America
author: Roth, Philip
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE PLOT AGAINST AMERICA, by Philip Roth, is a shocking story by an author whose writing style I simply don't like. Too much telling, not enough showiTHE PLOT AGAINST AMERICA, by Philip Roth, is a shocking story by an author whose writing style I simply don't like. Too much telling, not enough showing. Too much mundane detail. Too many winding viewpoints that wander to the point of confusion.The premise of the novel is an alternate history version wherein aviator and American hero Charles Lindbergh runs for president against Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1940. He wins on the slogan "Vote for Lindbergh or vote for war." Lindbergh is as isolationist and "friendly" with Adolph Hitler. Soon after he is elected, a horrific anti-Semitic wave takes over the country, forcing Jews to relocate, and causing riots that kill hundreds of innocent Americans, who happen to be Jewish. The story line is eerily similar, if you substitute "Muslim" for "Jewish," to current events in 2018, and that's what makes the premise of this novel so frightening. Written in 2004, this book proves Roth had a prescient vision similar perhaps to that of Ray Bradbury, Isaac Asimov and others. However, that wasn't enough to save the book in my eyes. THREE horrifying STARS...more

title: Behold the Dreamers
author: Mbue, Imbolo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read BEHOLD THE DREAMERS, the debut novel of Imbolo Mbue, for my book club. While I am happy to read almost any decent book, I can't say that I loveI read BEHOLD THE DREAMERS, the debut novel of Imbolo Mbue, for my book club. While I am happy to read almost any decent book, I can't say that I loved it or would wholeheartedly recommend it to others. It is the most recent pick for Oprah's Book Club, but it doesn't have the gravitas that most of Oprah's books have.BEHOLD THE DREAMERS is the story of a Jende Jonga, a Cameroonian immigrant, and his wife Neni, and their children. Jende came to America in 2007 to pursue the American dream, and got a job as a chauffeur for Clark Edwards, an executive at Lehman Brothers—the year before Lehman (and so many other financial institutions) went bankrupt. As a driver for Clark Edwards, his wife Cindy, their sons Vince and Mighty, Jende is witness to the family's private life. Mbue draws parallels between the Jonga family and the Edwards family, showing the struggles and realities of having too little money and similar but different struggles and realities of having a lot of money. (Mbue says in the Q&A at the end of the book that it was challenging for her to develop empathy for the One-Percenters, but she realized they have incredible struggles of their own.) Through the novel, the Jonga family must fight Immigration to get papers for a Green Card and/or hope for asylum from Cameroon. As the story progresses, both families encounter tragedies and must pick up the pieces and move on.Again, I can say I liked this book—I was eager to turn the page to find out what happened to the characters—but I cannot say I loved it. Three Stars...more

title: Wicked River
author: Milchman, Jenny*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I could not put this book down! WICKED RIVER, by Jenny Milchman, is a tense page-turner/thriller/scary beach read in all the best possible ways. WICKEI could not put this book down! WICKED RIVER, by Jenny Milchman, is a tense page-turner/thriller/scary beach read in all the best possible ways. WICKED RIVER is the story of newlyweds Natalie and Doug Larson who go on a canoe trip in the Adirondacks for their honeymoon. What Natalie doesn't know is that her new husband has an ulterior motive for this outdoor adventure that leads the couple into trouble way beyond what Doug could have predicted. Through the course of their harrowing trip they learn who they really are, and who their new spouse really is. Who among us knows how we (or a loved one) would react if put into the worst possible situation? It leads to all kinds of interesting questions and reflections.The writing in this, Milchman's fourth novel, is excellent. The characters are realistic, her observations are keen, and her knowledge of camping, hiking and canoeing seem very authentic. (Not being a camper/hiker/or canoeist, I can't be much of a critic, but either Milchman knows her stuff or this book has been very well researched.) Best of all, Milchman leads her sympathetic characters into so much trouble that I stayed up late several nights in a row because I couldn't put the book down. My only knock is that I wish it weren't quite so long. At 450 pages, I'm afraid not as many people will read it. That being said, it reads very quickly. If you like a thrilling, adventurous, well-written love story, you will love WICKED RIVER.FOUR harrowing STARS...more

title: Wonder Valley

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's a hard-knock life in WONDER VALLEY. Ivy Pochoda's previous novel, VISITATION STREET, a book I loved, told the story of disadvantaged girls in BroIt's a hard-knock life in WONDER VALLEY. Ivy Pochoda's previous novel, VISITATION STREET, a book I loved, told the story of disadvantaged girls in Brooklyn, while this book tells about disadvantaged people in Southern California. The chapters jump back and forth between 2006 and 2010 in the voice of six disparate characters who have really (or nearly) hit rock bottom and are searching for a better life. In the end, the stories converge.The book is blurbed as "a classic L.A. novel," by Michael Connelly, but I beg to differ. Though it begins in traffic on an L.A. freeway and spends a little time on Skid Row, most of the stories takes place in the desert outside Joshua Tree and Twentynine Palms. When I think L.A, I think palm trees, Hollywood, the Hills, the ocean, etc., etc. This novel is not about the good life.WONDER VALLEY asks several questions: What defines a person? Are we each the sum of our experiences and what has happened to us? Can we overcome our past (mistakes) and escape our demons? Do our circumstances define us? How do some people come to terms with their past while others feel tortured by their mistakes for life? Can people atone for their mistakes if their mistakes include murder?I wanted to like this book more than I did. Maybe my expectations were high because of VISITATION STREET. In the end, I couldn't relate to the characters—thank goodness, I suppose, because we are talking Skid Row here. I also felt like the jumps between 2006 and 2010 added unnecessary confusion. I think Pochoda could have shortened the timeline and told it in a linear fashion without losing the story.Three-and-a-half tragic Stars (rounded down to Three)...more

title: Jane Eyre: Includes Ebook
author: Brontë, Charlotte
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not sure how I missed so many of the great modern British novels in my educational upbringing, but I suppose "better late than never" applies to mI'm not sure how I missed so many of the great modern British novels in my educational upbringing, but I suppose "better late than never" applies to my first reading of JANE EYRE, by Charlotte Brontë. Published in 1847, JANE EYRE is the story of Jane Eyre, an orphan raised by an aunt who virtually hates her. After being abused by her aunt and cousins, she is sent (gratefully) to a school for girls. From there she becomes a teacher, then a governess, and eventually meets Mr. Rochester. What I love about Jane is that her character is so solid in who she is and what she believes in and stands for. She is sure of herself, even when compromising her principles would lead her straight to the altar with the man she loves. Jane is smart, well-spoken, and bold. Interestingly, she is not pretty, and basically every character in the novel comments on her looks. Neither is Mr. Rochester known to be a handsome man, though he, too, is a man who holds tight to his principles (in all but one instance, i.e. asking Jane to marry him). Let’s just say he has a few skeletons in his closet.Though I loved this story, I have to deduct half a star because there are too many very convenient happenings. When Jane runs from the altar, for example, she ends up at ... her cousins' house, cousins she'd never met before. If Ms. Brontë had just said she was searching for them and finally, finally found them, I would have liked this completely. Four-and-a-half KICK ASS Stars (round to Five Stars)...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not sure Dan Brown books are meant to be critiqued on an intellectual level, although I imagine he would like to be given more credit for his philI'm not sure Dan Brown books are meant to be critiqued on an intellectual level, although I imagine he would like to be given more credit for his philosophies. Dan Brown is a true storyteller, and his books are page turners. Even at 450 pages, ORIGIN took me only six days to read. In the vein of Ayn Rand, he seems to be preaching his view of the world, and what he things people should believe, via an entertaining novel. Ayn Rand did it much better.The latest installment in the Robert Langdon series, ORIGIN is about a Steve Jobs-type genius who has invented an extreme AI computer and solved the mysteries of "Where do we come from?" and "Where are we going?" Except chaos happens before he can announce his discovery to the world. Langdon and a stunningly beautiful, sensitive, intelligent woman must save the day—because I do think the entire story takes place in less than 24 hours. Brown is a master at not giving his protagonist what he wants until the very last scene, which is what keeps readers turning the pages. In my humble opinion, if Dan Brown had a better editor, I could like his work much more. "Stop with the italics," someone should tell him. "Langdon doesn't need to have seen EVERY WONDERFUL THING before. Let him discover an occasional marvel along with your readers." "Quit reminding people he has an 'eidetic' memory." Brown name-drops many artists, architects, authors, paintings, books, buildings, historical figures, etcetera, etcetera, and says in the opening pages that all of these are "real." It's almost like he's trying to justify his travel expenses for his accountant and the IRS. Anyway, I like art, architecture, traveling, and history, so I enjoyed the references, but I can see how others might skim right over names and places as boring filler. The book seems overly long, but I imagine he’s contractually bound to turn out 150,000-word books.Brown has an interesting message in this book, his own idea (I hope and assume), about where we are going as a human race. I'm not sure I disagree with him, although I hope his timeline is off by a few decades. I liked this story, I just don’t think Dan Brown is a very good writer.Three (and a half) original-if-not-eloquent Stars...more

title: In a Dark, Dark Wood
author: Ware, Ruth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It has been a long time since a book made me seriously scared in my own home. IN A DARK, DARK WOOD, the debut novel of Ruth Ware, did just that. IN A It has been a long time since a book made me seriously scared in my own home. IN A DARK, DARK WOOD, the debut novel of Ruth Ware, did just that. IN A DARK, DARK WOOD is the story of Nora (aka Lenora, Lee, and Leo at different stages of her life) who is invited to a bachelorette party at another friend's house in a secluded wooded area. Nora doesn't know why Clare, the bride and her former best friend, even invited her (they haven't spoken in ten years), but a mutual friend talked her into going. Another friend, Flo, Clare's current BFF, is hosting the party. She is "Single White Female" creepy. The girls and one gay male hang around the house, drink copious amounts of alcohol, play games and do a Ouiji board. With no cell service, no landline, and mysterious footprints in freshly fallen snow, the mood quickly becomes dark. Then an intruder breaks in in the middle of the dark, dark night. Bad things happen. Nora wakes up in the hospital with no memory of how she got there or where everyone else is. She over hears cops in the hallway say the word "murder," but they won't tell her who's dead. Nora flees the hospital and fights to fill in the missing hours before she is arrested as the killer.Ruth Ware does an excellent job of setting the mood for her stories (I recently finished her second book THE WOMAN IN CABIN 10). Her dialogue is realistic, character development is spot-on, and the book is well-written. My only knock on this one is Nora is a tad whiny. She wonders why the hell she even went to this bachelorette party so many times it became annoying. If you can get over that nag, you will love this mystery.FOUR dark STARS...more

title: The Woman in Cabin 10
author: Ware, Ruth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What is it you most hope for in a novel? A gripping story, am I right? And if it's a mystery, like THE WOMAN IN CABIN 10, you're probably hoping the eWhat is it you most hope for in a novel? A gripping story, am I right? And if it's a mystery, like THE WOMAN IN CABIN 10, you're probably hoping the ending is logical, but one you didn't guess along the way, right? THE WOMAN IN CABIN 10, by Ruth Ware, reminded me of AND THEN THERE WERE NONE, by the great Agatha Christie. While the latter took place on an island with only 10 characters, this novel takes place on a high-end (read small) cruise ship with only 10 rooms. Though the cast of characters is a bit larger (and a tad confusing), the self-contained mystery held the same a-murderer-is-among-us creepiness. Ware gave us just enough red herrings to cast doubt on many players.In this book, Laura (Lo) Blacklock, a British travel writer, is booked to take the maiden voyage of the Aurora Borealis, a Norwegian-based ship. Lo is a troubled (sympathetic) character from page one. On her first night on the ship, she hears a scream and a splash, certain someone (the woman in the cabin next to hers) has been thrown overboard. Yet no one is missing. Because of her troubled past, Lo won't let this mystery die (no pun intended). She pushes and pushes and pushes, until, duh, she pushes too far and the killer has to shut her up. Ware skillfully makes life more and more miserable and desperate for Lo—which makes the book more and more of a page turner. I could barely put the book down for the last 100 pages. All of my guesses along the way of who actually died, and who actually killed that person were wrong. Even the very final pages had a twist I didn't see coming. Now isn't that what you hope to hear about a novel? It's not going to win the Pulitzer, but it is a very well-written, engaging mystery.Five Creepy Stars...more

title: The Stranger
author: Camus, Albert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There aren't a lot of books by Nobel Prize winning authors you can read in a single day, but THE STRANGER, at 123 pages, is one you can. Originally wrThere aren't a lot of books by Nobel Prize winning authors you can read in a single day, but THE STRANGER, at 123 pages, is one you can. Originally written by Camus in French in 1942, the edition I read was translated by Matthew Ward in 1988. The Stranger is a strange story about a young, disenfranchised Frenchman named Meursault living and working in Algiers, then under French rule. The story opens with the famous line: "Maman died today." Meursault travels to his mother's funeral (she's been living in a "home,") then returns to his lonely apartment. His life spirals momentarily up, then quickly downward. Meursault seems to lack all emotion, or at least, basic human empathy. He simply doesn't seem to have a heart. Then he kills someone. (I don't consider it a spoiler if the book is 75 years old.) In Part II of this book, Meursault goes to jail and awaits trial, and potentially a beheading. There we see a glimpse of his soul—or lack thereof.I have no doubt this book deserves Five Stars, but the story is so bizarre (because the protagonist is so cold and withdrawn) that I would need to read it at least once more before I fully understood it. I'm not even sure if "The Stranger" is Meursault himself or the man he killed. This is a book that begs for discussion. Four Strange Stars...more

title: The Sympathizer
author: Nguyen, Viet Thanh*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are not enough fawning adjectives for me to describe how I feel about THE SYMPATHIZER, by Viet Thanh Nguyen. It deserves every award it receivedThere are not enough fawning adjectives for me to describe how I feel about THE SYMPATHIZER, by Viet Thanh Nguyen. It deserves every award it received, most notably the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 2016. Nguyen's writing is brilliant. His use of verb tense (past, then present, then future) and POV (first, then third, then second) are astounding. Scenes flowed through time like fairies through a forest. My vocabulary improved because of this book, as well as my knowledge of history, specifically the Vietnam War. Nguyen's perspective and ability to tell this story is probably unique; I can't imagine anyone else telling this story as well as he did. But what is this story really about? War is the backdrop; the story, I believe, is about identity. Who are we? Paraphrasing a late passage: Who we see in the mirror is not the same person as how others view us. We often deceive ourselves, forgive our own flaws, rationalize our behaviors; most of us live with cognitive dissonance, somehow splitting our personalities and justifying conflicting beliefs. (Ever known anyone who's had an affair? Exactly.) Given those questions, who are we really? And what happens when we change, grow? What happens when the child becomes the adult, the student becomes the teacher, the revolutionary becomes the ruler? Who among us hasn't said, If I were in charge, I would do it differently, only to "become our parents" or instill stupid rules for others because in reality, rules are necessary. THE SYMPATHIZER is challenging, intellectually and emotionally. It is difficult to get into, and takes a commitment to pick it up—not because it's heavy, because there is so little white space. It clocks in at 382 pages (paperback version), but Nguyen and/or his editors chose to NOT separate out most of the dialogue. If printed in classical format, it would have easily topped 500 pages. Many of the scenes (of war and interrogation at their worst) are horrifying and difficult to read. But they're real, or so I believe. There are also beautiful scenes—or at least sentences—that made me laugh, and made me underline/star/dog-ear as "universal truths" or "incredible writing." This book is dense, but important. I am glad to have read it. I already want to read it again, one day, after I've read a few lighter novels. Five Unparalleled Stars...more

title: Homegoing
author: Gyasi, Yaa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: HOMEGOING, by Yaa Gyasi, is an incredible achievement for a young, debut novelist. Similar in ways to ROOTS, by Alex Haley, Homegoing tells the story HOMEGOING, by Yaa Gyasi, is an incredible achievement for a young, debut novelist. Similar in ways to ROOTS, by Alex Haley, Homegoing tells the story of eight generations of an African family. Beginning in Ghana in the late-1700s, one woman, Maame, has two daughters, each with a different man. One daughter marries a white man and lives in a castle, and her half-sister is captured and thrown into the dungeon of the same castle with hundreds of slave women. Gyasi weaves a narrative from the POV of one member of each generation (think: sixteen linked short stories), culminating with two long-distant cousins meeting each other in the year 2000 in California. No easy feat! Gyasi is an excellent storyteller. Her writing is evocative, and the stories are gut-wrenching. As you can imagine, this is not an easy book to read. Gyasi doesn't gloss over the realities of slavery, tribalism, superstition, drug abuse, abandonment, death, or prejudice. I found the book to be very heavy, though others in my book club saw hope emerge, especially in the final pages. Beyond the harsh realities of what each character endured, it was difficult to keep the characters straight. If not for the character chart at the beginning of the book, I would have probably cast it aside because I wouldn't have been able to follow both sides of the family. Additionally, Gyasi was perhaps overly thorough with history and facts; parts of the story seemed to get bogged down.I probably wouldn't have picked this book up if it hadn't been chosen for my book club, but I am glad to have read it.Four Stars...more

title: News of the World
author: Jiles, Paulette*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: NEWS OF THE WORLD, a novel by Paulette Jiles, is one of those book club books I never would have read on my own, but I am happy I did. It's a Western,NEWS OF THE WORLD, a novel by Paulette Jiles, is one of those book club books I never would have read on my own, but I am happy I did. It's a Western, set in Texas in 1870-71, and tells the story of Captain Jefferson Kidd, a septuagenarian who is hired to return a little girl to her relatives. She had been captured four years previously by Indians who killed and mutilated her parents and sister. As expected, the girl is troubled. The unlikely pair start out in north-central Texas and follow winding, rutted trails south to San Antonio where her aunt and uncle are said to live. The road is treacherous at best. They must be on constant guard for cowboys, Indians, even crooked US Government troops, during a time when citizens were not allowed (legally) to carry handguns or powerful rifles. Along the way they stop in towns so Captain Kidd can read the newspapers to the townspeople to earn money. The book is only 209 pages, and I wish it would have been longer. I enjoyed the characters so much that I wanted to ride along with them for more adventures. They develop a grandfather/granddaughter relationship, and he tries to teach her English, manners, and civilized customs (like sleeping indoors). Captain Kidd is a cranky and rather sad man after losing his wife and being trapped on the opposite side of the Mississippi from his children. Escorting this little girl, Johanna, gives the man purpose. She teaches him a few things, too, including how to love again. By the time they arrive at the home of her aunt and uncle, he is heartbroken to leave her. I was eager to keep reading to see how it would end. Jiles makes some interesting style choices in this book, e.g. no quotation marks. I can almost appreciate why (she wants us to be disoriented like the girl, I assume), but I found it rather annoying. Also, I thought she could have included more scenes and incidents. Some scenes began with tension and then fizzled out. I really liked this story, but I felt it could have been better developed.Four Stars...more

title: Midnight in Broad Daylight: A Japanese American Family Caught Between Two Worlds
author: Sakamoto, Pamela Rotner*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The true story behind MIDNIGHT IN BROAD DAYLIGHT, by Pamela Rotner Sakamoto, is highly intriguing. It's the tale of Harry Fukuhara and his brothers whThe true story behind MIDNIGHT IN BROAD DAYLIGHT, by Pamela Rotner Sakamoto, is highly intriguing. It's the tale of Harry Fukuhara and his brothers who fought against each other in WWII. Harry's parents, a Japanese couple who immigrated to Washington State in the 1920s, had five children in America (four boys and one girl). The children were American citizens, and for years, the the family was free to travel back and forth to Japan by ship. Until Pearl Harbor. When WWII hit America, the four brothers were split between Hiroshima, Japan, and America. Harry became an interpreter for the US Army. His brothers fought for the Japanese Imperial Army. I cannot imagine anything worse than that. But ...Pamela R. Sakamoto is a professor, a historian, and an excellent writer. It's obvious she tried to make the story exciting, but there were way too many details and facts included in the book to make it exciting to me. I found it positively boring. In my opinion, this story should have focused more on the years 1940-1946 or so, with flashbacks and snippets of their childhood and their lives following the war. Instead we get a near cradle-to-grave account of Harry's life plus his siblings and a lot of Harry's mother's life before she had children. It was simply too much.Miraculously, all five children and their mother survived the war (even the family members in Hiroshima at the time of the bomb). I am in awe of the Fukuhara family's story and their grit, but I am not a fan of this book. I want to draw a comparison to Louis Zamperini's story in UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand, but there is really no comparison. TWO gritty STARS...more

title: Nutshell
author: McEwan, Ian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have such conflicting emotions about NUTSHELL. First, Ian McEwan is, or at least comes across as, brilliant. His many books are so different from eaI have such conflicting emotions about NUTSHELL. First, Ian McEwan is, or at least comes across as, brilliant. His many books are so different from each other, yet all so good, and I can picture him laughing through tears as he wrote this one. It is indeed laugh-out-loud funny in many parts. It's also a mystery of sorts, or at least very suspenseful. Yet in the end, it missed the mark for me.NUTSHELL is a riff on HAMLET, with many obvious nods to Shakespeare's greatest tragedy. However, and this is why I deducted two stars, NUTSHELL is told from the POV of a fetus. The baby, an unborn male in his third trimester, can apparently hear everything that happens surrounding his mother. The book opens with the fabulous line, "So here I am, upside down in a woman." His mother, Trudy, (taken from Hamlet's Gertrude) has separated from John, the baby's father, and is currently enmeshed with Claude (taken from Claudius), John's brother. Trudy and Uncle Claude are plotting to kill John so they can sell the valuable family home and split the money. The characters are well developed, though I'm not sure I liked any of them. Trudy and Claude are laughably despicable.I could probably have gone along with the premise (fetus as narrator) because the writing is brilliant. However, this unnamed baby "speaks" not only in the first person, he's also omniscient. He knows things that even his mother doesn't know. Sorry, no. As a writer, I could never release my sense of the rules or my sense of belief to just go along with this all-knowing baby's point of view. It wouldn't have been as catchy, for sure, but if McEwan had made the son say, a 15-year-old blind or autistic child that the mother and uncle dismissed, or something to that effect, then I might have loved this book. Then there's the ending. I can see McEwan's case for ending it the way he did, but I wanted it to end differently (as did others in my book club). That being said, if you are open to the premise and love good, intelligent writing (I had to look up so many words!), then you might get a real kick out of NUTSHELL. I'm glad to have read it, I just can't say it's a wonderful book.Three pregnant Stars...more

Published in 1957, just six years after CATCHER IN THE RYE, Gidget's voice is derivative of Holden Caulfield to be the point that it's hard to take the book seriously. Obviously, the character "Gidget" became something more in its own right in the subsequent movies and the TV show, so the book was a success, I just wish her voice had been more original. GIDGET is a sweet coming-of-age story about a sixteen-year-old girl who falls in love with a surfer. It's a quick read that I picked up as "research" for my WIP. Glad to have read it. title: Goodbye, Vitamin
author: Khong, Rachel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: GOODBYE, VITAMIN was an easy book to choose. With a catchy name, strong s and blurbs by authors I respect, and being under 200 pages, why not reGOODBYE, VITAMIN was an easy book to choose. With a catchy name, strong s and blurbs by authors I respect, and being under 200 pages, why not read it? GOODBYE, VITAMIN, by Rachel Khong, is a funny book about a difficult subject. Khong did an excellent job of bringing laughter to a story about a thirty-year-old woman who, after becoming un-engaged, goes home to live with her aging parents for one year. Her father has Alzheimer's and her mother is struggling with his care taking. In a story that could have been overwhelmingly sentimental or depressing, Khong found a light-hearted way to present her narrator as an astute and observant girl who is fighting her way through a difficult time. The premise—that the end stage of life is, in a way, parallel to childhood—isn't an original idea, but Khong's voice (the way she tells the story) is fresh and smart. It is written in the style of a diary, as the daughter reflects on the time she spent with her family. I'm very happy to have read this book. My own mother has Alzheimer's, and I found one paragraph that really struck me. The daughter and father are outside one day feeding pigeons, and she realized this: "You repeated about how nice the day was, either because you really wanted me to know it or because you'd forgotten you already mentioned it, but all of a sudden, it didn't matter what you remembered or didn't, and the remembering—it occurred to me—was irrelevant. All that mattered was that the day was nice—" So true. Being present for our loved ones is what matters most. As cute as the title is, in the end, I feel it was "forced" from the text. In no way, after reading the book, did this seem the fitting title, but, hey, it did pique my curiosity, and I did buy the book. Three-and-a-half unforgettable Stars (rounded to four)...more

title: A Gentleman in Moscow
author: Towles, Amor*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For so many reasons, I should have loved A GENTLEMAN IN MOSCOW, by Amor Towles, and yet, no. I underlined many poignant lines and starred several passFor so many reasons, I should have loved A GENTLEMAN IN MOSCOW, by Amor Towles, and yet, no. I underlined many poignant lines and starred several passages. I learned a bit about Russian history and smiled at some of the funny quips, but all-in-all, I found the book rather boring.A GENTLEMAN IN MOSCOW is the tale of Count Alexander Ilyich Rostov who was declared a "former person" by the Soviet government in 1918 and forced to live in exile in a luxury hotel for the rest of his life. The story spans thirty-plus years in 450 pages. During his stay at the hotel, the Count interacts with a multitude of colorful characters, and at one point is pleaded with to become the sole guardian of a six-year-old girl he has never met.On the surface (or rather, the jacket cover), this summary sounds like a great idea for a book. I read it for my book club, and all the other members loved it for its descriptive and elegant imagery. Several members found it to be a gripping story with the ever present possibility that the government would change their opinion on the Count and have him executed after all. But Towles never hinted at that. There is no mention of the Count being checked up on, or interviewed past 1922. He is free to roam and enjoy himself for nearly forty years. Here is my summary of the book: An educated, erudite, and humorous upperclassman reconciles himself to this life of luxury—on page 28. Yes, he sleeps in a small attic room, but he can roam free throughout the enormous hotel. He can receive friends and make new friends, dine in the hotel's five-star restaurant and drink the world's best wines. He reads newspapers and literature and poetry. He meets and sleeps with—no, not the quiet, sweet seamstress—he sleeps with Russia's most famous and most powerful actress! And the little girl he takes care of? She grows up to be a world-renowned musician. Did I mention she is beautiful? How can the reader sympathize with this man? He never wants for anything, not one thing. We don't even hear mention of the very special dinner the Count and his friends want to have with very rare ingredients until, Presto!, they acquire the final ingredient. There is no character arc in this book. No transformation of mood or priorities. Until page 388, there isn't really a plot; before then the novel feels like a collection of short stories with related characters. And then there's the alliteration. Every single word in every single chapter title begins with the letter A. Only the letter A. And, the alliteration spills into the prose to the point of being obnoxious. This book had so much potential. The educated, erudite, and humorous Count shouldn't have reconciled himself to being trapped inside one building for at least half the book. He should have had to earn his privileges and his meals. He should have had a dying mother he was unable to visit. He should have yearned for the actress but later realized it was sweet Marina who was the love of his life. Towles could have built an enormous amount of tension by making the Count be randomly searched, interviewed, threatened, etc., etc. throughout. The plot, of course, should have kicked in no later than page 50. But none of that happened.Three Imperfect Stars...more

title: Rules of Civility
author: Towles, Amor*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: RULES OF CIVILITY, by Amor Towles, snuck onto my TBR list. A friend had given me a copy, and then a woman in my book club chose Towles's second novel,RULES OF CIVILITY, by Amor Towles, snuck onto my TBR list. A friend had given me a copy, and then a woman in my book club chose Towles's second novel, A GENTLEMAN IN MOSCOW, for an upcoming book. I saw that as a sign to read Rules of Civility, his debut novel, first. Published in 2011, Rules of Civility became a NYTimes Bestseller, so it had to be good, right? And it was! I read it in less than a week—not quite "unputdownable," but certainly more captivating than gardening or bingeing on any TV shows. One thing I know for sure, Towles is brilliant. His bio says he graduated from Yale and then Stanford. Now he's an investment banker in NYC. Ho hum, right? Anyway, Rules of Civility is about Katey Kontent, as in, "She is quite content with her life." Katey is as smart as Towles must be, quick witted and observant. But here's the thing, as Kurt Vonnegut said, a character should "want something right away, even if it's only a glass of water." And other than ultimately wanting a good life, Katey Kontent doesn't want anything in this story. If there was ever a story about life "happening" to a character, it's this one. She meets a girl named Eve. They're in a car accident with a handsome stranger, Tinker Grey, wherein Eve is badly injured and scarred. (Towles even names that chapter "Deus Ex Machina.") After that, Katey fumbles around, makes nothing but minor decisions, and eventually gets a better than average job. We know from the prologue that she ends up married, but the story has virtually no plot. It's simply the unfolding of a year in Miss Kontent's life, the year being 1938 in New York City. Don't get me wrong, I really enjoyed this story. For reasons yet unknown to myself, I could barely put it down. It was never "Does Katey finally get ____ ?" It was more like, "I hope Katey is okay. Maybe I should read a few more pages." Ultimately, as Katey puts a few retrospective clues in order, the book has the taste of a mystery novel. It unfolds nicely and ultimately satisfies, and concludes with many poignant observations. I really enjoyed Rules of Civility, and I am truly looking forward to A Gentleman in Moscow.Four Chivalrous Stars...more

title: Britt-Marie Was Here

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: BRITT-MARIE WAS HERE, by Fredrik Backman, resonates (days and even weeks later) with a subtle, yet powerful message: Make sure the world knows you werBRITT-MARIE WAS HERE, by Fredrik Backman, resonates (days and even weeks later) with a subtle, yet powerful message: Make sure the world knows you were here.Britt-Marie is a sixty-something woman who has just left her husband. She is forced to apply for a job for the first time in her unplanned and not-overly happy life. In other words, a lot of life just "happened" for Britt-Marie and, not knowing how to assert herself, she went along with it. As a child, Britt-Marie and her family suffered a horrific accident. Ever since, she has tried to make things perfect (or at least appear perfect) as a misguided way of making up for the long-term effects of the accident. After a trip to the unemployment agency, she is sent to a small, failing town to run a community center. While there, she meets a host of colorful characters, and is more or less drafted into becoming the local kids' soccer coach—a sport she despises. When her estranged husband Kent comes to find her and bring her back home, Britt-Marie must, for the first time in her life, make a decision about what's best for her and what she wants. Does she return to Kent, or does she make a new life with Sven?Backman, also the author of A MAN CALLED OVE, asserts his authorial voice a little too loudly here for my personal taste, and I never quite got an image of most of his characters. I know many authors keep character descriptions to a minimum so that the reader can fill in their faces with their imagination, but I often couldn't picture the characters doing some of the things they did—everything from swearing to running after soccer balls, etc. I wish Backman had developed them a bit more. That being said, I could relate in many ways with Britt-Marie, which is often what readers hope for in a novel. I would definitely recommend this book to my friends.FOUR assertive STARS...more

Ove, an elderly man who lives by himself in a neighborhood being taken over by rich, young families. Ove hates them all, although some less than others. Ove is on a mission (which I won't spoil here), but his mission is interrupted by "a pregnant foreign woman," her "lanky" husband, and their two darling daughters when the husband flattens Ove's mailbox. When Parvaneh, the pregnant wife, realizes what Ove is up to, she unwittingly becomes the antagonist, but in the most loving way. A Man Called Ove is a heartfelt read, both sweet and poignant. It will certainly make the reader stop and think about walking a mile in another person's shoes.Four Touching Stars...more

title: A Constellation of Vital Phenomena
author: Marra, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: SECOND REVIEW: I recently read A CONSTELLATION OF VITAL PHENOMENA for the second time because, after reading it once, I chose to lead it for my book cSECOND REVIEW: I recently read A CONSTELLATION OF VITAL PHENOMENA for the second time because, after reading it once, I chose to lead it for my book club. I am so glad I did. The first time I read it (see my  below), I was stymied by Marra's choice of using the omniscient vision to tell us of minor characters's pasts and futures. While some women in my book club liked this layer, I still don't. But on the second reading, I was able to focus on Marra's beautiful and poignant writing. I would still give the book four stars because of these "odd choices," (see below) but on the second reading, I have to admit I cried at the ending. I knew what was coming, yet I was less distracted by his writing and more in tune with the characters's emotions. That is powerful writing. This is still a difficult story, but I would definitely recommend it to readers who appreciate deep literature.FIRST REVIEW:I mostly loved A CONSTELLATION OF VITAL PHENOMENA, by Anthony Marra. It paints the chilling story of "the world's worst doctor," an orphaned girl, and a bold surgeon who are brought together under the brutal circumstances of Chechnya's two modern day wars. It feels broad and epic even though it clocks in at only 350 pages, but maybe that's because a blurb from the New York Times Book Review calls it "A 21st-century WAR AND PEACE." ACofVP is sad and horrific at points, but if it teaches us anything, it's that behind the headlines of every war there are people—parents and siblings, children and doctors—who suffer tragically along with the soldiers and rebels who are commanded to fight, kill, and conquer.Marra's writing is evocative and touching, yet he made what I consider to be odd choices. Told mostly in third person, past tense, Marra inserts occasional omniscient glimpses into random characters' futures. For example, on page 57: "The guard, thirty-one years old, had never received a paycheck, and wouldn't have known what to do with one if he had; in three years, when the hospital issued paychecks again ... the guard would frame his in glass and hang it on his wall without ever depositing it. For the rest of his life, he wouldn't trust the numbers people put on paper." It's as if Marra wants us to know that each of his characters are round, fully-formed "people" with full lives and futures (or not, if they die on the page).Though many passages are difficult to read, ACofVP is a deep, heartrending story in the best possible way. FOUR vital STARS...more

title: Lila        (Gilead, #3)
author: Robinson, Marilynne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I recently read a quote by Pulitzer Prize winning author Marilynne Robinson. She said she writes her novels in one draft—no revisions. Okay, whoa. I cI recently read a quote by Pulitzer Prize winning author Marilynne Robinson. She said she writes her novels in one draft—no revisions. Okay, whoa. I cannot begin to imagine the intense thought and foresight that goes into the planning stages of a novel with no revisions.LILA is the third book in Robinson's prize-winning trilogy; the first two books being GILEAD and HOME, which I have not read. In LILA, we learn the backstory of Lila, a neglected child who is taken (in) by a gritty, migrant-worker character known as Doll. Lila grows up on the road in a scrappy, hard-luck life, to be sure. She does things to survive that she can't bear to speak about. The timeline is jumpy in this novel, but we soon know that the grownup Lila is married to John Ames, a minister in Gilead, Iowa. The bulk of the narrative tells us how she went from a child on the run to the minister's wife. The novel is, needless to say, eloquent and lofty and literary, but we turn the pages as quickly as a genre novel in order to learn her fate: Lila is married to the minister, but she continually dreams of fleeing him and Gilead—even though she is pregnant with his child—because she never learned love and trust as a child.If you have read the first two novels of this trilogy, LILA might seem to fill in the blanks. But, because I haven't read them, this book feels to me like a discussion on whether or not there is a God. Lila, being mostly uneducated and naive, knows nothing of God or the Bible. John Ames, of course, has lived a life dedicated to Christianity and the Bible and the Church. He schools her on it all, very gently. I didn't object to the religious nature of this book, but it did feel to me like Robinson intentionally chose such a naive character so that she could write both sides of the "Is there or isn't there?" discussion about God. While this is a beautiful novel in which I underlined many passages and dogeared many pages, I can't say I will recommend it to very many friends. The target audience seems quite limited.FOUR lofty STARS...more

title: The Underground Railroad
author: Whitehead, Colson*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I learned that THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD, by Colson Whitehead, won the Pulitzer Prize when I was about half way through the book. I wish I had finishedI learned that THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD, by Colson Whitehead, won the Pulitzer Prize when I was about half way through the book. I wish I had finished it before I heard the news. It is an astonishingly brilliant book, with many layers and nods to great literature of the past (e.g. Anne Frank's time spent hidden in an attic), but it's harder to be objective when you know a book has won the Pulitzer Prize. The Underground Railroad follows the path of Cora, a feisty young slave who escapes from a Georgia plantation, as did her mother a decade earlier. Whitehead uses allegory to turn the underground railroad into a tangible, primitive subway system. It wasn't a real railroad, we know, but a secret network of brave, righteous people who were willing to risk, indeed sacrifice, their lives to fight the abhorrent system of slavery. I liked his decision as I felt it made the book more physical and relatable (many of us have been on subways; few of us have been secreted through the night on a flight toward freedom). I read this book with my book club, and interestingly, my biggest knock against the book was a welcome relief to others in my group. The Underground Railroad has no "info dump" in the early pages. Whitehead gives no backstory or grounding about who the multitude of characters are when he first introduces them. Instead, every other chapter is a stand alone backstory for one important character. Where my friends found this as a necessary breather from the "pornographic violence," as one described it, I felt it robbed the book of forward momentum. As Cora is escorted from Georgia to South Carolina, then North Carolina, Tennessee and beyond, her trek is put on hold so we can learn more about the people who either help her or brutalize and murder slaves and their accomplices. I also found certain passages to be didactic. Maybe that's a necessary evil for true events that took place nearly two hundred years ago, but it came across as "the voice of the author" as opposed to the life of the characters.The Underground Railroad is undoubtedly a book that would reveal more and more brilliance with subsequent readings. As I said above, there are many subtle layers in this novel. I'm sure this is one factor that swayed the Pulitzer Prize committee to name this as the best work of fiction in 2016. It is a very difficult read—Whitehead does not whitewash the extreme violence (think DJANGO UNCHAINED) that blacks, both slaves and freemen, endured—but it is a story that I wish millions of Americans would read so that, by chance, history will not repeat itself in this way ever again.FOUR tenacious STARS...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There is so much to love in A CONFEDERACY OF DUNCES, by John Kennedy Toole. Of all the Pulitzer Prize winning novels I've read (more than some, a lot There is so much to love in A CONFEDERACY OF DUNCES, by John Kennedy Toole. Of all the Pulitzer Prize winning novels I've read (more than some, a lot fewer than others), ACofD stands apart as unique and distinct; for one thing, it's a lot more humorous than most. It begs to be read over and over as I'm sure I would get more out of it with each reading.Written in the late '60s in New Orleans, Toole, whose personal story is worthy of its own discussion, is spot on with the words and slang of his characters. The dialogue could be taught as a lesson on dialogue. And the characters—wow!—each one is a riot in his or her own way. Ranging from pathetic to brilliant to sad to farcical (some all at once), the vivid characters engage in mishaps and mayhem as protagonist Ignatius J. Reilly, attempts to find a job that will earn him enough money to bail his distraught mother out of a financial jam, all while suffering acute acid reflux and militaristic activist ex-girlfriend named Myrna Minkoff. And that's just the tip of the iceberg. I highly recommend this book.Five Farcical Stars...more

title: Circling the Sun
author: McLain, Paula*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: CIRCLING THE SUN, by Paula McLain, is a fictionalized account of a real person, in this case, Beryl Markham, the first woman to have made the solo fliCIRCLING THE SUN, by Paula McLain, is a fictionalized account of a real person, in this case, Beryl Markham, the first woman to have made the solo flight from Europe to North America. This genre, not just historical fiction (a story takes place at least fifty years before the author wrote it), walks the fine line between memoir and fiction. Many of the people, dates, and actions are true, but the author gets to make up much—or all—of the dialogue and emotion. A skilled author or movie director can affect or rewrite history, much like Oliver Stone has done with his movies like JFK, NIXON, SNOWDEN, etc. What is true, vs. what do we remember from the book? This concept, in and of itself, bears a separate discussion.While well written, Circling the Sun focuses on Markham's childhood instead of her years as a pioneering aviator. I wouldn't have a problem with that if the cover and blurbs didn't make such a strong point that the story is about "the aviator." Other than the prologue, Markham doesn't even learn to fly in this book until page 332 (out of 355). I imagine is because other biographies of Markham focus on that period, but also it is widely reported that the aviator and the author share a unique trait: both girls were abandoned by their mothers at age four, and both mothers returned when their daughters were about twenty years old. Markham lived a colorful life. She grew up "wild," and became unapologetically promiscuous, including a supposed affair in the 1920s with the then Prince Harry, and also Denys Finch Hattan, a man made famous by Isak Dinesen, aka, Karen Blixen of OUT OF AFRICA. In fact, McLain seems to have borrowed heavily from that novel/movie in creating her characters, with too many similar scenes.I enjoyed reading Circling the Sun. I found it to be an intriguing page turner. However, I feel McLain loved Markham too much. She made her too perfect, smart, and without a conscious. I would have liked it better if Markham was a little more conflicted.THREE circuitous STARS...more

title: Lincoln in the Bardo
author: Saunders, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: LINCOLN IN THE BARDO, George Saunders' first novel, is one of those books you almost have to read twice—or at least I would—to appreciate it fully. I LINCOLN IN THE BARDO, George Saunders' first novel, is one of those books you almost have to read twice—or at least I would—to appreciate it fully. I am a huge fan of George Saunders' short stories, but because of the format he chose to tell this story, I never really got into it."Bardo" is a state of flux, in this case, similar to purgatory for our souls. "Lincoln" refers to Willie Lincoln, Abe Lincoln's son, who died at age 11 while his father was in office. The story takes place in the cemetery at night (possibly over one single night? I am not positive on that) where Willie was temporarily interred. Saunders got the idea for the story years ago, when he heard that President Lincoln went alone to visit his son in the dark of night and pulled his dead body out of his coffin to hold it one more time. From that image, Saunders, who now studies a form of Buddhism, asked himself the question: What would the other "members" of the cemetery think of that? If they could think, of course. That led to a cast of characters! Literally. As in 160 different ghosts and historical figures weighing in on the events of Abe and Willie Lincoln.And that's where Saunders lost me. The story is told in choppy bits and pieces of (both real and fake) historical letters and books about the Lincolns, plus the thoughts of countless ghosts. The book is mostly dialogue from, yes, 160 different people. I both read the book and listened to the audio version. The audio version was fun and fascinating (using several famous voices, including Saunders himself), but it was also frustrating. The parts that were ostensibly non-fiction accounts ended with a proper citation of the source, and had hundreds of "Op Cit" notations if he used sources more than once. That was very jarring and repeatedly pulled me out of the story. Plus, trying to keep track of every ghosts’ name and story was nearly impossible. I really wanted to read this book, so I am glad it was chosen for my book club. George Saunders is one of the most creative storytellers of our time, but the format of this novel was gimmicky and a fail, in my opinion. I doubt I would have finished it on my own.THREE imaginative STARS...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: DESCENT, by Tim Johnston, is dubbed a "literary thriller," and I would like to stress the "literary." The best part of this keen book is Johnston's wrDESCENT, by Tim Johnston, is dubbed a "literary thriller," and I would like to stress the "literary." The best part of this keen book is Johnston's writing. DESCENT is Johnston's first adult novel (after a YA novel and a collection of short stories), and I am in awe of his turn of a phrase and his extraordinary description of the ordinary. I underlined many uncanny, unique observations that are instantly perfect and spot-on. (I would retype a few to illustrate my point, but I'm afraid they would lose their power as excerpts.)DESCENT is the story of the Courtlands, a family of four from Wisconsin who go on vacation in the mountains of Colorado. One day, the son and daughter go for a run up the mountain, but only the son comes down; the daughter goes missing. For the next year and a half, the mother, father, and son struggle to hold on as the search for Caitlin continues. The premise is great, the characters are well-developed and round, the plot and minor characters are solid. I have two relatively small issues with the book. First, Johnston begins each chapter with pronouns—it takes a page or more each time to figure out who the heck he's talking about. At the opening of a book, or the opening of a short story, this can be intriguing and fun; but chapter after chapter—for 74 chapters—this became really frustrating. Second, the story was a little long. It would have been a stronger book if the mini-adventures the characters go on were eliminated or shortened.If you love beautiful sentences (as I do), and you appreciate an elevated thriller, I recommend DESCENT. The last one hundred pages are as "riveting" as the cover blurbs claim.FOUR Chilly STARS...more

title: Ambition and Desire: The Dangerous Life of Josephine Bonaparte
author: Williams, Kate*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The spoils of the spoiled, that should be the subtitle for this biography. As one who prefers novels to all other books, I would never have read this The spoils of the spoiled, that should be the subtitle for this biography. As one who prefers novels to all other books, I would never have read this book if not for my book club. While I am glad to know more about Josephine and Napoleon Bonaparte and their era, I cannot say I liked or would recommend this book. I have to believe there are better books out there if you want to immerse yourself in this world. This book reads like an old history text--the kind that made generations of kids hate history. Based on the bibliography, it seems probable (and it felt like) Kate Williams simply read and regurgitated facts. There was very little mood, emotion, or sensory detail in the chapters. There is precious little mention of the flowery or fowl scents that must have filled each and every day, nor the lustful feel one gets when stroking velvet or satin, no clips of horses hooves or peals of laughter and music at the multitude of balls the Bonapartes threw. I don't hold Williams responsible for how hideous Napoleon or Josephine or any of the rest of them behaved. As far as that goes, reporting just the facts was appropriate. But she could have made reading about these crazy historical figures a lot more interesting. THREE spoiled STARS (because I was curious enough to read through to the end)...more

title: The Improbability of Love
author: Rothschild, Hannah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Check your expectations before you open THE IMPROBABILITY OF LOVE, by Hannah Rothschild. Forget that this is a thick novel named for a painting—a la TCheck your expectations before you open THE IMPROBABILITY OF LOVE, by Hannah Rothschild. Forget that this is a thick novel named for a painting—a la THE GOLDFINCH. Forget that a half-dozen authors you've heard of blurb about this book as if it's worthy of their precious reading hours. Forget that one author even evoked the name of Charles Dickens in her blurb. Ignore the deckled edges and the linen-textured cover paper. This book is a farce. The Improbability of Love is the name of a painting that an innocent, yet self-taught, world-class cook named Annie stumbles upon in a thrift shop, then buys and carries around as if it were a loaf of bread, as does her alcoholic mother. Annie then "coincidentally" gets a job as a personal chef for London's top art dealer, and meets a young painter who falls in love with her and knows how to begin restoration on this masterpiece. Next she fixes dinner for the world's foremost expert on the artist who happened to have painted this masterpiece, and then ... you get the idea. Now throw in a dozen or so of the wealthiest people in the world who want to buy this painting which is expected to sell at auction for the highest price ever paid for a painting. Ever. Now throw in a Nazi war criminal, gay decorator, a shady heiress, plus rap stars, Russian mafia-types ... There's no doubt that Rothschild is a very smart, worldly woman with much to say. Her sentences are all fine and nice; no complaints there. But this book needed a ruthless editor who would have made her cut out much of the cast and most of the coincidences. It was as if Rothschild was trying to recreate LOVE ACTUALLY meets DOWNTON ABBEY meets INGLORIOUS BASTARDS.I wish someone had told me this book was a satire before I opened the cover.TWO Improbable STARS...more

title: H is for Hawk
author: Macdonald, Helen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Bloody hell, Mabel," I whisper. "Who spiked my tea with acid?" Is that not one of the greatest lines in literature?H IS FOR HAWK, by Helen Macdonald,"Bloody hell, Mabel," I whisper. "Who spiked my tea with acid?" Is that not one of the greatest lines in literature?H IS FOR HAWK, by Helen Macdonald, is a memoir from 2015 about a British woman who uses hawking as a way to overcome the sudden loss of her father. Macdonald, a lover of falcons and falconry since the age of nine, chronicles her time training a young goshawk (whom she names Mabel) as she also works through her grief. Her writing is lyrical, and her knowledge of hawks is vast. The story is both timely and historical in that she references multiple master falconers over the past several hundred years, including E.B. White, author of THE SWORD IN THE STONE, CAMELOT, and a non-fiction book called THE GOSHAWK. The quote, above, is from the first day that Macdonald carries her young hawk on her gloved hand out in public for the first time. In her state of near-depression, Macdonald had been somewhat of a hermit, using her bird as an excuse to avoid the real world. When they go to a park and Macdonald removes Mabel's hood, Macdonald herself is "overwhelmed by light and detail ..." and "heightened perceptions" as if someone had spiked her tea with acid. I love that line.H is for Hawk is a fascinating book full of detailed passages about the sport of falconry, but I was more interested in Macdonald's personal story of healing after her father's death. It seems she is trying—perhaps not undeservedly so—to insert herself into the centuries old canon of falconers. FOUR feathery STARS...more

title: Smoke
author: McKenzie, Catherine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: SMOKE, by Catherine McKenzie, is a surprisingly gripping story. I've read several of McKenzie's books, and I expected this to be a light-hearted chickSMOKE, by Catherine McKenzie, is a surprisingly gripping story. I've read several of McKenzie's books, and I expected this to be a light-hearted chick lit novel much like her others. While McKenzie always has something real to say in her books, SMOKE pulled me in a lot deeper than I expected.SMOKE is the story of two estranged friends in the town of "Nelson," a thinly disguised version of Jackson, Wyoming. One of the women, Beth is a former fire-fighter now arson investigator whose marriage is falling apart. Mindy, her ex-best friend, is a married mother of two searching for her authentic self. The novel is framed by a forest fire that has burned down one man's house, and is threatening to burn the entire town if the fire fighters can't stop it. Beth has the unenviable job of determining who started the fire—in a town the size of "Nelson," it's bound to be someone she knows. Although the novel starts out slowly (too much backstory too soon), it really gets going and I found it difficult to put down. McKenzie did a great job of offering up potential culprits and options, and the story has quite the cinematic climax. I must be exactly her target audience, because I really related to both of the women and their situations. It's a bit predictable, but I underlined many poignant sentences which raised my rating up from three and a half stars.FOUR sparkling STARS...more

title: The Night Circus
author: Morgenstern, Erin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE NIGHT CIRCUS, by Erin Morgenstern, is one of those big, juicy, dive-in-head-first kinds of books. Morgenstern has created a world that swallows yoTHE NIGHT CIRCUS, by Erin Morgenstern, is one of those big, juicy, dive-in-head-first kinds of books. Morgenstern has created a world that swallows you whole. It's fantastical, and it makes you want to immerse yourself in the story as long as possible. I found it difficult to put this book down. (I've been looking for a book this all-encompassing since I read CLOUD ATLAS, by David Mitchell.) Set at the turn of the 20th century and told in present tense, The Night Circus is the story of Celia Bowen, the daughter of Hector, aka Prospero the Enchanter; and Marco, the adopted son of "the man in the grey suit." The two men have had an ongoing contest about whose prodigy can outdo the other's for years. In this instance, the circus becomes the framework for the "game" between Celia and Marco. Morgenstern reveals the plot to the characters at the same time she reveals it to the reader which adds wonderful tension and mystery to an already mystical and enigmatic tale. Her writing is superb, and the story is unique, creative, and layered with deep meaning. I loved trying to puzzle out the story, and where it was going, and how it would end.The Night Circus is full of luscious descriptions of the circus tents, as well as the clothes and houses and manners of the day—but maybe it's a little too full. At times the cast becomes unwieldy, and several questions (and peoples' fates) are left unanswered, but ultimately, that didn't ruin the story for me. I have a couple other quibbles, too, but I don't want to mention any spoilers. I can't say this is my favorite book ever, but it is one of the best books I've read in years. Four-and-a-half Magical Stars, rounded up to Five....more

review: MOVIEOLA!, by John Domini, is a book like no other. The voice is fantastic—distinct, droll, and cynical, full of high-level movie producer shorthand aMOVIEOLA!, by John Domini, is a book like no other. The voice is fantastic—distinct, droll, and cynical, full of high-level movie producer shorthand and innuendo. The book is essentially ten linked short stories that walk "us" through the making of a movie, because yes, most of the stories are told in second person present tense. For example, the very first lines: "For the opening we go with The Arrival of the Hit Men. That's the way to make a trailer, a hundred seconds or so of grabber screen time: start with killers in an airport. No need to be crass about it. No need for any kind of race thing, religion thing, politics thing. Pure fear, that's what we want, the lowdown cello throb like someone's pulling a bow right across the spinal column." MOVIEOLA! is smart and sexy, thick with truth and humor. True Hollywood execs will either laugh their asses off, or dismiss it entirely out of shame. Either way, it's a funny read.FIVE STARRY STARS...more

title: Before I Go to Sleep
author: Watson, S.J.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Why is it the more someone says, Trust me, the less you feel you can trust them? BEFORE I GO TO SLEEP, by S.J. (Steve) Watson, is a seriously creepy bWhy is it the more someone says, Trust me, the less you feel you can trust them? BEFORE I GO TO SLEEP, by S.J. (Steve) Watson, is a seriously creepy book that reminded me in ways of Stephen King's MISERY.The premise of this, Watson's debut novel, is that the protagonist, Christine, a forty-seven-year-old amnesiac wakes everyday with almost no memories of her life. Every single day, she is shocked to find a man (her husband, Ben) in bed with her, and shocked to realize she's "old"—she thinks she's twenty-seven. Her husband has hung photographs of the two of them in their bathroom with stickers of their names so she can try to reorient her life each morning. Every day she asks him questions about her life, like what happened to her (she was hit by a car). But every night when she goes to sleep, she loses all the memories she created or asked about that day, and the entire process must begin again. Watson does an excellent job of showing us this happens each day, but not putting us through the agonizing repetition of reliving it with Christine. As the novel progresses, Christine receives a phone call from a Dr. Nash, a man who is also trying (unbeknownst to Ben) to help her recover her memory. Dr. Nash has her write everything she learns in a day in a journal that she then hides from Ben each night. Both men repeatedly tell her to trust them. And that's where things get tense. With the help of the secret journal, Christine begins to have flashes of memories that lead to the culmination of the story. Watson embeds hints so sneakily that I did not realize what was really happening to Christine until late in the story. The final twist and the climax are excellent. Before I Go To Sleep is a page-turning thriller. If you're looking for a creepy-good book, you will not be disappointed.FOUR unforgettable STARS...more
