review: The theme for Camron Wright's THE RENT COLLECTOR is hope: A young couple with a sick child is forced to live by scavenging the municipal dump just outThe theme for Camron Wright's THE RENT COLLECTOR is hope: A young couple with a sick child is forced to live by scavenging the municipal dump just outside Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The wife, Sang Ly, finds someone who can teach her to read in hopes that she can teach her son to read, and he can have a better life. This someone is "the rent collector" of the dump, an angry, alcoholic woman who we learn used to be a distinguished teacher. This is a noble premise for a novel. What's more, it's mostly true. This novel is based on a true story as told by Wright's own son in a documentary called RIVER OF VICTORY.Unfortunately, The Rent Collector reads like the script of a documentary, like it was phoned in. The voice of the narrator (Sang Ly, not the rent collector herself, a la Nick Caraway telling Jay Gatsby's story, or Ishmael telling Captain Ahab's story) sounds nothing like a young, desperate mother who lives in a dump. Neither the writing nor the dialogue are evocative; they are factual and straightforward, much like an American man in an office describing a movie he saw. I did learn about a world heretofore unknown to me, and I admire the spirit of the young couple who went to extraordinary lengths to give their child a better life, but I can't say I enjoyed the book. Two and a half Stars ...more

title: Girls' Weekend
author: Achterberg, Cara Sue*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Cara Sue Achterberg is fantastic at creating characters and getting into their minds and lives. GIRLS' WEEKEND, Achterberg's second novel, is the storCara Sue Achterberg is fantastic at creating characters and getting into their minds and lives. GIRLS' WEEKEND, Achterberg's second novel, is the story of three forty-something women who go away for a weekend, leaving husbands and children behind. They rent a beach house not too far from home, and have so much fun they decide to stay ... indefinitely. Each of them has different issues to work through, and the off-season resort provides the perfect place to reorient their lives. As a married/divorced/remarried woman, I can relate to so many of the emotions that Achterberg gives her different characters. Dani, a former artist and mother of two, feels she's lost her identity to the role of mother. Meg, mother of five who lost her baby two years prior, must learn how to overcome her grief to rejoin real-life. Charlotte, an interior designer and mother to a "perfect" teenage boy, must decide if she and her husband still love each other, or if they're just staying together for their son. The women bond and coach each other over meals, wine, running, and talking. They are all very different, yet long-time friends. Their dialogue is often direct—they way a true friend should be able to communicate. Not all of them have a tidy, happy ending, which I was pleased to find out. Not because I wished any of them bad fortune, just because it felt more realistic.This novel is a perfect beach read. It is engaging, fast-paced, and realistic ... with a lot of alcohol and a few handsome strangers mixed in.Five Girly Stars...more

title: The Life and Times of the Thunderbolt Kid: A Memoir
author: Bryson, Bill
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Funny, factual, poignant. Those seem like positive adjectives for a memoir to me. I know many memoirs aren't meant to be funny, but we could all use aFunny, factual, poignant. Those seem like positive adjectives for a memoir to me. I know many memoirs aren't meant to be funny, but we could all use a good chuckle now and then, right? Bill Bryson's memoir, THE LIFE AND TIMES OF THE THUNDERBOLT KID, hits all three smack on the head.I don't normally read memoirs, but I have multiple connections to this book, so I was long overdue in picking it up. Bryson is from Des Moines (my current hometown), he went to the same schools as my husband and have mutual friends, and now my son lives in his childhood home. No, Des Moines isn't THAT small, these are all just happy coincidences.In the 1970s, Bryson moved to England. He has gone on to write more than a dozen non-fiction books, mostly about travel, but this memoir is about his childhood. Born in 1951, he covers the decade well and touches on life in the 1960s in middle-America, too. I have a particular interest in this era, so in addition to getting a kick out of the history of Des Moines, I was as delighted to read about the mood and the overall attitudes of Americans at the time. I feel like there's not much to say about a memoir. You can't really argue the facts because that's the point of a memoir (as opposed to a biography): it's told as he remembers it. Bryson is an excellent writer, and the story is filled with hyperbole—an appropriate voice for a young boy's memory. FOUR Thunderous STARS...more

review: Some people were born to be writers. David Atkinson is one of them. NOT QUITE SO STORIES is a collection of two dozen short stories that range from drSome people were born to be writers. David Atkinson is one of them. NOT QUITE SO STORIES is a collection of two dozen short stories that range from droll to strange to bizarre. Each one delivers a punch—not a punch-line, necessarily, more like a punch in the gut. Similar in ways to the great George Saunders, most of Atkinson's stories start with an everyday, normal situation, and then bang!, there's a twist that no one save the author could have predicted. Not Quite So Stories is possibly the funniest, weirdest collection of wit and intelligence I've read in a long time. Atkinson's creative twists are original and unexpected, but we can expect to see a lot more from him in the future.FIVE Twisted STARS...more

title: The Time Traveler’s Wife
author: Niffenegger, Audrey*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What this book gains in originality and vivid description it loses in length and editing. THE TIME TRAVELER'S WIFE, by Audrey Niffenegger, clocks in aWhat this book gains in originality and vivid description it loses in length and editing. THE TIME TRAVELER'S WIFE, by Audrey Niffenegger, clocks in at nearly 600 pages (the paperback version), or 17.5 hours (in the audio version, which is how I "read" it). I wanted to read this book because dozens of top lit agents say they'd love to find a new book "like The Time Traveler's Wife." As a writer, I decided I should know what's so special about this book that, thirteen years later, agents still cite it on their wish lists.Niffenegger, who I learned is a visual artist, apparently one day got the idea to tell this story as a graphic novel, but discovered the difficulty of representing the choppy timeline visually. So she wrote it out. The title tells us what the story is about. We have a time traveler, named Henry, and he is married to a woman named Claire. Though not the first to tell a time-travel story, or an intimate love story with a complication (even Shakespeare liked it), the story did feel fresh. However, this book was at least 200 pages too long, in my opinion. The story would have been much improved if we didn't have to hear every single event of Henry's time travel. Time after time (no pun intended), we get another scene in which Henry jumps out of "now" and lands in "then." Often, nothing significant happens "then." It just happens. Over and over. I imagine this story, with it's jumps through time, was an editor's nightmare. The verb tenses alone had to be insane to get right, but why did the editor allow it to go on for 600 pages? I have one more problem with this story, and I feel compelled to say it. This book has many graphic sex scenes. I have no problem with that, but more than once "Claire" uses the c-word. At one point, after just having given birth, Claire is talking about how painful the birth was. She starts with her breasts and nipples and works her way down. No one is going to deny that childbirth is painful, but why oh why did Niffenegger have her use the c-word instead of "vagina"? And why did the editor allow it. Claire, the character, is a wealthy, educated woman in her 30s. It was totally out of character for her. And that's not the only time she used what I consider one of the most vile words in the English language. It was so unnecessary.Yes, I took off one star just for her use of that word.On my journey as a writer, I will try to retain Niffenegger's lyrical, evocative writing, try to retain her attention to detail and description. I will also remember what I didn't like about this book.Three belated Stars...more

He grows up to be known as the great musician Frankie Presto. His outlandish story is narrated by "Music," or I suppose the spirit of music. Frankie is the most amazing guitar player/singer/handsome man who has ever lived (the hyperbole is the narrator's, not mine). Albom has him interact with the true greats like Elvis, Duke Ellington, Little Richard, Hank Williams, etc., throughout his life.The book is a quick read, and the story, though often unbelievable bordering on miraculous—finally explained in the final pages—is decently intriguing, but I have to say every time the narrator bragged about his own abilities, I cringed. title: Lord of the Flies
author: Golding, William
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: LORD OF THE FLIES, by William Golding, written in 1954, has always held a sort of mystical, horror-movie aura for me. I never read it as a child, nor LORD OF THE FLIES, by William Golding, written in 1954, has always held a sort of mystical, horror-movie aura for me. I never read it as a child, nor did I see the movie (either version), even though it is a modern classic, or at least a book that is commonly taught at school.I listened to the audio version of this book, narrated by Golding himself long after he wrote it; his scratchy voice warbled like a old man's. I envisioned him sitting in a thread-bare, overstuffed chair near a fireplace, telling the story to his grandsons. The performance would have been substandard if he weren't the author, but because he was, I loved it. Yes, we hear him inhale and swallow (Say it ain't so!), but he emphasizes the dialogue just as he intended it. Golding's writing is evocative and vivid and terse. I felt as if I were running through the weeds and forests, and climbing up the rocks and swimming in the ocean with the characters. The story is about human nature at its very core. A group of British boys (maybe two dozen?) wash up on a deserted island after their plane crashes during WWII. All the adults and any girls perish in the crash. Once the boys realize what has happened to them, they convene and attempt to make a plan. One boy, Ralph, takes charge in the beginning and prioritizes being rescued by lighting a fire so ships might find them. Another boy, Jack, leads his friends to find food. They become the "hunters." As you can imagine, the two sets of boys diverge. The hunters become "savages." Not everyone survives. What an exciting premise! How would human nature develop under such dire circumstances, especially in children who, in theory, are still innocent and naive? If I had read this in junior high, I imagine I would have been horrified by it. As an adult, and after so many years of hearing about this book, it wasn't as horrible as I thought it would be. I suppose that speaks to my expectations, as well as the types of books and movies being made today (e.g. Alive, Hunger Games). My knock on the narrative is the flatness of the characters. Ralph spoke incessantly about lighting a fire (yes, I realize the foreshadowing purpose, but still); "Piggy" was a victim of his poor eyesight and asthma; Jack was singularly focused on finding "meat." If I had had the genius to write this story, I hope I would have made the characters more "round" and given them more depth. The book is short, so I suppose Golding didn't feel had time to develop the boys and still keep the book as brief as he wanted, but I think deeper characters would have made this a five-star story. Also the title ... It's a fantastic title, but I wish Golding had developed the "Lord" as the power of our imagination more fully.Four Bloody Stars...more

title: Everything I Never Told You
author: Ng, Celeste*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: REVIEW FROM SECOND READING: Oct. 2017I reread EVERYTHING I NEVER TOLD YOU, by Celeste Ng, for two reasons. First, it's a nuanced and poignant story. SREVIEW FROM SECOND READING: Oct. 2017I reread EVERYTHING I NEVER TOLD YOU, by Celeste Ng, for two reasons. First, it's a nuanced and poignant story. Second, because the ladies in my first book club disagreed on what they think happened, and I wanted to know what the ladies in my second book club would think about it. They disagreed, too! The ambiguity definitely makes for a lively, divergent discussion."Lydia is dead." That is the opening sentence of this family drama, set in the 1970s in small-town Ohio. One morning, the Lee family wakes up for school and work, but the middle daughter, Lydia, is gone. A few days later, the police find her body at the bottom of a nearby lake. Problem is, no one in this bi-racial family—with a Chinese-American father who hated being "different," and blonde wife who wanted to be different—is open enough to communicate ANYTHING about their true feelings, motivations, or suspicions. No one will tell the others or the police what they know, so the family begins to disintegrate. There are three possibilities for what happened to Lydia: murder by a neighborhood boy, suicide, or accident. Different members of the family believe different scenarios. Although this is a tragic, cautionary tale (some members of my book club thought it was awfully depressing with no reprieve), it is a deep story with themes ranging from communication to discrimination to how NOT to behave as parents. Lydia was the favorite child; both parents showered their two oldest children with extreme vicarious pressures, while the youngest child was often invisible to them. I have an overwhelming desire to tell every tight-lipped person I know to read the book to understand the value of communicating, not just in the face of a tragedy, but on an everyday basis about our hopes, dreams, and desires. Families must communicate. On second reading, I still give the book Four-and-a-half Stars, but this time I'm rounding up to Five Stars, just to be fair to the author.REVIEW FROM FIRST READING: Mar 2016EVERYTHING I NEVER TOLD YOU, by Celeste Ng, is unique in so many ways. Ng (pronounced Ing) made several bold choices, including the godlike, omniscient point of view, and the narrator's ability to see into the future. Given the way this story ended, it could only have been told in the omniscient voice, but I am still debating whether or not I liked being told what would or wouldn't happen at a future moment in this family's life.Everything I Never Told You is the beautifully written story of the Lee family who live in a small town in Ohio in the 1970s. The father, James, is a Chinese American who felt "different" his entire life. He married a bright, blue-eyed girl named Marilyn who wanted to stand out. They had three children, Nathan and Hannah, both dark-eyed like their father, and Lydia, who inherited her mother's blue eyes. Lydia, the "chosen child," dies, and that is where the novel begins. "Lydia is dead." is the first sentence of the book. The police investigation runs parallel to the storyline of each family member trying to deal what happened to Lydia and why. Each character knows bits and pieces of information that none of the others do. Based the title, obviously, we know one of the themes of this novel is communication: how important it is to talk and be honest with those we love. Another message from Ng is about the dangers of parents who live vicariously through their children, and/or the overbearing expectations that some parents put on children. Lastly, this story speaks to prejudice. At the time and place of the story, the Lees stand out as the only "Oriental" family of this small town. We learn that even though they often forget they're "different," others don't let them forget it for long. Ng does an excellent job of showing what childhood events shaped each character, and his or her motives for how they behave "today." Each character is round and sincere and believable. "How did Lydia really die" is the question that keeps the reader turning the pages. Ng casts doubt on several characters, thus making us wonder if someone killed her, or if it's a suicide like the police think. The ending, which I won't give away, does not disappoint. It was brilliant, in fact. Plus, Ng makes many astute and memorable observations about people, families, life, and love. I underlined many passages.So why didn't I give this book five stars? I was eager to know what happened to Lydia, but I thought several quiet, everyday scenes dragged a bit. Plus, as I mentioned above, the narrator occasionally tells us things like "Later—and for the rest of his life—James will struggle to piece words to this feeling ..." Now, I realize an omniscient narrator would know these things, but I didn't like being told what would happen at a time past the end of the novel. Just a personal preference, I guess. Everything I Never Told You is a well-written, poignant story with a compelling storyline. I would recommend this book to almost anyone. Four (and a half) Stars...more

title: My Name Is Lucy Barton        (Amgash, #1)
author: Strout, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The final few pages of MY NAME IS LUCY BARTON, by Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Elizabeth Strout, offered a slight redemption for this novel, in my The final few pages of MY NAME IS LUCY BARTON, by Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Elizabeth Strout, offered a slight redemption for this novel, in my eyes. But, I am surprised by how much I didn't like this book.My Name Is Lucy Barton is the story of an older woman looking back on her painful life. It opens and focuses mostly on a nine-week hospital stay when Lucy was younger and married with two young daughters. Lucy's mother comes to stay with her in the hospital for five days out of the nine weeks. It's the first time they have spoken in many years. Lucy survives, obviously, but the rest of her life is plagued by sadness and guilt due to certain events, revelations, and decisions she makes. (I would be more specific, but don't want to include spoilers.) This book doesn't have a plot; it consists of multiple scenes from Lucy's life, almost all of them sad. By the end, we realize the book is about familial love. Familial love is deep and undying, yet so often, too often, it's our family members who cause us the most pain. Whether the pain comes from your father or mother, your spouse or children, the pain is horrendous because it's nearly impossible to reconcile so much love and so much pain coming from the same source. Yet the reality of this is almost universal. Name one family that hasn't had some inner strife.My biggest issue with this novel, though, is Lucy's "voice" (her word choices). It's not distinct enough to show us her personality as does, say Holden Caulfield's voice or Humbert Humbert's. In this book, the voice (i.e. the writing) comes across as bad editing. Lucy Barton is looking back on her life as an older, successful writer. She says she "comes from nothing," yet she's obviously an educated adult. This "voice" is a style choice by two brilliant women, Elizabeth Strout and her distinguished editor Susan Kamil, but I feel differently about it. C'est la vie, I suppose.I read this book for one of my book clubs, and I feel confident that after I hear my wise friends speak about it, I'll probably like it more. But for now ...Three Stars...more

title: The Invention of Wings
author: Kidd, Sue Monk*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Set in the early 1800s, THE INVENTION OF WINGS, by Sue Monk Kidd, is the story of Heddy, aka "Handful," a young slave girl, and Sarah Grimke, the daugSet in the early 1800s, THE INVENTION OF WINGS, by Sue Monk Kidd, is the story of Heddy, aka "Handful," a young slave girl, and Sarah Grimke, the daughter of a plantation owner, who receives Handful for her eleventh birthday. For better AND worse, Sarah attempts to emancipate Handful the next day, but ends up just giving her back to her mother. And thus begins story between these two girls who are as similar as they are different.Kidd is a beautiful writer and storyteller. Told in alternating narratives, the pace is quick and compelling. It's obvious Kidd, a white woman, did detailed research for this book, and seems to have expressed even the slaves' lives and vernacular quite well.I listened to the audio version of this book for one of my book clubs, (the audio version was very well done) so it wasn't until Kidd narrated the afterword about the story behind this story that I realized it was based on real people. It's largely a true story. Sarah Grimke and her younger sister Angelina were real women from Charleston who fought against slavery long before women were allowed to even speak in public places. While I have no major problems with this book, it doesn't feel fresh to me. It tells a lovely account of real people dealing with the horrifying reality of slavery, but it doesn't give us anything we haven't seen/heard/read before in books and movies like ROOTS, TWELVE YEARS A SLAVE, THE KITCHEN HOUSE, etc.Four Lovely but Unenthusiastic Stars...more

review: I have mixed emotions about FORTUNE SMILES, by Adam Johnson. Can you both love and hate a book? No, I don't hate it so much as I hate thinking that thI have mixed emotions about FORTUNE SMILES, by Adam Johnson. Can you both love and hate a book? No, I don't hate it so much as I hate thinking that there are undoubtedly people in our world as horrible as "Dark Meadow."Fortune Smiles is a collection of six short stories by Johnson, who won the Pulitzer Prize for The Orphan Master's Son, a truly incredible story. Johnson is without a doubt one of our best living authors. His writing is flawless, his imagination astounding, his research impeccable, although he picks such obscure situations that I certainly wouldn't spot any errors. For this collection, it was as if Johnson chose six of the most unusual occupations he could imagine, and then asked himself what their personal life stories might have been like. For instance, "What kind of family man would an East German prison warden have been?" or, "How would a UPS driver deliver packages after Hurricane Rita if he suddenly had sole custody of his two-year-old son?" Those are two of the stories. There's also the husband of a paralyzed woman; the dying wife of a Pulitzer Prize winning author (this is so touching it makes you wonder about the health of Adam Johnson's wife); two North Korean defectors trying to survive in South Korea, one is happy to be out, the other can't survive in the "chaos"; but the most disturbing story was about Dark Meadow, a damaged IT guy who fixes pedophiles' computers for cash—he both steals images and leaves something behind on their computers. That last story hit me emotionally. But beyond picking unique characters and situations, Johnson excels at being in the head of these characters. His POV and the depth of personal details he touches on is remarkable. No one is "just" a UPS driver. This guy, for example, called "Nonc," has an ambitious girlfriend who does not like the fact that they now have a kid to take care of. (When and how can they have sex? They found a way!) Plus, Nonc's father is dying in California, his baby-mama is in prison, and he can't understand the child's made-up words. Did I mention this was in the wake of a major hurricane? What's more, each story has a message. Not in a pedantic, moralistic way, just in the "Hey, people, if you think you've got it rough, imagine this ..." way. Talk about opening our eyes and our hearts! So, what to rate it? Fortune Smiles deserves five stars for its writing and originality, but I can't say I LIKED all the stories. One or two were slow to develop, I thought, even though they ended as powerfully as all the rest. FOUR Fortunate STARS...more

review: MEDIUM HERO, by Korby Lenker, is a book you want to hug. It's 215 pages long, but they're tiny pages. Seriously, the book is about four inches by seveMEDIUM HERO, by Korby Lenker, is a book you want to hug. It's 215 pages long, but they're tiny pages. Seriously, the book is about four inches by seven inches. It begs to be read in a single afternoon. Comprised of 27 short stories, Medium Hero is a raw, intimate, apparently-fictionalized accounting of a young man's life, though it feels a bit like you've picked up his private journal. Lenker, according to the book jacket, is a musician of some acclaim who has traveled around the country performing and observing life, and turned those observations into funny and/or poignant stories. With a deep online presence, Lenker seems to be a Renaissance kind of guy. He sings, he writes, he reads. I imagine he can make cocktails and a surprisingly delicious pasta dish in a pinch, if need be. In this collection, he has turned intimate situations into universal stories that resonate with a broader audience. Reading it, I felt I knew the characters personally—or someone quite similar. And that is a true talent for a writer.Four Heartfelt Stars...more

title: The War of Art: Winning the Inner Creative Battle
author: Pressfield, Steven*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Could there be a better book to kick off the new year for a struggling writer? No.THE WAR OF ART, by Steven Pressfield, author of The Legend of BaggerCould there be a better book to kick off the new year for a struggling writer? No.THE WAR OF ART, by Steven Pressfield, author of The Legend of Bagger Vance, et al, is a gem of encouragement, written from Pressfield's heart. He writes of Resistance: the force field that rains down upon everyone trying to break out of their mold. Writers, artists, entrepreneurs ... heck, he'd probably say it could apply to overweight people who want to finally get in shape, and so many others. The War of Art is about "seeing" how "the world" conspires against us to prevent us from reaching our goals. Whether our struggles are internal ("I'm not good enough to succeed!") or external (when loved ones are threatened and therefore unsupportive of our efforts), Pressfield illuminates the roadblocks that get in our way. Then he shows us how to overcome those obstacles and succeed.The War of Art is short (165 small pages) and well-written. His words really spoke to me and encouraged me to keep striving toward my goals. I took off one star because the final few pages get a little preachy. It's his book and he can speak of God and Angels if he wants to, but I felt it would have been a stronger finish if he hadn't. Very happy to have read this, though.Four Artful Stars...more

title: Fates and Furies
author: Groff, Lauren*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Now this is a book. This book will suck you in, drag you to the farthest depths of the ocean, then spit you back on shore just before your lungs lose Now this is a book. This book will suck you in, drag you to the farthest depths of the ocean, then spit you back on shore just before your lungs lose their last puff of air. FATES AND FURIES, by Lauren Groff, ain't for sissies. Groff's writing is forceful and unique. She doesn't explain anything; you have to figure out what she's talking about as you read along. It's almost as if the original draft was twice as long and she edited out every other sentence, or perhaps most of the words from each sentence. Brilliant, if you're willing to work a little. And the POV? It's essentially third person omniscient, but Groff adds in bracketed narrator-voiceovers, almost like a wink. It's quite clever.Fates and Furies is a two-part story about a larger-than-life couple: Lotto and Mathilde. The first half, Fates, focuses on Lancelot, called Lotto, a "Golden Boy" in his mother's eyes, though he grows up to be pock-marked and too tall (6'6") for his chosen profession as an actor, so he stumbles into becoming a playwright. He's the kind of guy who gets all the girls and all the attention. Here, from page 42, a female friend discussing Lotto: "He's the sluttiest," Danica said. "He gets away with it because of the way he looks at you. Like, if he were actually good-looking, he'd never be as deadly, but five minutes in a room with him, and all you want to do is get naked."Things just seem to happen for Lotto, to the point that a person might hate him. But no one hates him outwardly because he's too important. He's the boss or the President or the uber-wealthy father that you can't afford to hate. Lotto is like a sex-crazed, melodramatic, drunken Roman Candle, though he deeply loves and is faithful to his wife.Furies, the second half of the book, focuses on Mathilde. She plays the loving, supportive wife in the first half of the book. But if Lotto is a Roman Candle, Mathilde is the one who lights and holds the firework while it's shooting its flame into the dark sky. Furies not only shows us who Mathilde really is, it shows us how egocentric (daft) Lotto is. Groff hinted at the darkness behind Mathilde in Part 1, but it's not until we read Mathilde's life story that we realize how deep a character she is. Deep and dark, very, very dark. If everything went right for Lotto, it's safe to say almost everything went wrong for Mathilde. Out of necessity, she created herself as she was growing up.Groff must be brilliant, at least she is in the world of literature. With Lotto as a playwright, Groff can use her knowledge of the Classics, specifically the Greek myths, to guide his career. Now, I know very little about the Classics so much of this was over my head, but she did a decent job of explaining it so I could appreciate that there was a deeper meaning without losing the storyline. I do have a couple issues with this book. One, I hate the GONE GIRL twist. It's not until Part 2 that the reader realizes the female lead is so dark. I wish Groff had alluded to that a little more in Part 1 instead of trying to shock us like Gone Girl did. Also, this book takes off at a sprinter's pace, but Groff can't or doesn't sustain it through the 390-page marathon. It was almost as if she was in love with Lotto herself, and that came through brilliantly. I would take off a half-star for these if I could.Ultimately, Fates and Furies is an explosive love story with a brilliant perspective on life and love. Groff nails certain relationships and personalities so squarely that I underlined and dog-eared numerous sentences and paragraphs. Four-and-a-half Furious Stars (rounded up)...more

title: Slade House
author: Mitchell, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: David Mitchell is like a ventriloquist, able to "speak" in the distinct voice of so many different characters. His mind is as creative as a young chilDavid Mitchell is like a ventriloquist, able to "speak" in the distinct voice of so many different characters. His mind is as creative as a young child's, building tales as tall as a mountain. He is one of the best living writers, almost too good, perhaps, because it's so hard to keep up with him.SLADE HOUSE, Mitchell's latest gem, is a perfect example of his cryptic tales. As a stand alone novel (or probably novella because it's short), Slade House captivates and excites the reader. With equal parts literary, horror, and fantasy, it tells the story of people who disappear from Slade Alley in London on the last Saturday of October every nine years. Each of the five chapters begins on that day (starting in 1979 and ending in 2015) with the tale of "the chosen" visitors to Slade House. This is where the horror part comes in. If the residents of the house (that doesn't exist on any map) can convince them to enter and imbibe something, they don't leave. Mitchell does a lyrical job of making this seem elegant and plausible.But it's difficult to take Slade House as a stand alone novel. It links directly back to his last book, The Bone Clocks. So much so that I had to go back and reread the ending of The Bone Clocks because Slade House feels to me like a link from that to a new novel. I felt by the time I finished Slade House that it was written as a business decision to lay a path toward another book. All that being said, it's difficult for me to criticize David Mitchell. He IS one of the best writers of our time, and I will absolutely read any book he writes. Four cryptic Stars...more

review: THE LIE, by T.C. Boyle, is exactly what short stories are supposed to be. The quintessential short story, if you will. It's real, and also exaggeratedTHE LIE, by T.C. Boyle, is exactly what short stories are supposed to be. The quintessential short story, if you will. It's real, and also exaggerated. It's funny, and also sad. It's short, and yet says so much. It starts in media res, and leaves you wondering what will happen after it ends. I listened to the audio version on audible.com. It was narrated by the author himself. Writers shouldn't always read their work, but he does a great job.The Lie is a week in the life of an unnamed narrator: a husband, father, and employee at a production company. One day, he can't bear to go to work so he tells his boss a little lie ... You know how it goes. But, Boyle has that wonderful was of picking up on the minutiae of life that makes the reader immediately identify with. Four Honest Stars (he loses one for not being terribly original)...more

title: Bastard Out of Carolina
author: Allison, Dorothy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: BASTARD OUT OF CAROLINA, by Dorothy Allison, is one of those books you don't forget. Written in 1992, BOOC was recently reprinted as a 20th AnniversarBASTARD OUT OF CAROLINA, by Dorothy Allison, is one of those books you don't forget. Written in 1992, BOOC was recently reprinted as a 20th Anniversary Edition with a new afterword. I'm surprised this book isn't more well-known. It's powerful and heartbreaking, and so well-written. BOOC is the story of Ruth Anne Boatwright (known as "Bone), a little girl born out of wedlock in South Carolina in the 1950s. The Boatwrights are poor and dysfunctional, but the women are wise. They understand each other and they take care of one another. The men, though loyal to their blood relatives, are badass drunks who are in and out of work, women, and jail. Bone's mother, Anney, is a pretty girl with no luck. She's fierce, and yet mostly helpless (not unlike any poor woman in the 1950s South). It's a tough world for Bone. We never learn who her father is, we just know she looks different from the rest of the family. She struggles to understand who she is and how the world works. Bone loves gospel music, the Church, and Shannon, an Albino friend who suffers tragedies of her own. As you might imagine, incest is a strong theme in this book. Incest, love, and hatred are linked so tightly that you really can't put this book down. The end is ... not what you imagine. It's worse.This story is not a memoir, but Allison states in the afterword that the experiences and the emotions are real. So real, in fact, that the book was banned from several schools. Its message is loud and important, but the reality is so painful that not everyone will want to read it. Five Tragic Stars...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: BARK, by Lorrie Moore, is a collection of eight diverse short stories, and every sentence in each one is jam-packed with detail and emotion. Moore's wBARK, by Lorrie Moore, is a collection of eight diverse short stories, and every sentence in each one is jam-packed with detail and emotion. Moore's writing style is unique, but it's hard to put a finger on exactly what makes it so. It is in turn stream-of-conscious, obsessive, messy, poignant, and beautiful. Plus, Moore makes brilliant, honest observations. I underlined and starred many passages.These stories were written over at least ten years, the oldest dating from 2003. It's interesting to compare a writer's work over a decade—because you do get a different feel from oldest to newest, though it's easy to tell they are all "Lorrie Moore stories." Each one has a different set of characters, though in general they are troubled, scrambling, quirky, well-developed characters who are trying to find love in a difficult world. My comments throughout include "quirky," "bizarre," "crazy," "funny," "a riot," and "so true!" I'm not a huge fan of short stories, so this book didn't thrill me like an epic novel does, but if you like story collections, you'll probably really enjoy this book.Four Short Stars...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The characters in THE MAGICIAN'S LIE, by Greer Macallister, are distinct, round, and real. We care about them, and about what happens to them. The chaThe characters in THE MAGICIAN'S LIE, by Greer Macallister, are distinct, round, and real. We care about them, and about what happens to them. The characters and the plot make this book a page turner.The Magician's Lie is the story of Ada/Arden, a young girl who, in 1905, is a rare female stage magician with a traveling show. One July night at the end of her show, a man (her husband) is found dead. Arden flees, knowing she is the prime suspect. Arden is caught quite by accident by Virgil Holt, a young lawman with real troubles of his own. Macallister did an excellent job of giving these characters motives: Arden wants to be free; Holt thinks his troubles will disappear if he turns in this suspected murderer. But did she or didn't she kill him? The main plot of this book takes place over one long dark night in a one-room "police station." These chapters are juxtaposed with Arden recounting her life's story—which she insists is essential to Holt believing that she is innocent—from the age of four. Her life was rife with struggles and sadness. Unfortunately, these flashbacks turned into mostly telling, no showing. I wish the tales that Arden recounted had been written in scene instead of exposition.Four Magical Stars...more

title: Career of Evil        (Cormoran Strike, #3)
author: Galbraith, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love mysteries and thrillers. Though I primarily read literary fiction, I like to throw in an occasional commercial fiction mystery because of the pI love mysteries and thrillers. Though I primarily read literary fiction, I like to throw in an occasional commercial fiction mystery because of the pace and intrigue. CAREER OF EVIL, by Robert Galbraith, aka JK Rowling, definitely qualifies because we all know Rowling is an excellent storyteller.That being said, this is my least favorite of the three Comoran Strike detective books. This series is about a former British soldier who started his own detective agency after the Afghan war. He is an amputee, and he's apparently very attractive. In The Cuckoo's Calling, the first Strike novel, he hires young, attractive Robin Ellacott, and together they beat the British Police in solving major crimes. It's the pull between Strike and Robin that keeps me coming back for more. Otherwise, the stories are a bit like Law & Order. (No knock there; I like L&O.) In Career of Evil, a woman's severed leg is delivered to Robin at Strike's office. Yuk. Because Strike is an amputee, this event has several layers of mystery and innuendo, not the least of which is who's leg is it? And who sent it to Robin and Strike? The police have their ideas, and Strike has his ideas. And the race is off! Who will solve it first? I don't dislike this premise.The problem was that this book is nearly 500 pages of "Is it him? Or is it him? Or is it him? Or is it them?" I finally decided that either Rowling's editor was afraid to say, Cut out 100 pages!, or that her publisher told her to make it 500 pages so they could charge more for the book. Either way, many stretches felt repetitive and tedious. I can say the the ending, perhaps the last 75 pages, were quite exciting ... especially the last five pages. That means I will most likely buy the next Strike book. I just hope the mystery story is worth my time.Three and a half bloody Stars (rounded down to three)...more

title: Purity
author: Franzen, Jonathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: PURITY, by Jonathan Franzen, is a big, adventurous story. It is unique and engaging, broad yet also intimate. Franzen is obviously brilliant, and the PURITY, by Jonathan Franzen, is a big, adventurous story. It is unique and engaging, broad yet also intimate. Franzen is obviously brilliant, and the details of the story are well-researched, precise to the Nth degree. I listened to the audio version, which clocks in at 25 hours—that's long—yet I finished it fairly quickly because I was always eager to get back to the characters' lives. Purity is the story of Purity "Pip" Tyler, a bright, twenty-something Californian who lives with her reclusive mother. The mother, Penelope, is ... a basket case. We don't get an official diagnosis (because she's a recluse) but she is clinically sociopathic in many ways. We meet Pip when she's working at a bad telephone sales job, overwhelmed by $131,000 of school loans that her mother keeps telling her not to worry about. The hook is that Pip has no idea who her father is, and her mother won't divulge it no matter how Pip tries to get it out of her. Pip wants to find him in hopes that he can help pay off her student loans. When Pip meets a woman who convinces her to join The Sunlight Project, an organization that exposes secrets much like WikiLeaks, she jumps at the chance and flies to South America to join up. She thinks she can use the organization's fact-finding tricks to discover who her father is, and what her mother's real name is (she is living under an assumed name with the guise they are hiding out from an abusive ex-husband). The bulk of the novel is Franzen's plunge into each of the major characters' backstories. This is both good and bad. IMHO, he goes too deep into too many lives. I felt as if he was trying to elevate this novel into Pulitzer Prize territory. Instead of being awed and fascinated, it turned me off.Franzen proves he knew his characters inside and out, up and down, frontwards and backwards. There are no flat characters in this book. They are all so round, they're obese. Usually that's great, but I found long stretches of this story boring. Once we finally learn who Pip's father is, we get SO much detail on her parents' relationship I had to skip ahead. It was painful to hear their problems go on and on and on. One other character worth mentioning is Andreas Wolf, the Julian Assange-like founder of The Sunlight Project. Whoa. Wolf is from East Germany, raised by a father who works for the GDR, and a mother who has serious problems of her own. Andreas Wolf is so screwed up, he is one of those fictional characters that I might never forget. Franzen says he thought of the name/theme "purity" long before he decided to name the primary character Purity. It follows that the message of this novel is: Honesty is the best policy. It seems every character's lies came back to haunt him or her in devastating ways.Purity could not have been an easy book to write. The writing was clean, the story was captivating, the characters were real. I just wish Franzen hadn't tried so hard.Four Pure Stars...more

review: I have been intrigued by the premise of ME BEFORE YOU, by Jojo Moyes, since I first heard of it a few years ago—the story of a paraplegic and his careI have been intrigued by the premise of ME BEFORE YOU, by Jojo Moyes, since I first heard of it a few years ago—the story of a paraplegic and his caregiver. I imagined it would be heartbreaking. Instead, I'm sad to report, it was entirely predictable. Well, not entirely. No one could say it has a Hollywood ending.Jojo Moyes is a very good writer. This book isn't sappy or overly sentimental. The characters were fairly well-rounded (as in they all had lives beyond the main plot), but they were essentially stereotypes. Rich, athletic, handsome playboy becomes paralyzed; mousy, underachieving small-town girl is hired to be his "babysitter" ... Oh, need I go on? The book does take a serious turn in the end, which I applaud. Moyes glances upon a highly controversial subject, but either she was making a stand for her opinion via her protagonist, or Moyes never actually been in love with someone who has no will to live. Either way, I disagreed with the protagonist's behavior.Three Stars...more

title: The Whistling Season        (Morrie Morgan #1, Two Medicine Country #7)
author: Doig, Ivan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE WHISTLING SEASON, by Ivan Doig, is one of those enveloping, epic tales set in a distinct time and place—the winter of 1909 in rural Montana. This THE WHISTLING SEASON, by Ivan Doig, is one of those enveloping, epic tales set in a distinct time and place—the winter of 1909 in rural Montana. This is the first book of Doig's that I've read. He died this year leaving a legacy of thirteen novels and several more non-fiction works. It's easy to see why so many people loved his work. I loved a lot ABOUT this book, even if I can't broadly say I loved the book. There are dozens of fantastic sentences and scenes.The Whistling Season is the story of the Milliron family (a dad and his three sons) who live on a ranch in Montana. The boys' mother passed away, and their house is turning into a, well, somewhat of a mess. The father, a wonderful character, sees an ad in the newspaper and decides to hire a housekeeper from the Midwest. That, as they say, changes everything. Rose arrives in splendid dress with, as a surprise, her brother, Morrie Morgan. If the father is a wonderful character, Morrie Morgan is phenomenal. With a grand handlebar mustache and a personality to match, Morrie is a bit of an enigma. He is brilliant, or at least highly educated. Together Rose and Morrie teach the Millirons a lot about life. My frustration with this book was its lack of focus. The first two chapters are backstory about the Milliron men. (Only a renowned author could get away with that.) The story is told mostly in flashback from the first person POV of the oldest son, so naturally we think of him as the protagonist. But ... the back cover of the novel leads an uninformed reader to think the story is about Rose, the housekeeper, who doesn't arrive until Chapter Three. Rose does play a vital role, but this book is billed (on Goodreads, et al) as "the first of three Morrie Morgan books." In fact, I learned at my book club discussion that the Milliron family isn't even in the two other Morrie Morgan books. Other than The Great Gatsby, this is the only book I can think of where the narrator is not the protagonist (and The Great Gatsby has a good reason for that). You see why I say the book lacks focus.I imagine if a reader knows the book is really about Morrie, they might just fall in love with it. For me, Three and a half twinkling Stars (but I rounded up because of the beautiful writing)....more

title: I'm Not Her
author: Achterberg, Cara Sue*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'M NOT HER, by Cara Achterberg, is a captivating story about two 23-year-old women who "trade places," and are forced to live each other's life. The I'M NOT HER, by Cara Achterberg, is a captivating story about two 23-year-old women who "trade places," and are forced to live each other's life. The reader must suspend her disbelief, but that's easy because the premise is a familiar one: The movies TRADING PLACES and BIG used the same concept. But this novel cuts right to the core the themes of Who are we, really? and What makes us who we are? Achterberg strikes a nerve with these meaty questions, and she does it well.The two women in the story are polar opposites: Carin, the pretty, blond, wealthy, high-achieving, yet somewhat-miserable single girl; and, Leann, the obese, poor, unhappy, unhealthy, unhappily-married mother of a six-year-old. One day, when Carin is in Leann's check-out lane at the Shop N Save grocery store, a sign falls and hits Carin on her head. At that moment, the women "trade places." Carin, who knows nothing about being a mom, has no place to go except Leann's filthy, low-rent apartment. By the end of the first page, I couldn't stop reading to find out how each woman would fare in the other's world. Like all good books, the characters' situations go from bad to worse to OMG! This book is definitely a page turner.Achterberg is an excellent writer. The prose is clean and honest—deceptively simple, I like to say. I dog-eared and underlined numerous well-turned phrases. She truly gets inside the heads of both women, and writes the story with their alternating perspectives. She also nailed the voice of each woman (one educated, one who dropped out of high school). It's rare that a novel makes me stop and think as much as this one did. Achterberg (through her characters) asks the questions: What makes us who we are? Our mind, our body, and/or our situation? How much of "us" is defined by things we didn't choose for ourselves? We don't pick our parents or our hometown or our social class, but those factors generally define a person. Yes, some people are able to rise above any hardship and succeed despite our shortcomings, but not most people. I'm Not Her is a story I will recommend over and over. If every teenager in America read this book, I think our country would be a better place. FIVE shining STARS...more

title: The Paying Guests
author: Waters, Sarah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE PAYING GUESTS, by Sarah Waters, is a powerful story, but so not what you might expect.Waters is an incredible writer. Her observations, descriptioTHE PAYING GUESTS, by Sarah Waters, is a powerful story, but so not what you might expect.Waters is an incredible writer. Her observations, descriptions, and mastery of language is some of the best I've ever heard/read (I listened to the audio version). Truly beautiful writing. And the story? Oh, the story ... Set in London just after WWI, The Paying Guests starts out as a sad but realistic account of an upperclass woman named Frances Wray. Frances lost her two brothers and her father in the war, so now she lives with her mother in their large but deteriorating home on Champion Hill. After discovering that the father squandered their family fortune, Frances and her mother are forced to lay off their servants and take in boarders. Okay, so it's historical fiction. Check.Their boarders, a young married but childless couple, Lillian and Leonard, move into the Wray's home. They are just slightly younger than Frances. As we might guess, shenanigans happen. Frances falls in love. Then we get a handful of surprisingly graphic sex scenes. (Is this the path that Fifty Shades of Grey paved?) Anyway, okay, so it's a tangled romance novel. With a twist. Check.Then, someone dies. In fact, they are murdered. The guilty party/parties go to great lengths to cover up the murder, but in the end, it is discovered and the book turns into a courtroom drama. When an innocent man is put on trial, the guilty person(s) must deal with enormous amounts of ... guilt. Will the man be convicted? Will the real killer step forward? Will the lovers prevail or end up hanged for murder? Okay, so it's a courtroom drama. Didn't expect that! The Paying Guests is nearly 600 pages long (21 hours to listen). Though it's an interesting story, and beautifully written, I think it was at least a hundred pages too long. Frances does an enormous amount of whining! I had to fast forward through one section because I just couldn't bear the "oh poor me" syndrome. And I'm a bit surprised by the title. I don't think it aptly describes the real story here. I think The Paying Guests would have benefitted from a more-ruthless editor.Four roller-coaster Stars...more

title: Last Word
author: Blum, Jonathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: LAST WORD, by Jonathan Blum, had the same emotional impact on me that A Prayer for Owen Meany, by John Irving, did. For both books, I was reading and LAST WORD, by Jonathan Blum, had the same emotional impact on me that A Prayer for Owen Meany, by John Irving, did. For both books, I was reading and reading and reading, then suddenly, bang!, you understand what's been happening all along. In Owen Meany, that bang doesn't hit until about page 600. Thankfully, Last Word is much shorter (only 86 pages long), and that bang hits about page 84.Last Word is the story of the Langers, a Jewish family: Kip, the father; Eric, his chubby thirteen-year-old son; Andi, the second wife; and their two younger daughters. Eric is having trouble at his private Jewish academy, and the parents are continually being brought in to discuss his behavior. The story takes place over most of a school year, so at only 86 pages, Blum has done a remarkable job of focusing on just this one storyline. The book is very well written. The father in this book upset me—I imagine he was supposed to upset me. He was so out of touch with his son that I wanted to shout at him. Like Annie Proulx (and many other writers), Blum has, in a way, used the setting for this story (inside a strict Jewish family and school) as another character; it's that integral to the story. Not being Jewish, I was ignorant of some of the words/holidays/traditions and history that were referred to often. That didn't detract from the story, in fact, it opened a door to a rich world that I know very little about, but I did feel like an outsider.This book has stuck with me since I finished it. It brought out quiet but real emotions in me. Because of that (especially because I don't think I am even Blum's target audience and I was still emotionally moved), Last Word earns ... Five Stars...more

title: The Sense of an Ending
author: Barnes, Julian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: No man ever steps in the same river twice. —Heraclitus No woman ever reads the same book twice. —Karolyn SherwoodI recently finished THE SENSE OF AN ENo man ever steps in the same river twice. —Heraclitus No woman ever reads the same book twice. —Karolyn SherwoodI recently finished THE SENSE OF AN ENDING, by Julian Barnes, for the second time. The first time, I loved it. The second time ... I still loved it, but I took issue with a few things. TSOAE is the story of Tony Webster, a sixty-ish Englishman who is bequeathed five hundred pounds from his college girlfriend's mother whom he met only once. Tony has no idea why she thought of him at all—he hasn't even seen the ex-girlfriend for forty years—so he sets off to figure it out. This introspective journey turns into a mystery of sorts, which makes the already short novel (155 pages) read very quickly.The primary theme of TSOAE is memory, and how it warps and wafts with time. There's also a secondary theme, and that is remorse, which Barnes describes as, "A feeling which is more complicated, curdled and primeval. Whose chief characteristic is that nothing can be done about it: too much time has passed, too much damage has been done, for amends to be made." (p108) This second idea makes the novel a sort of cautionary tale: Be careful with your words and deeds because they are more powerful than a young person might imagine and cannot be undone. TSOAE won the Man Booker prize in 2011. It was Barnes' fourth nomination, and first win. There's no question he's an excellent writer, and this is a wonderful story. My teeny, tiny knock against it is that what I originally read as wise and eye-opening became pedantic on my second reading. Others in my book club described it as painfully slow, but I disagree with that. I consider it literary. (Maybe that's the same thing?) Anyway, TSOAE is chockfull of brilliant thoughts, lines, and perspectives on life. Although it's not quite as brilliant as I thought the first time I read it, I still give itFive twinkling StarsI wonder what I'll think if I read it a third time....more

title: Station Eleven
author: Mandel, Emily St. John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: STATION ELEVEN, by Emily St. John Mandel, is a fantastic book in so many ways. The plot is fresh, the pace is quick, the writing is superb. I could baSTATION ELEVEN, by Emily St. John Mandel, is a fantastic book in so many ways. The plot is fresh, the pace is quick, the writing is superb. I could barely put the book down. Time after time, Mandel nailed keen observations of today's world ... and then created a world in which everything humanity has become dependent on is simply gone. Then, of course, she gave us characters to care about, people who we want to survive and thrive. The book opens in modern day Toronto. An actor named Arthur Leander is playing King Lear and dies of a heart attack on stage. That is where we meet Jeevan and Kirsten and Arthur's circle of friends and family. That same night, the "Georgia Flu" arrives with a planeload of Europeans and proceeds to decimate 98% of the human population. The novel jumps back and forth from Year Twenty (of the post-flu era) to Arthur's life from about age seventeen until his death on stage. The survivors suffer a much hotter climate, illness without antibiotics, and other people who turn evil in order to survive. In an extremely realistic vein, one man leads "his people" as The Prophet. All that being said, I feel Mandel lost an enormous amount of impact with her ending. I don't want to give too much away, but I kept waiting for certain characters to meet, and maybe even fall in love. One of the stars of the first chapter (the character I first fell for) never really showed up again. Plus, some of the bad guys died too easily. There are more picky little things like this, but I don't want to elaborate. These small complaints should not keep you from reading this book, because it's really, really good.Four compelling Stars...more

review: AS NIGHT FALLS by Jenny Milchman is a gripping tale of a family torn apart. The scariest element of this book is that Sandy, the protagonist, could beAS NIGHT FALLS by Jenny Milchman is a gripping tale of a family torn apart. The scariest element of this book is that Sandy, the protagonist, could be me. Or you! She's an ordinary working mother, with an ordinary husband and an ordinary daughter—until they're thrown into an extraordinary situation. One snowy night, two escaped convicts invade their home and take over their lives. In a single night, secrets are revealed, emotional walls are broken down, and we see what these characters are made of, all at the same time. Better still, this story has a twist about half way through that I did not see coming. Apparently some readers weren't as surprised as I was, but even if you guess the twist, it doesn't ruin the story. From that point on, the story gets more and more intense and really bad things get worse. (I can't say more without adding spoiler alerts.)As Night Falls is a great book for anyone who likes homegrown thrillers! Well done, Jenny!Four Frightening Stars...more

title: Go Set a Watchman
author: Lee, Harper
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: GO SET A WATCHMAN, by Harper Lee is an important book, and I urge every fan of To Kill A Mockingbird to read it. For anyone who has heard that the illGO SET A WATCHMAN, by Harper Lee is an important book, and I urge every fan of To Kill A Mockingbird to read it. For anyone who has heard that the illustrious, heroic Atticus Finch is portrayed as a racist here, and therefore refuses to read it, I say, Open your eyes to the bigger picture. For those who don't know this already, Go Set A Watchman was written BEFORE Mockingbird. As the story goes, young, eager Harper Lee presented GSaW to her editor who read it and, instead of having her rework it, she asked Harper for the story about what happened to Scout Finch as a child. That story became the Pulitzer Prize winning novel, To Kill A Mockingbird. In other words, if the manuscript of GSaW hadn't had so many problems, we might never have gotten To Kill A Mockingbird. Imagine ...GSaW takes place when twenty-six-year-old Scout (now called Jean Louise) Finch goes home to Maycomb, Georgia, for a two-week visit. She now lives and works in New York City, and has new eyes with which to see her backwards hometown. And what she sees horrifies her. What she sees is real, not the glossy-eyed, little-girl view of her righteous father. Yes, it's upsetting to everyone who also held Atticus Finch as the Good Man during the difficult racist years of the early 20th century in the South. But here's the thing ...GSaWatchman paints a truer picture. It tells us what was True in the 1950s in the South. Anyone who doesn't want the truth, the whole truth, is not being open-minded. The truth is important, even if it hurts. But exploring the bigger picture opens our eyes to issues that seem to be presenting themselves all over again with the tragedies happening in Syria and the entire Middle East. it's easy to draw parallels between the tensions between the blacks and whites in the South, and the "potential" Syrian immigrants today. That's one reason this book is important.As a stand alone book, Go Set A Watchman would probably not have been published today if it hadn't been written by The Harper Lee. It rambles, it's unfocused, and it switches between third-person and first-person without warning. Yet Lee's passion and potential ring out so clearly here that it's obvious she was destined to write an important novel—who knew it would be her first published book?Three Stars (if taken as a stand alone book)...more

title: The Mask        (Vanessa Michael Munroe, #5)
author: Stevens, Taylor*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have read every one of Taylor Stevens' Vanessa Michael Munroe novels, and THE MASK is her best one yet. The story is focused and perplexing, and SteI have read every one of Taylor Stevens' Vanessa Michael Munroe novels, and THE MASK is her best one yet. The story is focused and perplexing, and Stevens' writing is terse yet smooth.For the uninitiated, Vanessa Michael Munroe is a tall, strong woman who can pass as a man when she so chooses. Michael, as she is then called, is an "informationist": she finds information for her clients. Her work is complicated, dangerous, and often violent—extremely violent. Munroe was raised in Africa by missionary parents and tortured as a young girl by evil men. She survived that childhood and now carries her anger, intuition, and survival skills with her. (Think female Jason Bourne.) The Mask takes place in Osaka, Japan, where Munroe has gone to visit her boyfriend, Miles Bradford. Bradford, a security contractor, is working for a tech company that suspects one of its employees of selling trade secrets. Soon Bradford is arrested (framed) for murdering one of the employees, and carted off to prison. Munroe must step in (as Michael) to determine who really killed the employee, and at the same time, she must determine who is selling the secrets because the two crimes are linked.Another reason I think The Mask is Stevens' best novel yet is that her character, the kick-ass, not-afraid-to-kill Vanessa Michael Munroe, has become more complicated. In The Informationist, Stevens' first novel, Munroe killed a lot of people. (Note: James Cameron's production company has bought the movie rights for all of Stevens' Munroe stories!) In this novel, Munroe has become less-eager to kill. She still does, but she now lets the minor bad guys live. Munroe has developed a conscious about killing, and does so only when absolutely necessary—when her life or another innocent person's life is on the line. One thing is sure: Stevens, and by extension Munroe, is brilliant. You have to stay focused when you read her novels. The story here is complicated, and the players numerous, but Stevens excels when she writes the most violent scenes. In those, you feel Munroe's pain, motivation, and rage. Stevens spent many unpleasant years in Japan herself, and the personal flavor she brings to this story comes blasting through.Five Unmasked Stars...more

title: Summerlong
author: Bakopoulos, Dean
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: SUMMERLONG, by Dean Bakopoulos, is a great read. The story is poignant and weighty, but Bakopoulos has written it in a way that keeps it from being doSUMMERLONG, by Dean Bakopoulos, is a great read. The story is poignant and weighty, but Bakopoulos has written it in a way that keeps it from being downright sad or depressing. It felt a bit like a Shakespearean comedy in that the characters are so active we almost forget their world is imploding.Summerlong is the story of Don and Claire Lowry who live in Grinnell, Iowa (which happens to be just an hour down the road from me). Don Lowry is a realtor who has lost everything due to the Great Recession. Claire is a novelist—or rather, she wrote one novel ten years ago. In other words, both of them have hit rock bottom, and now their marriage is crumbling. One day Don Lowry (as he's called throughout the book) stumbles upon a young girl called ABC who has also hit rock bottom. Her lover died, and now she wants to die. That same night, Claire meets Charlie, a guy who has returned to this tiny Midwestern town to clear out his father's office. (Yes, Charlie, a failed actor, has hit rock bottom, too.) So Don Lowry and ABC start "a thing," and Claire and Charlie start a thing. Oh, and Charlie and ABC start a thing. (read: varying levels of flirtation --> hooking up). They all smoke weed, and drink, and wander through the night, and skinny dip, and ... You get the picture. They're busy!What I liked best about this book is that the main characters seem real; they are really hurting, and they're finding ways to ease their pain. Anyone who's been through a bad breakup will relate. (Some of the minor characters seem less realistic.) We keep turning the pages because Bakopoulos gives us hope that Claire and Don might reconcile. Do they? Read the book to find out!Four Hot Hot Stars P.S. Did I mention there was a lot of sex?!...more

title: The Dinner
author: Koch, Herman
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow. Talk about psychotic characters! THE DINNER, by Herman Koch, is a story that grows more shocking and more disturbing the more you analyze it. KocWow. Talk about psychotic characters! THE DINNER, by Herman Koch, is a story that grows more shocking and more disturbing the more you analyze it. Koch (will someone PLEASE tell me how he pronounces his last name?!) weaves in details and backstories about his four main characters in the most distinct yet subtle way. I rank his story/character skills right up there with Patricia Highsmith and Kazou Ishiguro, two of my all-time favorites. Koch has a keen, cutting view of humanity; it is in turn, both honest and chilling.The Dinner is the story of two brothers and their wives who go out for dinner to discuss a situation their sons are involved in. (That's like calling a tiger a kitten. It's a pretty serious "situation.") The adults' solutions are as diverse as North, South, East, and West. And at least two of the four suggestions will rip the tablecloth out from under your dinner plate. Koch adds another layer, though: the structure. The novel takes place over dinner, one single, elegant meal—plus quite a bit of backstory parsed out as slowly as the pompous waiter serves the meal. It starts with the Aperitif and continues through the Digestif. With each course, we learn a tiny bit more about each character, until it feels like Koch dumps a pot of stew on the table that splashes on the two couples and you, the reader. If you like shocking, disturbing, perfect stories, you will love this book.Five (Michelin) Stars...more

title: Twelve Women in a Country Called America
author: Cherry, Kelly
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Kelly Cherry has created twelve characters so real one might think these are true tales of women she knows. In TWELVE WOMEN IN A COUNTRY CALLED AMERICKelly Cherry has created twelve characters so real one might think these are true tales of women she knows. In TWELVE WOMEN IN A COUNTRY CALLED AMERICA, each story is distinct, realistic, original, and powerful. Every story says something real about women, families, and life in general. The twelve women range from young to old, single to married, straight to gay, mothers to non-mothers, poor to wealthy, and on and on. And Cherry gets them all right. Of the twelve stories, I have my favorites, of course. "Au Secours" is about a wheelchair-bound woman who awaits her husband's return from prison—he shot her and left her paralyzed. It goes from sad to tragic in a very realistic way. "The Starveling" is another favorite. It tells the story of Calista, a woman whose mother left home when Calista was six. Now Calista must sort through her distorted definitions of love (motherly, and also romantic) in order to learn to love herself. But I underlined, dog-eared, and starred many passages in every story. Cherry, who has also published many books of poetry, has created beautiful phrases, poignant observations, and amazing insights. She is an excellent observer of humanity.As a disclaimer, this book was given to me pre-publication. (I was asked to read it to consider it for my book club; It would be an excellent choice!) But that does not alter my opinion; to be honest, I didn't expect to like it. I'm not a huge fan of short stories (I prefer epic novels), and I have no affinity for the South (I've never spent much time there). So for me to say I loved this book—and to give it five stars—means that it is truly a wonderful book. I highly recommend it.Five star-spangled Stars!...more

review: THE ROSIE PROJECT, by Graeme Simsion is a delightful, entertaining book. It would be an excellent light-hearted choice for a book club because it doesTHE ROSIE PROJECT, by Graeme Simsion is a delightful, entertaining book. It would be an excellent light-hearted choice for a book club because it does have a serious and controversial overarching subject.This is the story of Don Tillman, a thirty-something geneticist with Asperger's Syndrome, though he doesn't recognize it in himself. Don is on a mission to find a wife, so he has created "The Wife Project," a self-created online questionnaire for women so he will know if they are worth his time to take on a date. (Due to his Asperger's traits, his daily schedule is of utmost importance.) One day, a woman named Rosie walks into Don's office. He thinks she's there for the Wife Project and arranges for them to go out for dinner. Rosie is, predictably, the opposite of what Don has determined his "perfect" wife would be. He recognizes her as "attractive," but he immediately dismisses her as a potential wife. Instead, they embark on the "Father Project" to find Rosie's true father (Rosie's now-deceased mother told her that she was the product of a fling). Though this book is very well written, it is predictable and counts on more than a few coincidences. That said, I really liked this book. Plus it's short enough to squeeze into a busy TBR list. I'd recommend it to men and women looking for a good read.Four (and a half) rosy stars....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book came highly recommended to me. I wish I had liked it as much as I thought I would. THE LIKENESS, Tana French's second "Dublin Murder Squad" This book came highly recommended to me. I wish I had liked it as much as I thought I would. THE LIKENESS, Tana French's second "Dublin Murder Squad" book, is captivating and entertaining, but upon critical , I found it lacking ... or at least, it didn't live up to my expectations.The premise behind The Likeness is this: A girl is found dead. Just so happens she looks exactly like a detective in the Dublin Murder Squad. (The first of many coincidences!) To find her killer, the lead detectives pretend the girl didn't die and send their detective in to live as the dead girl in hopes of freaking out the killer. If we can take the leap of faith that two strangers can really look that similar, then this is a great start. (In fact, there's an artist named Francois Brunelle who's doing a book of photographs of unrelated twins. It's freaky and fantastic, and helped me go with this premise.) But the story is so complicated that it's extremely confusing: the dead girl was actually pretending to be a fictitious girl that the detectives created years ago for another undercover case ... yeah, exactly. If it hadn't been explained to me in advance, I'm not sure I would have made it to page 50. There are also references to character names and police cases that may have been subjects in French's previous book (In the Woods), but I haven't read that and she didn't explain them well enough to make it clear. As I pushed on, I realized the premise is extremely similar to The Secret History, by Donna Tartt. One character "infiltrates" a group of intelligent but odd college students who have banded together in a creepy way. Then one of them dies and we watch the survivors implode. Great idea, but The Likeness felt to me like a watered down version of the phenomenal The Secret History. That said, French sprinkled in some wonderful truisms and observations on people and the world, and I highlighted many sentences that rang true to life. In the end, I felt this book was a hundred pages too long. Many scenes could have been eliminated or condensed to make the story more clear and powerful. If you like puzzles and are willing to suspend your disbelief, then you might like this book. I hope to read more of Tana French's work someday because I think she has a lot of talent (she just needs a better editor).(Three and a half, rounded up to, like, ...) Four Stars...more

review: THE NIGHTINGALE, by Kristin Hannah, is a wonderful novel. Hannah paints the scenes, fills them with aromas, then leads the reader on a journey along wTHE NIGHTINGALE, by Kristin Hannah, is a wonderful novel. Hannah paints the scenes, fills them with aromas, then leads the reader on a journey along with the characters. The novel is "appropriately" heavy, yet it's a love story, too. It carries a gravitas I didn't expect.I didn't think I would like this book as much as I did. After recently reading All The Light We Cannot See, by Anthony Doerr, (also a book about innocent people in France during WWII) that won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction, I thought The Nightingale would pale in comparison. I can't say it was as good as Doerr's book, but it was beautiful and heartrending in its own way.The Nightingale is the story of two sisters: Vianne, the older, wiser, married sister; and Isabelle, the younger impetuous rebel. The girls' mother died when they were little, and their father, emotionally ruined from WWI and his wife's death, sent them away to be raised by others. They both have issues with him. Now, Isabelle wants to fight the Germans, so she joins the Resistance. But Vianne, a mother, wants to keep her head down, protect her children, and follow the new government no matter how much she must suffer for it. These characters (all the characters) and their actions and motivations ring true. As Vianne suffers the long, brutal winters with no heat and little food, my heart hurt for her. I cannot imagine the hell people suffered at the hands of the Nazis, but Hannah made me feel their pain. Isabelle may have outstretched reality a tad, but was valiant and brave and heroic all the same.Four (and a half) Stars...more
