title: The Buried Giant
author: Ishiguro, Kazuo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE BURIED GIANT, by Kazuo Ishiguro, is a multi-layered fable that takes place in rural England, circa 600 A.D. Ishiguro, one of my favorite authors, THE BURIED GIANT, by Kazuo Ishiguro, is a multi-layered fable that takes place in rural England, circa 600 A.D. Ishiguro, one of my favorite authors, tells the tale of an elderly British couple, Axl and Beatrice, who go in search of their long lost son. However, they can't remember much about him (or anything else for that matter) because Querig, a mystical she-dragon breathes a mist that has erased everyone's memory. Along their journey, they meet and are joined by three people: Edwin, an orphaned Saxon boy; Wistan, a Saxon warrior on "an errand" to slay the dragon; and an elderly knight named Gawain, also on a quest to destroy the dragon.Ishiguro writes in a beautiful voice (one of his best qualities), and thus this is literary fiction at its finest. The loving couple, Axl and Beatrice, though eager to find their son after all these years, realize that if Querig is indeed slain, they will be able to remember their worst memories as well as their best memories. But their love today is so strong they promise themselves they will not relive or rekindle their bad memories because whatever happened, at least they now know they made it back to each other. That's pretty sweet—but will they be able to keep that promise?On a broader level, we have the Saxons who, shortly before our story takes place, were vicious enemies of the Britons. Because of Querig's fog of forgetfulness, the two factions are now able to be friendly. But they too know if Querig is slain, there will be repercussions; their people will once again be on a rampage to slaughter each other and their women and children.Thus we have the story: Is it better to remember the past, and atone for our sins? Or is it better to forget and move on? Ah, an excellent discussion for a high-level book club! Ishiguro argues both sides of that question in this story. And he does it perfectly. Five Giant Stars...more

title: The Girl on the Train
author: Hawkins, Paula*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN, by Paula Hawkins is a whodunit-beachread. If you want a mystery to devour, this is the book for you. If you liked Gone Girl, thTHE GIRL ON THE TRAIN, by Paula Hawkins is a whodunit-beachread. If you want a mystery to devour, this is the book for you. If you liked Gone Girl, this is the book for you. Because that's exactly what this is: Gone Girl fan fiction. I'm sure the use of the word "Girl" in the title was intentional. I won't say I disliked this book, but I will say it's derivative. Rachel is the girl who rides the train (to and from London) each day to a non-existant job. She was fired because she's an alcoholic. Perhaps Hawkins was trying to say something about the evils of alcohol, or perhaps she just needed an excuse to make the protagonist an unreliable narrator. Now, I like unreliable narrators, but Rachel's talk of acquiring/drinking/recovering from her alcoholic binges became tedious over the first fifty pages. It wasn't until page 54 (I read the ebook version) that this story got rolling. That's when Megan, the woman that Rachel "stalks" from her train window each day, went missing. What I liked best about The Girl On The Train was that I couldn't guess who was responsible for Megan's disappearance. A good whodunit has to keep the reader guessing—and this did! Hawkins also threw in a few poignant and insightful lines that I loved. My favorite was something "Megan" realized while in therapy: "... the holes in your life are permanent. You have to grow around them, like tree roots around concrete ..." I believe that to be true, yet I'd never thought of it that way.Unfortunately, I felt Rachel was an unrealistic character, even taking her alcoholism into account. She inserts herself into the mess of solving the crime (I imagine most alcoholics would be too self-centered to go to the trouble). She makes unrealistic decisions (like the idiots in horror movies; you get the picture) that totally frustrated me. But maybe I expect too much ...Three and a half Stars (rounded to four because I can recommend this to my friends who want an exciting book but aren't as critical as I am)....more

title: The Color of Water: A Black Man's Tribute to His White Mother
author: McBride, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's difficult to argue with a well-told memoir. It's not like we can fact check it, or argue with people's own feelings and memories. But I found no It's difficult to argue with a well-told memoir. It's not like we can fact check it, or argue with people's own feelings and memories. But I found no faults with THE COLOR OF WATER, by James McBride. His is an amazing story. Or, more accurately, The Color of Water is the story of McBride's remarkable mother. If this were a fictional tale, you'd swear it couldn't possibly be true.McBride's mother, Rachel Deborah Shilsky, aka Ruth McBride Jordan, was a white, Southern, Jewish woman who had twelve children from her marriages to two black men. Dennis McBride, her first husband and father of eight children, died of cancer just before James McBride was born. Ruth met Hunter Jordan shortly after Dennis's death. They married and had four more children. When James was fourteen, his step-father died of a stroke. Ruth was left with twelve biracial children and no money. So you know what she did? She kept herself together, kept her children focused on school and Christ (whom Ruth had found when she married her first husband), and got them all through college—all of them. They became doctors, professors, computer engineers, and at least one (James), a writer, who recently won the National Book Award for Fiction. Then Ruth earned a degree in Social Work from Temple University at age 65. The tragic tale of Ruth was told without sympathy, anger, or blame. McBride relayed his mother's story, juxtaposed with his own—so eloquently that it felt he was here, on my living room sofa, talking about his "mommy," as he still calls her. The title comes from Ruth herself. When a young James began questioning his mother about race, she deflected his questions. When he asked what color God is, she replied, "God doesn't have a color. God is the color of water. Water doesn't have a color." Don't get me wrong, this is a sad story. The struggle, violence, racism, and hatred that Ruth and her children endured is heartbreaking. But it couldn't have been told any better than this.Five Colorful Stars...more

title: Can't We Talk about Something More Pleasant?
author: Chast, Roz
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is painfully honest. The fact that it's told as a graphic novel (read: comic book) makes it readable, even through the sadness. Because Roz This book is painfully honest. The fact that it's told as a graphic novel (read: comic book) makes it readable, even through the sadness. Because Roz Chast is a cartoonist for "The New Yorker," to name one of many publications she has graced with her talent, it follows that her memoir would be a graphic novel. It's her "voice," if you will.CAN'T WE TALK ABOUT SOMETHING MORE PLEASANT? is the story of the decline and death of Roz's parents. She has no siblings, so as her parents aged (they were married for 69 years), she was the only one to take care of them. As the children of Russian immigrants, her parents, George and Elizabeth, lived in Brooklyn. Fortunately, even as teachers they managed to save quite a bit of money. They both lived into their nineties and needed extensive care for the last few years of their lives. Elizabeth outlived her husband by two years and needed round-the-clock care for her final year. This story would be heartbreaking for any family, but the unique and excruciating element here is the fact that Roz did not have a happy childhood. Her parents (specifically her mother) were harsh. Elizabeth had a temper and she ran the show. Basically everyone was afraid of her. Roz could have sugar-coated the story, been sentimental and attempted to show her family in a rosy, Facebook glow, but she didn't. She was honest to the point of touching a nerve for anyone who has been in (or near) her shoes. Whether or not you've watched your parents age, requiring extensive medical treatment, you probably don't want to imagine the duty of having to bathe your ninety-year-old father. Or pay tens of thousands of dollars EVERY MONTH for their care home and nurses. These are the realities that Roz had to face. The most striking (for lack of a better word) situation that Roz relayed was concerning her mother (Page 176 in the hardback book). At that point, her mother had been in Hospice, essentially bedridden, with 24/7 care for several weeks. Roz was, naturally, mentally preparing for her mother's death. Then one day, Roz goes to visit her mother, and Elizabeth was sitting on the sofa, fully dressed and eating a tuna sandwich—all thanks to the help of a Jamaican nurse. To see her awake and revitalized was shocking, an emotional roller coaster. Roz admits how difficult it was adjust to her mother's resurgence, especially because these two were never close, never "friends." Instead, her decline stretched on for another year, thus draining Roz's emotional resources, her time with her family and work, and the funds her parents had saved. (If that sounds harsh to you, I imagine your parents are still young and healthy.)I read this book for my book club. I probably wouldn't have picked it up on my own for two reasons: first, because as the title states, this is not a pleasant subject; second, because my parents, specifically my mother, are now in their eighties and I can see the end approaching like a freight train in a tunnel. I don't want to think about their deaths. Worse yet (in my opinion) would be a slow, messy, amnestic death. But we don't get to choose. Bravo for Roz Chast for sharing her tale so honestly. In a way, she gives the rest of us permission to have conflicting emotions about the wild ride most of us will eventually have to take.Five weepy stars...more

title: We Are Water
author: Lamb, Wally*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I liked one line from the last page of WE ARE WATER, by Wally Lamb: "We are like water, aren't we? We can be fluid, flexible when we have to be. But sI liked one line from the last page of WE ARE WATER, by Wally Lamb: "We are like water, aren't we? We can be fluid, flexible when we have to be. But strong and destructive, too ... Like water, we mostly follow the path of least resistance." But that's it, that's the only thing in this entire book that I liked. I suppose I might have liked the original premise. I can imagine Lamb saying, "I want to write a story about a mother who leaves her husband, the father of their three grown children, and marries a woman. I want to tell that story." That could have been a good story, especially considering the woman is an artist who marries her art dealer. (As a former art dealer, I was eager for a dip back into those waters (no pun intended).)This is the first book of Lamb's that I've read so I don't know how it compares to his others. I "assume" they were different and much better because Oprah chose two of his previous books for her book club. However, I know this: This novel in five parts is told from the first person point of view of multiple characters in alternating narratives. There was quite a bit of "stream of consciousness" in the narrative which authors like Virginia Woolf did very well. These characters, though, came off as whiny idiots—especially the wife. Lamb made her sound like an eight-year-old with a mental disability. (That's as nice as I can state my true feelings.) He also failed the two daughters, especially the couple's youngest, Marissa. Is Lamb a misogynist?? The females were ridiculous, and he did marginally better with the male characters. Still, I EXTREMELY DISLIKED every character's dialogue, actions, reactions, motivations, and inner thoughts. This book was melodramatic to the point of being painful to read. The only reason I finished it is because I read it for my book club.One last point ... (This might be a spoiler, but I won't go into any details.) We find out through the course of the book that Annie, the wife, was sexually abused as a child. Lamb gives her abuser 50+ pages of his own, as he details the shitty life he had growing up. I imagine this was Lamb's acknowledgement that most pedophiles and rapists were also victims in their youth. BUT, the way Lamb delivers the abuser's story it comes across as if he's defending the man!! Like, Hey, readers, it's not really his fault. Look how life failed him first! Give me a bleeping break. One drop of a Star...more

title: 2 A.M. at The Cat's Pajamas
author: Bertino, Marie-Helene*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 2 A.M. AT THE CAT'S PAJAMAS by Marie-Helene Bertino would have been a fantastic short story. No book has ever made me want to be an editor more than t2 A.M. AT THE CAT'S PAJAMAS by Marie-Helene Bertino would have been a fantastic short story. No book has ever made me want to be an editor more than this one. I love the title and the premise of this book: Three disparate characters mashup fantastically in a unique setting. (That's essentially the premise of every Ann Patchett novel, and I love Ann Patchett.) The trouble with THE CAT'S PJs is that it lacks focus and Bertino tries way too hard to have a unique "voice." When I say "lacks focus," what I means is there are so many characters that it's nearly impossible to track what's happening to whom at any given moment. Soon enough, I just didn't care.The three main characters, all residents of Philadelphia, are Madeline, a nine-year-old motherless, blues-singing protégé; Sarina, Madeline's freshly divorced teacher; and Lorca, the owner of a nightclub called, yes, The Cat's Pajamas. The entire story happens in twenty-four hours, and the "chapters" are short, some as brief as a sentence or two. This makes for quick reading and an easy page-turner—a good thing because otherwise I probably wouldn't have finished it.My biggest gripe with the book, though, was the improbability factor. First, poor Madeline's widowed father is essentially comatose with grief. She is being "looked after" by a neighboring deli-owner woman who was a friend of Madeline's mother. Madeline's house is so filled with roaches that she names them. (How is the father who never leaves his bedroom paying rent?)(If Madeline is "so much like her mother," why isn't the dad enamored with her?) Second, in the first five pages we learn that Madeline is nine, and in fifth grade. Unless she's a girl-genius (she's not), she would be in third grade. Third, supposedly Madeline sang along with a Billie Holiday record absolutely perfectly "before she'd ever spoken her first word." WTF? I could go on with more and more examples of this nonsense, specifically Lorca's completely unrealistic relationship with his drug-addicted son Alex, but you get the picture.Bertino did scatter a handful of lovely truisms throughout the book, but for each one, I have a dozen passages underlined with negative comments—everything from my aforementioned "WTF?" to "This makes no sense to me." to "Ridiculous!," "Completely unrealistic!," "Who is this character again?" and "Why are we in the head of a dog?!" Because, yes, the novel is written in the omniscient POV to the point we even get into the head of a dog during one chapter. How did Bertino's editor let that happen? If they were going for funny/quirky, they should have referred to WHERE'D YOU GO, BERNADETTE, a funny/quirky novel that was at least well-written.Enough said. This book found an agent and a major publisher, so there you go.Two (and a half) stars...more

title: Strangers on a Train
author: Highsmith, Patricia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's a reason the USA Today named STRANGERS ON A TRAIN, by Patricia Highsmith, one of the greatest mysteries of the 20th century: because it is. HiThere's a reason the USA Today named STRANGERS ON A TRAIN, by Patricia Highsmith, one of the greatest mysteries of the 20th century: because it is. Highsmith, author of The Talented Mr. Ripley books, managed to combine "the perfect murder" set up with a perfect psychological profile in under 300 pages. It is the kind of book people want to read over and over because the brilliance is so subtle.Briefly, two men, Guy (an unassuming yet "genius" architect) meets Bruno (the bored and twisted son of a wealthy widow who is now married to a man Bruno hates) on an overnight train ride. Bruno comes up with the idea that he could murder Guy's cheating ex-wife, and as a quid pro quo, Guy could murder Bruno's stepfather. With enough inside information and no apparent motives both would get off scot free. Except it doesn't quite work like that. Not only is Highsmith's writing style impeccable, she also paints vivid scenes and detailed profiles of mentally disturbed characters. We quickly learn Bruno is crazy, and slowly realize that Guy is losing his mind as well. Plus, Highsmith makes the reader wonder if it's true that "anyone could commit murder under the right circumstances," even us!If you or a friend loves a classic murder mystery, this is an excellent choice. It was written in 1950, but the story is timeless.FIVE crazy STARS...more

title: A Great Deliverance        (Inspector Lynley, #1)
author: George, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I bought this book because it was on a list of the Greatest Mysteries of the 20th Century. Although Elizabeth George has written well over 20 books, II bought this book because it was on a list of the Greatest Mysteries of the 20th Century. Although Elizabeth George has written well over 20 books, I have never read any of them before this. Now I may have to search some of them out. Intelligent and well-written, A GREAT DELIVERANCE definitely earns its spot on the aforementioned list. It is layered and complex with several red herrings and complicated characters. I could barely put it down. Set in England in the mid-eighties, A GREAT DELIVERANCE is the story of Sergeant Barbara Havers and Inspector Thomas Lynley of Scotland Yard who are sent to York to investigate a murder. Nineteen-year-old Roberta Teys was found sitting beside the decapitated corpse of her father with an axe on her lap. She says, "I did it. I'm not sorry." Yet the case isn't that simple, of course. Not only are the suspects and central players varied and complex, so are Havers and Lynley and their respective families. George has linked the multitude of layers in this novel together so deftly that they become intertwined and begin to feed off each other. One interesting thing I noticed in the story is that George continually strikes contrasts. For instance, Havers is an unkept and brooding woman; Lynley is handsome and suave. We meet a set of sisters, again one is beautiful and one is frumpy. This continues with locations, buildings, and other characters. In the end, I think George was trying to make the case that the world is full of good and evil. My knock on this book is that it is so long and complex there were quite a few threads left untied. It makes me wonder if George's next book continued with some of the same characters. I guess I'll find out the next time I'm looking for a good mystery.Word of warning: The ending is difficult to read. It speaks to the most horrendous of crimes.Four mysterious Stars...more

review: THE MOVING TARGET, written in 1949 by Ross Macdonald, is classic noir. I bought the book because it was listed by USA Today as one of the top mysterieTHE MOVING TARGET, written in 1949 by Ross Macdonald, is classic noir. I bought the book because it was listed by USA Today as one of the top mysteries of the twentieth century. I liked it, but I wouldn't rank it that high. I wasn't familiar with Macdonald, but I am a fan of Dashiell Hammett (The Maltese Falcon) and Raymond Carver (The Big Sleep, etc.). Macdonald is said to have "inherited the mantle" of the two earlier greats; I can see that.Noir is an interesting genre. It was probably the prototype for the TV series Law & Order, et al. Each novel/episode fits a cookie-cutter mold. Hard-boiled detective seeks bad guy; insert lovely dame, big money, dark sets, and good people who end up being the bad people. The formula is extremely addictive. That being said, I got rather bored with this book. Not because it's not well-written with interesting characters (it is), but because it felt a bit like the James Patterson syndrome: change the names and cities, and I would think I've read it before.If you love noir, you'll love this book.Four dark stars...more

title: Never Let Me Go
author: Ishiguro, Kazuo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: NEVER LET ME GO, by Kazuo Ishiguro, is one of my five all-time favorite books. In fact, I think it may be the most powerful story I've ever read. The NEVER LET ME GO, by Kazuo Ishiguro, is one of my five all-time favorite books. In fact, I think it may be the most powerful story I've ever read. The beauty lies in Ishiguro's writing—as well as everything he doesn't write. He gives the reader no backstory until it's absolutely necessary. He lets the reader intuit so much of the story—and we do! He writes as if he has been living as the narrator (Kathy H.) for her whole life. Ishiguro is the master of this.Never Let Me Go is the quintessential "high-concept" book. Meaning, the true subject of this powerful story cannot be told without major spoilers. Here's what I can say: This is the story of three friends (Kathy, Tommy, and Ruth) in England in the late 1990s. The story is told from Kathy's POV, much of it in flashback. Ishiguro, most famous for his Booker Prize-wining Remains of the Day, gets Kathy's voice just right—she sounds like a sheltered 31-year-old woman, not the 50-year-old man Ishiguro was when he wrote the book. To that end, the only knock against this book is the disjointedness of the story; it repeatedly jumps from a present scene to a past scene as the narrative makes a particular point. But I believe Ishiguro wants us to feel disjointed. This is not a happy-go-lucky tale. (I imagine some people might hate it for the same reasons I love it.) Never Let Me Go touches on ethical and moral issues that are extremely divisive. If that's confusing and you want to know why, READ THIS BOOK. It's incredible.Five (five) Stars...more

title: And Then There Were None
author: Christie, Agatha
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How fascinating to see into the mind of such a brilliant mystery writer, for that is what AND THEN THERE WERE NONE does. It lets us see how Agatha ChrHow fascinating to see into the mind of such a brilliant mystery writer, for that is what AND THEN THERE WERE NONE does. It lets us see how Agatha Christie, the "Queen of Mystery," concocted the perfect crime. So perfect, she said in a later interview, that she realized she had to write an epilogue to the book so those of us who are not brilliant mystery writers could figure it out. The premise of this novel is well-known: A group of people are lured someplace and killed off one at a time until "there are none." Specifically, eight people are invited to a private island for a week-long vacation by a "Mr. Owen." The home has two servants. These ten are the only people on the island because their host never arrives. After their first evening meal, the butler is instructed (via a letter) to play a record. The record, instead of music, is a voice that lists the guests one by one and names people they are supposed to have killed. In other words, each of the ten people has secretly murdered somebody and gotten away with it. Then the guests begin to die, one after the other, according to an old poem about "Ten Little Soldier Boys" who die one at a time.Agatha Christie is the master of sprinkling red herrings and vital clues throughout her mysteries in order to throw the reader off track. I'll say she certainly fooled me! Only in retrospect did I say, "Of course that's how it had to happen." I felt the very ending was a bit farfetched, but not enough to lower my  of the story.Five Eerie Stars...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: LANDLINE is a funny, well-told story, with smart and insightful nuggets throughout. This is my first book by Rainbow Rowell, but it's easy to see why LANDLINE is a funny, well-told story, with smart and insightful nuggets throughout. This is my first book by Rainbow Rowell, but it's easy to see why her YA novels ELEANOR & PARK and FANGIRL got so much good press; she's quite the storyteller.LANDLINE (women's fiction with a splash of magical realism) tells the story of Georgie McCool, a comedy writer in LA who struggles with the balance of work and family. That story line isn't new, but the magical realism feature (a magical landline phone) makes it fresh and fun. The day the novel opens, Georgie must break the news to her husband and two young daughters that she can't go home to Omaha for Christmas because the sitcom she and her (male) writing partner has just been given the green light by a big network exec, and she must stay in LA to write the pilot. The male writing partner, as you might expect, also throws a complication into the story.Georgie is a lovable mess who can at times think brilliant thoughts, and at other times be frustratingly dense. In some passages, I felt like Georgie McCool might be the "Literary Character I Most Relate To." Other times I wanted to yell at her. I guess that proves I was emotionally invested. Score one for the author!I doubt LANDLINE will ever be considered a literary classic, but it's a very good book and I'm glad to have read it (or, specifically, listened to it as an audiobook).Four ringing stars....more

Both BIG LITTLE LIES and her last book, THE HUSBAND'S SECRET, strike the sweet spot between Women's Fiction and Thrillers. Plus, her writing is excellent.Set in Australia, Big Little Lies is a story about the death of a parent, told from the perspective of three mothers of kindergarteners. We get snippets of interviews with parents about the death throughout the book, yet until the very end, we don't know who it is that died. Or who the "murderer" is. Like the best thrillers, I didn't guess the ending before the author revealed it.The best part of Moriarty's story, though, is her character development; the characters seem so real I was constantly thinking they reminded me of people I know. title: All the Light We Cannot See
author: Doerr, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In many regards, ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr, is a perfect book. It is a textbook example of "literary fiction," yet it leads the reIn many regards, ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr, is a perfect book. It is a textbook example of "literary fiction," yet it leads the reader on an unputdownable journey through the hells of war, specifically the early 1940s in France and Germany.Let's start with the characters: Marie-Laure, a precious, curious, motherless young girl who loses her eyesight at age six; her father, a man who loves her so much he teaches her to be independent and brave; Werner Pfenig, a brilliant and curious orphaned boy, frail but too smart for the Nazis to ignore; Werner's sister Jutta, wise beyond her years and able to see good from bad; these are just a few of the fully developed souls of the story. The two main characters, Marie-Laure and Werner, don't meet until near the end of the book, yet ATLWCS feels like a love story because of the descriptive writing. Doerr has succeeded at one of writing's biggest challenges: He has mastered a lyrical yet distinct voice. The story, told in present-tense (so much harder to pull off than it sounds), puts the reader in the story, walking beside the characters through war-torn villages.The plot also amazed me. Doerr wove two independent stories into one, like a magic trick. We kind of know where the story is going, but then, Voilá!, it happens and we cheer. I fell so deeply into the world he created that I didn't want it to end. In fact, with twenty pages left, I made myself set it down because I didn't want it to be over yet. Do I have any quibbles with this book? Yes, but only because it's so near perfect that I studied every element, picking it apart with the hope of becoming a better writer myself. Any thoughts I had in this regard are too minor to mention.Five *Flaming Blue-diamond* Stars...more

title: Their Eyes Were Watching God
author: Hurston, Zora Neale
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THEIR EYES WERE WATCHING GOD by Zora Neale Hurston is no ordinary book. The first clue is the fact that it was written in 1937 and is still in print. THEIR EYES WERE WATCHING GOD by Zora Neale Hurston is no ordinary book. The first clue is the fact that it was written in 1937 and is still in print. The second clue is the blurb on the front cover by Alice Walker (THE COLOR PURPLE): "There is no book more important to me than this one." But still, I hadn't expected it to touch me so deeply.The bulk of the novel is told as a flashback by Janie, a beautiful biracial woman living in Florida in the 1930s. She is pushed, at age 16, into a loveless marriage by her grandmother, but soon leaves her husband for Joe Starks, a flashy man who promises her "riches." Indeed, Starks becomes mayor of a small town and gives her a life a "privileged" (yet miserable) life. He controls her. He is jealous and abusive. But as oppressed women often do, she stays with him and becomes a shell of a woman. When Joe Starks dies, Janie does not grieve. She soon finds a lively, younger man named Tea Cake. And, though everyone warns her off Tea Cake, he quickly becomes the love of her life. Janie is a romantic. She believes in flowers and spring and bees and love. But the best thing about Janie is she believes in herself. She knows as a child, a young woman, and into her second marriage that she deserves to be treated well—and to be loved. It's this belief that leads her to the relationship that lives up to her dreams and values. Janie and Tea Cake aren't just a married couple, they are best friends. This is rare and heartwarming. And it makes the tragic ending so much harder to take.THEIR EYES WERE WATCHING GOD is filled with brilliant thoughts and sentences, though I had to work a bit to get into it. It's told in an authentic dialect that takes several pages (chapters?) to get into. But I'm so glad I did. I can honestly say I related to Janie as much as any other literary character. This is a powerful, well-written story, and I will always remember it.Five Brilliant Stars...more

title: My Brilliant Friend        (My Brilliant Friend #1)
author: Ferrante, Elena
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Elena Ferrante's novel, MY BRILLIANT FRIEND, reads like a memoir; that's both good and bad. MY BRILLIANT FRIEND tells of the relationship between LilaElena Ferrante's novel, MY BRILLIANT FRIEND, reads like a memoir; that's both good and bad. MY BRILLIANT FRIEND tells of the relationship between Lila and Elena from age four until they are sixteen. There are not two but three more books in this series—a total of 1700 pages—about these two girls growing up in Naples, Italy, post WWII.Translated from Italian by Ann Goldstein, the story is descriptive and entertaining. Ferrante skillfully paints each scene so that we feel we are there, on the inner streets of a poor, desperate neighborhood. Not unlike children in American slums, each child (Elena, Lila, and their friends) must struggle to find his or her way to survive. Education, especially for young girls, must be fought for; most parents would rather their children work or help around the house. Abuse, physical, mental, and sexual, is rampant. Multiple scenes tell of shouting and beatings by fathers, mothers, even brothers.My favorite element of this book is the complex characters. The girls' friendship is co-dependant at best, dysfunctional or destructive at worst. Both girls are highly intelligent, though only Elena has the support and resources to continue her education beyond grade school. Lila both helps and hinders Elena with her schooling—her presumed "way out" of the neighborhood. Lila must find another way.The prologue of this book tells us that Lila, as an older woman, has disappeared. The ending is left so wide open that it's difficult to NOT pick up Ferrante's next book. However, I found the story a bit tedious. It's 325+ pages of scene after scene after scene of Elena's emotions and self-esteem being whipped around by her "friend." By the time I finished this book, I felt worn out.Another interesting point that can't be ignored is the story about "Elena Ferrante" herself. That's not her real name, and in fact she may not even be a woman. Ferrante never does interviews or public appearances. She believes the work should speak for itself. Many people, primarily Italians, believe she's a man. I'm not sure if it matters either way, but the mystery behind the pseudonym threatens to overshadow the story. Maybe that's his/her plan. An excellent marketing ploy, indeed. Four Stars...more

title: The Narrow Road to the Deep North
author: Flanagan, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My feelings about this book shock me. Let me start by saying that almost every sentence in THE NARROW ROAD TO THE DEEP NORTH, by Richard Flanagan, is My feelings about this book shock me. Let me start by saying that almost every sentence in THE NARROW ROAD TO THE DEEP NORTH, by Richard Flanagan, is lovely—even when he is describing the most horrific events of war. Flanagan's writing is evocative, lyric, and spare. He has incorporated many poems, mostly haiku, which lofts the novel into a higher realm. However, despite all the lovely sentences, I still didn't like this book. Seriously didn't like it. Largely based on true events as told by his father, Flanagan, an Australian who lives in Tasmania, depicted the war scenes so vividly I started to itch when he spoke of the lice that infected the soldiers. TNRTTDN has many characters, but the protagonist is Dorrigo Evans, a surgeon and an Australian colonel who is captured by the Japanese during WWII. As a colonel, he is in charge of the other Australian POWs at a camp in Siam (now Thailand). Their mission, under the hands of several ruthless Japanese soldiers, was to build a railway through Siam to Burma. Even today, this task is thought to be impossible, but these POWs were forced to attempt it in a fraction of the time it would have taken with heavy equipment, proper tools, and adequate food and clothing. Of course the POWs had none of those. The scenes are difficult to read, and even harder to fathom that much of it might really have happened. The story of the Australians as Japanese POWs is juxtaposed with Dorrigo Evans' life at home, before and after the war as he ponders why he is now a famous and lauded war hero. Dorrigo is a lost soul, a man in search of love. He marries a woman named Ella, but he's "in love" with a woman named Amy. When he's not with either of those two, he sleeps with whoever's handy. Now, I understand that characters are supposed to be complicated, but Amy, for starters, was the most ridiculous female in literature. Flanagan never showed me "love" between Evans and Amy (who was married to his uncle). They went from curious to lust to confusion to despair, and back to lust ... but never did they seem like they were in love. If one sentence said his love for her "defied poetry," the next sentence asked if he really did love her at all. And she was worse. She was supposedly so conflicted about her life and her love for her husband and Dorrigo that I finally had to skip her scenes altogether. I was honestly relieved to get back to the war scenes! They were horrifying, but the sections about Dorrigo's love life were horrible. Another oddity: Flanagan used the word "strange" so frequently that I have to wonder WTF. It was as if "strange" was a theme he was trying to subliminally weave into the novel, but if so, strange is a terrible word choice. It's entirely vague. It really means nothing—or too many things. It's not a theme. I think it was just sloppy writing and/or editing. TNRTTDN won the Man Booker Prize for Fiction in 2014, an award I highly respect. But I have no idea how or why they could have picked this book (politics, I suppose). I believe that the world was overdue to have a book that told the plight of the Australian involvement and POWs of WWII (I certainly learned a lot from the book), but the love story element ruined this book for me. Two Narrow Stars...more

title: The Bone Clocks
author: Mitchell, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How much influence do expectations have on a ? Too much, I'd guess. I had been waiting impatiently for THE BONE CLOCKS, by David Mitchell, for fHow much influence do expectations have on a ? Too much, I'd guess. I had been waiting impatiently for THE BONE CLOCKS, by David Mitchell, for four, five, six months—since the moment I saw it would be released in September. I expected to love this book ... but I didn't. Mitchell's 2004 novel, CLOUD ATLAS, is among my Top Five all-time favorite books. I have heard incredible things about his other work, too, (namely GHOSTWRITTEN and NUMBER9 DREAM), but I haven't read them because I've heard they were early (weak) variations of his masterpiece, Cloud Atlas.Well, so is The Bone Clocks. Like Cloud Atlas, Mitchell's latest novel is divided into six parts, each segment taking place years apart from the others. The Bone Clocks follows protagonist Holly Sykes through her life, beginning as a teenager in 1984, and ending in 2043 when she is an octogenarian. Holly has "heard voices" since she was seven. Because of this, she has drawn the attention of two warring factions of "atemporals," humans whose lives don't follow the standard rules for life and death. In fact, she becomes the nexus for an ultimate showdown between the two groups. Though I "cared" about her, I found her motivation throughout the novel rather timid.Every sentence in this novel is perfect, but what David Mitchell does best is Voice. He is brilliant at making each character sound unique. Plus, his imagination as far as settings, wild twists, and new worlds is phenomenal. However, (and then I'll stop beating this horse) none of the characters or futuristic scenes shine as brightly as they did in CA. As an example, in 2043, we no longer use cell phones, we use "devices." As in, "Device me when you're finished here." Device? I'm disappointed that Mitchell couldn't have found a unique or specific word to replace "phone." Although I have no way of knowing how I'd feel about The Bone Clocks if I'd never read Cloud Atlas, I can say that it falls short of his masterpiece. Thank goodness, though, that every writer doesn't follow Harper Lee's example of quitting after writing their masterwork, or the world would have missed out on a lot of great literature. If you haven't read Cloud Atlas, make sure you put it on your TBR list—today. If you have read Cloud Atlas, just lower your expectations for this novel. It's good, it's just not that good.Four Stars ...more

title: The Silkworm        (Cormoran Strike, #2)
author: Galbraith, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Robert Galbraith is the pseudonym JK Rowling uses for her Cormoran Strike detective series. We all know that by now, right? And most of us know that bRobert Galbraith is the pseudonym JK Rowling uses for her Cormoran Strike detective series. We all know that by now, right? And most of us know that before her cover was blown, the first novel in this series, THE CUCKOO'S CALLING, had paltry sales. It wasn't until the world discovered the true writer that these novels became bestsellers. I, for one, probably would not have picked up (hell, I probably would never have even heard of) The Cuckoo's Calling if not for the truth behind the pseudonym.THE SILKWORM is a good story, but not a great story. It's a well told, mentally challenging whodunit. In this case, a mediocre novelist is killed in the same, horrific manner in which the protagonist of his latest novel is murdered. There are a handful of potential killers, and Galbraith indeed fooled me. I had picked one character (in retrospect, I can see that Galbraith wanted me to guess the person that I did), yet when the real killer was revealed, I wasn't surprised. In fact, I was more disappointed in myself for not getting it right. However, the reason that crime shows and mysteries are so incredibly popular is not just about a particular case; it's because the audience/reader becomes connected to the detectives and their personal lives. Cormoran Strike is a deeply flawed, entirely sympathetic detective. His assistant, Robin, is eager and attractive. Galbraith teases us with their interaction. It's reminds me a lot of the old show MOONLIGHTING with Bruce Willis and Cybill Shepherd. They were attracted to each other, but never hooked up—until they did, which ruined the will-they-or-won't-they excitement. It seems to me that Galbraith is walking the fine line between detective series and literary fiction. I think I'd like the series better if "he" amped up the mystery and let go of the intellectual, psychological character development. What remains to be seen with the Cormoran Strike series is will I or will I not read them all. The novels are long, and simply not that exciting. Galbraith better kick this series into high gear! Four stars...more

author: Hustvedt, Siri
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: THE BLAZING WORLD, by Siri Hustvedt is a brilliant yet bizarre book. Its structure is unique, as are the voices of the characters.THE BLAZING WORLD isTHE BLAZING WORLD, by Siri Hustvedt is a brilliant yet bizarre book. Its structure is unique, as are the voices of the characters.THE BLAZING WORLD is the story of Harriet Burden, an artist with intense gender issues. As a child, Harriet was fearful and in awe of her father, as was Harriet's mother. As an adult, Harriet stands 6'2" and goes by the the nickname Harry. Interesting considering she blames her "failure" as an artist on the fact that she's a woman (maybe that's why she goes by Harry). Harry marries an art dealer named Felix and they have two children together, a daughter and a son. For years, Harry stood in her revered husband's shadow, and never reached the level of success that she felt she deserved. After Felix dies, Harry arranges three exhibitions of her work, though they are presented under the name of male artists, her beards. The first two go swimmingly; the third implodes. From there, Harry spins out of control of her life.Hustvedt must be a brilliant woman, possibly too brilliant for me. This story is told through interviews with Harry's friends and family, and excerpts from her diary entries—both sources bounce over philosophy, literature, art, and body fluids to the point that she lost me on multiple occasions. THE BLAZING WORLD is not a "pretty" story; I'm sure Hustvedt didn't want it to be pretty. While there are some bright and insightful lines throughout, I much prefer a good, old-fashioned, sink-into-the-story-like-it's-your-favorite-sofa kind of novel. This wasn't that.Three Stars ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Julia Fierro's debut novel, CUTTING TEETH, is literary fiction wrapped in the cloak of "mommy lit." The premise—a Brooklyn-based mommy group and theirJulia Fierro's debut novel, CUTTING TEETH, is literary fiction wrapped in the cloak of "mommy lit." The premise—a Brooklyn-based mommy group and their spouses and children spend a weekend at a beach house—is the backdrop for a character study of the parents. We learn about the five couples plus one nanny via their interaction with their children and each other. Wisely, what could have become a muddled mass of names and relationships was alleviated by a chart at the beginning of the book delineating the five families which I referred to countless times. Cutting Teeth has the flavor of an Ann Patchett novel: Throw a group of random people into an intense situation and see what happens: True personalities come out. For better or worse, the characters show us who they really are.Fierro, a graduate of the Iowa Writers Workshop, is an excellent writer. Her sentences and dialogue are flawless. Her character description is so detailed it's as if she were a psychiatrist revealing her clients' deepest secrets. This story is told via alternating narrators, eight of them. Each character has a distinct voice, personality and backstory. It had to be a complicated novel to write!Being a Midwesterner, I felt the characters were extreme, but ... Fierro is a Brooklyn-based mother herself, so I'm sure she knows what she's writing about. In fact, I'll bet fellow NYC mothers reading this book will laugh out loud at behaviors they've seen many times. This book will be most appreciated by parents of young kids—and might serve as a cautionary tale for their next vacation!Four Stars...more

title: Bend, Not Break: A Life in Two Worlds
author: Fu, Ping
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't read a lot of memoirs. So, BEND, NOT BREAK is either a perfect example of why I don't, or it's simply a terrible book. Ping Fu must be a brillI don't read a lot of memoirs. So, BEND, NOT BREAK is either a perfect example of why I don't, or it's simply a terrible book. Ping Fu must be a brilliant person. She apparently overcame great odds as a young girl in China, was then "quietly expelled" from China, and eventually succeeded in America as the head of Geomagic, a software company that works to create 3D products. This memoir, however, is poorly written (style-wise), full of inaccuracies (many since recounted by the author), and begs for, alternately, pity or admiration. It goes from "Poor, poor me," to "Aren't I amazing!" in 0 - 60 words. She generally takes all the credit for her successes, but none of the blame for her failures. For example, on page 260 of the paperback edition, she says, "Still, I don't know how my thesis research [on female infanticide in China] had gotten me in trouble." Really? Such a smart person, and yet she couldn't figure out why the Chinese government under Chairman Mao would object to that? Alternately ... on page 130, Ping Fu tells about the birth of her daughter: "The birth was easy. Nurses said that in all their years of midwifing, they had never seen a delivery like mine: I didn't push my baby out with cries of pain, but with hysterical laughter." Okay, people, I've had four children. The second one I delivered by myself at home (it happened that fast). Giving birth was easy for me, but NO ONE laughs their way through it. Trust me.If those examples aren't enough, I could cite numerous passages of Ping Fu's false modesty. To summarize the temporary failure/setback of her company, Geomagic, Ping blames her lack of confidence to trust herself. In other words, I am so smart, I should have never hired another CEO. He was just a front, and I would have done better. And, including this comment from Stuart Frantz, one of her board members: "I always thought you were a visionary, Ping. You're also psychic." just enforces her gigantic ego. I view this book as a failure and a bore. One Star....more

title: Deep Water
author: Highsmith, Patricia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I consider Patricia Highsmith to be one of my "literary idols." So, when Gillian Flynn picked DEEP WATER as her Wall Street Journal book club book, I I consider Patricia Highsmith to be one of my "literary idols." So, when Gillian Flynn picked DEEP WATER as her Wall Street Journal book club book, I bought it immediately. Yeah, I should have known: I didn't love GONE GIRL, therefore, I am not surprised that I didn't love DEEP WATER.Written in 1957, DEEP WATER is the story of Vic and Melinda Van Allen, an unhappily married couple living in Massachusettes. Melinda has one affair after another, right under Vic's eyes. He is, on the surface, completely unfazed by his wife's liaisons. While this story is interesting as a study of human nature, it is boring as hell as far as literature goes. It's only 227 pages—thank goodness—but the story is entirely tedious! The husband Vic is a very interesting, well-rounded character, but there is essentially no subplot. It's all about Melinda sleeping with every single single guy who moves into their tiny northeastern town of Little Wesley. Seriously, that's all it's about. Melinda has affair after affair, while Vic sits back and does nothing (until he does "something"). Highsmith's writing is clean and crisp, though the dialogue is stilted and overly formal. In light of STRANGERS ON A TRAIN, THE PRICE OF SALT, THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY, it's no wonder I'd never heard of DEEP WATER. It is certainly not one of Highsmith's better novels. I'm glad to have read DEEP WATER, but I can't give it more than Three Stars....more

title: That Night
author: McDermott, Alice
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Chapter one of this novel was assigned to me by a writing teacher as an example of a "promising" novel opening. In deed, the opening chapter presentedChapter one of this novel was assigned to me by a writing teacher as an example of a "promising" novel opening. In deed, the opening chapter presented an intriguing situation and left me with many questions about the rest of the story. So I bought the book. In brief, THAT NIGHT is about a teenage couple in the early 60s that is torn apart after the girl gets pregnant and sent away. Published in 1987, THAT NIGHT by Alice McDermott, is one of the rare books where the narrator is not the protagonist. The most famous example of this technique is F. Scott Fitzgerald's THE GREAT GATSBY. In that book, the protagonist, Jay Gatsby, dies before the end of the story—thus the reason he can't be the narrator. McDermott gives us crumbs of personal information about her chosen narrator (a young neighbor-girl who remains unnamed throughout), so little information, in fact, it made me beg for more, it made me keep reading to find out why this particular girl is telling the story. (We don't even know she's a girl until late in Chapter one.) By the end, I was disappointed that my questions were not answered satisfactorily. There are nothing more than vague reasons why this girl is telling the story. It feels forced, as if McDermott simply wanted to attempt a story like The Great Gatsby.McDermott sprinkles this novel with some beautiful, astute observations and clever ticks of humanity, though to pull them out of context to list them here would diminish their impact. My biggest issue with this novel was the POV. The narrator, the young neighbor, tells the story in an omniscient point of view. She tells us the story with God-like knowledge, getting in the minds and lives of the other characters, knowledge she simply couldn't know unless she was the protagonist's psychiatrist or pastor or ultimate best friend. She ends up being nothing more than a neighbor on that crucial night. I think McDermott should have either eliminated the narrator, or given us her viewpoint, not an omniscient voice.Ultimately, I feel this was a failed attempt at a challenging literary technique.Three Stars...more

title: In Cold Blood
author: Capote, Truman
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The true story behind IN COLD BLOOD, by Truman Capote, has haunted me for forty years. Capote artfully recaps the horrific, seemingly random murders oThe true story behind IN COLD BLOOD, by Truman Capote, has haunted me for forty years. Capote artfully recaps the horrific, seemingly random murders of a Kansas family in November, 1959. The book was published in 1966, and in 1967, it was made into a popular and highly acclaimed movie. You see, I grew up in Kansas in the 60s and 70s, and the story of the Clutter family murders was legendary in my little-girl world. The name alone "In Cold Blood," is intended to send a chill up your spine, as it did mine. I was too afraid to watch the movie or read the book—until now. IN COLD BLOOD is touted as the first non-fiction novel. (Novels are fiction, and tell a story with a plot. Theoretically, the reader wants to keep reading to find out how it ends. We, of course, know the ending of this story before we pick up the book.) The beauty of Capote's telling is that he reveals the facts in such a suspenseful, captivating way that the reader is continually engaged and fascinated. I think this is due to the chronological format Capote uses to walk us through the crime, the depth of the details he includes, and the way he alternates chapters between the investigators trying to solve the crime with the two criminals' life stories. He puts the reader in the story.Capote was a brilliant writer, and by all accounts a very colorful person; I would love to have known him. I picked this book up now for several reasons, not the least of which was to release my childhood ghosts. I'm very happy to have read it, but I suppose it didn't live up to its legend in my mind.Four bloody Stars...more

title: Defending Jacob
author: William Landay*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Once again, I wish Goodreads would let ers give half-stars. DEFENDING JACOB, by William Landay is a riveting story, but I can't say it was perfeOnce again, I wish Goodreads would let ers give half-stars. DEFENDING JACOB, by William Landay is a riveting story, but I can't say it was perfect. Nonetheless, in debating between four stars or five, I rounded up this time. DEFENDING JACOB is the story of fourteen-year-old Jacob Barber who is accused of killing a classmate. Jacob's father, Andy, is the Assistant District Attorney who would have been in charge of the case if it hadn't involved his son. This is a very well-written, unsentimental story. It is gripping and a bit scary—well, scary as in unsettling.Much like the technique Vladimir Nabokov used in LOLITA, Landay has the father narrate the story from a witness stand. We know he's testifying before a grand jury, but Landay peppers in anxious comments and oblique hints that there's more going on than just the trial of Jacob. This was brilliant. During Jacob's trial, we are never quite certain which way the jury will vote, guilty or not guilty. The primary characters, Jacob, Andy, and Laurie, the mother/wife, are so well-drawn that they feel like your neighbors. (I imagine that's why they have such common names.) Landay portrays the father's stern professionalism, the mother's emotional distress, and the teenaged boy's reticence so accurately that I felt I knew them. Plus, Landay adds a sense of humor in the early pages—where it still seems appropriate—that makes me think he could write for a sitcom if he wanted. Landay is an excellent observer of humanity.What's more ... The ending comes an incredible shock. Talk about a twist! It inches toward unbelievable, or maybe it begs for a sequel, but it was very powerful. It's one of those elements that make me want to talk to other readers to see what they thought about it. (To be more specific would be a major spoiler.)All that being said, DEFENDING JACOB was a bit too long. Landay was a lawyer/assistant district attorney before he began writing. In other words, he knows too much. I'm sure no good lawyer could stand to present a partial case, and I imagine that carries over into his writing. My biggest knock of this book is that the technical details of Jacob's trial bog it down a bit. I listened to this as an audiobook so I couldn't skip over the boring parts because it's difficult to flip back if you missed a key line. So, despite my minor grievances, I highly recommend DEFENDING JACOB, especially for anyone who likes courtroom dramas.Five Stars...more

title: Wonder        (Wonder, #1)
author: Palacio, R.J.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: WONDER, by R. J. Palacio is an important book. It addresses the inside life of Augustus, a severely disfigured young boy. Specifically, it follows himWONDER, by R. J. Palacio is an important book. It addresses the inside life of Augustus, a severely disfigured young boy. Specifically, it follows him through the fifth grade, his first year in a public school. It deeply explores his emotions, as well as those people close to him. WONDER is well-written and extremely touching. I challenge anyone not to get choked up at the end of this story (and possibly several places throughout). Palacio chose to give Augustus and several other key characters their own (First Person) chapter, thus getting inside each person's head one by one. This was probably the right decision, as it would have been tough to pull off an Omniscient point of view for all characters at the same time. My problem with this choice, however, was that it slowed down the narrative and made the story a bit tedious. So that Palacio could illustrate specific events through multiple characters' eyes, she had to repeat these key scenes multiple times. I also felt the narrative was a bit preachy at times; a little more subtlety might have made it a stronger book.Everybody has at one time or another encountered people with visible disabilities—whether it be a bald head due to chemotherapy, someone in a wheelchair, or someone, such as Augustus with a birth defect—and this book truly, deeply addresses that awkward moment. Because of this book, I will be better able to see these people as PEOPLE, not as their disability. I am very happy to have read WONDER. I recommend it.Four Stars...more

title: The Catch        (Vanessa Michael Munroe, #4)
author: Stevens, Taylor*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Taylor Stevens' hero, (Vanessa) Michael Munroe, is at it again! Munroe is a woman who typically dresses and behaves like a man to travel and work in aTaylor Stevens' hero, (Vanessa) Michael Munroe, is at it again! Munroe is a woman who typically dresses and behaves like a man to travel and work in a world that doesn't treat women well. Munroe is a troubled person. She grew up in Africa in an abusive and violent environment where she learned survival skills the hard way. Her childhood shaped her and has never left her. Instead, she uses the knowledge and skills she learned growing up to exact information from terrorists, kidnappers, and the like. In THE CATCH, Munroe has traveled back to Africa to keep herself away from the man she loves—because she brings violence and heartache to those she loves the most. She is soon forced to join the crew of a security team aboard a ship traveling through the pirate-infested waters off Somalia. When the ship is indeed taken over by pirates, Munroe is called to action to help good triumph over evil. I have read all of Stevens' novels, and can say THE CATCH is the most cerebral of her stories. For much of this book, the action takes place in Munroe's head. After being injured in an early fight, she must out-think and out-scheme several nefarious delegations, including Russian, Somalian, and Kenyan. If thriller heroes have "superpowers," Munroe's is her intelligence, with lightning fast reflexes as a close second. She speaks more than a dozen languages and can learn a new language in a matter of days. This is how she can play one team off the next while staying one step ahead of everyone. Stevens' writing is terse and gritty, just like Munroe. Any flowery or sentimental writing would be out of place here. Stevens, who herself spent much of her childhood in Africa, knows that continent and its ways very well. I referred to a map multiple times to get a better feel for where the action was happening. (I wish the publisher would print a map at the beginning of her novels!) If you like a brainy, thrilling story, you should read THE CATCH.Four thrilling Stars.[Note: I won an advanced copy of this novel in a contest, but would absolutely have read it anyway! No fan of Munroe's should miss this book!]...more

title: Stoner

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: STONER, by John Williams, is a near-perfect book—at least that's what I imagine English majors, grad students, and literary critics would say. Since ISTONER, by John Williams, is a near-perfect book—at least that's what I imagine English majors, grad students, and literary critics would say. Since I am none of the above, I can say this: Stoner is a near-perfect book, though I found it a bit ... quiet for my taste. If you've read very many of my other s on Goodreads, you know I prefer a stronger plot. STONER is the story of William Stoner, a Midwestern farmer who disappoints his family by studying English at college (and then becomes an English professor) instead of returning to the family farm. Stoner soon falls in love with a young lady he barely knows, marries her, and they have a child. Over the next forty years, Stoner's life is one disappointment after another. He lives a life of quiet desperation.The beauty of STONER is the study of humanity that Williams illuminates for us. He relays a depth of character that few writers can describe, from falling suddenly in love to falling painfully slowly out of love, from elation to depression, from isolation to escapism, and on and on. The levels of mood and thought that Williams touches on cross an impressive range. One unique quality that I noticed in STONER is Williams' use of oxymorons. Time and again, Williams describes people or events with adjectives such as: "safely irresponsible"; or, "a frail strength"; or, "a distant closeness." Taken out of context like this, they may seem reckless or nonsensical, but in the story, they shine a brilliant light on the characters. While this book for many reasons deserves FIVE STARS, I give it FOUR STARS for being a tiny bit tedious....more

review: I love Donna Tartt. I loved THE GOLDFINCH, 2013's Pulitzer Prize winner of Fiction, and I loved THE SECRET HISTORY, her debut novel. Having read both I love Donna Tartt. I loved THE GOLDFINCH, 2013's Pulitzer Prize winner of Fiction, and I loved THE SECRET HISTORY, her debut novel. Having read both books, I can say they share a theme of sorts: What does the weight of a secret do to your mind? THE SECRET HISTORY is the tale of Richard Papen, a smart but poor kid with negligent parents, who aches to assimilate with a group of five eccentric Classics students at a small Vermont college. These five—four boys and a girl who is a twin to one of the boys—are under the tutelage of Julian Morrow, a brilliant yet out-of-touch professor who does not prevent his insular class from taking their ancient studies to their extremes. Did the rituals of ancient Greeks create the myths they are so famous for? The story builds until the group has their answer; then chronicles the group's implosion as they deal with the consequences of what they learned, and what they did. Yes, things happened. Thus the history of their secret.Tartt has become one of my very favorite writers. Every sentence in this novel is perfect: packed with detail yet still lyrical. She has created seven unique characters (Richard, plus the five students, plus the professor). They are distinctly different, yet completely familiar. Each is drawn with his/her own voice, quirks, and responses to the pivotal point of the book. The conclusion is surprising yet completely realistic.About three-fifths of the way through the story, I felt it dragged a bit, but not enough to alter my opinion. Both Donna Tartt and The Secret History are incredible. If you like a deep, character-driven story with a page-turning plot, you will love this book.Five Stars...more

title: Middlemarch
author: Eliot, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Reading George Eliot's MIDDLEMARCH once won't be enough, though I'm thrilled to say I have indeed finished it. At 850 pages, and written in 1870, MiddReading George Eliot's MIDDLEMARCH once won't be enough, though I'm thrilled to say I have indeed finished it. At 850 pages, and written in 1870, Middlemarch is not for the feint of heart. It is deep and dense and arguably perfect. Many individuals and "Best Books" lists rate it as The Best Novel Ever Written. I don't disagree, once you get into it. Middlemarch enforces the adage "People never change." The emotions, reactions, behaviors, and inner thoughts of the characters are no different than any of us today. It further supports my belief that a person, any one specific person, CAN change; it's humanity on the whole that hasn't changed for at least hundreds of years. And that's what makes this book a classic for all time.Where to begin? First, George Eliot was the pen name of Mary Ann Evans, a mostly self-taught journalist and philosopher who later turned to fiction. She was a progressive, much too smart and headstrong to let the mores of her day stop her from fulfilling her ambitions which is why she published under a man's name. Her other notable books include SILAS MARNER, ADAM BEDE, and DANIEL DERONDA. (I admire her so much I named my dog George Eliot.)Middlemarch is a fictional village in the middle of England, filled with middle-class people. I imagine Eliot wanted to illustrate that every life is full and deep and complicated, not just Charles Dickens's orphans or Thackery's socialites. And so she sets off to tell us about seemingly every resident of the town. The novel began, however, as two separate novels of two specific characters, Dorothea Brooke, a "handsome" yet headstrong young woman; and Tertius Lydgate, a progressive doctor who seems to have no luck at all, so these two tie most of the others together. Eliot "knew" her characters better than (or as well as) any other novelist has ever known his/her characters.Middlemarch, the book, is a perfect example of the Omniscient point of view. The unnamed narrator knows all and tells all. The story is both broad sweeping and intimately specific. Eliot leads us so smoothly between characters that the book reads like a "single shot" movie, wherein directors like Hitchcock (or a recent favorite, Alejandro G. Iñárritu, director of Birdman) never seem to stop the camera; each character leads us to—then leaves us with—another character who continues the story. This stresses the point that "No man is an island." We are all interconnected in our circles. How we treat our barista in the morning could affect how he treats his coworkers which could affect how they treat their spouse and children that night. This technique is both realistic and humorous because the characters of Middlemarch are quite serious and busy, yet taken as a whole, we see the ridiculousness of people. Exaggerated by the customs and mores of the time (the novel is set in 1830s, England), Eliot illustrates how honest communication trumps all. When people are dishonest, or simply don't speak up, then misunderstandings occur. Again, this is, in turn, either quite serious or quite funny. This even becomes a driver for the plot: the fact that women weren't allowed to speak their minds, and that even men were not supposed to defend themselves, kept me turning the pages to find out how each storyline would play out and who would speak up for whom. (I am not being very specific because to give one illustration would lead to another which would lead to another, and this  would never end.)One last accolade ... I listened to the audio version of this book, performed by the brilliant Juliet Stevenson. Stevenson has recorded many, many books (look her up), and she does an award winning job with Middlemarch. She switches between languages and accents and genders flawlessly throughout this broad-sweeping story. She is unparalleled.As a writer, I view Middlemarch as a prototype: The perfect novel has been done; now take bits and pieces of this book to create your own. And by bits and pieces, I mean "Do not write an omniscient POV story about an entire village" lest all novels would be 850 pages.Five Perfect Stars...more

title: The Fault in Our Stars
author: Green, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Read this book. That's all I really need to say here: Read this book. Don't think for one second, "I don't read young adult novels." Don't think, "It Read this book. That's all I really need to say here: Read this book. Don't think for one second, "I don't read young adult novels." Don't think, "It might be too sad." If you will ever die, or if you know anyone else who will ever die, then read this book. John Green has taken Death, and put it in its place. He has unsentimentally brought to life the subject of death. THE FAULT IN OUR STARS is the story of two people (don't say teenagers) who meet (don't say in a cancer support group) who fall in love. This could be an epic novel in which the characters live happily together for seventy years, but no one lives "happily ever after" because we all die. This novel speeds it up into a "little infinity." THE FAULT IN OUR STARS is brilliant and funny and heartbreaking and perfect. It touches the deepest human emotions, including humor. In a way, it's an instruction manual on how to talk to people who are dying, and how to live while we're dying. Read this book. In fact, I think I'll heed my own advice and read it again. It's that good.Five Bright, Twinkling Stars ...more

title: The Orphan Master's Son
author: Johnson, Adam
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's difficult to criticize a Pulitzer Prize winning novel. I mean, if it wasn't near-perfect in many esteemed peoples' eyes, it wouldn't have won theIt's difficult to criticize a Pulitzer Prize winning novel. I mean, if it wasn't near-perfect in many esteemed peoples' eyes, it wouldn't have won the Pulitzer, right? Yes, Adam Johnson's THE ORPHAN MASTER'S SON is superb on many levels:The writing: lyrical and non-pedantic? Check. The subject matter: unique and fascinating? Check. The characters and setting: unique, round, well-developed? Yes, definitely.The plot and pacing: gripping? Eventually yes.Adam Johnson illuminates the horrifying, hidden world of North Korea via a handful of diverse characters. He tells us in post-publication interviews that he drew upon years of research and travel and interviews with North Korean defectors to write this novel, but that it was extremely difficult to learn the truth about life in this communist country. He admits that he had to invent certain aspects of citizens' daily routines, but what he includes as accurately as possible is both fascinating and cruel. This definitely opened my eyes to the sad reality of life under a tyrant's regime.I read The Orphan Master's Son for my book club, and I'm grateful to my friend who chose it because I never would have picked it up on my own. It is character-driven literature—and we can include the setting as a character; it was that important to the story—yet near the end, there is a crucial goal that drives the plot. I enjoyed that for both the subject matter and the fact that it spurred me to finish the story. Though I generally prefer faster paced novels, this book wholeheartedly deserves Five Stars. ...more

author: Milchman, Jenny*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Jenny Milchman's debut novel, COVER OF SNOW, is a page-turner! Its 320 pages are riveting, right up till the dramatic end. COVER OF SNOW is the story Jenny Milchman's debut novel, COVER OF SNOW, is a page-turner! Its 320 pages are riveting, right up till the dramatic end. COVER OF SNOW is the story of Nora Hamilton who wakes up one morning to discover her husband, a small-town cop, has committed suicide in their home. Nora becomes an "amateur detective" to figure out what really happened because she doesn't have any idea why he would do it. In the weeks following his death, Nora uncovers decades of secrets, and feelings long since buried in herself. Along the way, she meets a handful of well-written characters with problems of their own, yet they all guide her toward the answers she craves. The setting of COVER OF SNOW is as important as any character in the book. Milchman knows her snow! The novel is very cinematic, and I could feel the chill of the wind as I read along. Set in rural, up-state New York, COVER OF SNOW is an authentic depiction of small-town life, and the complicated relationships of such close living. This book is a suspenseful whodunit. And like the best novels, I didn't guess who the guilty party was until way late in the book. Even when we find out, the final "chase scene" is very exciting. I want to put a copy of this book in every winter cabin—it's the perfect book to read in front of a blazing fire on a snowy weekend!Four icy Stars to COVER OF SNOW...more

review: I can now say, "I've read Tolstoy." THE DEATH OF IVAN ILYCH is listed as a novella, but my copy has only 104 pages (very little pages with a lot of whI can now say, "I've read Tolstoy." THE DEATH OF IVAN ILYCH is listed as a novella, but my copy has only 104 pages (very little pages with a lot of white space), so it can barely be longer than a short story. Nonetheless, it's a powerful, engaging tale.Ivan Ilych is a Russian man who, in the late 19th Century, rises through the ranks of law school until he becomes a judge. He pursues typical worldly comforts (women, prestige, salary, a fine home, etc.) until he becomes ill. His illness overtakes him (on about page 35 of my copy), and as he suffers more and more until his eponymous death, he examines his life to figure out why he must suffer so much.I won't explain what he discovers (that would be a spoiler), but the more you know about Tolstoy's life post-ANNA KARENINA, the less of a surprise the ending will be for you. Unsurprisingly, Tolstoy brilliantly depicts universal behaviors and thoughts in this brief account of one person's life. If you can't say you've actually read Tolstoy, then pick up this tiny book and read it. It's heart-rending, but beautiful.Five Stars ...more

title: By Night in Chile
author: Bolaño, Roberto
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: BY NIGHT IN CHILE, by Roberto Bolaño, is a book like no other. It earned its five stars from me. This novella (118 pages) is written as one paragraph.BY NIGHT IN CHILE, by Roberto Bolaño, is a book like no other. It earned its five stars from me. This novella (118 pages) is written as one paragraph. No breaks, no chapters, no help at all for the reader. In deed, there are numerous 400+ word sentences. Yes, single sentences that run for nearly two pages.By Night In Chile is the deathbed rambling (confession?) of Father Sebastián Urrutia Lacroix, an elderly Chilean priest who is mentally searching for "the wizened youth," a young man whom Urrutia wants to confront. A scholar, poet, literary critic and world traveler, Father Urrutia recounts the major events of his life (seemingly without pause for a breath!) where he crossed paths with "the wizened youth." This rambling leads him to a startling revelation. Bolaño's skill in pulling off this literary feat—and it is no less than astounding—is unparalleled. This book should come with a warning to young writers: "Professional writer at his best. Do not attempt this on your own." It has been criticized by many for being pedantic (or worse), and it wasn't until halfway through the book that I began to appreciate it for what it is. In retrospect, this story would have lost all its power without the nonstop, stream-of-consciousness telling. Bolaño knew that.This is a book that would become deeper and more brilliant with subsequent readings, or being discussed with others who've read it. at 118 pages, that's doable. Five Enlightening Stars...more
