my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's a lot to discuss with THEFT, by BK Loren. Loren has "created a world," a story that she seems intimately familiar with, but one that is probabThere's a lot to discuss with THEFT, by BK Loren. Loren has "created a world," a story that she seems intimately familiar with, but one that is probably foreign to most of America. Set in the Colorado prairie, as well as the desert of New Mexico, and touching on an Indian Reservation, her setting is an integral element of this novel. Essentially, this is the story of Willa, a woman called in to search for Zeb, her older brother who's running from the authorities. Loren expertly weaves in flashbacks from 1980, the tumultuous and pivotal year of their childhood days. Now Willa hasn't seen Zeb for decades, and of course she's torn: She wants to see him, but she does not want to turn him over to the authorities. Normally, Willa tracks wolves on a New Mexico National Forest. Her goal is to reintroduce them to the wild. She works with and against the authorities at the same time. At the beginning of this novel, she is tracking two particular wolves. Loren intertwines this subplot with Willa and Zeb's story. It's a good parallel, and works well, but maybe a tad didactic. It feels like Loren wanted to educate readers on a serious issue so she wrote it into her story. A wild animal lover might have been ecstatic about this part of the book. What I liked most about THEFT was the characters. They were conflicted in many ways that felt very natural. From a young girl's fears and sadness over her mother's battle with Parkinson's, to a grown man's frustrations with an overbearing government and the true value of right vs. wrong, Loren did an excellent job of fleshing out true emotion.The title, THEFT, also deserves a little discussion. The novel is not about a physical robbery; it is a metaphor for multiple things that are stolen from us in life. I love the title. It's punchy and enigmatic at the same time.THEFT is a novel of layers. There are many themes woven in the plot and subplots. I think this is a book that would continue to unfold with subsequent readings.Four Stars...more

title: Life After Life        (Todd Family, #1)
author: Atkinson, Kate
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am SO glad I read this acclaimed book. LIFE AFTER LIFE, by Kate Atkinson, received a lot of press in 2013; some of it glowing, some of it critical. I am SO glad I read this acclaimed book. LIFE AFTER LIFE, by Kate Atkinson, received a lot of press in 2013; some of it glowing, some of it critical. I don't want to shy away from books just because some people find them challenging. But, you can see from the number of stars I gave LIFE AFTER LIFE, that I came down on the critical side.Atkinson "swung for the bleachers" with this book. (It's the first of hers I've read.) In my opinion, she struck out. There's no question Atkinson is a skilled writer. Her prose is lovely (I underlined many poignant phrases), her characters are distinct, and the concept is captivating: "What if you could live again and again, until you got it right?" Unfortunately, the format failed. This story is about Ursula Todd, who is born and reincarnated multiple times in the 525 pages of the novel. She is always born in England on the 10th of February, 1911 to the same parents, but her life takes different paths until, I suppose in the author's mind, she "gets it right." I imagine all the pieces to this jigsaw puzzle of a book are here, the reader just needs to fit them together the way Atkinson did in the months she wrote it. Yeah, well, I have too many other books I want to read to spend that much time fitting the pieces together in order to deem it brilliant.(Here come a few spoilers …)In addition to Ursula, there are many key characters: siblings, parents, an aunt, neighbors, friends, boyfriends, etc., who all factor in to the story. One of my primary criticisms is that Atkinson never explains why many of them behave the way they do. Brother Maurice is obnoxious throughout yet we never learn why; Sylvie, Ursula's mother, goes from loving to bitter to suicidal, but Atkinson never tells us what happened to her—there were multiple hints of infidelity, yet no revelations. If an author's going to make such a big deal about a character's personality, she should explain his/her actions. My biggest criticism of this book, however, comes between pages 300 - 450 (approximately). [Spoiler alert:] Ursula finds herself in Germany, best friends with Eva Braun, Adolf Hitler's real-life mistress and later wife of forty hours. During Ursula's final (I think) incarnation, she murders Hitler—this is in the prologue! Atkinson gives us 150 pages of Ursula living through WWII, aiding the wounded, and eking out an existence at what has to be one of the worst periods of history. It was TEDIOUS to say the least. "We must bear witness." Yes, I realize that, but Atkinson gave the best part of that storyline away in the prologue! Instead of just putting her in the room with Hitler, with a gun in her purse, Ursula kills him on page 2! That seems to be the "seed" of the novel much like Stephen King in "11/22/63" sends his protagonist back to see if he can stop the assassination of President Kennedy. So, not only is the basis for the novel NOT original, it's tedious. Plus, while Ursula's in Germany, we assume she's going to meet her cousin who was adopted by a German family at birth. Ursula meets several German men, yet none of them turn out to be her cousin (or do they? It was never made clear!). Atkinson set this subplot up like a slow-pitch to a slugger, yet it was never completed. There was one character, Jürgen, who might have been him, but we never find out! Argh! What I liked best about this book was Ursula herself. Ursula learned from her "mistakes," and she had strong, independent thoughts (at least in her later lives). She wasn't strong enough though to save the book.Two and a half stars, rounded up to Three Stars. ...more

title: Grain Brain: The Surprising Truth about Wheat, Carbs, and Sugar--Your Brain's Silent Killers
author: Perlmutter, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't know about you, but this is not the kind of book that I EVER read cover to cover. (In other words, I skipped around a lot.)The information in I don't know about you, but this is not the kind of book that I EVER read cover to cover. (In other words, I skipped around a lot.)The information in GRAIN BRAIN, by David Perlmutter, MD, is well-substantiated (at least to my layman's mind), and he presents a strong case for avoiding grains. A friend of mine who has run eighteen marathons first mentioned this book to me. She felt the information was important and most likely true enough that she bought the book—although her diet is no where near what Dr. Perlmutter recommends. I, on the other hand, have followed most of his guidelines for many years now. I've mostly avoided grains since the Atkins craze in the late 90s. I bought this book to reinforce what I know, and to see what the latest information is. Plus, I'm always on the lookout for new recipes and meal plans. There's a lot of science inside this 300 page book, which a person can obviously either read or skip. As a believer going in, I skipped most of it, but I still feel like I got a lot out of the book. I hope that readers with a more scientific background felt the facts were accurate, well-substantiated, and original.My only question is: Should I shelf it in my library? Or in my kitchen?Four Stars (because I find the science parts too dry)...more

title: The Flamethrowers
author: Kushner, Rachel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sometimes when I read a book, I want to  it right away because it sparks excitement in me. Excitement or frustration, both inspire immediate actSometimes when I read a book, I want to  it right away because it sparks excitement in me. Excitement or frustration, both inspire immediate action. THE FLAMETHROWERS by Rachel Kushner is not one of those books. THE FLAMETHROWERS was on beaucoup Top Books of 2013 lists, including the NYTimes Top Five Novels. Because of that, because I can admit those critics are probably smarter than I, I wanted to let this book resonate to see how I felt about it days later. My opinion hasn't changed: This book is highly overrated. Kushner can laugh herself to the bank with that, I'm sure.Don't get me wrong. There are dozens of brilliant observations and comments about life throughout this book. But there are also entire chapters that are bizarre, tangental, and confusing. My comments through the book range from "Great observation. Relatable, and universal" (Pg. 24), to "Preachy" (Pg. 123), to "WTF?" (the entire 10th chapter), to "This is the stuff of brilliance" (page 325). Kushner weaves two stories together—one begins in Italy in 1916; the other in Nevada and New York in the 70s—and deftly links them through Sandro Vallera, the son of the Italian protagonist. Gold Star for that. "Reno" is the protagonist for the later story, an artist who moves to NYC to follow her dreams. Reno and Sandro are both artists, as are most of their friends. As a former art dealer, I was really excited for that storyline. Unfortunately, Kushner disappointed me by dropping random famous names to make her story seem more authentic. It felt like she found the answers to a Jeopardy category: "New York Artists from the 70s, Alex." The names she mentions and the actions of these artists had little or nothing to do with her story. Mentioning them felt forced as a way of marking the correct decade.My most particular critique is this: Reno, the young, female artist who's trying to make it in NYC, is without a doubt the protagonist. But who exactly is the antagonist? This is Reno's story, the other characters just float through for a few paragraphs or chapters. Even Sandro, the character with the second most scenes, doesn't seem to be the antagonist. He screws up their relationship (literally), and then Gianni comes in. Before and after Sandro, we had Ronnie. Perhaps "life lessons" is the driving antagonistic force? That seemed vague to me.I suppose that when a book gets such superior accolades, it's human nature to look for its faults. Damn expectations! I could go on with a few other rants (How does Reno speak such fluent Italian after so much time passed from her only trip there? Why make such a big deal about Reno's skiing acumen if she doesn't ski in the final scene at the ski slope?), but these are starting to sound picky.Suffice it to say, lower your expectations and you might really enjoy this book. There's a lot to enjoy with THE FLAMETHROWERS, but it won't make my Top Five books of the year. I am left hoping that one of my close friends reads this book so that we can discuss it. I'd love to know what I'm missing.Three and a half stars, rounded up to Four Stars for its occasional brilliance. ...more

I have read Catherine McKenzie's other novels, so I expected it to be "women's fiction," but it really leans more toward "chick lit." Based on the premise—If you had the chance to start over, would you take it?—and based on the storyline—A woman travels to Africa and after a massive earthquake, is presumed dead—I expected much more gravitas. Instead, this book is nearly 450 pages of back and forth between Emma, the protagonist, and her "old" boyfriend, and her "new" boyfriend: "Why did you say that?", "Why are you being so mean?", "How could you sleep with HER?", "You REALLY like me?"I also thought the subplots overwhelmed the main plot. If FORGOTTEN had been 150 pages shorter, I probably would have liked it a lot more. It's not a bad book; it's just not the kind of book I like.Two and a half stars, rounded up to three....more

title: The Goldfinch
author: Tartt, Donna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: SECOND READING: Sept 2, 2014I've just re-read THE GOLDFINCH by Donna Tartt because I chose this book for my book club to discuss and I wanted to refreSECOND READING: Sept 2, 2014I've just re-read THE GOLDFINCH by Donna Tartt because I chose this book for my book club to discuss and I wanted to refresh my memory on its details. The first time I read it (see my original  below), I loved it for many reasons. While most of them still hold true for me, I have to say I didn't find it worthy of the 2014 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction which it won since my previous .Donna Tartt is a storyteller extraordinaire. I love the depth of her details and the reaches of her imagination. I am surprised however by her abundant usage of adverbs and clichés. This alone should have knocked it out of contention for the Pulitzer, in my opinion. Beyond that, while I grew extremely tired of Theo and Boris's use of drugs during my first reading, I accepted it because I was so into the story. The second time through (plus hearing how tired everyone else grew of it too) made me realize that it was truly way over done. I would recommend this book only to people who love an epic novel. I would also knock this down to 4.5 Stars if Goodreads would let me. FIRST READING: Jan 31, 2014You know how sometimes a person, or a thought, or a book hits your life at just the right moment, and you learn something from him/her/it? And you somehow know that if it had happened at any other time in your life, it might never have touched you in the same way? Well, THE GOLDFINCH hit me at just the right moment. I loved this book.THE GOLDFINCH is 771 pages. Is that too long? Probably. Yet I can't think of a single scene I would remove. Even during the passages where I wondered, What's the point of this? Where is it going? Yeah, Donna Tartt always answered those questions in due time.Where to begin? The prose, the plot, the characters, the theme? All wonderful and unique. Tartt's description of each character is so vivid, so fantastically specific that I could picture each one in turn. What a lesson in flawed characters! Even the ones we're "supposed" to like, we don't always. And isn't that the way it is in real life? Don't you even dislike your best friend every now and then? Get a little mad at your spouse on occasion? Exactly. THE GOLDFINCH is the story of Theo Decker, a thirteen-year-old boy who finds himself in possession of a masterwork of art from the Metropolitan Museum after a terrorist bombing that killed his mother. The way Tartt leads him from that shell-shocked boy to a damaged man of twenty-eight feels so realistic, so deep and probable that if someone told me this was based on a true story, I would probably believe it. Not that I have much in common with Theo or his childhood friend, Boris, or his mentor, Dobie, or any of the other characters (at least not the big stuff), but I loved them all because of how this story ended. The ending was perfect. Plausible, yet not sweetly Hollywood-slick. Though, the book is so descriptive, it could easily be turned into a movie.I would love to discuss the theme of this book and the character development (Theo is the perfect example of a reluctant hero), but I don't want to give too much away. If you're debating on this book due to the length, let me say, Yes, it's long and winding, but the journey is fabulous and the ending will feel like a reward. I have a few knocks against the book, but they're not important enough to alter my rating.I will be choosing this book for my book club because I am eager to discuss so many elements. Also, if anyone is curious, not only did I read the book, I listened to it on audible.com. The narrator, David Pittu, does an excellent job with a multitude of characters and foreign accents. The audio version added so much to my reading experience. I highly recommend it.Five drunk, gritty, gorgeous Stars (Read the book; you'll understand.)...more

title: Girlchild
author: Hassman, Tupelo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let me start by saying I loved this book. It's a quiet book, with a quiet title, and must have had a quiet launching. Since that time (12-18 months agLet me start by saying I loved this book. It's a quiet book, with a quiet title, and must have had a quiet launching. Since that time (12-18 months ago), it has gained attention, accolades, and praise, all rightfully so. I wouldn't even have picked it up if it hadn't been chosen by a friend for our book club. Thank you, friend.GIRLCHILD is fiction, listed as a novel, though it's not by any means typical. Each "chapter" is more like a diary entry, some as short as a paragraph. In fact, as a writer, I felt that many of Tupelo Hassman's "entries" were more typical of "backstory notes" or "research" or "mind-mapping;" the details that authors must invent, yet typically don't spell-out in their novels. But Hassman's technique worked beautifully.GIRLCHILD is the gritty story of Rory Dawn, a young girl growing up in a trailer park outside of Reno. She's the only daughter of an alcoholic single mother who herself is the daughter of a gambling addict. Most of their troubles go down hill from there. Rory, though, is very bright, bright enough to see that there is more to the world than their dysfunctional existence, and bright enough to set her sights beyond the gravel road that leads to her dead-end development. The question is, Is she bright enough to escape the world that most have no hope of escaping?Any  of GIRLCHILD would not be complete without comments on Hassman's writing, or rather the "voice" of Rory Dawn. Hassman's bio says she received an MFA from Columbia (!), yet in interviews she explains that she spent many of her childhood years in a trailer park. That explains so much because Rory's point of view and language sounds tragically authentic. There was at least one scene that brought tears to my eyes, and a few scenes that made me cheer. Hassman is known to be a poet, and her sentences reinforce that. Even as she describes squalor, alcoholism, sexual abuse, bullying, and desperation her sentences sing. I underlined and dogeared many, many passages. As is typical of me, I want to BEG Goodreads to let us use half-stars. I would give GIRLCHILD 4.5 stars, but I'm rounding this one down. There were a few inconsistencies that kept it out of Five Star territory, namely the epistolary entries from Rory's grandmother. The letters were written with a flair that we never saw from the grandmother's personal interactions with her daughter or granddaughter. Huge disconnect. Four Gritty Stars...more

title: The Good Lord Bird
author: McBride, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'll have to fight hard to give THE GOOD LORD BIRD a fair . In full disclosure, let me tell you the first three hurdles this book has to jump inI'll have to fight hard to give THE GOOD LORD BIRD a fair . In full disclosure, let me tell you the first three hurdles this book has to jump in my mind. First, I read this book for my book club. I have to admit that I am more critical of a book if I need to sound sorta smart when I discuss it in a group of really smart people. Second, just before I started the book, it was announced that THE GOOD LORD BIRD won the National Book Award. That's like seeing a movie that just won a Golden Globe for best picture: It's held to a higher standard from the opening lines, all the way through. Third, I grew up in Kansas. We studied John Brown and the abolitionists intensely in the fourth grade. Unfortunately, that memory made this book feel a bit like homework. Ooh, just thought of a fourth knock. Historical fiction that is centered on real people frustrates me to no end. I'm particular enough that I have to look up every character's name to see if he/she was real or is part of the author's poetic license. That can really slow a book down.Now that I have that out of the way, Yes, I liked THE GOOD LORD BIRD; no, I didn't love it, nor would I have voted for it for the National Book Award (I thought George Saunders' TENTH OF DECEMBER was the best book of the year). James McBride is an excellent writer, no argument there, but he gave himself a nearly impossible task: THE GOOD LORD BIRD is written in the first person, from the POV of Onion, a young boy who's masquerading as a young girl. Plus, he, Onion, is an uneducated black kid in the late 1850s. Imagine trying to get that dialect right, and still make the text understandable to those of us in the 21st century. McBride did a great job, but there seemed to be a number of inconsistencies. I love an authentic voice, but most of all I like consistency. Also, I noted several paragraphs where I felt the prose was redundant/repetitive. McBride would "show" us and "tell" us the same thing in a single paragraph. If I had been his editor, I would have eliminated several sentences throughout that I thought detracted from his prose. McBride (via Onion) presents John Brown as one crazy, religious zealot. Again, I have to stop and wonder if Brown was known to be as McBride depicted him, or if that just made for a better story. My fourth grade teacher never mentioned his personality traits. Does that matter to anyone but me? If I hadn't been reading this for my book club, I might have just sunk into my sofa and rode along with Captain Brown, Onion, and the gang, suffering through the icy winters and bloody battles on the plains. I love history, and I love fiction, but somehow mixing the two brings up the aforementioned frustrations.One curious point that McBride made repeatedly was Onion's desire to run off from John Brown and his small army, but he never does. Now, it's apparent that Onion has no place to go, but that never seems to stop his desire to break away. Is McBride trying to illustrate Hope? That as long as we think we can better our lives, we can keep going? Or, what? This comment was repeated so many times, that I fully expected Onion would follow through and leave, but he doesn't. Obviously, in first person POV, the character must be in each scene for us to know the story so Onion needed to stay with Brown up until the bitter end, but I have to wonder about McBride's point was in repeating that so many times. I'm going to go with the message of Hope. I like that idea best. I had thought that because of the Prologue, McBride would end his book with an Epilogue that could wrap up the story without Onion being present.In the closing pages, specifically page 414 in the hardback edition, THE GOOD LORD BIRD's themes jump poetically off the page. To me, the themes seemed to be "Perspective" and "Authenticity." John Brown (a religious, white optimist on a mission) and Onion (a non-believing, black orphan who just wants to grow up) are intentionally opposite characters. It's natural that different people see the world differently, and this story helps us to "walk a mile in their shoes." On page 415, Captain Brown teaches Onion the importance of being true to one's self. "Whatever you is, Onion, be it full." Plus, the lessons we learn in life, if we share them, will empower those of future generations. Those are powerful messages. I'm giving THE GOOD LORD BIRD Four Stars. I might like it better after my book club discussion, but as it registers in my personal library, it doesn't rise above four....more

title: Visitation Street
author: Pochoda, Ivy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What an incredible talent! Ivy Pochoda is one of my new favorite authors. The front flap will tell you that VISITATION STREET is about the disappearanWhat an incredible talent! Ivy Pochoda is one of my new favorite authors. The front flap will tell you that VISITATION STREET is about the disappearance of "June," a fifteen-year old girl who goes out in a raft in the bay off Red Hook, Brooklyn, with her best friend Val. But somehow, the story isn't really about June's disappearance in the typical police procedural/crime novel way. The story is about the people of Red Hook—the imperfect, struggling, conflicted people of a disadvantaged neighborhood—who are connected to the event in very different ways. Pochoda, who used to live in Red Hook, wrote this novel in present tense. She leads us down the local sidewalks and makes us feel like we are walking along the broken, eerie streets with each character as he or she tells us how they are affected by or dealing with June's disappearance. The story is quiet, yet captivating.I should say that it took me a few chapters to really get into the story, but I think that was because I was expecting something much different, a typical mystery, if you will. VISITATION STREET is Literary first, Mystery second. But the more I read, the more I loved this book. Pochoda's turn of a phrase or description of ... well, basically, anything, is phenomenal. Every single sentence is perfect.I could go on and on about this book: the setting, the characters, the plot, the writing ... It's all superb. Don't hesitate: Read this book.Five Bright Stars...more

title: The Theory of Opposites
author: Scotch, Allison Winn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Is it me who's changing, or is it chick-lit that's changing?I loved Allison Winn Scotch's first novel, THE DEPARTMENT OF LOST AND FOUND. This novel, TIs it me who's changing, or is it chick-lit that's changing?I loved Allison Winn Scotch's first novel, THE DEPARTMENT OF LOST AND FOUND. This novel, THE THEORY OF OPPOSITES? Not so much. Ms. Scotch, whom I adore via Social Media, might prefer to call this Women's Fiction, but it didn't seem to have the gravitas to lift it above Chick Lit, in my opinion. Willa, the protagonist, had a sense of humor, but, like the protagonist in Catherine McKenzie's FORGOTTEN, her inner thoughts came off as whiny, woe-is-me insecurity. I can't take three or four hundred pages of that anymore. This is the story of Willa, daughter of a famous theorist, wife of a tech-demi-god, friend of a daredevil … But Willa seemed too weak throughout the story to be the "heroine." For example, when she decides to take charge of her life—an important move for a protagonist—even that idea was her friend's, not Willa's. Isn't that Cardinal Rule #1 in fiction? The hero must be the hero?Anyway, this is a light and ultimately happy story, but perhaps more of a beach read than I was hoping for.Three Stars...more

title: The Kitchen House
author: Grissom, Kathleen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let me start by saying that I read this book for my book club. I would not have picked it up on my own because I'm not a huge fan of historical fictioLet me start by saying that I read this book for my book club. I would not have picked it up on my own because I'm not a huge fan of historical fiction. That being said, Kathleen Grissom did a wonderful job with this, her debut novel. Grissom's writing is clean and formal, as it should be when relating a story from circa 1800 set in Virginia. The premise—that a seven-year-old Irish girl who is orphaned on her trip to America becomes an indentured servant of the captain of their ship, and then is raised by his slaves until she is sixteen—must be historically accurate because the author did years of research for this book. However, let me start by saying that this shocked me. Were little white girls truly made "indentured servants" in the late-18th Century? Why was she indentured in the first place? The girl, Lavinia, was a red-headed, freckle-faced, traumatized orphan who looked a lot like the ship captain's wife? Wouldn't her parents have paid their way BEFORE they got on the ship? Yes. Then why would she be indentured to anyone? But if there was reason for her to be "indentured," would they really have sent her to the kitchen house to be raised by the slaves? Isn't it more likely that she would have served the family in the "big" house? Beyond that, Grissom created realistic characters that I really cared about. Her portrayal of the slaves seemed spot on, the Pyke family also seemed highly authentic (based on other books and movies I've read and seen over the years), but the most captivating aspect was the interaction between the Pyke family and their slaves. It was in turns both tender and horrifying. [On a side note, I went to see 12 Years a Slave, a movie directed by Steve McQueen, while reading this book. His portrayal of the true story of Solomon Northup, a free white man who was kidnapped and enslaved in Georgia, was eerily similar to Grissom's portrayal of the same time period.] My biggest knock on this book, other than I never understood why Lavinia was indentured in the first place, was this: Lavinia, from about age nine to twenty, is remarkably (unbelievably) wise and insightful, except when it came to the white men in the story. Perhaps, after losing her real mother and father, she lost her natural teachers about matters of the heart, but her "black family" taught her everything else about life and love. Lavinia was completely blind when it came to Marshall and Ben's actions, the two white males who were about her age. That dichotomy frustrated me. My favorite part of this book was the plot. It became more and more exciting near the end. Yes, that's as it should be, but it's not always the case, especially with literary fiction. My favorite books, in general, are well-written, plot-driven stories. THE KITCHEN HOUSE is both.Four strong stars....more

title: The Silent Wife
author: Harrison, A.S.A.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I often think I'm more critical of really good books than I am of mediocre books. THE SILENT WIFE is a REALLY good book, so I have complaints, but theI often think I'm more critical of really good books than I am of mediocre books. THE SILENT WIFE is a REALLY good book, so I have complaints, but they are rather nit-picky. In fact, I even considered giving A.S.A. Harrison's first novel Five Stars. THE SILENT WIFE is far better (miles beyond!) GONE GIRL. They are often compared because they have similar plots, though they were released so close together I am sure that's just a coincidence. In THE SILENT WIFE, Jodi and Todd are a couple; they've been together for twenty years, though they never actually got married. Todd is a real estate developer who has multiple affairs. Jodi is a part-time therapist with her own issues. The back cover of the novel tells us that Jodi kills Todd, and that more than anything keeps us turning the pages to find out when and how. After it happens, the final fifty pages are even more riveting because the reader is dying to know if she gets away with it. A.S.A. Harrison, who died of cancer before this book was published, was a wonderful writer. Her sentences are clean and sparse. Her observations of people are often startlingly poignant. She dove deeply into her characters psyches. Harrison wrote four non-fiction books before THE SILENT WIFE. I am curious if she was a psychologist herself (there is very little biographical information about her online).My issues with this book center mostly around money—income, expenses, costs, etc. The characters seemed to live way beyond their means … but that's a trivial point considering what a great story this is. I highly recommend it!Four and a half Stars—rounded down to Four....more

title: Night Film
author: Pessl, Marisha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Where does one begin in ing NIGHT FILM? This book is long and multi-dimensional. I actually made a list with LIKE and DISLIKE elements. AlthoughWhere does one begin in ing NIGHT FILM? This book is long and multi-dimensional. I actually made a list with LIKE and DISLIKE elements. Although I would say I liked this book, my dislike column was twice as long as my likes.Briefly, NIGHT FILM is the story of an investigative journalist, Scott McGrath, who sets out to discern wether a young girl's death was suicide or murder. The young girl, Ashley Cordova, is the daughter of an eccentric and reclusive movie director known for his horror films. McGrath has had previous dealings with the father, Stanislas Cordova, and McGrath's career was nearly ruined because of it. Additionally, the book is FILLED with multi-media images: fictitious web pages; newspaper clippings; pages torn from phone books; polaroid images; and most importantly, a symbol that lets the reader (via the book's very own phone app and QR reader) scan a symbol to "find out more!"Let's start with what I liked: Marisha Pessl's imagination must roar through her brain in techni-color! Wow, the plot of this book (plus the story lines of all of Stanislas Cordova's "films") is amazing. The best way I can describe it is like this: Imagine taking a 24-hour roller coaster ride, with harrowing climbs, terrifying falls, sharp turns and twists and loop-de-loops, all while traveling through NYC's Central Park, witchcraft stores, abandoned warehouses, creepy forests, mile-long mazes of pure darkness ... Then, in the final pages, your roller coaster pulls back into the station and stops. You look at your friends in amazement and wonder, "Did that really happen?" It's almost mystical. Pessl has "created a world" that sweeps the reader off his/her feet. Pessl's plot is definitely the driving force in this book—it's a page-turner. We really want to know the "truth" behind the Cordova mystique. Okay, that's all the Likes I had. Now for the rest of the story:I felt the writing was sub-par. Not as bad as Stephenie Meyer's TWILIGHT series, but way below what I expected for a book with this much press and praise. (I have long felt that "Concept" trumps "Quality" in many books.) Pessl's sentences are clunky, often slowing down the narrative. Her excessive use of ITALICS made me want to scream and throw the book down. Did she think her readers weren't smart enough to get what her characters were trying to say? Her best writing, in my opinion, was when she wrote the "copy" for her fictitious news clippings. Why did she have to ruin the book with her italics? Why didn't an editor overrule her desire for said italics? Additionally, I felt her metaphors and similes, for the most part, fell flat. They often didn't seem to make sense, or have any relation to the characters and situations. (I could list numerous examples, but this  is already stretching quite long.) Her male protagonist was unconvincing. He "thought" like a girl. Plus, McGrath, the freelance journalist is apparently quite rich—there's an oxymoron! He owns a home in NY's West Village, and throws money around like a hedge fund manager. Later, he is joined in his search by two young people who had had interactions with Ashley, the deceased daughter. I thought their trio felt forced and unrealistic. My last point is the interactive element, the app and symbol-reader. So we all know that most movies don't live up to their books, right? One of the book's best qualities was its creepiness. (The cover is fantastic!) I hesitated to download the app because I wanted to read the book on its own merits. Near the end of the book though, I thought, I should at least check it out, know what it's about, to give a full . I was so disappointed when I did. The few symbols I scanned led me to shiny, pretty, Hollywood images of beautiful girls applying firetruck-red lipstick in million-dollar bathrooms. It completely ruined the spooky feel of her story! If Pessl wanted to make movies, she should have done so. (Yes, she has already sold the movie rights to this book, so it shouldn't be long before her glossy film is in a theatre near you.)In closing, while Pessl has a great talent for storytelling, I think she spent way too much time on the concept and interactive elements, and not enough time on writing good sentences. At her level, verb tenses in each sentence should match. I would give this book 3.5 stars, but I'm rounding down on this one.Three black stars to NIGHT FILM....more

title: The Husband's Secret
author: Moriarty, Liane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not sure what I expected from this book, but it was a delightful surprise. Liane Moriarty is an excellent writer. She has a way of capturing real I'm not sure what I expected from this book, but it was a delightful surprise. Liane Moriarty is an excellent writer. She has a way of capturing real thoughts and emotions and translating them into actions for her characters. There are three seemingly disparate groups of people in THE HUSBAND'S SECRET, that Moriarty weaves together seamlessly for an intricate tale. (I listened to this book as an audiobook, so I didn't have the advantage of looking ahead to sections or chapters or headings to know what to expect.) The book is set in Sydney and Melbourne, Australia, which made it fun to read/ listen to (I really enjoyed Caroline Lee's performance and pronunciations in an authentic Australian accent). The premise of the book, with no spoilers, is what do you do with a piece of information that would tear your family apart? I love that premise. I call it the tragic dilemma. Moriarty told the story of each group of people so well that I felt like I knew the characters, but it's the plot that drives the story. I really wanted to know how the plot resolved itself.I have two small knocks against this book. First, I thought it was a bit long, and might have been even better if she had eliminated, say, fifty pages. (Moriarty draws a thematic parallel to the Berlin Wall which seemed a bit forced.) Second, Moriarty adds an omniscient epilogue about how the characters' lives would have played out if certain events had never happened. I didn't like that. Why tell us all the ways a novel could have gone, but didn't? I would give this book 4 1/2 Stars if Goodreads would let me, but I'm rounding down because of the epilogue. Still, a strong recommendation....more

title: How to Write a Sentence: And How to Read One
author: Fish, Stanley
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As a writer without an MFA, I decided recently that it would be a good idea for me to pick up a few books on sentences, books that MFA students are prAs a writer without an MFA, I decided recently that it would be a good idea for me to pick up a few books on sentences, books that MFA students are probably reading. This is one of five that I purchased. I haven't gotten through them all yet, but I think it's safe to say that this one will fall to the bottom of my favorites.How To Write A Sentence and How To Read One feels a lot like a fireside chat—a very intense fireside chat. My guess is that Stanley Fish is a storyteller, a man who loves deep, intellectual discourse. He probably also likes to hear himself talk (but that's totally a guess because I've never met the man). This book discusses sentences, the key word being "discusses." It's more of a narrative than it is a primer. Fish offers lengthy commentary about the hows and whys of sentences. Most of his examples are old, I mean, really OLD. I haven't counted them out, but I think it's safe to say that he uses more examples from the 17th century than he does from the 20th century.Now, here's the basis for my Three Star : Mr. Fish is undoubtedly a brilliant man and a superb writer, but I'm not looking for didactic discourse from works that are nearly 500 years old. If any contemporary writer tried to write like John Milton or Francis Bacon, he or she would probably suffer great criticism and possibly even literary rejection. Yes, it's good to learn from the classics, but writing in the 21st century is a different ballgame (in certain ways). In the epilogue of this book, Mr. Fish says, "My hope is that this discussion will be continued ..." Again, discussion is the key word. If you like to learn via narrative discourse, you might love this little book. I much preferred June Casagrande's It Was the Best of Sentences, It Was the Worst of Sentences, despite the clichéd title.Three Stars...more

EATS, SHOOTS & LEAVES, by Lynne Truss also adds a bit of humor in tYes, of course this little grammar book has some good information; don't they all? EATS, SHOOTS & LEAVES, by Lynne Truss also adds a bit of humor in the mix—which is much appreciated when dealing with a subject as droll as grammar. I have it on my shelf, and I will keep it, and I will refer to it on occasion, I'm sure. I'm giving it only three stars though, because she includes a lot of unnecessary prose. When I need grammar advice, I want to pull a book off a shelf, find the right page, and get back to writing. I don't want to read jaunty little stories about what not to do, or what tragedies might befall us if we omit commas or misplace apostrophes. I also don't want pages and pages of what NOT to do. "Just the fact, ma'am." Three Stars...more

title: The Cuckoo's Calling        (Cormoran Strike, #1)
author: Galbraith, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Is there a person on earth who does not know by now that Robert Galbraith is a pseudonym for J.K. Rowling? My first response to this book is: How in tIs there a person on earth who does not know by now that Robert Galbraith is a pseudonym for J.K. Rowling? My first response to this book is: How in the world did any literary agent PASS on this novel? It is brilliantly written, and an expertly told whodunit. It's not a thriller by any means; it's much more literary than that. In fact, I don't think I've ever had to refer to a dictionary more times while reading a mystery novel than I did for this one. It's a high-level mindbender at its best, yet it's still a quintessential detective story. So, a brief synopsis: Cormoran Strike is a down-on-his-luck detective. He's a disabled ex-military cop. A big guy. In walks Robin, a secretarial temp—but not by any shades of grey like Anastasia! (Forgive me if I got that reference wrong; I have not read that book.) Robin is smart, attractive, and engaged to another man, though Galbraith/Rowling has definitely laid the groundwork for a relationship with these two. The case in The Cuckoo's Calling is about a supermodel who plunges to her death, which was ruled a suicide by the police. The girl's brother hires Strike to investigate because he's sure she was pushed off a balcony.I'm not sure what I liked more about this novel: the character development; or the plot. They were equally brilliant. I suppose once an author has learned how to describe characters like Lord Voldemort and Dumbledore, it's not too difficult to describe a man like Cormoran Strike. Each of her characters feels very real and very "round." Each of them, especially Strike and Robin, had a nice arc of enlightenment in this story. But the plot ... it too was fantastic. It never strayed from the primary line (except to briefly elucidate a character's backstory). By page 170 (out of 455), Rowling had cast doubt on every minor character as a possible murder suspect. In fact, with 50 pages remaining, I had only narrowed down the possible villain to one of three people. I love NOT being able to guess "who did it." Then, lo and behold: the bad guy wasn't even one of the three I had on my list! Bravo, Ms. Rowling! In the end, the unraveling of the case was just slightly a stretch (the ending of some mysteries are impossible to believe), but Strike does an excellent job of pulling all the loose threads together to determine the killer. Additionally, the writing in this novel is very smart. I underlined many well-turned phrases and descriptions. Last year, critics called Dennis Lehane's Live By Night a top literary-mystery. Well, The Cuckoo's Calling easily trumps Lehane's novel in that category. This is my kind of book: a well-written, perfect mix of plot-driven and character-driven. Definitely Five Stars....more

title: Mortality
author: Hitchens, Christopher
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You know the tired question: If you could have dinner with any three people, living or dead, who would you choose? I now know I would choose ChristophYou know the tired question: If you could have dinner with any three people, living or dead, who would you choose? I now know I would choose Christopher Hitchens as one of them. I have owned the book MORTALITY for nearly two years. At 100 tiny pages, I could have (and did) read it in a matter of hours. Except I was afraid to. I know a few people who battle terminal illness, so I was afraid that reading this book would be too difficult (emotionally) to bear. Yet I also knew how much I wanted to because Hitchens was such a brilliant man. Now I wish I'd read it sooner, because that would have given me the opportunity to have read it many times since.Mortality is a powerful book. It is essentially a collection of articles Hitchens wrote for Vanity Fair Magazine after he was diagnosed with Stage IV esophageal cancer. Hitchens, a renowned atheist, was a force of nature. In his own words, he knowingly burned "the candle at both ends," and found "that it often gives a lovely light." He speaks so clearly and wisely about what it's like to be sick, and how naive those of us who love a sick person can be. He speaks of his treatments with no pity or whine. He speaks about his religious friends and their efforts to pray for him. He speaks on Prayer, and Religion, and Death so brilliantly that I feel confident in using the word "brilliant" twice in the same short . (A more religious person may disagree with me there.)Mortality is a tough book to read because "none of us are getting out of here alive." This could be our own story one day, or that of a loved one. But read it. It's valuable and interesting and thought provoking. It makes me want to read everything Hitchens ever wrote, and watch the YouTube videos of him speaking. FIVE brilliant Stars...more

title: It Was the Best of Sentences, It Was the Worst of Sentences: A Writer's Guide to Crafting Killer Sentences
author: Casagrande, June
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I call myself a writer. I've been at it for over five years. Yet this tiny little book still taught me big lessons. Mainly, I learned to stop using seI call myself a writer. I've been at it for over five years. Yet this tiny little book still taught me big lessons. Mainly, I learned to stop using semicolons. I also learned to write short sentences. No, I'm not trying to be facetious here, this really is a powerful little book. June Casagrande does an excellent job of illustrating her points with both bad and good examples. She walks us through the basics, and shows us how to spot—and how to fix—bad writing. It's easy to think a sentence is a few words followed by a period, question mark, or exclamation point, but we all know there's more to it than that. She explains it all.This book would be very valuable for any writer who's trying to improve her writing, be it fiction or nonfiction. I highly recommend it.My only question is: If I stop using semicolons, how will my Reader know I've gone to college?Five stars....more

title: The Old Man and the Sea
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I hadn't read this book in nearly twenty years, so I decided it was time for a re-read. There's no question Hemingway is a master-storyteller, though I hadn't read this book in nearly twenty years, so I decided it was time for a re-read. There's no question Hemingway is a master-storyteller, though if you've read my other Hemingway s, you know he's not my favorite writer. I like more detail, more description.While this is a lovely little story on its own, the biblical references cannot be ignored. My question today is whether or not Hemingway himself would try to separate his story from all the Christian references—or did he intend it to be directly related? I don't feel the need to get into this  too deeply here. I'm sure it's been chewed up, and savored or spit out enough already. I will say I listened to this as an audio book, narrated by the talented actor Donald Sutherland. Unfortunately, I did not think Mr. Sutherland did a very good job, nor did the producers of this recording. His voice was uneven and un-energetic. I know the story is about an old man, but I found Mr. Sutherland's performance almost boring. That's too bad.In any case, if you are a fan of fishing, baseball, or the end of Christ's life, you will probably love this book. I assume you know that already.Four Stars, because Hemingway can write beautiful sentences....more

title: The Light in the Ruins
author: Bohjalian, Chris*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book surprised me. Chris Bohjalian has written sixteen novels, several of which were NYTimes Bestsellers, one of which was an Oprah book. So he mThis book surprised me. Chris Bohjalian has written sixteen novels, several of which were NYTimes Bestsellers, one of which was an Oprah book. So he must be a good writer, right? The Light in the Ruins was my first Bohjalian novel, but unfortunately, I can't say that I liked it. In fact, I barely made it through.It's difficult to succinctly put my finger on why I didn't like it, but here are a few thoughts. One publicity blurb I read said it was a retelling of "Romeo and Juliet." Yeah, no. Just because an Italian woman falls in love with a man who her family does not approve of, does not make it a retelling of Romeo & Juliet. Also, I'm not a fan of Bohjalian's writing style, his use of grammar rules. Incomplete sentences. Extra details. Didn't work for me. They say the great writers can get away with NOT following the rules, but I think this book is an example of what happens when a writer tries, but fails. Third point: Mr. Bojhalian lost me with too many minor characters (red herrings?) and too many WWII facts as the various contingents fought their way through Italy. That may be the first reason that I started skipping pages. At some point, I said, Who did what? Bohjalian didn't make me CARE enough about the characters to keep them all straight. The only reason I hung on to the end was to find out whodunit. And when I found out, I was disappointed. The killer wasn't who I wanted it to be.There's no need for me to belabor my point here. I'm sure many people loved this book. I'm just not one of them. Three Stars. Just my humble opinion....more

title: The Enchanted Life of Adam Hope
author: Riley, Rhonda*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The premise of THE ENCHANTED LIFE OF ADAM HOPE falls somewhere between "high-concept" and "magical realism." That is to say, it requires the reader toThe premise of THE ENCHANTED LIFE OF ADAM HOPE falls somewhere between "high-concept" and "magical realism." That is to say, it requires the reader to take a leap of faith. In my mind, this is a wonderful jumping off point to begin a novel.  THE ENCHANTED LIFE OF ADAM HOPE is an epic tale of three generations of a family, centered around Evelyn Roe. The story begins in 1944 when Evelyn finds "what she takes to be a badly burned soldier" and nurses him back to health. This "soldier" first becomes Evelyn's mirror image, and then he becomes Adam Hope. They marry and have five daughters. Adam Hope is obviously not "one of us." We learn all of this from the front flap, but I SO wish there'd been a way to hold back that information. I would love to have discovered those magical facts as I read. According to the back flap, this is Rhonda Riley's first novel, though it's evident that she has been writing for a long time. Her prose is lyrical and lovely. She writes with a unique candidness, an unabashed honesty, a rare openness concerning love and sex and even bodily functions, but not in an overtly sexual way; it has a medical sense that makes me think Ms. Riley might have been a nurse before she was a writer. Either that, or she's a very open mother. The story reminds me in ways of THE THORN BIRDS. (I can imagine Ms. Riley smiling at that.) Descriptions of the setting—first North Carolina, then Florida— evoke images of McCullough's Australia. The perfect love, and also lost love, in ADAM HOPE is reminiscent of Maggie's life in THE THORN BIRDS. If you love a lyrical, romantic tale, you will love THE ENCHANTED LIFE OF ADAM HOPE.Three stars...more

title: The Bell Jar
author: Plath, Sylvia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are undoubtedly many reasons why THE BELL JAR has become a classic American novel (published in 1963). Though I have not read any of Sylvia PlatThere are undoubtedly many reasons why THE BELL JAR has become a classic American novel (published in 1963). Though I have not read any of Sylvia Plath's poetry, she was a very talented writer (she was the first poet to posthumously win the Pulitzer Prize (in 2006)). I was captivated by the story of THE BELL JAR, a thinly veiled memoir, because of its deeply personal and tragic nature. However, I must say that I think the reason this book is still actively read is because of Plath's poetry and her tragic personal life and eventual suicide—not necessarily because this debut novel stands out for its own merits.It's quite remarkable that a writer, specifically a woman in the late 1950s-early 60s, could tell the world such a devastating, heartbreaking personal story. In THE BELL JAR, Plath (1932 - 1963) retells the story of her own downward spiral—one that led her to a six-month stay in an asylum and sent her through many rounds of electroshock therapy. I cared for the protagonist, "Esther," and I hurt inside when I read what she was going through. This story takes place when Esther (Plath) was 18 years old and struggling to become a writer, a time well before her troubled marriage to the poet Ted Hughes. In certain ways, Plath owes her legacy to Hughes. He inherited her estate and saw to it that much of her poetry was published posthumously, but he also burned or "lost" other important works after her death that allegedly incriminated him as an adulterer. They were separated at the time of her death, but not divorced. If Hughes had not inherited her estate, Plath might have been best known for subsequent novels.THE BELL JAR is a well-written, captivating story. I highlighted many lovely phrases, and Plath did an excellent job of building Esther's anxiety and chronicling her madness and pain. However, I was surprised that the writing was as simple as it was. It's very good for a debut novel, but not outstanding like I had expected it to be for a novel that has remained so well-known after all these years. Four Stars...more

title: The Ocean at the End of the Lane
author: Gaiman, Neil*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a surprising delight! Neil Gaiman is one of those people you want to hate, but you just can't because he's so amazing. Gaiman makes everybody elsWhat a surprising delight! Neil Gaiman is one of those people you want to hate, but you just can't because he's so amazing. Gaiman makes everybody else feel like a first class slacker.This past week, I was going to be driving for twelve hours, so I decided to look for a new audiobook to keep me company. I think Twitter is the reason I looked this book up to consider it for my ride. Gaiman is a Twitter freak (he even thanks his 1.8M Twitter followers in his acknowledgements.) He tweets a lot, and retweets a lot. This is the first work by Gaiman I've read, so I didn't know what to expect, but it was getting a lot of raves, and the audio version is about six hours long; perfect for my trip. Knock my socks off, it did! First, the multi-talented Gaiman (that's an understatement) performs the story himself. Now, one might think that any author would be the best reader of his own story, but that is very seldom true. I equate Gaiman's performance to that of Colin Firth's THE END OF THE AFFAIR, and very close to my all-time favorite: Jeremy Irons' version of LOLITA. This is a story about a man who goes to his childhood hometown for a funeral, but pays a visit to the farmhouse of his neighbors when he was seven. When he sits beside a pond that his then-friend Lettie called an ocean, his memories come flooding back and he recites the fantastic story of himself and Lettie. And when I say "fantastic," I mean it in the true sense of fantasy. Lettie is not an ordinary girl, but I'll let you discover for yourself what kind of girl she is. Now, I don't read fantasy novels, nor science-fiction, and yet I loved this story. And you will too. Gaiman makes us feel as if this fantasy world actually exists, parallel to our own. He writes about this alternate reality so vividly that we feel as if we'd known about it all along, but had simply let the knowledge recede deep into our brain like our own childhood memories. The vulnerable, inquisitive, yet unnamed narrator, at age seven, recalls a string of events that change his life. I can't say much more without getting deep into the plot, so let it suffice to say that the story is engrossing and exciting. Gaiman's imagination will delight you. Buy the book, you'll love it!FIVE STARS!...more

title: Tell the Wolves I'm Home
author: Brunt, Carol Rifka*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved this book. That shouldn't have surprised me considering TELL THE WOLVES I'M HOME was on beaucoup Best Books of 2012 lists, but I did. The protI loved this book. That shouldn't have surprised me considering TELL THE WOLVES I'M HOME was on beaucoup Best Books of 2012 lists, but I did. The protagonist in this story is a 14-year old girl, and I read very little YA lit—maybe that's why I didn't pick it up before now—but this is NOT a Young Adult book. Nor, according to interviews with Carol Rifka Brunt, was it supposed to be a coming-of-age story. Yes, the young girl, June, grows up (emotionally) in this story, but the story itself is so much more than that. Briefly, The Wolves is about 14-year old June, the younger of two daughters, whose Uncle Finn is dying of AIDS. Set in 1987, the story has a palpable gravitas that it wouldn't have if it were set in 2012. Back then, AIDS was new, unknown, and very scary. June and Finn are best friends, at least in June's mind. It's not until after Finn dies (that's not a spoiler; we know that from the first sentence) that June learns Finn has a lover, Toby. In fact, June is the last to know everything in her family. The story is about how she starts to take charge of her world. The ending is happy and heartrending at the same time. So what makes The Wolves so good? Brunt has managed to channel core emotions—the emotions EACH of us has—through the voice of a child. When these thoughts and fears come from the mouth of a teenage girl, they seem real but not threatening to us as adult readers. Do you know a single person who isn't insecure to some degree? Who doesn't feel like everyone else has more friends than she does? Who doesn't wonder what she's missing out on? Today, this is known as FOMO, fear of missing out. "Kids" are desperate to NOT feel like June. But we all do, to some degree. In fact, I think June might be the literary character to whom I most closely identify.But it's not just well written characters that make this book worth buying; the plot is riveting and real. June's sister, Greta, and their mother, Dani, each have significant subplot stories. Some readers say they "hate" Dani, Finn's sister, but again, that's because Brunt has done such a marvelous job of showing how fear manifests itself in relationships.If I haven't convinced you yet to run out and buy this book, let me add that Brunt has a lovely way with words. She has captured universal feelings and cloaked them in seemingly innocuous, yet powerful sentences. I highlighted dozens of passages, the most amazing being two paragraphs in the middle of Chapter Forty. (I have the ebook, so not sure what page that is in the hardback.) In this chapter, June is talking with Finn's partner, Toby, about dying. Toby's observation on dying is touching and beautiful and important for all of us. Buy the book just for that.Is TELL THE WOLVES I'M HOME sad? Yes, but it's also lovely. Buy the book, read the book, thank me later.FIVE STARS...more

review: Taylor Stevens has given us another page-turning thriller! THE DOLL feels more cerebral to me than her first two novels (THE INFORMATIONIST and THE INTaylor Stevens has given us another page-turning thriller! THE DOLL feels more cerebral to me than her first two novels (THE INFORMATIONIST and THE INNOCENT), and I'm happy for that. THE DOLL features Stevens' kick ass androgynous hero(ine), Vanessa Michael Munroe ... though I'm not sure the name "Vanessa" appears more than once in the book. Michael, as she is better known, is abducted on Page 1. Her boss/boyfriend Miles Bradford takes the lead in helping free her while she is put to work for her abductors. The story continues this two-pronged approach at defeating the criminals.The plot of THE DOLL is tight, exciting, and full of action; fewer people are brutally killed than in THE INFORMATIONIST (this is a good thing in my opinion!). The characters are more fully fleshed out than before; Stevens does an excellent job of getting into the heads of each of her characters, even the "bad guys." Michael—who continually proves she's much smarter than you or I—plays mind games with her foes; I like that in a hero. If there's anyone who still doesn't know the true life story of the author, Taylor Stevens, he should definitely read her bio before reading her books. Stevens' background is an amazing story, and it explains a lot about how she knows what she knows. THE DOLL is an exciting, emotional, interesting novel. Four bright and shiny stars!...more

title: Mort Morte
author: Sterry, David Henry*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Holy mother of murder, Mort Morte! I'm thinking that David Henry Sterry ate Aesop for breakfast one day and burped this book out later that afternoon;Holy mother of murder, Mort Morte! I'm thinking that David Henry Sterry ate Aesop for breakfast one day and burped this book out later that afternoon; there has to be a lesson in here somewhere, but I'm still stunned speechless so I can't quite articulate it. I think it has something to do with the medicinal qualities of tea ... Are you a fan of Beavis & Butthead? The Simpsons? Family Guy? Did you laugh when you saw/read American Psycho? If so, you're going to love this short story. And by short, I mean short.Mort Morte is the story of a boy who loves his mother, and who knows evil when he sees it. Mort Morte is a boy who is ready to right wrongs, unfortunately in all the wrong ways. Mort Morte is a troubled child. Then he commits murder. Not once, not twice, read the book to find out how many times. Mort Morte's mother is a troubled woman. She keeps marrying the wrong man. Not once, not twice, read the book to find out how many times. Seriously, MORT MORTE is a brilliant satire, a sad commentary on the dark side of life, and a hysterically disturbing story. I can't say it's my kind of humor, but the book is original, fast paced, and captivating. Despite all the aforementioned murder, I had to keep turning the pages to see what would happen next. And that is the sign of a great story.Four Stars (If I were a bit more twisted, I'd probably have given it five!)...more

title: Bluets
author: Nelson, Maggie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: BLUETS is not a novel, nor is it a book of poetry, yet it tells a story. The back cover says it's classified under Essay/Literature, so that's probablBLUETS is not a novel, nor is it a book of poetry, yet it tells a story. The back cover says it's classified under Essay/Literature, so that's probably right.I bought this book on recommendation of a good friend; it's not the kind of book I normally buy. In this crazy world, it's difficult for me to slow down enough to appreciate such beautiful writing. In deed, I'm sure I would do a horrible job trying to recount this book with any sort of accuracy. What I can tell you, is that this 95-page book is divided into 240 numbered paragraphs—thoughts, really. Each of them is lyrical, meaningful, and touching. In the opening pages, I thought Maggie Nelson was describing love, but not for another person, for the color blue. Ultimately I came to think was that "blue" is essentially a code name for whomever one might love, kind of a more poetic form of ____________. BLUETS is the kind of book that I might only truly understand if I could discuss it with much smarter and deeper people than myself. This is the stuff of grad school, in all the best ways.I'd like to read BLUETS again when life is less harried. Four stars—I'm sure it deserves five, but it was too esoteric for me....more

title: Moonwalking with Einstein: The Art and Science of Remembering Everything
author: Foer, Joshua*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Once again, my expectations going in to this book have greatly influenced my final rating. (This happens to me all the time, especially with movies.) Once again, my expectations going in to this book have greatly influenced my final rating. (This happens to me all the time, especially with movies.) The title is fantastic: Moonwalking With Einstein—I love it! Original, catchy, very visual. But the subtitle might be where I was thrown: The Art and Science of Remembering Everything. I thought Joshua Foer was going to teach the reader how this is done. He doesn't. It's not that easy. (Um, duh. Right?)Foer does an excellent job of chronicling how this book came about, and how he became the USA's Memory Champion. In essence, he says any of us could have done the same if we put in the same amount commitment and hours of practice that he did. He relates stories and studies of both extremes of memory: a man known as S who remembers everything (to his own detriment); and a man who can't remember anything for longer than about 30 seconds. Foer goes into the science of the brain just enough to explain how it functions. He does give us the basics of how it's done, but it certainly isn't a training manual.Best of all, the story is told like a novel. He begins at the germination of his idea for an article, and ends with a suspenseful recounting of the competition that he won. He wraps up his final thoughts well. I enjoyed this book. I underlined and dogeared a lot of wisdom, suggestions, and facts about how memory works, and I do believe that I will be able to commit more to memory—if I so choose. The ending gist of this book is that memory is a dying art. With computers, cameras, and cell phones, it's just not that necessary to remember everything anymore.Perhaps with a different subtitle, I might have been able to give it five stars, but ...Four Stars...more

title: Beautiful Ruins
author: Walter, Jess
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Normally, I write my Goodreads s immediately after finishing a book so every thought is fresh, but I've let my thoughts on BEAUTIFUL RUINS by JeNormally, I write my Goodreads s immediately after finishing a book so every thought is fresh, but I've let my thoughts on BEAUTIFUL RUINS by Jess Walter resonate for a couple days, and resonate they have. Jess Walter is an excellent writer. His sentences were never awkward: they never got in the way of the story. In that regard, I can see why The Huffington Post called BEAUTIFUL RUINS a "beach read." It's a beautiful love story and easy to read. On the other hand, I think to call it a beach read is almost an insult. Walter cleverly made a complicated story seem simple.This story jumps from 1962 to "Recently," with various stops in between (plus one chapter that jumps back to 1846), and each piece of the story is delicately woven into a lovely, cinematic whole. There are also multiple important characters, nearly a dozen, in fact. And, each of these characters is believable, deep, and speaks in a distinct voice. See what I'm talking about? Walter's talent is bordering on genius. Further, through the characters, Walter expresses multiple poignant, insightful views on humanity. I would love to cite several examples, but taken out of context, they seem to lose their power. Let it suffice to say I underlined multiple, powerful phrases. I don't think that BEAUTIFUL RUINS will become an American classic, but I do think that casual readers will be delighted by this book, and that writers will be impressed by the elegant way Jess Walter tells his story.Five Stars...more

title: Where'd You Go, Bernadette
author: Semple, Maria
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Can a person be completely ambivalent? Extremely ambivalent? If so, that's how I feel about WHERE'D YOU GO, BERNADETTE?It's essential for me to state Can a person be completely ambivalent? Extremely ambivalent? If so, that's how I feel about WHERE'D YOU GO, BERNADETTE?It's essential for me to state that I listened to this book on audible.com. The narrator, Kathleen Wilhoite, gave a powerful performance of Maria Semple's book. Note that I said "powerful" not "fantastic." I don't think, even if I purchased a paper copy of this novel and read it again, that I could get Ms. Wilhoite's voice out of my head as I read it for myself. When reading Bee's lines, the narrator used a childlike voice; that was okay for the most part. When she read Bernadette's lines, I believe the voice was pretty natural for her. That was okay. But when she launched into foreign accents, I shuddered! East Indian? Russian? Australian? Irish? No! STOP! Not working. The amazing part—and probably the reason she was chosen as the narrator—was in the second half when Bee goes to a Christmas Concert, and Ms. Wilhoite begins singing Oh, Holy Night. Wow! The lady can sing. So the story. Ms. Semple did an excellent job of telling the story from a 12-year old's point of view. Bernadette's daughter Bee is a genius. (That's convenient, because a genius 12-year old can say and know things that most kids don't know.) The story is told as an epistolary recounting of Bernadette's final days (before she disappears), and Bee becomes an amateur detective who's trying to find her mother. Bee is funny, precocious, and sweet. Bernadette, however, is a mess, and I had a difficult time accepting her as a realistic character. She has issues (Don't we all?), but they've stretched on for over twenty years! And Elgie, her husband, seems to barely notice. Yes, he's a workaholic, but come on.I could go on, nitpicking the inflated plot and the minor characters, but I don't think this book was supposed to be taken that seriously. (I'm kind of a serious person.) WHERE'D YOU GO, BERNADETTE? is a light-hearted, funny story with an endearing message: Be true to yourself, but don't ignore your loved ones. I enjoyed this novel, but I can't give it Four Stars. Once again, Goodreads, I'm feeling stymied by the lack of a Half Star option. Therefore:Three Stars....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Elizabeth Strout is, according to Wikipedia, a 57-year old, extremely intelligent and accomplished Pulitzer Prize wining novelist. She has a law degreElizabeth Strout is, according to Wikipedia, a 57-year old, extremely intelligent and accomplished Pulitzer Prize wining novelist. She has a law degree. She is married and lives in Maine. These characteristics undoubtedly figured in to her creating her Pulitzer Prize winning novel (or rather linked short stories) OLIVE KITTERIDGE. I loved that book. Wikipedia does not, however, mention if Ms. Kitteridge has any children.In THE BURGESS BOYS, Strout chronicles the unraveling of a family, or perhaps the self-accualitzation of the family members, depending on your point of view. While Ms. Strout expertly described the life and inner workings of Olive Kitteridge (a retired school teacher), I don't think she hit the same mark with the Burgess brothers or the Burgesses's children. Many times I felt she missed the mark of how they talk or think.For example, a third Burgess family member, sister Susan, has a son named Zachary. Zach, though we know he's a troubled seventeen-year old, often calls his mother "Mommy." Also, the older Burgess brother, now in his 50s, continues to call his younger brother Bob "knucklehead." Even though we also know Jim has issues of his own, I found these two stereotypical catch-phrases to be very off-putting. As the mother of four grown boys, I think I can speak with some authority and say that these behaviors (by Zach and Jim) are not very realistic. More importantly though, I felt this novel got off to a very slow start. Yes, Zach's dilemma (he threw a frozen pig's head into a mosque during Ramadan) happened by page 19, but that's not really what the novel is about. The novel is about how lies affect lives. Strout doesn't get to the heart of that until about half way through the book. That's when it started getting interesting to me. If this book hadn't been written by Elizabeth Strout, I don't think I would have made it to that point.So, I'm no Pulitzer Prize winning critic, but I am an avid reader. I give THE BURGESS BOYS 3 1/2 stars, rounded up to 4. ...more

title: Cider House Rules
author: Irving, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was surprisingly disappointed in this novel. I read The Cider House Rules for three reasons: One, I remember loving A Prayer For Owen Meany (I rememI was surprisingly disappointed in this novel. I read The Cider House Rules for three reasons: One, I remember loving A Prayer For Owen Meany (I remember it being long and boring until BANG, it blew me away); two, this book is a classic so I wanted to be familiar with it. The movie—which I intend to watch soon—won multiple Oscars; three, I wanted to read a story with a rogue doctor, and Wilbur Larch is that. But, hello, nearly 600 pages of wildly omniscient voice, capturing way too much detail about thoughts/actions/facts/details about history/characters/Burma/etc. that have nothing to do with the plot? Sorry, but it seemed only to show off Mr. Irving's incredible depth of knowledge. Mr. Irving is a master-writer; no doubt about that. But I found the pace sluggish. I know, I know ... Who am I to slam John Irving? No one. This is just my humble opinion.What I'd love to discuss with others are these three points:[Attn: spoiler alert]1) How does a character as seemingly humble and "salt-of-the-earth" as Homer live with two such substantial lies? What kind of man would spend 16 years living in the same house with his lover and her husband, and settle for sneaking off with the girl in the dark of night? And to wait 16 years before telling your son that he is your son? Come on ... And then to perform abortions if you feel like you're killing children? No, you either believe in the act or you don't. I cannot imagine a person (orphan or not) being that UNTRUE to himself. Homer has character—this is obvious in the way he raises his son—so I don't think he would live with "Wait and see" for that long. A week, two weeks, tops. Not that Irving doesn't try to justify his decisions, not that Irving doesn't show Homer's struggle with this, just that in the end I felt Homer Wells was not a realistic character.2) Who's the worse character, Homer Wells or Candy Worthington? Dear God, woman, make a decision. Either that, or join a commune, but don't, for Heaven's sake, live with the lies. 3) The title: The Cider House Rules ... I found that an odd choice. My guess is that our take-away should be "Everyone has their own set of rules for life." Any opinions on that? Mr. Rose certainly had his own cider house rules. Wilbur Larch had his own rules on abortions. Candy had her own rules ("I can live with both the men I love and my son whom I will never acknowledge if I want to."). I suppose Mr. Irving said, "My hero can be a wishy-washy, two-faced, non-licensed doctor if I want him to be." My favorite characters with the two we were supposed to hate: Dr. Wilbur Larch, the criminal abortionist and drug addict; and Melony, the wild, angry lesbian. Not that I can relate to either of them, it's just that they seemed to stay in character throughout the story. All right, I'm starting to feel badly about my own opinions. I gave a lot of hours to this novel. I wish I had read it and discussed it when it first came out so I can figure out what I missed. I still plan to watch the movie, if only to see what Irving did to the story with some constraints.Three non-shining stars.Final note: Since I finished this book, I have watched the movie adaptation. For maybe the fist time ever, I can say I liked the movie better! In the movie, Homer and Candy don't turn into idiots at the end. Homer goes back to the orphanage when Wally comes back from the war. And, Homer doesn't come across as such a hypocrite. Lastly, I thought the movie did a better job of offering up an explanation for the title. I now believe the title suggests: one group of people cannot--and should not--try to impose rules on a different group of people. The cider house rules imposed on the "negro" migrant workers by the farm owners were essentially ridiculous, AND, the rules were written on a piece of paper despite the fact that none of the workers knew how to read. ...more
