title: Shenanigans!
author: Owens, Joseph Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: SHENANIGANS!, by Joseph Michael Owens, nearly demands its own literary category. It's listed as a short story collection/novella, but it reads like a SHENANIGANS!, by Joseph Michael Owens, nearly demands its own literary category. It's listed as a short story collection/novella, but it reads like a memoir. I can't help but think that the stories aren't too far from the author's real life. I met Joe once, at a workshop, and I know many of the main character's personal facts to be pretty darn similar to his own. That being said, the adventures that the main character, Ben Palko, undertakes could be entirely fictional, in which case the book is even more amazing than I realize. Shenanigans! is seriously funny. Ben Palko is a self-deprecating twenty-something white male who is alternately a student and or employee in the Midwest. Think Catcher in the Rye meets Office Space. He speaks to us in a casual, personal, colloquial voice, kinda like a best friend. In the stories (labeled as Chapters), he relays snippets from his life that range from grossly hilarious (Contemptibly, A Hair) to insightful (We Always Trust Each Other, Except When We Don't) to heart-rending (The Year That Was ... And Was Not).Shenanigans! is short, barely 100 pages, but it's full of wisdom and style. Let's hope this is the first of many books by Owens.Five Stars...more

title: The Map and the Territory
author: Houellebecq, Michel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read THE MAP AND THE TERRITORY for a book club, and I was very excited to read it. It contains several of my favorite subjects: art, literature, famI read THE MAP AND THE TERRITORY for a book club, and I was very excited to read it. It contains several of my favorite subjects: art, literature, family relationships, and it's set in France. Unfortunately, it didn't live up to my expectations. This was my first book by Houellebecq, so I can't put TMATT into context with his other work, but I would like to read at least one more.This novel is broken into three parts plus a prologue and an epilogue, but it felt more like related short stories than a novel. The book was at times comically cynical, touchingly sensitive, wildly unfocused, and infuriatingly pedantic. I felt like much of the novel was nothing more than a medium for Houellebecq to attempt to impress the world with his knowledge, though Slate Magazine accused him of plagiarizing French Wikipedia, so how much of his rambling was personal knowledge is up for debate.Essentially, this is a story about an artist named Jed Martin. Jed is basically a sad sack. His mother committed suicide, and he has a distant relationship with his father. He has no friends to speak of, other than a girlfriend named Olga for part of the book. Jed becomes wildly successful despite himself.There's one line in particular that sums up this novel for me. On page 129, Jed's gallerist Franz says: "we're at a point where success in market terms justifies and validates anything, replacing all the theories." Well there you go. Houellebecq is "famous"—or at least famous enough—that he can apparently get away with a novel that wanders all over hell and back plot-wise. Jed's meteoric success as an artist must be Houellebecq's jab at how unrealistic the art world can be (not that I disagree with him), but it really became laughable. Although I underlined many nice passages, most of my marginalia is negative. Three Stars....more

title: Motherless Brooklyn
author: Lethem, Jonathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am shocked that I didn't like this book more than I did. First, Jonathan Lethem! This is the first book I've read by Lethem, but of course, I've reaI am shocked that I didn't like this book more than I did. First, Jonathan Lethem! This is the first book I've read by Lethem, but of course, I've read a lot about him, about what a wonderful writer he is. No disagreement there. Second, a neo-noir? I'm in! I love the old Raymond Chandler/Philip Marlowe novels (although they can move a bit slowly for my taste). So, combine Lethem with a noir, amateur detective novel and I expected to love this book.I didn't.MOTHERLESS BROOKLYN is a story about four orphans who are "chosen" by a small-time mob guy to help out with his dirty work. The narrator and protagonist is Lionel Essrog, a man with Tourette's Syndrome. Lethem does a fantastic job with this character, making him smart and sympathetic at the same time. I can honestly say that I feel I understand this syndrome better than I did before reading the book, and if/when I encounter someone afflicted with Tourette's, I will not be as shocked or scared as I might have been before. That's good writing. Lethem's manipulation of the English language through this character voice is funny and brilliant. However, the story failed me. Chapter 1 opens with Lionel and one of his buddies on a stakeout. Fantastic! I was really into the plot and the writing. Then Chapter 2 goes deep into the characters' backstory, almost an info-dump, if you will. The backstory is not incorporated into the novel, it's laid out for the reader in one chapter. By the time I got to Chapter 3, I had to go back to the beginning to remember what was happening in the plot. Now, are the characters interesting and well-rounded? Yes. But I thought he could have done smaller flashbacks instead of lumping that all into one stand-alone chapter. Plus, there are essentially seven "main characters;" that's a lot to keep track of in a whodunit.Most importantly for this , I thought the mystery, "the case," got lost. Why exactly is Lionel on a chase when he basically knows "whodunit"? And, how do all these characters link together? Apparently I'm not the only one who felt this way, because the penultimate chapter, Formerly Known, spells the whole story out. If the mystery had been well told (sorry, Mr. Lethem), he would not have needed to walk the reader through the plot in this chapter, at least not to the extent he did. He gave us new information, a no-no this late in a mystery. The reader should be able to piece it all together if the mystery is well-told. Again, in my humble opinion, most of these facts should have been incorporated into the story so we could get CLOSE to the truth on our own. While I loved Lionel Essrog, I did not love this book. Three and a half stars. ...more

title: A Room of One’s Own
author: Woolf, Virginia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's easy to see why Virginia Woolf has remained one of the top female writers of all time: her prose is poetic, and her thoughts observations are intIt's easy to see why Virginia Woolf has remained one of the top female writers of all time: her prose is poetic, and her thoughts observations are intelligent yet sensitive. This book is brief, yet packed with powerful ideas; I think a reader could talk about it for more hours than it takes to read it. It's obvious Ms. Woolf did a lot of research for this essay, but she kept her focus admirably narrow. I imagine she could have written a dozen volumes on the subject "Women and Fiction" if she had wanted. So, "a room of one's own and five hundred a year" ... Woolf says that's what a woman needs to write. Certainly that is a good place to start, but what about a passion, an opinion, a voice? Maybe she has these qualities in spades so she takes them for granted. I know a few wealthy women with more than a few extra rooms who could never write a decent book. I also know women who've had neither, yet have written best sellers. But, as I keep reminding myself, this book was written almost 90 years ago. It wasn't very long before she wrote it that women got the right to vote, the right to hold certain jobs, and the right to own land. She also discusses children, and the fact that most of the few notable women writers before her had no children. Wow. It's difficult to imagine being a woman back then—but I imagine women of 2113 will look back and think 2013 was a horrible time to be a woman! Weird.Anyway, like many others who have ed this book on Goodreads, I expected a much harsher feminist rant from Ms. Woolf. But I found her opinions quite democratic. She notes the harsh attitudes pertaining to women from the days of Shakespeare to 1928 (when she presented the essays that became this book), but I felt she did so in a matter-of-fact manner, not an angry diatribe. Some men might disagree.I enjoyed A Room of One's Own, but I can't say that I loved it. Four Stars...more

The truth of their experiences and feelings are universal.I plan to pull my copy of THE ESSENTIAL TALES OF CHEKHOV off my shelves over the next twenty, thirty, or forty years to read more of the stories, and most likely, read the ones again that I have already loved.FIVE STARS...more

title: Tenth of December
author: Saunders, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book, TENTH OF DECEMBER, by George Saunders, makes me want to reduce every other book I've ever rated down one star. Because to give this book FiThis book, TENTH OF DECEMBER, by George Saunders, makes me want to reduce every other book I've ever rated down one star. Because to give this book Five Stars, along with the twenty or so other books that I have given Five Stars, just isn't fair.This book proves that it's possible for ME to LIKE short story collections written by white, middle-aged American men. (See previous s for Hemingway, Diaz, Denis Johnson, JD Salinger.) Saunders is able to do in a few pages what most authors will never be able to do: rivet the reader's mind and heart to the story at hand—and that comes from a lady with ADHD.Take "Escape From Spiderhead," my hands-down favorite of this collection of ten stories. I was so captivated/appalled/awed by this story that, unlike every other story in the book, I didn't even slow down enough to underline the amazing sentences like I did in all the other stories... other than beside one paragraph I wrote: Fantastic! This is easily the most powerful story I've ever read. It is original, emotional, and poetic—yet scarily brutal. Every story has new characters (as opposed to other collections that are linked by one main character (Diaz), or collections that have a common character in different settings (Hemingway)), and this presents the reader with a welcome challenge: with each new story, the reader must pay close attention to determine who the protagonist is, where and what is involved with the new setting and plot, and the protagonist's backstory. Saunders never hands you that on a lovely platter; he greedily holds onto the important facts until way late in the story, making you work at what's really going on. Then, as he drops a delicious morsel, you hungrily snatch it up and say, Thank you, Mr. Saunders! This is the best story I've ever devoured! In each of the above mentioned stories, the characters have such a distinct voice, so spot-on and pitch-perfect, that the reader feels he/she IS the character. A chubby 12-year old kid with a fantastic imagination? Yes, that's me! A murderer, in a lab, participating in horrendous experiments? Yes, that's me! A mother afraid to give her baby to her own brother? Yes, that's me! But you don't have to take my word for it. The cover story of the Jan. 6, 2013 NYTimes Magazine called Tenth of December "The best book you'll read this year." And those people at the NYTimes generally know what they're talking about. Five Shining Stars!...more

title: Here Is New York
author: White, E.B.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: New York City is a club, and E.B. White makes you want to join. Written in 1949, this essay is lyrical, magical, and honest, and only 31 pages long. WNew York City is a club, and E.B. White makes you want to join. Written in 1949, this essay is lyrical, magical, and honest, and only 31 pages long. White, of CHARLOTTE'S WEB fame, packs more sentiment into each sentence than some writers can squeeze into an entire paragraph. Though many of the landmarks he mentions are long gone, White sweeps the reader from Ellis Island to Harlem with stops in the LES, Greenwich Village, Broadway, and Central Park along the way, offering vignettes of the characters, smells, sounds, and emotions peculiar to each neighborhood. His words are not sugarcoated; he clearly describes the dirt and crime and challenges and still makes the reader feel they would be lucky to live there and experience the city first hand.It's like wanting a puppy even though you know it's going to pee on your floor and chew on your shoes. You still want the puppy.The greatest quality of New York, according to White, was the apparent unwritten agreement between the vastly disparate demographics; it's like the immigrants inherently knew the rules of getting along in the city, and they (mostly) followed those rules. The balance therein was what made New York City the greatest city in the world. I'd say that's more true today than it was in 1949.E.B. White is the antithesis of the Pied Piper. White tells you everything bad about New York, and yet you still want to follow him into the city.Five Stars...more

title: Reading Like a Writer: A Guide for People Who Love Books and for Those Who Want to Write Them
author: Prose, Francine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Imagine reading for decades only to learn that you've been missing the point your entire life!Francine Prose, author and teacher, likes to say that shImagine reading for decades only to learn that you've been missing the point your entire life!Francine Prose, author and teacher, likes to say that she reads "sentence by sentence." She reads for the beauty each sense imparts. She also worships the work of Anton Checkov.Oops. That's not exactly how I've been reading all my life. I've never read Checkov (although I did just order a book of his 100 best stories because of her.) I generally read for plot and action, quickly, so that I can get to the end and start another book. Ms. Prose suggests slowing down, which I will now that I understand why. READING LIKE A WRITER is a book that everyone who would like to write a book should read. She pulls myriad examples out of classic novels (as well as many books I've never heard of) and illustrates how and why they are outstanding examples of good writing, writing worth striving for. I suppose that there are some readers out there who have no inkling to write a book who would appreciate her guidance on how to appreciate literature, but the book has the feeling of a masters' level writing class. (That's a good thing.)My only knock on this excellent book is that I would have liked more examples taken from contemporary writing, more examples even from the 20th Century, as opposed to centuries old passages. Writing has changed, what readers expect from a book has changed, and more recent examples would be more applicable to those of us trying to become better writers in the 21st Century.That being said, I consider this book a MUST READ for any writer who doesn't have an MFA. I underlined hundreds of sage passages. Once again, I'd like to be able to add a half-star. Four Stars ...more

title: This Is How You Lose Her
author: Díaz, Junot
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is the straw that broke my Goodreads back. I cannot do justice to rating this book with just Five Stars. Even audible.com gives us three catThis book is the straw that broke my Goodreads back. I cannot do justice to rating this book with just Five Stars. Even audible.com gives us three categories (Overall, Performance, Story). Goodreads should have Ten Stars, or else categories: Overall, Writing, Story/Information. I want to start a Goodreads revolution! Please, Goodreads, give us more stars with which to rate books!Junot Diaz is the master of his own sui generis. I would give him Ten Stars for his writing ability. He writes like Rihanna sings; his voice is distinct and instantly recognizable; that is the ultimate talent of a writer. I don't understand all of what he writes (I'm not up on my Spanish swearword slang), but he certainly gets the gist across—powerfully. This book is packed with emotion, and by the final story (out of nine), the reader actually feels immense sympathy for the lying, cheating, sex-crazed bastard Yunior. (Forgive me, Mr. Diaz, if this is more autobiographical than fiction.) Now, as a white, middle-American female, can I relate to the story? Not so much. Do I aspire to write like Diaz? Again, not so much. That would be like me trying to pass off Kimchi as an old family recipe. Is this the kind of book I love? No, sorry, can't say that it is. I prefer novels with characters to whom I can relate. For that I'd give him Four Stars (out of Ten). However, the fact that he made me care about the aforementioned man in the end does speak to his talent as a writer, I have to say.Junot Diaz won the Pulitzer Prize for his last book, The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao, so for me to give this book Three and a Half Stars (the average of both categories) is almost laughable. (Who am I to give a writer of this character such a low score?) So, based on the painful restraints of Goodreads existing scale, I'm giving this book Four Stars. Not because I liked it that much, but because I know it's worthy even though I won't recommend it to most of my friends....more

title: Road Dogs        (Jack Foley #2)
author: Leonard, Elmore
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let's just start here: ROAD DOGS is not a mystery novel. Silly me, I thought it would be—Elmore Leonard being a "Grand Master" of the Mystery Writers Let's just start here: ROAD DOGS is not a mystery novel. Silly me, I thought it would be—Elmore Leonard being a "Grand Master" of the Mystery Writers of America, and all. ROAD DOGS is my first Leonard novel. I picked it up for a number of reasons, the primary one being that I'd never read this master writer before. He's known for terse writing, fantastic bad guys, even better dialogue, and ... wait for it ... mysteries. ROAD DOGS is literary fiction about a bank robber, Jack Foley. You can't call him the hero because he never does anything heroic in the story. He simply lets the other characters (mostly bad people) ruin themselves. In this story, Jack Foley befriends Cundo Rey, a murderer, while they're both spending 30 months in a Florida jail. When they're released, they go to Cundo's home in Venice, California. Jack Foley's story, from beginning to end of this novel, is a quintessential literary fiction character arc as he goes from "bad guy" to "not such a bad guy." (I can't really call him a good guy.) The writing here is exactly what I expected from Leonard: terse and crisp. He has prison/gang/Cuban slang down cold! It's the plot that threw me for a loop. Not that this was a bad story by any means, but Leonard trots us down one path, then suddenly veers off to a completely unexpected story line, not once, but twice! In a mystery novel, a crime is typically committed at the outset, which is then solved by the protagonist. Well, that's not this story.So, if you're interested in reading a good story about interesting bad guys, you'll like ROAD DOGS. If you're looking for a great mystery novel, keep looking.I'd give this 3 1/2 starts if Goodreads would let me, but I'm rounding up to Four Stars....more

title: Sweet Tooth
author: McEwan, Ian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's no question that Ian McEwan is an excellent writer. SWEET TOOTH might even make a good movie (like ATONEMENT). But... wait for it... I didn't There's no question that Ian McEwan is an excellent writer. SWEET TOOTH might even make a good movie (like ATONEMENT). But... wait for it... I didn't like this book as much as I hoped I would. The s for this were quite strong; one said something to the effect of: The twist at the end will delight you. Yeah, no. I thought the end was disappointing. I absolutely wanted another chapter about the current day life of the protagonist (the opening pages tell you the story is a flashback). Plus, the story seemed awfully pedantic. McEwan seemed to be showing off his knowledge of 1950s - 1970s World politics and British literature. Some, of course, was necessary, but for my personal taste it was simply too much. I suppose at his level, he has a lot of erudite friends to impress. I imagine McEwan got quite the kick by talking about the nascent Man Booker Prize (which he won in 1998 for his novel AMSTERDAM), and that the writer in this story hung out with an unknown Martin Amis.I bought SWEET TOOTH because I wanted a good read with a female protagonist. I was forty pages into it before I said, this is kind of boring. Any person who skips exposition and jumps to the dialogue will finish this book in about ten minutes. It's mostly telling, less showing, very little speaking. But then, "telling" seems to be a British trait. All that being said, I highlighted many delightful phrases. The story is "sweet," a love story that lets us root for the couple to be happy. Three Stars for SWEET TOOTH. (Three and a half stars if Goodreads would let me.)...more

title: The Wisdom of Psychopaths: What Saints, Spies, and Serial Killers Can Teach Us About Success
author: Dutton, Kevin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I cannot imagine a single person who wouldn't find this book fascinating. I am a writer, so I bought this book as a reference for creating better "badI cannot imagine a single person who wouldn't find this book fascinating. I am a writer, so I bought this book as a reference for creating better "bad guys." Every good book needs one or two psychopaths, no? I thought I'd skim it for a some traits and clues into the world of a psychopath. As it turns out, I was captivated by the stories, the writing, and the way Kevin Dutton interweaves the lives and traits of psychopaths with "normal" people. For instance, surgeons, astronauts, and corporate CEOs have—and MUST have—many psychopathic qualities, qualities that are necessary to reach the highest level of their professions. They just don't normally cross that all-important line into violence. The Wisdom of Psychopaths is about 220 pages, so not a long book. Dutton mixes a keen sense of humor in with his stories and anecdotes so it reads pretty fast. My only knock is that some of the stories/studies start to feel redundant... although, maybe that just goes to show how many and how long psychopaths have been around. I imagine it was a challenge for him to find the professional/public balance of data and information. But keep reading... he doesn't even get to Saint Paul until page 189—and that's an interesting story.Fascinating book. Glad I bought it.Four Stars....more

title: In Our Time
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Reading Hemingway, for me, is like running a marathon. I don't want to run a marathon, but I want to say "I have run a marathon." Hemingway is not oneReading Hemingway, for me, is like running a marathon. I don't want to run a marathon, but I want to say "I have run a marathon." Hemingway is not one of my favorite authors, but I feel obligated to read his work. (My opinion would undoubtedly be different if I were a twenty-something male.)I admire—and would not begin to argue—the importance of Hemingway's work on American and therefore world literature. His writing style is distinct, spot-on, and unique. Trouble is, I'm not very interested in the laconic, macho man persona. In fact, I wonder how many women would say they honestly LIKE Hemingway's stories. That being said, of the sixteen stories in IN OUR TIME, four stood out to me as my relative favorites: The End of Something; The Three-day Blow; The Battler; and Mr. and Mrs. Elliot. These four seemed to have a little more depth, a little more motivation behind the characters' actions. I also enjoyed the layers in The End of Something. The title could refer, in varying degrees, to the end of the town mill, the end of trout season, and most significantly to the end of Nick and Marjorie's relationship. I like that Hemingway gave the story a vague title and more than one subplot. Also, we see at the very end how upset Nick is at having ended the relationship; I like to feel the characters' emotions in literature. I do admire Hemingway's trademark short, sharp, declarative sentences typically tucked into the middle of a paragraph. For example, in The End of Something, just before Nick is about to break up with Marjorie, and she is rowing the boat back onto the shore, Hemingway writes: "Little waves came in with it." That is very likely literal, but it also applies figuratively. Waves of anxiety? Waves of dread? Maybe all of the above, and that's what makes it such a great sentence. But, back to MY  of this collection. Meh. Too many of the other stories did nothing for me. Three Stars....more

title: The End of the Affair
author: Greene, Graham
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I first read this book in the 90's, but when I saw on audible.com that it had been recorded and performed by Colin Firth, I had to "read" it again witI first read this book in the 90's, but when I saw on audible.com that it had been recorded and performed by Colin Firth, I had to "read" it again with his voice in my ear. I'm so glad I did. Firth's performance of Greene's words was gorgeous.The novel, let me just say it, is heartbreaking. That shouldn't come as any surprise considering the title; the beginning of an affair is (according to literature and Hollywood) the most exhilarating feeling in the world, thus, the end of an affair might be expected to be the worst feeling in the world. But Greene doesn't focus on Sarah's husband discovering the affair between his wife and their friend, Maurice. The story, set during WWII in London, focuses on WHY Sarah broke off her affair with Maurice. Maurice was madly in love with her, and he was destroyed by her decision. But the novel is about more than that. It's also about religion, specifically about the existence of God. In the beginning of the book, none of the three main characters, Sarah, Henry and Maurice, believe in God. Throughout the story, Sarah begins to believe in Him, and Maurice struggles to understand that as well. This, of course, figures into why Sarah ended the affair (but not as directly as you might think, so I won't spoil it for you by elaborating).Graham Greene would undoubtedly be on a list of The Greatest Writers of the 20th Century. His sentences and explanations of our crazy world are beautifully elucidated. If you're considering this novel, I most definitely say, Read it. It will touch your heart and lock inside your head. Just be prepared to do a lot of deep thinking.Five Stars....more

review: To be honest, I own this book but haven't read it in its entirety; I watched the movie and kind of read along as it played. I love Dennis Lehane's worTo be honest, I own this book but haven't read it in its entirety; I watched the movie and kind of read along as it played. I love Dennis Lehane's work, and I thought the movie of MYSTIC RIVER was powerful, heartrending, and riveting. It is gruesome, indeed, but the "beauty" of such an ugly story can be found in the character development and story arc. Lehane reminds us that we are shaped by our childhood. No matter how old we are, we will respond based on the events in our lives that affected us deeply.This story is about three young boys who were neighborhood friends in Boston in 1975. One of the boys is kidnapped for four days. Then, twenty-five years later, something tragic happens that reunites them as men and fathers. Each man responds to the current tragedy according to his background surrounding the childhood kidnapping and how it changed him. Five tragically sad Stars...more

title: Live by Night        (Coughlin, #2)
author: Lehane, Dennis*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am a big fan of Dennis Lehane's, but I'm not the target audience for this book. I agree with most of the big s of Live By Night: it's a high-lI am a big fan of Dennis Lehane's, but I'm not the target audience for this book. I agree with most of the big s of Live By Night: it's a high-level gangster novel, and it is very well-written. But in my opinion the plot is not necessarily fresh, and it never reaches the brilliance of Shutter Island.Live (rhymes with give) By Night chronicles a good-hearted though misguided young man named Joe Coughlin. Lehane elevates him by making him a non-racist in a time when almost everyone else is driven by racism. Also, for the first half of the novel, he doesn't kill anyone. How can we not like this guy? But he learns to kill... and then he learns to love... So we like him again, and of course we root for him.What sets this novel above the average crime novel is Lehane's literary gift. One example: "Far off at the horizon line, thin bolts of lightning carved jagged white veins in the skin of the world. Their faint and sudden light would reveal swollen clouds as dark as plums massed out there like an enemy army." This book is a great read but it won't make you lose any sleep.Four Stars....more

title: The Casual Vacancy
author: Rowling, J.K.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Casual Vacancy by J.K. Rowling is a stellar example of the fact that acclaimed authors can get away with things that novice writers cannot. There The Casual Vacancy by J.K. Rowling is a stellar example of the fact that acclaimed authors can get away with things that novice writers cannot. There is nothing mystical or fantastic about The Casual Vacany; in theory, anyone could have written a 500 page book about small town life. But in today's literary climate, few novice writers could have gotten it published.Which came first, Ms. Rowling's cinematic stories or the first movies of her books? The Casual Vacancy opens (after the death of Barry Fairbrother) with the teenagers of Pagford traveling on their school bus around the small town picking up the kids who figure into this story. [The story is about a slew of Pagford's adults and their teenage children, and the interaction between them.] I could clearly imagine the scene: Andrew's face pressed against the glass, trying to act cool, but aching to see Gaia, the new girl, get on the bus. The end of the novel has a similar feel: A handful of the characters storm from their homes (for many different reasons) and all cross paths near the park and the river. Very cinematic, indeed.In between those two scenes, the novel is thick and detailed, but not in a boring manner... if you have come to care about the people. If. The Casual Vacancy is a sprawling, omniscient tale about the inner feelings and relationships that we all have or have had, it's just rare these days to read a contemporary novel that goes into such detail. But then, Ms. Rowling is British, so maybe it's a birthright for her to continue in the vein of Dickens, say, and his caricatures of stereotypes. For example, the enormous deli owner, Howard Mollison, who has heart troubles, etc., etc.One other interesting technique that Ms. Rowling uses is her parenthetical explanations. Where some authors might jump to a flashback scene, Rowling just includes a few paragraphs of backstory. Perhaps this is because the novel was already quite long and she couldn't justify adding another 100 pages or so, but it certainly felt odd in today's literary world.All that being said, The Casual Vacancy is a beautifully written, elegiac tale of the vagaries of life. Most of the story lines did not end happily, but it was a very fulfilling novel, and I am glad I read it. Four Stars (because it took a long time to get invested in the characters)....more

title: The Light Between Oceans
author: Stedman, M.L.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I haven't read a more harrowing story since SOPHIE'S CHOICE, or possibly THE THORN BIRDS; all three books touch that primal mother/child bond at its dI haven't read a more harrowing story since SOPHIE'S CHOICE, or possibly THE THORN BIRDS; all three books touch that primal mother/child bond at its deepest point. I wanted to read this the moment I read the plot: A lonely couple finds a baby and raises it as their own, then refuses to give it back to its rightful mother, until... And not only does Stedman have a good hook, the plot intensifies as it nears the end of the book—as a good book should. Part 3 is hard to put down.M.L. Stedman (I'll try not to hold it against her that she goes by initials) writes gorgeous prose. I highlighted dozens of phrases, too many to list, but here are a few: when describing the ocean, "... she had the impression she could walk to Madagascar in a journey of blue upon blue." later, "... the darkness curled around her lamp like a closing fist." and, "...thunder grumbles at being left behind by the lightning." and so many more. So why only 4 stars? Bear with me for an analogy: You know how, when you go to a nice restaurant and look forward to a good meal, but your food is cold, or they put the dressing on when you specifically said to put the dressing on the side, and how when that stuff happens it's so easy to blame the waitress and give her just a slightly lower tip even though the screw-ups weren't necessarily her fault? Ok, this book is like that. It's difficult not to blame the author when the real question is, Who was the editor here? THE LIGHT BETWEEN THE OCEANS is told from an omniscient point of view, with a cast of characters so long it becomes almost comical. And on top of that, Stedman switches between present tense and past tense at random points and intervals. Who let her do that?! There seems to be no rhyme or reason for her choices, and it was very disconcerting. She can write either tense beautifully, and if she had stuck with past tense for Parts 1 and 2, then switched to present tense for Part 3, I could appreciate that. But no. It's not chapter by chapter either. The book is filled with tiny little snippets of scenes that could be any number of character's point of view and either verb tense. (Please, if someone can explain why it was done the way it was, I would be grateful.) Also, her ability to enter scenes at the last possible moment, and leave them at the first moment (a strength in writing) is exemplary, until the second half of the book where it becomes so choppy that I longed for her to eliminate some so that she could develop and strengthen others.Ok, I said my piece. I don't want to knock the author for what an editor should have caught. I've tried to find background on this novel, but there's next to nothing: no listing of Stedman's agent or editor or friends or reading groups. I am eager for her next work, but I hope it gets a little more polish.Four Stars...more

title: How Fiction Works
author: Wood, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I would never flatter myself enough to be critical of this book. James Wood is nothing short of brilliant, a man who has read seemingly every great boI would never flatter myself enough to be critical of this book. James Wood is nothing short of brilliant, a man who has read seemingly every great book ever written and, even if someone smarter than myself could argue certain points with him, he takes a stand, has an opinion, and can articulate it beautifully.HOW FICTION WORKS is one of the best books on writing that I have ever read. It is densely packed with erudite points and lessons and examples from great literature of any century. Wood delineates 123 well-researched lessons in 248 pages. As a writer, I found many lessons that will hopefully help me improve my craft. The two best examples: Points 7 - 16 on Free Indirect Style, and Number 119 on Hypotyposis (yeah, you have to read it to know what he's talking about). I especially like his word and definition of "lifeness" (Point 123).This book, to me, is like a grad-level textbook. Not for the faint of heart, just for those of us with a passion to know a fraction of what James Wood does.Enough said. Five Stars...more

author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I suppose, considering the author of this epic story is Stephen King, I should rate it Five Stars. But if you've read any of my other s, I speakI suppose, considering the author of this epic story is Stephen King, I should rate it Five Stars. But if you've read any of my other s, I speak from the heart here on goodreads. (The minute I get hired by the NYTimes Book Review, I'll be a bit more objective.)11/22/63 is an excellent story, but in my opinion, about 200 pages too long. There is no doubt in my mind that King is one of the best storytellers of our time. That's even better than being a great author. Of course, he's both. King writes a story like he's talking to his best friend over a campfire. I love that about him, but this story would take an entire summer-camp worth of campfires to finish. And that is my only knock.In this book, the protagonist is shown "a rabbit hole," through which he travels back in time to September 1958. It doesn't matter how many times he travels through the rabbit hole, each time he goes back to the exact same moment in time. When he is convinced by a friend (in the present) to go back and stop the assassination of President Kennedy, he must "hang out" in the Land of Ago for more than five years. Okay. It's King's choice, so it's difficult to knock, but those five extra years take up those 200 pages that I could have done without. Now, I know, being Stephen King you can't throw out a half-baked plot—he's got to live up to the world's expectations—but I still felt he could have shortened the intervening years a tad.Getting past the length, this is a perfectly hatched story. And, not too gory for me. I must admit, this is my first Stephen King novel because I don't have any desire to read about people smashing/hatcheting/drowning others in gallons of blood. Yes, there are a few murders and knifings here, but they weren't the focus of the story. King's imagination and thoroughness in relaying the details are superb. He dotted every i and crossed every t. I even really liked the ending; I was so afraid after all the time I'd spent with the book that I wouldn't.I listened to this book via audible.com. Every time I do that, I have a hard time separating the story from the performance. I have to admit, I wasn't expecting the soft voice of Craig Wasson as Jake Epping, but once I got used to it, it felt right. (Jake is a high school English teacher, so I guess it was fitting.) Wasson does imitations, as I suppose most professional book readers do. And because the bulk of this novel is set in Texas in the early 60s, it's not surprising that some of the characters sounded... familiar, e.g., the one guy who sounded like Bill Clinton. All in all, he did an excellent job.If goodreads would allow us to give half-stars, I would give this four and a half, with only half a point deducted for the length. (Hello, goodreads, how about it?) But for now, Four Stars, Mr. King. I might even read one of your other books!...more

title: Jesus' Son
author: Johnson, Denis
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An alternate title for this story collection might be: Holden Caulfield Grows Up and Becomes a Drug Addict. But that's not an insult! Denis Johnson isAn alternate title for this story collection might be: Holden Caulfield Grows Up and Becomes a Drug Addict. But that's not an insult! Denis Johnson is certainly one of America's greatest living authors. I am also a big fan of JD Salinger's Catcher In The Rye. Both Jesus' Son and CITR have the gift of voice. Both are about struggling white males in America. Both are written in first person POV, so deep and so real, that I felt like I was the protagonist, and I'm a middle class white lady! Jesus' Son is a novel told in 11 short stories. Each one gives us a snapshot of the protagonist's life (Did Johnson ever give him a name? I think he mentioned it somewhere in this book, but I can't find it. I believe that was intentional to help readers relate to him.) Anyway, he starts as a college-age kid in Iowa City and grows up—literally and emotionally—as the stories progress. He is surrounded, in the first stories, by crooks, alcoholics, drug addicts and poor people, then, in the final story, he is working in a care home and makes several references about going through detox. He even begins to care about other people in the end.So the good and the bad about this book? The good: Johnson's writing is amazing. His sentences hit lyrically and emotionally. And he's often funny! Johnson loves to juxtapose adjectives, and the affect is powerful. ["It was a sad, exhilarating occasion." "A bull elk stood still... giving off an air of authority and stupidity."] The endings to each story are great, too, very enigmatic. So, why not Five Stars, Karolyn? The bad: Even though this is a very short book, I felt the dysfunction and despair was starting to feel redundant, although in retrospect, that might say more about me than this book. I'm sure Johnson wanted the reader to see this guy hit rock bottom, then climb out just at the end. There was one fantastic line in "Beverly Home," the final story: (Our guy is now working at a care home, helping a young man (33) with multiple sclerosis, whose wife was divorcing him. The patient could barely speak anymore due to his condition.) Johnson writes: "No more pretending for him! He was completely and openly a mess. Meanwhile the rest of us go on trying to fool each other." Wow! How true is that?Well, that's enough. If I keep talking about the book, I'm liable to give it Five Stars after all, but while I was reading, my gut reaction was Four Stars....more

title: Raise High the Roof Beam, Carpenters & Seymour: An Introduction
author: Salinger, J.D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's difficult for me to rate these two short stories as one book. RAISE HIGH THE ROOF BEAM, CARPENTERS delighted me, SEYMOUR: AN INTRODUCTION, less sIt's difficult for me to rate these two short stories as one book. RAISE HIGH THE ROOF BEAM, CARPENTERS delighted me, SEYMOUR: AN INTRODUCTION, less so.But let me start with SEYMOUR. I made a little note in the margin about seven pages into this story: "feels almost like a literary challenge or exercise to keep up this voice so long; it's like the voice of an inmate in jail or an asylum with nothing but time on his hands." I imagine if JD Salinger didn't hate me for saying that, he might love it. The story is told in the first person voice of Buddy Glass talking mostly about his brother Seymour, but also life in general, and himself in specific. Only a master could write this. If/when I read this again, I think I will get a lot more enjoyment out of it. For now, I found it so true to itself that it was difficult to read without losing interest.The first story, RHTRB,C, is so sublimely fantastic that it saddens me that Salinger never published another book. I hope, hope, hope that his heirs will allow the manuscripts that allegedly filled multiple rooms of his secluded cabin to be published, and soon. Salinger's writing is the definition of showing not telling, and brevity is brilliant. No one else can say so much in so few words. But then, you probably knew that. Four Stars for this reading. I'll let you know when I read it again, and I will....more

title: Jessica Z.
author: Klomparens, Shawn
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's such a delight to stumble onto a good book that I didn't choose just because others (meaning the NYTimes, et. al.) told me I should read it.JessiIt's such a delight to stumble onto a good book that I didn't choose just because others (meaning the NYTimes, et. al.) told me I should read it.Jessica Z., set in hilly San Francisco, is a fast paced, well-written story about a twenty-something girl trying to figure out who she is and what she wants out of life and love, all while dealing with the post-9/11 fear of terrorism. Jessica has all kinds of problems—family, relationship, work—and the author, Shawn Klomparens, sorts them out one by one, taking the reader rapidly through her associated emotional states.This book has a lot of subplots and red herrings. Klomparens does an excellent job of keeping the reader on his/her toes about several of the characters, namely Josh, Gretchen and Emily; the reader stays wary, and therefore engaged, until the very end of the book. On the surface, this book might seem like Women's Fiction (because of the female protagonist) or even a Romance (based on the cover), but it is quite suspenseful—almost a whodunit. The most impressive part, in my opinion, is immediately following a tragedy (I won't say what). Klomparens expands upon Jessica's emotional state so that the reader truly feels the impact of what she is going through. Then he deftly leads her out of it to tie up one of the many subplots that ties right back to the main plot: how a person's past shapes their present day persona. Very well done.Written in 2008 (or slightly before), this book carries the angst and anger that Americans felt post-9/11. Reading it in 2012, I am reminded of the day to day anxiety we felt then; I think it's important that we Americans do not forget that time in our history.Jessica Z. is an engaging read. I strongly recommend it. Four Stars...more

review: I bought this book for two reasons. First, I try to make a point of reading others' debut novels so I can see what is selling and what other writers aI bought this book for two reasons. First, I try to make a point of reading others' debut novels so I can see what is selling and what other writers are up to. Second, Ms. Garvis- Graves lives only about fifteen minutes away from me and she just inked a "good" seven figure deal for this novel, it's movie rights, and I believe, her next novel. Not bad for a mom-writer from Des Moines. So, what did I think? I think Ms. Garvis-Graves is a smart woman. This is no classic, erudite tome (I read it in a few hours' time), but this is what the public wants. Blue Lagoon meets Lost. On The Island is a sweet story with a happy ending (that's not a spoiler because many readers will have different opinions about what that means). The dialogue is sophomoric, and the book would benefit by being 75 pages shorter, in my opinion, but it's a great "beach read." Her writing is far superior to that of Stephenie Meyer! So, kudos to Ms. Garcia-Graves on her achievement. I'd give Five Stars on her concept, sticktoitiveness and marketing ability, but I have to say Three Stars on the novel itself....more

title: Gone Girl
author: Flynn, Gillian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow. I just finished this book and I have so many conflicting emotions that I had to write this  immediately. First, the story is extremely compWow. I just finished this book and I have so many conflicting emotions that I had to write this  immediately. First, the story is extremely compelling and well-written (except for a couple points I'll make in a moment). Flynn alternates short, intense chapters from the two main characters. From the very beginning, the husband, Nick, and the wife, Amy, have mostly contradictory recollections of their marriage (Amy's chapters are excerpts from her diary because it opens with her missing). Nick, of course, being the primary suspect in her disappearance. Flynn does an excellent job of hinting at various minor characters with potentially nefarious motives; possible red herrings, if you will. I like that in a book. At this point I found it an exciting whodunit.The book is divided into three parts, and each break is a major twist in the tale of Nick and Amy. Saying too much right here would definitely spoil the story... so I won't. I liked the book a lot until (it's very difficult to put down... until) I had about 100 pages to go (my e-version had 507 pgs). At that point, Flynn lost me. The characters who started out as so "relatable" became caricatures (at least one of them). And then the ending... Sorry, but I hated it. I found it completely bizarre and improbable. But then, maybe it was appropriate for the caricatures and Flynn knows much better than I do about how a story like this really would end. Like I said above, the novel is well-written; Flynn is a talented writer. But, she jumps from 1st POV to 2nd POV just often enough that it's very jarring. I suppose she and her agent and/or editor made the judgement call here, but it still didn't work for me. I also thought the verb tenses jumped around in Part 2 when they shouldn't have. One of my pet peeves, I guess. Three stars. ...more

title: The Tiger's Wife
author: Obreht, Téa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Tiger's Wife by Téa Obreht is a far cry from the books I normally read, but multiple cosmic forces led me to it, until I had no choice but to readThe Tiger's Wife by Téa Obreht is a far cry from the books I normally read, but multiple cosmic forces led me to it, until I had no choice but to read it. And I'm glad I did.A critic from the Washington Post says this book "never slips entirely into magical realism..." Really? I thought it did, but if not, then let's call it Mythical Realism. First we have Natalia, a young, modern day doctor in a Balkan country, doing her part to help the needy and the orphans. Then we have her grandfather, who we find out has just passed away. While Natalia is on a missionary trip to help the children at an orphanage, she tries to unravel the mystery behind her grandfather's death, and in doing so she recalls and/or relives the mythical stories that her grandfather told her when she was a little girl. This story is wealthy with layers. It meanders to depths of imagination that are beautiful, dramatic and detailed, but at times (a la Jonathan Franzen) Obreht goes so far into the backstory of semi-minor characters that I actually yearned for the primary plot; these backstories do, however, subtly weave depth into the final tapestry of The Tiger's Wife, and earned it a spot on the New York Times' Top 5 Novels of 2011. In fact, the title character, the tiger's wife, is one of these minor characters. Like The Great Gatsby, the protagonist/narrator is not the title character. That's tough to pull off. The tiger's wife—and the other storyline about the deathless man—are, to some degree, the myths by which Natalia uncovers the truth behind her grandfather's life and death.Obreht is a supreme storyteller. The lyrical prose and the detail she imbues into the scenes make the book seem much longer than 338 pages. (That could be good or bad, depending on the reader's personal preferences.) This story slips in and out of different points of view and periods in time. The plot of Natalia lasts approximately one month in time, yet the book goes back many decades to fully tell the whole story. To say it's confusing would be unfair, but I would say the reader must want to concentrate on the gorgeous details or risk getting lost in the colorful threads.If you're looking for a deep, engaging read this would be a wonderful book for you to pick up. I think this is a novel that I would enjoy more with each reading. In other words, you may have to "work" at this book a little, but the reward is there if you do. Four Stars...more

title: Darkness, Take My Hand        (Kenzie & Gennaro, #2)
author: Lehane, Dennis*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I find it interesting to read an early work by an author after you've read their later work. I'm a big fan of Dennis Lehane, and I have read/seen MystI find it interesting to read an early work by an author after you've read their later work. I'm a big fan of Dennis Lehane, and I have read/seen Mystic River, Shutter Island, Gone Baby Gone, and now this one, Darkness, Take My Hand, which was written in 1996. This is the second in Lehane's Kenzie-Gennaro detective series. I nearly put the rest of my life on hold while reading this book, but it didn't quite reach the level of Shutter Island. There were many beautiful, dramatic passages in this novel describing the weather, or voices, or friendship... dramatic right up to the tipping point of being overwritten. I wonder how Lehane views his writing in this novel today.Point of note: I listened to this book via audible.com performed by Jonathan Davis, so I will try to separate my opinion of the reading from my opinions on Lehane's story. (For the record, Davis' performance was solid, gritty, emotional, but slightly overdone when it comes to the characters' accents and the direction of "he said" or "she said." Often times Davis held on to those phrases too long and they became cumbersome.)First opinion: Don't give this book to your grandmother for Christmas. Brutal, gruesome, violent, and sadistically evil, are all appropriate adjectives for the work. There are also a few steamy sex scenes, but those pale in comparison to the violence committed by multiple characters. The degree to which Lehane takes the horribleness is, of course, his call, but it was a bit tough for me. I thought during this book that Lehane is probably a fan of Stephen King. That being said, the plot was gripping and compelling, and I didn't know "whodunit" until Lehane wanted me to—he skillfully dropped hints and suggestions to make the reader suspect multiple characters as possibilities. Also, I admire the way he drew out the ending. Too often the end of some novels wrap up too quickly, like the writer is tired of the story and just wants to finish the book. Lehane's "bad guy" is bad until the very end.Second opinion: Anyone who loves a gritty, gripping mystery will love this book, even if "cellular phones" were a novelty back then. Lehane does an excellent job with his characters, making them sympathetic, flawed, brave and scared in equal parts, and emotional to the point of being quite real—at least they felt real to me—I've never actually met serial killers or even detectives. Lehane is also one of the best writers when it comes to ending chapters with hangers: time and again I would say, "I'll just read till the end of this chapter," but Lehane would drop some enticing clue that compelled me to keep reading.Not only do I give this book 4 Stars, I'm going to read another Lehane book as soon as possible. ...more

title: Life on the Other Side: A Psychic's Tour of the Afterlife
author: Browne, Sylvia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In the interest of anyone who's not open to what psychics have to say, let me just cut to the chase: Five Stars to Life on the Other Side.For those ofIn the interest of anyone who's not open to what psychics have to say, let me just cut to the chase: Five Stars to Life on the Other Side.For those of you with more curiosity... This book blew me away. A tiny bit of backstory: I had never heard of Sylvia Browne until last week, had never seen her on the Montel Williams Show, nor ever heard of her "theories," but I have long believed that certain people come into your life at a certain time for a reason that's not usually understood until you've learned something vital from them. Often, you won't realize this until you look back on that time/person/knowledge with 20/20 hindsight. The last six months of my life have led me directly to this book.I am not the person to tell you that all of what Ms. Browne says is true and that you must believe her, but I can tell you that my beliefs, rough as they are, match identically with what she says is true based on her sixty years as a psychic. She sites thousands of interviews with people from all over the globe who have had "weird" things happen to them, and from those experiences plus her own, she "knows" what the Afterlife holds. I think my agreement with her would come as no surprise to Ms. Browne. Good news for any skeptics: Religion really plays no part in her beliefs, other than there definitely is a God. After that, Catholicism, Judaism, Buddhism, Protestantism, et al, are Earthly interpretations that have no distinction in the Afterlife as long as you "do good" on Earth. The book, co-written by Lindsay Harrison, is well-written, straight-forward, and very interesting. If you have the time and curiosity, I highly recommend this book... even if it's just to consider the possibility of the Other Side....more

title: Truth & Beauty
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a difficult book to score because it can be looked at in a number of ways. Ann Patchett writes beautiful prose. It's as though her words floatThis is a difficult book to score because it can be looked at in a number of ways. Ann Patchett writes beautiful prose. It's as though her words float in on a cloud that gently settles around me; I feel calm when I read her books. On that merit, I give it Five Stars. Real life is difficult to recount, because everyone's life overlaps simultaneously with everyone else's; in the hands of a lesser writer, this story could have been a jumbled mess.This is the story of Ms. Patchett's eighteen year friendship with the well-known writer Lucy Grealy. The two women became roommates and then friends at the Iowa Writers' Workshop in 1985 (oh, how I'd so love to interject personal tidbits here!) (Ah, what the hell... If you've read any of my other Patchett s, you know I love her writing, to the point that my name is probably on a watch list somewhere in case she senses she has a stalker who's creeping her out. I lived in Iowa City and moved away just days before she moved there. I sometimes wonder what might have happened if I'd met her all those years ago. Now my son is a student at the Iowa Writers' Workshop. I feel an odd connection, a symmetry, if you will.) Lucy Grealy was no average person. She survived cancer of her face at a very young age. This (and perhaps a dysfunctional family) shaped her, literally and figuratively, into a massively insecure person. Not that I'm criticizing or being unsympathetic; I cannot fathom living the life she did; I'm not sure if I could have survived it as long as she did. But what I find interesting—in a way that makes me doubt my Five Star rating—is why Ms. Patchett loved her so dearly. My harshest knock against this book is that I never quite understood WHY Ms. Patchett loved her so deeply. Near the end, (pg. 225) Lucy offers a reason which Ann rejects. Later Ms. Patchett says, and I paraphrase, she felt that only Lucy spoke her, Ann's, native language. That's beautiful, don't you think? I believe that this book is brutally honest, and that is of utmost importance. If so, EVERYBODY loved Lucy Grealy. But to love Lucy, from what I gathered, is to subject oneself to the puerile behavior and clinginess of a baby monkey, and I mean that in the sweetest way. Seriously. Lucy must have been brilliant. She was an acclaimed writer and teacher, she loved animals and people, she loved to dance and play pool, and she loved sex to the point that sh must have equated sex with love—she was always searching for love—even though most of us know "sex isn't love." We learned that in St. Elmo's Fire.If I were a psychologist, I might analyze this book based on the previous paragraph and come up with a different rating. But I'm a reader and a writer, so I'll base my  on Ms. Patchett's writing and stick with Five Stars....more

title: Stories I Only Tell My Friends: An Autobiography
author: Lowe, Rob
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you're considering reading this book, don't; LISTEN TO THE AUDIO VERSION! Rob Lowe performs the audio version so well that to read the printed versIf you're considering reading this book, don't; LISTEN TO THE AUDIO VERSION! Rob Lowe performs the audio version so well that to read the printed version would to cheat yourself out of half the joy. Rob Lowe does imitations of his friends, business associates, and fellow actors—a near perfect Cary Grant, for instance, and Liza Minnelli, and Chris Farley, and Bill Clinton... After a compelling first chapter, Lowe begins his memoir at the beginning. I found this part a bit slow, but it was necessary to inform the reader how long (since the age of 10) and how deeply (more than anything else) he wanted to become an actor. Then he dives in to his high school days when he's naively hanging out with Charlie Sheen, Emilio Estevez, Martin Sheen, Sean Penn, Holly Robinson (Peete), Sarah Jessica Parker, Melissa Gilbert, and so many others before they became famous. This takes off, of course, exponentially once he hits the set of Francis Ford Coppola's The Outsiders.Lowe is (to my surprise) an excellent writer. Maybe he had a ghost writer, but by the end of the story, I feel he might very well have written every word himself; apparently, over the last few years, he's done a lot of script writing. In any case, Lowe is not just a pretty face. He has lived a rich life with so many amazing, worthy stories that this book seems as though it were inevitable. He did indeed mention his sex tape fiasco, but he whitewashed it... as I guess most people would. I've never seen The West Wing, but after listening to Lowe's story about the show, including its cast, director, and White House fans, I want to go out and buy every season!This is one of the first memoirs I've ever read—normally I read novels—and I'm very glad that I took the advice of one of my friends and listened to this audiobook. It was very entertaining and informative, heartfelt and honest. I highly recommend it....more

title: Blue Shoe
author: Lamott, Anne*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This  surprises even me. I expected to LOVE this book, based on several different reasons (I loved Bird by Bird, and several of my trusted frienThis  surprises even me. I expected to LOVE this book, based on several different reasons (I loved Bird by Bird, and several of my trusted friends love Lamott's work). But I didn't. However, I think it says more about "Hollywood" and "commercialism" than it does about Anne Lamott. Ms. Lamott's characters are atypical. In addition, they are atypically honest. In today's world, characters (books, movies, TV) are generally beautiful people who have solvable problems. The characters in Blue Shoe are poor, overweight, missing teeth, some with dreadlocked hair (not that that's bad, it's just different from what we're normally exposed to). As quoted in the New York Times Book Review, Blue Shoe is "messy." That's a perfect word for it. Lamott describes the quotidian routine ad nauseam. Somehow, even though the book spans a couple years, it seemed to drag on, with lots and lots of routine and facts about the characters' lives. I know this pushes the novel into Literary Fiction and away from a plot-based story, but I have to admit I skipped huge chunks of the book that didn't seem to add much to the story. I may have missed good information, but in reading the last chapter, nothing came as a surprise (i.e., I didn't miss anything too important). Ms. Lamott is a wonderful writer. I underlined and dog-eared several passages. One of my favorites is a quote from the protagonist, Mattie: "I realized that all I ever have to do is tell the truth, and let go of the results." Wouldn't life be simpler if everyone on the planet subscribed to that? Well, maybe that would make real life as messy as this book... and then I wouldn't like real life as much. Anyway, call me brainwashed, but I guess I prefer the escapism of beautiful people solving life's problems in a more tidy fashion.Three Stars....more

title: The Sense of an Ending
author: Barnes, Julian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Considering reading this book? Just do it. But if you think it's going to be about a man who receives an enigmatic bequest from the mother of an old gConsidering reading this book? Just do it. But if you think it's going to be about a man who receives an enigmatic bequest from the mother of an old girlfriend, and so the man goes back through life to figure out why... Well, it is and it isn't. This is a novel about Time and Memory. The Sense of an Ending is a gorgeous novella, precious, poignant, and (ooh, I so want to say "perfect") honest. Julian Barnes, thrice shortlisted for the Booker Prize, and finally winner with this work, sees people, sees their minds and hearts and souls, and can articulate it all so well that the rest of us are better for it—an amazing talent. His strength lies as much in what he doesn't say as what he does say. He has mastered "showing not telling," except for the little blurb (chapter?) (I listened to this as an audiobook, so I'm not sure how it was separated out in print) in the middle where he says, and I paraphrase, "I got married, had a kid, got a job, got a better job..." Only a master can break the rules so masterfully.As I said, I listened to this on audible.com (huge shout out to audible!). It was read by the talented Richard Morant, a British man, appropriate because Barnes is British, as is his protagonist. Tony, the protagonist, receives 500 pounds and the promise of his deceased school mate's diary, but Tony has no idea why he's receiving either. The story starts back in their prep school days and he tries to remember it as clearly as he can, now some 40 years later. Tony talks at length about how memory, history, and perception are clearly inaccurate, but that's the best we have to go on. And so he walks us through all he can remember about his deceased friend to figure out why he has now inherited his diary, a soul-searching journey, to be sure.Many other s of this book say, "I didn't get it." And by that they mean the ending. Well, sorry, but if you don't get it, just read the last part again. It's obvious and it's brilliant. Tom Perrotta (The Leftovers) once said about literary fiction, "... you should be more interested toward the end of a book than you are at the beginning." Well this is that. The Sense of an Ending is literary fiction with a gripping story. And the ending is fantastic in a sad, quiet way. I love the fact that at the end of this book, the reader really only has a "sense of the ending." I think most readers had to give this some serious thought after they finished it... and if that's not brilliant, I don't know what is.It's not that I didn't have a few minor quibbles along the way with this book, but that's only because I'm a writer. (We always think we could have done it just a little bit better!) (Yeah, no.) As you have guessed by now, I give The Sense of an Ending Five Stars....more

title: This Is the Story of a Happy Marriage
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's no wonder I like Ann Patchett's novels so much; our lives seemed to have mirrored each other's in many ways. This is an audiobook which Ms. PatchIt's no wonder I like Ann Patchett's novels so much; our lives seemed to have mirrored each other's in many ways. This is an audiobook which Ms. Patchett (I wish she'd finally say to me, "Please, call me Ann.") narrates as a brief memoir about her current marriage, but explains that she must first tell the tale of her lineage: four generations of failed marriages. (Ironically, for me, she begins the story by saying that she was never fond of audiobooks until she heard the fantastic Jeremy Irons read Lolita; I had just finished listening to that very recording. Kismet, don't you think?) (I also agreed with her wholeheartedly.)This is the Story of a Happy Marriage is deeply personal and told in a calm but not syrupy voice. It would be tempting, I think, to just talk about her current husband and why it is so strong that one of Ms. Patchett's friends implores her: Tell the tale of your happy marriage. But she is bravely honest and reveals in seemingly great detail (who knows how much she left out?) how unhappy her first marriage was at age 23, and then her second major relationship (they were engaged but never married), also very dysfunctional, and she admits to a few loves along the way before she finally meets Carl, the love of her life and how she finally (after 11 years) agrees to get married again.From her own dysfunctional upbringing, to her relationships with her (divorced) parents, her step-parents and step-siblings, it's easy to see where the depth comes from for her novels. The best line in the book was the question a friend asked her when she was contemplating leaving her second relationship. In order to help Ms. Patchett make her decision, Edra (sp?) asks, "Does he make you a better person? If yes, then work out the problems. If no, then you'll know whether or not to stay."The audiobook is only 1 hour 18 minutes long, a bittersweet true story that goes a long way to make the rest of us realize that everyone has a story.I see no reason not to give this Five Stars....more

title: The Lifeboat
author: Rogan, Charlotte*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ah, Lolita, my little Lo... No wait, that was my last . But while we're on the subject, did anyone else notice the similarity of format? A persoAh, Lolita, my little Lo... No wait, that was my last . But while we're on the subject, did anyone else notice the similarity of format? A person who has been arrested, telling their story to a jury/lawyer as part of their defense... But that is where the similarities end. I wanted to like this book more than I did. Ms. Rogan is a good writer, but I can't say she's a good storyteller; there's a big difference. There are several poetic sentences, and wonderful insights about life and people. Ms. Rogan did not rush the ending—it was nicely drawn out. It's obvioous she poured her heart and soul into the novel.In the story, Grace Winter, the protagonist, is on trial for murder, and yet she is calm, placid, naive, clueless... The only thing believable this woman did was to intentionally "accidentally" meet a wealthy man (who was already engaged), and steal him away. She was portrayed as a victim all the way through to the end. Larry Brooks of Storyfix wouldn't like that!The novel, on the whole, could have and should have had so much violence, tension, and fear, but it really just skated over the surface of the narrative; just try to imagine 21 days at sea in an overcrowded boat with dozens of scared, hungry strangers! The narrative timeline felt disjointed to me, jumping back and forth and forth again between the past, the lifeboat, and the trial, sometimes all in the same paragraph. Also the dialogue did not ring true to the time period (1914). Lastly, and I don't know why this hasn't been talked about more, is the undeniable similarity to the Alfred Hitchcock movie, also calld The Lifeboat, which was written by John Steinbeck. In all the press I've read about his book and author (everywhere from People magazine, to Oprah Magazine, to the New York Times!), I've not heard her give any credit to either of those men. Coincidence? Yeah, no.I'd like to give this 2 1/2 stars, but I'll round up to Three stars because I feel a connection to Ms. Rogan: a wife, mother, and self-taught author throwing her heart out there for people like me to critique. Keep writing!...more
