title: Cloud Atlas
author: Mitchell, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: (FOURTH READING: September 2019) As I said in my earlier s, this is my “desert island” book, the one I am and would be happy to read over and ov(FOURTH READING: September 2019) As I said in my earlier s, this is my “desert island” book, the one I am and would be happy to read over and over. Each time I read and/or listen to it, I get more out of it. This time through CLOUD ATLAS, I grasped the theme and message more clearly. In each of the six related stories, David Mitchell shows us how, through time, those with power used and abused those without power. It would make you cry about the unjust nature of man if it didn’t also give us hope for our individual possibilities. This is definitely a story about the triumph of good over evil. Mitchell’s beautiful last line (not a spoiler!) is this: “ ‘... only as you gasp your dying breath shall you understand, your life amounted to no more than one drop in a limitless ocean!’ Yet what is any ocean but a multitude of drops?” In other words, each of us is as important as any of us. And together we are one. Five eternal Stars (SECOND READING: MAY 27, 2013) The first time I "read" this book (see below), I actually listened to it on audible.com. It's fantastic via the audio version because of the brilliant choices for readers. Then I saw the movie (typical movie response). Recently, I purchased the hardback version of CLOUD ATLAS, and read along with the audio version. You might think I'm crazy, but really I'm just THAT in AWE of David Mitchell's work. Any bit of excitement that was lost in my third "reading" of this story was replaced by admiration for the genius of David Mitchell. Okay, you get my gist. For me, this book is better each time you read it. And you will see I loved it the first time: (FIRST READ: NOV. 23, 2012) Finally! Now I know what book I will take to my proverbial deserted island. You know, What's the one book you would choose if you could read only one book for the rest of your life? CLOUD ATLAS, by David Mitchell. Yes, it's that good. I have two reasons for saying that.First, Mitchell's imaginative story and his mastery of the English language—as well as Olde English, and two languages he adapted from English—are phenomenal. Each of the six segments of this novel (told as six linked short stories) is fully developed and full of unique, round characters. The settings are—can I use the word phenomenal again?—as different from each other as Jane Eyre is from Star Wars. But Mitchell's talent goes beyond language and physical descriptions; this book is smart. I'm not giving too much away to say that all of the stories happen on Earth, the first segment taking place in the 19th Century, and the last in the 26th Century. Mitchell lets the reader figure out what has happened to the world in between each segment. And the title is perfect: CLOUD ATLAS: the novel is the legend of moving parts, i.e., clouds.The second reason I would take CLOUD ATLAS to my deserted island is because it might take me the rest of my life, reading and rereading this book, to fully grasp it all. This is a thick, literary, epic novel (528 pages). The book was originally released in 2004, and I have wanted to read it for a long time but was slightly intimidated by what I'd heard about it. When I saw that it had been turned into a movie, I moved it up on my TBR list to read before I saw the movie. Instead, I listened to this as an audio book (beautifully narrated by six different actors). I must admit I was so lost at several parts of the story that I didn't know what was happening, but I also couldn't stop listening. I saw the movie halfway through my audio experience which made me able to understand a movie that many people could not follow. The two experiences (audio book + movie) truly increased my enjoyment of each other. One day (soon, I hope) I will read the paper version, and I am sure that will further enhance my enjoyment. Reading CLOUD ATLAS will take some commitment, but this is a prime example of "you get out what you put in." If you love a story that pulls you in so deep that you don't even want to come out, AND you like a story that challenges your intellect a bit, AND you admire a wonderful sense of imagination, CLOUD ATLAS is your book.Bravo, David Mitchell. This novel should have won the National Book Award. Five Stars....more

title: Bird by Bird
author: Lamott, Anne*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Myriad lists, posts, and opinions cite Bird by Bird, by Anne Lamott as one of the "The Best Books on Writing." As a writer, I gorged myself on Ms. LamMyriad lists, posts, and opinions cite Bird by Bird, by Anne Lamott as one of the "The Best Books on Writing." As a writer, I gorged myself on Ms. Lamott's personal experiences and advice. As a reader, I gorged myself on the tidbits about life. My copy of this book is now worn, dog-eared and underlined so thoroughly that a judgmental person might laugh. Not that I care; I only care about how right-on Ms. Lamott is, over and over and over again. It's like when a friend tells you your ex-boyfriend is a creep, and you scream, "Well, sure. NOW I see it!" She doesn't sugar coat anything, Ms. Lamott. She shoots from the hip, as they say. Writing is hard, taking criticism is harder, and being published is no holy grail. In essence, writing is a job. BUT, the gem here is that the true reward, she tells us, comes from learning to see the world and seeing one's inner self more clearly. Once a writer can honestly, tenderly see the world and communicate that vision to others, then and only then, will he or she realize how important writing can be. Lamott also shares with us deeply personal and raw emotions that she has felt. Fear of humiliation, fear of rejection, and self-doubt; and if an excellent writer like her feels that way, it must be okay for the rest of us to feel that way... AND KEEP GOING. It's easy to see that Ms. Lamott loves writing and wants to encourage the rest of us to keep going, day after day, for the rest of our lives. How fantastic is that?To save this  from becoming too kiss-ass or sentimental, let me offer a few facts about the book. Ms. Lamott has basically transcribed a semester's worth of lesson plans from a writing class she has repeatedly taught (presumably at UC Davis). She explains many fundamentals and tricks on getting started as a writer, moving through "writer's block," learning how to "observe" the world, and advancing toward writers' groups and the perils of publication. Lamott, in equal parts, quotes literary giants, friends, and personal vignettes. But the ultimate compliment I can pass on about Bird by Bird, is a quote from a non-writer friend of mine. She LOVED this book for all the insight it offered into humanity. If a non-writer sings the praises of a writing book, it must really be worth reading.Bravo, Ms. Lamott. Five Stars...more

title: A Good Man Is Hard to Find and Other Stories
author: O'Connor, Flannery
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Book s are nebulous. Some ers base their assessment solely on literary merit; others, like myself, lean toward a more personal account. ThBook s are nebulous. Some ers base their assessment solely on literary merit; others, like myself, lean toward a more personal account. The way I see it, if you're looking for an objective opinion about Flannery O'Connor's A Good Man Is Hard To Find you can find that on Amazon or Wikipedia. If you're reading my , you must want MY opinion about this book. If I were being objective about this short story collection, I would give it Five Stars. The writings is superb, the stories are deep and visual, the realm (Southern America in the first half of the twentieth century) is wide. Another er might mention the absurdity of O'Connor's use of the "n" word, and the horrendous predjudice against African Americans in the book. But, as with the case of Tom Saywer and the brouhaha of editing out such words is, in my opinion, is a dishonest depiction of our history and reality. I think it is beneficial to Americans in the Twenty-first century to see how wrong our ancestors were, and to see how far we've come, and think about how far we still have to go. But back to my . This is how I see each of O'Connor's stories: La di da di da di da... Boom... La di da. Seriously, the story begins, the story progresses (casting a slightly unsettling vibe because her world is so different from mine), then whamo!, something crazy happens, and then she quietly wraps up the story. It's beautiful in such a subtle way. Also in each story, there are at least two significant characters; each one plays a roll in the "bang". Because of that, I thought of two alternative titles for this collection: It Takes Two To Tango, or I've Got A Brand New Pair of Rollerskates; You've Got A Brand A Brand New Key. But since her title has become an American cliché, I guess I'll let it stick.This collection contains ten stories. The title story blew me away, probably because I (wrongly) assumed it would be about a woman looking for a man. It wasn't, at all. it was shocking and fantastic in the worst possible way. You owe it to yourself to read at least this one story. I would love to elaborate on each of the stories, but that would take hours. Let it suffice for me to say this: This is an excellent collection of American short stories, but since this is my  and I prefer novels, I give it Four Stars. ...more

title: The Thorn Birds
author: McCullough, Colleen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not sure if I love Colleen McCullough or hate her. Well, of course I don't hate her so I must love her, but she did make me cry and lose a lot of I'm not sure if I love Colleen McCullough or hate her. Well, of course I don't hate her so I must love her, but she did make me cry and lose a lot of sleep this past week. This is the second time I've read The Thorn Birds, and I also watched the mini-series way back in 1983. (Am I that old? Maybe I saw it as a rerun.) In any case, it's been a few years and I had forgotten a few of the finer plot points, but the epic novel was still as powerful as I remembered it.The Thorn Birds is an elegiac, family saga set in Australia across the better part of the Twentieth Century. It deals with love, loss, religion, weather, emotions, and all kinds of other things over which we have no control. As a synopsis, if you mix the Cleary family (mother, father, eight sons (maybe more), and one lovely daughter) with a bitter old Aunt, stir in a gorgeous priest, an enormous ranch, and ton of money; cook that for 700 pages; out comes a bucket of tears and one small question: why are we even alive? Nothing is sacred in her book, most specifically and dramatically—okay, also ironically—God Himself. The characters in the novel are Catholic to varying degrees, and therein lies the grief.McCullough's writing (although I found the editing a little cumbersome) is deep, insightful, lyrical, and spot-on when she analyzes the interactions between her characters. A dozen passages or more spoke directly to me, asking those big-life questions that a person ponders during life's difficult moments or at least on quiet, introspective days. This book makes you think, people. Interestingly, one line jumped out at me; on Page 632 of the edition above, is the now well-known phrase "only the good die young." Interesting because McCullough wrote that line before Billy Joel's song of the same name was released (although both are attributed to 1977). Was it a common saying back then? I'm not sure, but if you Google it, the credit for coining the line goes to Mr. Joel. In any case, the novel is dramatic and heartrending, and if you're looking for a tear-jerker that you can't put down, this is your book. I reread it now because I was going through a Downton Abbey withdrawal, and it was just what I hoped for.I marked all Five Stars but only because I can't give it 4 1/2. I would dock it slightly for the aforementioned editing issues, and I can see where some would say it's over the top sappy... but that is exactly what I was looking for. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Immortalists is my first book by Kyle Mills. I chose this one first (even though he's better known for his "pure" spy-thrillers) because I was curThe Immortalists is my first book by Kyle Mills. I chose this one first (even though he's better known for his "pure" spy-thrillers) because I was curious about the medical aspect of this novel. In it, the protagonist is a "genius" scientist whose daughter has a very rare genetic disease that he sets out to cure, while also trying to figure out why other scientists studying similar diseases are being killed off. Because I'm not comparing The Immortalists to Mills' other works, I can say that I found it very engrossing—quite the page-turner; some ers feel it's less so than his other works. Mills' writing is high-level and pure; it never gets in the way of the story. He is a very good writer with superior story-telling abilities.This book is definitely plot-driven, which comes as no surprise. The flip side of that is that the storyline gives way to the plot. Meaning, I felt a few of the elements of the story were far-fetched (e.g., the parents leave their sick daughter in the hands of a man they barely know). That being said, the parents' decisions were based on brilliant reasoning—well thought out ideas by the author. They also escape billionaire bad guys one too many times for credibilities' sake... but, they had to, right?I really liked the ending of the book. It was logical, believable, and satisfying. Four Stars....more

review: I thoroughly enjoyed this book. Spin is a well-written, fast-paced, funny tale about a messed-up girl who goes after her dream job, and what the lengtI thoroughly enjoyed this book. Spin is a well-written, fast-paced, funny tale about a messed-up girl who goes after her dream job, and what the lengths to which she's willing to go to get it. Catherine McKenzie's characters are so flawed, we can't help but relate! But the best part is that the story has an underlying layer of gravitas: the perils of dishonesty and alcohol and drug abuse. This book reminded me, in that light, of Jonathan Tropper's This Is Where I Leave You; another well-written, funny book about serious matters. Anyone who's looking for a weekend read or a book to dive into after a long day will enjoy Spin. It's written in first person by a 30-year old female, but I've already told my hubby he should read it. Once I started this book, I couldn't wait to get back to it to see what Katie was going to do next.Four Stars....more

title: S is for Silence        (Kinsey Millhone, #19)
author: Grafton, Sue
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: On what basis do we "grade" books? Literary merit? Writing level, e.g., absence of unnecessary adverbs? Plot strength and suspense? Sympathetic characOn what basis do we "grade" books? Literary merit? Writing level, e.g., absence of unnecessary adverbs? Plot strength and suspense? Sympathetic character development?If you're reading this , I'm guessing you fall into one of two categories: Those who like Sue Grafton novels and want to know how this one compares to the rest, or my goodreads friends who follow my s because you think I'm brilliant. If you fall into the first group, I won't be of much help. In my previous life (about 15 - 10 years ago), I read Grafton's early entries into the alphabet series. I liked them because they were fun, easy, mildly tense and suspenseful. Then my life changed, and I haven't read many since then.I recently read and ed Bolaño's The Skating Rink. While that was my first Bolaño, that is certainly more similar to what I like to read today. I guess I've grown up and am looking for more of a literary challenge these days. But enough about me. A few months ago, I saw a quote from Tom Perotta (The Leftovers) in the NYTimes Book Review. Perotta is a highly respectable author, although I must say I have not read any of his books yet. But he had a quote that I remember and respect. He said—and I paraphrase–that while he's writing a book, he reads mysteries because they are typically so strong in plot. He notes that acclaimed literary fiction can often lose that page-turner quality, and he wants to avoid that in his work.And that is why I read S is for Silence. I read it as research for my own work. How does Grafton maneuver her female detective? How does she handle character development for a new reader when most of her readers have probably read each novel in the series and know the main character so well? How does she handle the plot of her mystery? That is why I read this book. And I'm glad I did.Grafton knows what she's doing (obviously by now), she's a very good writer (obviously), she has a flawed but intelligent and likable character. I was extremely interested in finding out whodunit. That being said, I thought the book was awfully long (maybe because I wasn't looking for a beach read, this was more like homework for me). There were so many characters involved, that when I found out who the bad guy was, I had to go back and remind myself about his background and involvement with the victim (which I thought was on the thin side). I certainly didn't guess him ahead of time.I took copious notes on my iPad while I read this book in keeping with my 2012 reading goal (read fewer books, fill them with marginalia, and LEARN from them). (I love my iPad for that reason: so many highlighting color options, so easy to !) Also, in keeping with my "grading" philosophy, I give S is for Silence 3 Stars because, while it's a very well written mystery, it holds little literary merit. You gotta save the 4 & 5 star s for works that might endure, don'tcha?Three Stars....more

title: Swamplandia!
author: Russell, Karen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Karen Russell is possibly the most creative writer I've ever read. Her imagination rivals that of JK Rowling. That being said, the story was a little Karen Russell is possibly the most creative writer I've ever read. Her imagination rivals that of JK Rowling. That being said, the story was a little far-fetched for me. Other than the sex lives of the three children, this felt more like a YA novel to me than adult literary fiction. Picture, if you will, Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn in the Florida swamplands. Somehow, while I felt sorry for the young kids, I thought the story line lacked plausibility. Maybe there's a dad somewhere who would leave three kids on an island with alligators but no food? Yeah, no. I did not identify with any of the characters, and at times I asked myself, "Why am I reading about teenagers again?"Once again I think the NYTimes picked this as a Top Five novel from 2011 because of its original voice and Russell's aforementioned remarkable way of seeing the world, but not because of the plot.Hey, I'm a plot person. Leave me alone.Yes, I worried for the little girl, but honestly, I skimmed through most of the book because it was filled with beautiful prose about stuff I just didn't care about. That being said, I highlighted dozens of passages because of Russell's remarkable words. All in all, Three Stars....more

title: The Miracle of Mindfulness: An Introduction to the Practice of Meditation
author: Thich Nhat Hanh
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's difficult not to give this sweet, peaceful book five stars. Perhaps I'm missing the point.The book is a translation of letters written in VietnamIt's difficult not to give this sweet, peaceful book five stars. Perhaps I'm missing the point.The book is a translation of letters written in Vietnamese from a Buddhist monk to a "Brother" in 1974. In other words, so not my life. Not that it needs to be. The book is deep and meaningful and I am sure that I would be a better person (less anxious, more patient) if I could adopt the practices that Thich Nhat Hanh prescribes to his friend. But this is America in the 21st Century, and I'm very happy with my life so I'm not looking for an alternative.In this lovely book, it is suggests focusing entirely on any given action that one must perform in a day. For instance, washing dishes. When a person is washing a dish, she should think only of that dish and how vital it is that she is washing that particular dish at that particular moment. Yeah... no day dreaming? No watching Two and a Half Men to alleviate the boredom of washing dishes? No multi-tasking? I'm a writer; if I didn't day dream during my daily shower, I'd lose half of my best plot points. It suggests that one learn how to breath. Oh, not just in and out, mind you. But slowly in, to the gentle count of 5, or 7, or even 10. This, honestly, is a practice I try to remember if I ever feel stress (and I have my characters do the same when they're under the gun—sometimes literally). But again, it is recommended to concentrate on each breath as if that is the soul function of life on earth.I'm not trying to be cynical here. This book was a gift which I was very grateful to receive. I deeply admire Buddhists and their sense of calm and peace. In fact, I used to feel that Buddhism made more sense to me that any other religion, but then the laundry called my name, and the kids needed help with homework, and Law & Order was showing a new episode. For now, Three Stars. I may revisit this when life slows down....more

title: The Long Goodbye        (Philip Marlowe, #6)
author: Chandler, Raymond
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Long Goodbye is a long book. With a lot of characters. Raymond Chandler is a master. His noir mysteries are the archetypes for detective stories, The Long Goodbye is a long book. With a lot of characters. Raymond Chandler is a master. His noir mysteries are the archetypes for detective stories, as far as I'm concerned. Chandler's sentences are perfect: terse, yet descriptive and balanced. In 2013, his stories seem chock full of clichés, but back in the 50s, I imagine they were original and irreverent, possibly even laugh-out-loud funny! Chandler's detective, Philip Marlowe, kicks ass—very quietly. He never gets ruffled, and he continually outsmarts the bad guys (naturally) and even the cops (sweet!). Nothing is sacred in Philip Marlowe's world. He can tell a beautiful woman she's full of $h!t, and still end up in bed with her. He tells the goons they're being ridiculous, and somehow doesn't get killed for it. My knock on this book is that it really did seem to go on forever. If you like twists in your mysteries, you'll love this book. Written in 1953, it reads at a much slower pace than say a Lee Child novel—that may be why I felt it was so long—but, again, Chandler's sentences are so fantastic that I wanted to read each one. Plus, he has a way of slipping vital clues into what can seem like a non-important scene or dialogue passage. Skimming will not help you solve the mystery!Four StarsP.S. My Random House Vintage Crime edition (1992) had quite a few typos in it. Don't you think they would have edited those out by now?...more

review: Once again I'm frustrated by goodreads Five Star scale. Why can't there be ten stars or half stars?Sister by Rosamund Lupton is an elegiac and engagi Once again I'm frustrated by goodreads Five Star scale. Why can't there be ten stars or half stars?Sister by Rosamund Lupton is an elegiac and engaging story written with an original style. I highlighted many of Lupton's passages for their elegant prose or well-said universal truths, and others for helpful tips for my own writing. As far as the genre, yes, it's suspenseful--Lupton kept my guessing and suspecting each character (just like her protagonist, Bea) all the way through the novel, but it's much more sentimental than the average suspense novel. Where this novel failed me was in its timeline. I didn't mind the swap back and forth between Bea's "talking" to her younger sister and "talking" to a lawyer, but it was difficult to follow at first (to the point that I'll have a hard time recommending this book to anyone but avid readers). Then, as the story went on, there were certain passages that became extremely confusing as in, Whoa, how much time has passed???In the end, I would give the story 4 stars for its I-can't-put-this-down-till-I-know-whodunit, but only 3 stars because it was confusing. Happy to have read it though. ...more

The pace is rapid, and the plot of The Innocent is as straight as a bullet through this gripping novel.(Vanessa) Michael Munroe, the literary world's newest superhero, infiltrates a cult as few people could describe as accurately as Stevens (if you haven't read the author's bio, do that next). This story is as horrific as it is entertaining, and while I imagine some there has been some dramatic license taken, it is very believable knowing how Stevens was raised. But the best part of this book is that Stevens has created an anti-hero that we/I not only root for, but one that we care about. Yes, she kills people, but her subsequent nightmares create sympathy for her. "Michael" makes ME feel smarter/stronger/faster. It's like the Holiday Inn commercial: I'm not a spy, but I have read Taylor Stevens' books. The Innocent is an excellent thriller, full of action, tension and mystery. I give it a strong 4 Stars. ...more

title: Back Of Beyond
author: Box, C.J.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one exciting mystery! Once I get about 75 pages in, I could hardly put it down.CJ Box lives in and writes about Wyoming and Montana; he knows This is one exciting mystery! Once I get about 75 pages in, I could hardly put it down.CJ Box lives in and writes about Wyoming and Montana; he knows this part of the country very well. Like Annie Proulx, his settings are such an important part of his stories (at least the ones I've read, and especially this one) that they are as significant to the plot as any of the characters. Back of Beyond walks a nice balance between a character-driven and a plot-driven story. There's no doubt that the plot is primary, but the protagonist is such a well-drawn character that I feel like I know him. He's like Elliot Stable on Law & Order: SVU; you gotta like this messed up cop! In fact, I might look for more Box books with Cody Hoyt in them. But I digress.In this story, a close friend of Hoyt's is murdered, so Hoyt goes on a wild adventure (a camping trip through Yellowstone National Park) to find the killer. There are about a dozen people on the trip, anyone of whom might be the killer. But there are twists and developments that are very exciting (scary? compelling?). Box planted just enough clues along the way that I narrowed down the characters to who the villain might be, but he left it vague enough that I didn't know exactly how it would turn out until Box wanted me to.Beware: There are a lot of gory deaths in this book. (Stephen King fans take note!)One more caveat I must add: I listened to this as an audiobook, performed by Holter Graham, and I did not like his storytelling. I understand these characters are cops, and from Montana at that, but the way Graham read the dialogue was stilted and stiff. It almost ruined it for me. Fortunately, the story was strong enough that I can highly recommend the printed version to anyone who likes mysteries. ...more

title: The Magician's Assistant
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It is rare to find a literary page-turner, but Ann Patchett never fails to give us exactly that. Her writing is elegant, sophisticated and quiet; it nIt is rare to find a literary page-turner, but Ann Patchett never fails to give us exactly that. Her writing is elegant, sophisticated and quiet; it never gets in the way of the story. The closer I got to the end of this book, the more obsessed I became with it, wanting to make sure that everyone was going to be okay, at least in some sense of the word. The Magician's Assistant follows the same pattern of Patchett's other novels: An unsuspecting character is thrust into a world full of people he/she never even dreamed of, replete with drama and emotion and confusion—as well as hope and love. Her stories can be one-sided, but she creates sympathetic characters who come to life for me in ways that few authors can manage. I always find myself wanting to hug the protagonist like my sister or brother. In this book, Sabine could have been my best friend—the one who has suffered so much sadness. Certain passages of this novel actually made me cry; that is how well Patchett creates authentic characters with real emotions. And whether her stories take us to Nebraska or the South American Amazon (State of Wonder), Patchett paints a picture of the environment so clearly that I almost needed a sweater to read the part of this book that takes place in the brutal cold of a Midwestern winter.Ann Patchett is such a wonderful storyteller that I finish each of her books totally spellbound.5 Stars....more

title: Lolita
author: Nabokov, Vladimir
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ah, Lolita, my little Lo, my lovely, luscious, lascivious Lolita...I have just, and I mean just, finished listening to the audiobook Lolita, written bAh, Lolita, my little Lo, my lovely, luscious, lascivious Lolita...I have just, and I mean just, finished listening to the audiobook Lolita, written by Vladimir Nabokov in 1955, and read in the most lustful, licentious voice of Jeremy Irons. I cannot imagine a more perfect way in which to be immersed in this masterful yet nasty novel. Forgive me if my words seem to flow, not from my American, middle-class, prudish fingertips, but through the unfiltered, unabridged, unspeakable truths disseminated by a worldly maniacal genius. Ah, who am I kidding. I can not for a moment write as brilliantly as Nabokov no matter how powerfully I try to channel him.Two thoughts overwhelm me upon the completion of twelve or so captivating hours at the proverbial knee of Jeremy Irons' storytelling best. First, in Mr. Irons' hypnotic voice, the alliterations of Nabokov sang so loudly that they nearly overtook the story. I wonder, do they jump out at a reader they way they did for me as a listener? I could give countless examples if only I had been taking notes as I listened or had this book in hand along with a pencil to underscore and scribble notes about as I read page by page. Alas, I chose the audiobook version because a., it was my free-trial book from audible.com, and b., I thought it was a book I would never read, mostly because of my disgusted prejudice against the storyline. Which leads me precisely to point two. My second thought, now that I've completed the book, is why was I so afraid of this book for so many years? I imagine it's because until ebooks and audiobooks became so easily available, the mere sight of the cover would surely elicit judgement, comment, possibly sneers were I to brandish it in public. And, for those of you who don't know me, I will do just about anything to avoid conversation with strangers. But my point is that never mind the hideous imagery of a forty-year old man repeatedly ravishing a twelve-year old girl, this is a gorgeous story, written in the most poetic and powerful words I have ever read. I hate to admit that it took me nearly one year, start to finish, to listen to these twelve odd hours of Lolita; myriad excuses could explain, but they are not important. Last summer, I would take walks around my neighborhood and listen to Jeremy Irons recant the story of Humbert Humbert. You see, my neighborhood claims one or two playgrounds and a sculpture garden to which schools regularly take field trips. Through the powerful combination of Nabokov and Irons, it made me, a forty-something mother of four, feel like a... creep. Yes, a total creep. (This might be why it took me so long to get through the audiobook.) Ironically, about halfway through the story, I began to let go of my disgust for H.H. and listen to his story. (Those of you who have read the book will know what happened at that halfway point; those of you who haven't, well, I'll just say, the book is a most remarkable story, disgusting storyline aside.) If you, my reader, (ah, Nabokov is speaking through me after all) do not know, dear Mr. Humbert is reciting the tale of Lolita in his own defense or at least confession of a crime to a jury. We first-time readers do not know until about 2/3 through the book, what crime he has committed, and not until very near the end do we know the victim of said crime. I would not dream of spoiling that for you here; I will only say that the suspense, the glorious, cinematic climax is so enthralling that had I been a student or random employee, I would have had to call in sick today just to hear the end of the story before I did one more task. And the end of the book, the very end, is so beautiful (a trite word here) and poetic and powerful that as soon as I hit "save" on this , I am going directly to a bookstore to purchase a hardback copy of this book so that I can reread my favorite passages if not the entire book today or one day or any day I am in need of seeing (not just hearing) a literary genius at work. Oh, by the way, in case you hadn't guessed, I give this book Five stupendous Stars....more

title: Taft
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Taft is Ann Patchett's second novel out of an oeuvre of six (plus a few non-fiction works). To date, I had read all her other novels; this was my finaTaft is Ann Patchett's second novel out of an oeuvre of six (plus a few non-fiction works). To date, I had read all her other novels; this was my final one to read. If you've followed my previous s, you know by now that I love her work, but I have to say this is my least favorite.Patchett has a formula—that is not a bad thing. She twists the stories so well that it's difficult to lump them into any single category. Patchett likes to throw total strangers into a bowl and see how they mix. In Taft, she tells the tale of a single-father black man in Memphis who manages a bar. "A girl walked into the bar." is the first line. I was immediately expecting a bit of humor, but there was little humor to be had.The story is told mainly in first person. Ok, so first person black man in Memphis told by a lovely white woman who did not grow up in Memphis. That is an undertaking. The voice of the primary character (whose name we don't learn until halfway through the book) does not come across to me as a black man. In fact, I didn't even know he was supposed to be black until a hundred pages in. I may have missed it, but none the less, it was not obvious. The character (John) didn't sound black, he sometimes sounded like a 30-year old Holden Caulfield.It's possibly unfair to judge an author's early works against her later works; becoming a better writer is always the goal. However, this novel did not draw me in as her other works do. I might have put it down after 50 pages if I wasn't such a big fan of hers. About half way through, I really started to care about the characters and I think the novel had a good (not great) finish. It is well-foreshadowed which created a certain degree of suspense. The title character, Taft (not the hero), is the deceased father of "the girl who walked into the bar." Patchett does a back and forth thing with "John" and "Taft" that is effective but confusing. It picks up the pace of the book, but the two story lines did not seem of equal importance for such a literary task. All in all, I can't give this novel more than 3 Stars. I'm glad I didn't read it before I read Bel Canto and State of Wonder—I might have been turned off. In any case, I still love Ann Patchett's work, and I am eager for her next novel. ...more

title: The Art of Fielding
author: Harbach, Chad*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I feel sorry for Chad Harbach. The Art of Fielding is an excellent book, but it received so much publicity and hype that it is nearly impossible to reI feel sorry for Chad Harbach. The Art of Fielding is an excellent book, but it received so much publicity and hype that it is nearly impossible to read it without great expectations. And as we all know, it's difficult to live up to such high expectations. For the first quarter of this novel (which logs in at 512 pages), I read it with a grudge: "This had better knock my socks off!" It didn't. But by the time I got to the middle, I began loving the story. I truly wanted to know what was happening with my friends Henry, Mike, Owen, Pella and the rest. And by the time I got to page 450, I could not put the book down until I finished it. Tom Perrotta (author of The Leftovers) recently said in an interview, "... you should be more interested toward the end of a book than you are in the beginning. Which is not always the case in literary fiction... That kind of primal narrative engagement, I don't know why literary novels should give that up." Mr. Perrotta would like this book. The Art of Fielding is definitely literary fiction, and the plot crescendos in the end like a mystery.Harbach is a great writer. It is obvious that he is well-educated (Harvard and Univ. of Virginia) and well-read. There are many references to the myriad novels on any given English Literature syllabus, primarily and specifically, Melville's Moby Dick. Harbach avoids using too many adverbs and concentrates on clever and erudite adjectives (e.g.: a curdled marriage, the expensive riotous green of the grass). The best element of the book, however, is the subtlety with which Harbach elucidates on humanity. The story is set on a fictitious Wisconsin college campus, and the main characters are members of the baseball team, plus the President of the University. Baseball is the framework for the story, but it's not about baseball; it's about what it's like to be human from many different perspectives. I wish I had found this book before I heard the remarkable publishing story behind it—I might have given it 5 Stars—but then again, I probably wouldn't have picked up a book about baseball....more

title: Train Dreams
author: Johnson, Denis
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I picked up this book, I didn't expect to like it as much as I did. I had not yet read anything by Denis Johnson—specifically his novel Tree of SWhen I picked up this book, I didn't expect to like it as much as I did. I had not yet read anything by Denis Johnson—specifically his novel Tree of Smoke did not interest me at all. (That 2007 winner of the National Book Award is about the Vietnam war.) So when I found Train Dreams which clocks in at 115 pages, I bought it immediately and moved it to the top of my To Read list. I'm so glad I did.Johnson pulled me into a story set at the beginning of the 20th Century about a man who works on a railroad. That alone shows how talented he is as a writer. His imagination is fantastic—the story took twists and turns I never would have thought of in a hundred years. I am also a fan of Johnson's writing style. He is not afraid of commas. (I tend to use a lot of commas in my writing, therefore I find comfort in writers of Johnson's caliber who do the same.) If you love Denis Johnson's work, this book will not disappoint you. If you've never read anything by him, this is the place to start. It is truly a heartbreaking story of "pulchritude." Five Stars....more

title: A Good Hard Look
author: Napolitano, Ann*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am so happy I "met" Ann Napolitano through Twitter. If I hadn't, I don't think I would have purchased, read, and loved her book.A Good Hard Look is I am so happy I "met" Ann Napolitano through Twitter. If I hadn't, I don't think I would have purchased, read, and loved her book.A Good Hard Look is set in Milledgeville, Georgia in the early 60s. Cookie, the protagonist is a "frenemy" of Flannery O'Connor. The two women "grew up together", but the story takes place when they are both in their 30s. The story is bittersweet and very engaging. This is where I must confess that I have never read any of Flannery O'Connor's work. (I was not an English major.) She's always been one of those authors who fall into my "One day I should read something he/she wrote" category. But since I was not familiar with O'Connor, I didn't buy A Good Hard Look when it first came out. I read the great s by others, but my stack of Books To Read already threatens to topple over on me in my sleep. Here enters Twitter. Ann Napolitano is quite engaging, and we have other favorite authors in common, specifically, Ann Patchett. The more she and I "Tweeted", the more interested I became in her work, so I bought this novel.Napolitano is a wonderful writer. Her prose is elegant and smart. The story draws you in, then about 2/3 through, it socks you in the face! Wow! One day life is good, then the next... well, you should read this book yourself to see what I mean. And, if there's anyone else out there who has shied away from this book because they're not familiar with O'Connor, don't let that stop you. In fact, I recently purchased A Good Man Is Hard To Find, a short story collection by O'Connor. So, not only did I find a wonderful book by a contemporary author, but I will finally read something by Flannery O'Connor herself. Thank you, Ann.4 Stars...more

title: Out Of Range        (Joe Pickett, #5)
author: Box, C.J.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One thing I love about reading is discovering a book you love by an author you've never read before. C. J. Box is one of those authors. (Ann Patchett One thing I love about reading is discovering a book you love by an author you've never read before. C. J. Box is one of those authors. (Ann Patchett is my other new favorite author.) I've never read his work even though I had seen his books in bookstores. Out Of Range is a great story. I picked it up because the story takes place in Jackson, Wyoming (where my WIP takes place. I wanted to read how a Wyoming native wrote about the same location).Box is a storyteller, in the best sense of the word. His writing is pure and never gets in the way of the story. Specifically, the hero Joe Pickett (this is apparently his fifth Pickett novel) is a fully developed, complicated man. He seems authentic and yet relateable, even for someone who's never personally dealt with a game warden. But my favorite element of this novel is the number (at least five, maybe seven) of "bad guys" in the story. Box kept me turning the pages because so many of his characters made me nervous - I was anxious to find out who did what, and what they were going to do next.I read this book in a couple days, and I'm very glad I did. I might even read another C. J. Box novel in the near future. I can't give it five stars because it seems a little cookie-cutter, but believe me when I say: I love cookies. Four stars....more

title: The New York Trilogy        (New York Trilogy #1-3)
author: Auster, Paul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Paul Auster, Paul Auster, where for art thou, Paul Auster?" Or rather, WHO for art thou?Paul Auster is like a raccoon that picks apart his characters"Paul Auster, Paul Auster, where for art thou, Paul Auster?" Or rather, WHO for art thou?Paul Auster is like a raccoon that picks apart his characters' brains sharing this fact, hiding that fact, mixing up the pieces until even the reader feels she's going mad... in this case, me. Paul Auster is like a master of disguises, inserting himself into his characters and stories and then slipping back out before we know he's gone.The New York Trilogy is, duh, a trilogy, and yet, I didn't know that until the very end of the third short story. A little dense, perhaps (again, I'm talking about myself). Except for a couple hints, I thought this was simply three short stories until Auster expertly weaves them back together. There are a few inconsistencies, and yet I think those might be intentional to leave normal people like me wondering... City of Glass, the first story, is meta-fiction, meaning it plays mind games with the reader. I loved that. Yes, he shows off, but that's part of his beauty. Auster is like a soccer player I once saw standing on a ledge high atop the steps at Sacre Coeur expertly juggling a soccer ball in ways that a mother cannot watch. He's just that much better than would-be writers like myself. The second story, Ghosts, is another mind game, White hires Blue to follow Black who lives on Orange Street, only Black is White and he is watching Blue. Get the picture? Exactly.Finally, The Locked Room wraps up the book. It maybe my favorite of the three, but I might have said that about the other two if I wrote separate s after each story. That's how immediate the trance from Auster's writing, how he pulls the reader in so deeply. The Locked Room has a love element to it, which is might be why I liked it best. Auster's novels are a little harsh, not in a chauvinistic way, just in a gritty guy way. His characters walk the streets of New York, often give up eating, showering, shaving, even talking much. They just tend to go quietly crazy. His characters ask nothing of the reader: You don't have to like me. You don't have to identify with me. You don't have to care about me. If you want to read this, ok; if not, piss off. Paul Auster is a brilliant writer, but I guess I enjoy a bit more human interaction from my literature.4 Stars ...more

title: The Patron Saint of Liars
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not really sure it's fair to judge a work from an author's oeuvre when you read them out of order. The Patron Saint of Liars is Ann Patchett's firI'm not really sure it's fair to judge a work from an author's oeuvre when you read them out of order. The Patron Saint of Liars is Ann Patchett's first novel, yet it's the fourth one I've read. Her most famous (successful) novel, Bel Canto, was the second one for me. I loved The Patron Saint of Liars. I could barely put it down. Patchett has the most incredible way of drawing me into her novels to the point I feel like I'm friends with her protagonist. This story might actually be my favorite of hers, except that after reading State of Wonder, Bel Canto, and Run, I had a few nit-picky complaints. Do you think that you hold your favorite authors to a higher standard? I think I do. The Patron Saint of Liars is about a pregnant woman who runs away from her husband because she doesn't love him and doesn't want to have his baby. She finds a home where pregnant girls can go (this is set in the 60s) to live out their pregnancy and then give their babies away. Only this woman decides to keep her baby. Like I said, I could barely put this book down, but the element that keeps me from giving it 5 Stars (other than some editing that I would have done differently) is that I didn't like the ending. It wasn't warm and fuzzy and neat and tidy.However, Ann Patchett deserves to end her stories any way she wants. She's an excellent writer, one of my all time favorites, and this is just a personal opinion. I recommend this book to all women, and to all men who want to understand women better.4+ Stars...more

title: Farewell, My Lovely        (Philip Marlowe, #2)
author: Chandler, Raymond
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Before I pick up a Raymond Chandler novel, I need to pick up a pencil. He has some of the funniest and best-said lines—in my opinion—in literary histoBefore I pick up a Raymond Chandler novel, I need to pick up a pencil. He has some of the funniest and best-said lines—in my opinion—in literary history. E.g.: "...he looked about as inconspicuous as a tarantula on a slice of angel food cake." "She gave me a smile I could feel in my hip pocket." "His gray eyes were lumps of ice." "... thought in my mind moved with a kind of sluggish stealthiness, as if it was being watched by bitter and sadistic eyes." How could a person write better description than that?This is only my second Chandler novel (The Long Goodbye is next for me). So far, I have to say that my biggest/only complaint with Chandler's work is that it can get muddled in the middle. In this novel, as well as The Big Sleep, I lost sight of exactly what his detective, Philip Marlowe, was trying to solve. Specifically, Marlowe is hired by a man who is soon killed, then he meets a few other players and he is off on a hunt... but until Chandler does a mini-summary of Marlowe's thoughts, I wasn't sure exactly what he was trying to solve, or whom he was working for. Perhaps I get distracted.In any case, I love Chandler's work, I would like to meet Philip Marlowe, I would like to emulate Chandler's career.4+ Stars ...more

title: The Skating Rink
author: Bolaño, Roberto
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My first Roberto Bolaño book! I can easily say the man is a poet and a literary genius. Without having read any of his other works, it's impossible foMy first Roberto Bolaño book! I can easily say the man is a poet and a literary genius. Without having read any of his other works, it's impossible for me to say how this stands in his oeuvre, but I can say it was a fantastic book to read. In case anyone reading this  has not yet read Bolaño, I can say this novella is an excellent entry for the curious. It is light enough and accessible enough that no one need be intimidated (like I was).On the surface, The Skating Rink is a story about a murder told alternately by three men. They are loosely linked by a beautiful, young ice skater—who may or may not be the one who is murdered. The story is rendered in very brief "chapters" from each narrator; each ends in a thought and an ellipse. One er called it another of Bolaño's "sui generis," and I loved it as a style choice. As I read the book, I could almost picture these three Latin men sitting around a massive oak table with a microphone placed directly in the center by a silent director giving each man a turn to add a layer to this delicate creation. There are so many levels on which to talk about this work: the plot, the characters, the writing, the genre, etc. On the writerly level, The Skating Rink receives 5 Stars from me, no question. Bolaño forms some of the most poetic, elegant, descriptive sentences I have ever read, beginning with the opening sentence: "The first time I saw him, it was in the Calle Bucareli, in Mexico City, that is, back in the vague shifty territory of our adolescence, the province of hardened poets, on a night of heavy fog, which slowed the traffic and prompted conversations about that odd phenomenon, so rare in Mexico City at night, at least as far as I can remember." I love it! "... the vague shifty territory of our adolescence..." The book is filled with these flowing gems.On a plot level, well, this is where I deduct one star. Many might disagree, arguing for the brilliance of the subtle, literary pace of the story and the graceful, loose ending. But this is my  and I like a stronger plot. I expected a different ending, and to be honest, I wasn't thrilled by Bolaño's choice there. That didn't ruin the book for me, but it does drop my  a notch. (I would be more specific, but I don't want to add any spoilers.)Once again I feel uncomfortably restrained by goodreads inability to award "half" stars. I'm going with 4 Stars, but the next time I read it, I might bump it to 5. I'll let you know....more

title: We the Animals
author: Torres, Justin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow, I started this book yesterday without knowing where it was going. Not that the ending wasn't expertly foreshadowed, it's just that I didn't expecWow, I started this book yesterday without knowing where it was going. Not that the ending wasn't expertly foreshadowed, it's just that I didn't expect it to be so powerful, and probably painful and cathartic for Torres to write. Briefly, this is a first person tale of a young boy with two older brothers, a white mother, and a Puetro Rican father. Life was the opposite of easy for them, but they had so much love between them that the story is heart-breakingly bittersweet. Justin Torres calls this a novel, but it reads like a marvelous blend of novel/short story collection/ memoir. I have not heard enough or read enough to know how true the story is, but true or completely fictional, I thought this was a fabulous book. It's very short and reads very quickly, so I highly recommennd squeezing it into your list (as your next book). Not only was the story gripping, but Torres is an excellent writer. I am already eager for his next book - I hope it is just as strong. Five stars. ...more

title: Run
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wish I could give half stars... This book deserves 4 1/2. Patchett, in my mind, has brought back the Omniscient novel. She elegantly and deeply descI wish I could give half stars... This book deserves 4 1/2. Patchett, in my mind, has brought back the Omniscient novel. She elegantly and deeply describes each one of her characters so well that I feel as if they are my neighbors and friends. Run by Ann Patchett—who has quickly become one of my favorite authors—is a tale of a Boston family; it's not about politics, as some say. Patchett makes the reader feel as if they are living in her imaginary world, in very tight prose. (Weird thing was, I actually was in Boston for part of the time I was reading it, but I would have felt that, even from Des Moines.) (In her novel, Bel Canto, I felt like I was inside the compound in the unnamed South American country where that story takes place.)My only knock on Run is Chapter 8 when one of characters is in the hospital. I wish I could ask Patchett why she felt the need to take that subplot where she did. I didn't feel it was necessary. In fact, it kind of disappointed me. But, I am such a fan of hers that I will easily let it slide and assume that she knows better than I do.Bravo, again, Ms. Patchett....more

title: Mentor: A Memoir
author: Grimes, Tom
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was very moved—and only slightly disheartened—by Tom Grimes' account of his writing life, and how it intersected/was shaped by Frank Conroy. It's noI was very moved—and only slightly disheartened—by Tom Grimes' account of his writing life, and how it intersected/was shaped by Frank Conroy. It's not just me... seems all writers flail, cry and scream about their writing! Tom Grimes is an excellent writer. The fact that his fiction has never reached the heights he'd hoped for as a young man is, perhaps, only a matter of time. If any novelist writes more than one or two phenomenal books in his or her lifetime, it's a path to eternal fame. Perhaps Grimes just hasn't written his yet. But this memoir is extremely well written. In fact, it reads like a novel, perfectly paced with a dramatic episode beginning in Chapter Nineteen. Wow! Deep, personal, moving and refreshingly honest. Writers and those-who-love-writers should all read this book to help understand the internal pressures of being a serious writer. As he says on page 142, "You don't choose the writer's life; the writer's life chooses you." I think the key is to keep one's expectations balanced with a life outside of the publishing world. Yeah, good luck with that. Five Stars, Mr. Grimes....more

author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved this book! Ann Patchett created an amazing world with an appropriate hero, antagonist, and a long list (but not too long) of supporting characI loved this book! Ann Patchett created an amazing world with an appropriate hero, antagonist, and a long list (but not too long) of supporting characters. The primary location for this novel is deep in the Amazon, and I felt like I was there with the description of the heat, the bugs, the river, and the people. I have spent considerable time in the depths Costa Rica (not the Amazon, but not dissimilar), and the novel felt very true to third-world equatorial countries. The book is told from an omniscient POV, which I enjoyed. The story was engaging, the plot gripping and fast-paced—I read it in less than 3 days—and the characters were very believable. I think I fell in love with Easter, the little deaf boy they meet in Brazil.. This was my first Patchett book, and I am eager to read Bel Canto, Run, and anything else she has written. I don't expect to be disappointed.My highest recommendation. Five stars....more

title: A Yellow Raft in Blue Water
author: Dorris, Michael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A dear friend of mine recommended I read this book—published in 1987—and I am happy to have squeezed it into my long list of books TBR. About 3/4 of tA dear friend of mine recommended I read this book—published in 1987—and I am happy to have squeezed it into my long list of books TBR. About 3/4 of the way through, I was contemplating whether I'd give it 4 stars or 5. As you can see, I give it 4 stars.A Yellow Raft In Blue Water was a remarkable tale of 3 women (daughter, mother, grandmother) written by a man. There is the requisite overlap of scenes, told from each woman's perspective, and yet each part of the novel is in 1st POV from each character. It was so enlightening in that it reinforced that we really know very little about our ancestors' lives and histories.This novel engaged me much more intensely than I expected it to. Michael Dorris did an excellent job of creating characters who were flawed enough that the reader truly cares about each one. I have two criticisms about this book, not that Michael Dorris need to worry about what I think. First, there were way too many metaphors and similes. Many of them were beautiful and elucidating, but they began to overwhelm me, especially in the Rayona section (Part 1 about the daughter). Second, throughout Part 1 and 2, the grandmother is extremely cold and angry. I expected Part 3 to explain why she was so cold, but it never really got there. Yes, it (she) answered many questions, but it didn't explain why she was so, so distant and removed from her daughter. Overall, I truly enjoyed this book. I recommend it, with only slight reservations. Chalk it up, if you will, to the fact that my friend RAVED about it... so it had no place to go but down. However, if you've any of read my previous s, 4 Stars is pretty damn good....more

Timothy Schaffert created some wonderful characters, e.g. Essie the Obit writer-grandmother; and Doc, who isn't really a doc. The story, about a young girl who may or may not have ever existed, was well told and very true to life, set in a small Midwestern town. My rating, of 3 stars rather than 4, says more about me and my tastes in literature than in Schaffert's writing abilities, which are superb. I enjoy plot-driven books more than literary, character-driven stories, and I realized a few times while reading that my mind had wandered off to other things. For anyone who likes precious family stories, I highly recommend The Coffins of Little Hope. For those of us who devour Dennis Lehane, my rating is 3 stars....more

review: Review Updated 2022: My book club chose FRANKENSTEIN as our annual "modern classic" choice. Wow, it holds up! I loved it even more this time around. IReview Updated 2022: My book club chose FRANKENSTEIN as our annual "modern classic" choice. Wow, it holds up! I loved it even more this time around. It's amazing how wise and prescient 19-year-old Mary Shelley was to have written this story more than 200 years ago.If you haven't read FRANKENSTEIN in a while, I highly recommend you give it another go. FIVE frightfully-brilliant STARSReview 2011: The world doesn't need my opinion on this book to declare it a masterwork, but if someone else out there hasn't read it before, I highly recommend it. I was afraid, since it was written in 1818, that it would be slow, dense and difficult to get through, but it was the opposite. Frankenstein is a fast paced, readable classic. This book is the perfect example of an exciting plot. Shelley, although she was a young woman when she wrote it, somehow mastered the edict to write only scenes that propel the plot. There was very little description of scenery, clothing, etc., except where it was important. Definitely, five of five stars. I'm very happy I finally read this classic!...more

review: This is a classic, undoubtedly, and an early influence on many of my favorite books and movies. I love Chandler's tight prose, twisting plots and hat-This is a classic, undoubtedly, and an early influence on many of my favorite books and movies. I love Chandler's tight prose, twisting plots and hat-wearing, monochromatically dressed bad guys. It's amazing to me (but then, I'm easily amazed) how much the English language has morphed in the past 70 years. There are so many words and phrases that I was completely unfamiliar with-but then, the LA underground of the 30s wasn't exactly my scene anymore than the LA underground of the 21st Century is. Also interesting is how writing has changed. This classic and quintessential work of noir fiction now reads like a "what not to do" manual of cliched metaphors. A classic, and yet, I'm happy noir fiction has evolved. ...more

title: Plotting and Writing Suspense Fiction
author: Highsmith, Patricia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was thrilled to find a how-to-write book by one of my favorite authors, Patricia Highsmith, of the Talented Mr. Ripley and Strangers on a Train fameI was thrilled to find a how-to-write book by one of my favorite authors, Patricia Highsmith, of the Talented Mr. Ripley and Strangers on a Train fame. And, while I underlined many wise and helpful hints throughout the book, I found it less helpful than say Stephen King's On Writing, and even Elmore Leonard's 10 Rules of Writing. First of all, through no fault of the late Ms. Highsmith, the book is now quite dated. She writes a lot about her interaction (direct interaction) with editors, publishers, her typewriter and carbon copy drafts, and her personal journey with one particular novel, The Glass Cell. From where I sit (behind a computer, non-published), the world of writing and publishing is a bit different these days. Ms. Highsmith was not a professor, so perhaps this book exists mainly to give us a peek into the mind of a great suspense writer. And for that, I loved it. At 145 pages, it is a quick read, and it will hold a permanent spot on my bookshelves....more

title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You know that eerie feeling when disparate energies collide? That's how I felt while reading the great novel, Fahrenheit 451 by Ray Bradbury.When thisYou know that eerie feeling when disparate energies collide? That's how I felt while reading the great novel, Fahrenheit 451 by Ray Bradbury.When this book was first published in 1953, it was labeled Science Fiction; still is. But reading it for the first time in 2011, it feels like "normal" fiction. The events/objects/feelings that Bradbury imagined shortly after WWII that are now part of our everyday lives is astounding: "Seashell Radio" ear plugs = iPod headphones; 24 hour robot tellers = ATMs; TV shows of "family members" that interact with the viewer = reality shows; the demise of books = e-publishing; the panic over the disappearance of books = writers everywhere! This book isn't science fiction, simply a mainstream novel that was published fifty years early. And ironically, it has just been announced that Fahrenheit 451 will soon be available as an ebook. OH MY, the laugh that Ray Bradbury must have had with that decision! So we have brilliant writing, a prescient (now contemporary) story, a love of books and publishing, a gripping plot, and a passion for knowledge—I want to party with Ray Bradbury!The story of Guy Montag parallels another of my favorite fictional characters: Dagny Taggart. Dagny Taggart is, of course, the heroine of Ayn Rand's Atlas Shrugged (published in 1957). Dagny went in search of John Galt, propelled by the idiocy of the "second-handers," i.e., those who tried to save intelligence from those who would burn all books in Fahrenheit 451. Perhaps it's not unusual to find a link between these two books considering they are of the same era, as are so many other of my favorites (too numerous to mention!). I love to picture what the world was like outside when these writers were inside putting pen to paper (literally) or pecking away on a clacking typewriter, fixing the tangled keys, replacing the ribbon when it ran out, sliding the return right to left at the end of each line, inserting page after page as quickly as they could type. After Hiroshima, I imagine it was easy to picture the end of the world just over the horizon; thank goodness that hasn't come true (yet).Fahrenheit 451 was received in its day by mixed s. Even now, specifically on goodreads, it has received mixed s. I think it is a wonderful and well-written book, and I'm surprised it's not more popular than it is. I would recommend it to anyone.Five Stars to Fahrenheit 451. ...more

review: Colum McCann is a master of literature. This novel, Let the Great World Spin, is elegant, poignant, lyrical and so beautifully written. I underlined mColum McCann is a master of literature. This novel, Let the Great World Spin, is elegant, poignant, lyrical and so beautifully written. I underlined many, many phrases to remember the way McCann describes ordinary objects or people in the most extraordinary way. I would love (or possibly hate) being a student of his at Hunter College.McCann wraps several personal vignettes around one singular event: Phillipe Petit's 1974 walk between the World Trade Center Towers. With incredibly diverse and imaginative stories, McCann sculpts the lives, in a complicated interlaced network, of people from many different walks of life, and yet the completed novel fits beautifully together ~ like the most delicate and gorgeous puzzle.The novel is long at 349 pages, and it reads very slowly, or at least I read it slowly because I didn't want to miss a single sentence. My dogeared, underlined copy will be on my bookshelf forever. I'm sure I'll refer to it many times over the coming years.Definitely and easily 5 Stars....more

review: I loved, loved, loved this book. Kazuo Ishiguro is one of the best writers of our time. This novel, written in 1990, takes place over only 6 days. It'I loved, loved, loved this book. Kazuo Ishiguro is one of the best writers of our time. This novel, written in 1990, takes place over only 6 days. It's a first person account set in the late 1950s of an aging British butler who goes on a journey via motorcar and analyzes his life as he narrates his trip.It took me a few pages to get into the quiet subtleties of the story, but that's only because I typically read newer, more commercial novels. Once I slowed down and savored every word, I began to appreciate it for what it is: simply one of the best literary novels I've ever read. It is brilliant, yet accessible. As "Stevens" recounts stories of his personal and professional past, Ishiguro never mentions the words "love" or "jealousy", yet the personal storyline is about exactly this - emotions that Ishiguro beautifully expresses in the ultimate example of "Show, don't tell."I could go on and on with my praise. In short, for anyone who enjoys literature, I highly recommend this book....more

review: Bravo Ellen Meister. Not only did she tackle highly controversial subjects (infidelity, birth defects, abortion, suicide, homosexuality, to name a fewBravo Ellen Meister. And as a reader who has her feet firmly on the ground, I even applaud her use of "portals" into a parallel life. I kept waiting for Meister to explain them away as a dream or fantasy, but she didn't, and in the end, I was glad she let them exist as portals.A captivating combination of character & plot driven, her writing was succinct, and it never got in the way of her story. I was so eager to see what the protagonist's decisions were going to be that I had a difficult time putting the book down. This novel starts out as a "What if I married someone else", but moves quickly into a dozen other "What ifs". And hasn't everyone asked that question of their own life? That's the best element of this book, I'll give it that. But NYTimes top 5 novels of 2010, really? The Pulitzer Prize for fiction, really?In today's world, originality is huge, but this book's acclaim can be analyzed the way Egan devises in the final chapter for the character Alex to choose a group of friends to "use" based on "need", "reach", and " corruptibility". Novels could thus be rated by "originality", "talent", and "audience appeal". I'd give her a 9 for originality (one point off for bordering on gimmicky - I take off 2 pts if I were brave enough to stand up to the NYTimes) and a 7 for talent (Thesaurus, anyone?). And speaking to her audience? Maybe I'm not her target market, but I think I am; I'd give her a 8, two points off for trying to sound ultra cool. That's a 23 or 24/30 in my world; not enough for my Top 5 list. My biggest knock is calling this a novel; I love a long, juicy story, perhaps that one reason I didn't like it more. This is actually a collection of related short stories, a la Olive Kitteridge by Elizabeth Strout, which I loved (and which won the 2009 Pulitzer Prize). With each chapter, Egan introduced new characters in new worlds in new time frames. I found that frustrating, not fun. If she had been more clear about new characters and time frames, I might have fully submerged into each chapter and finished it feeling invigorated.Jennifer Egan is now allowed to deduct major points from my  because she is an acclaimed, published author, and I am not. ...more

review: I think I'm on to Annie Proulx. I ain't never been to Wy-o-ming, and that's just a way she wants it. Tryin a keep the place all to herself. I have a rI think I'm on to Annie Proulx. I ain't never been to Wy-o-ming, and that's just a way she wants it. Tryin a keep the place all to herself. I have a romantic image of Wyoming, open plains leading the way to the majestic Tetons, and of course the cowboys. But Proulx leads one to believe the cowboys are only interested in the other cowboys or the warm mammals, the wide open plains are full of wolves and snakes, and the winters are so harsh that no visitor could ever survive. Her prose is so vivid, so honest, that I feel like I just got back from a vacation in her Wyoming. The landscape is the strongest character in each one of her stories. My only knock is that the tales are so similar, always a down and out hero, barely able to survive, endures more hardship, and then, Wham!, she ends it with a bang that just about leaves the reader breathless. She and Salinger are two of the best authors at creating a unique voice. ...more

author: Didion, Joan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: SECOND READING: More than a decade after my first reading of THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING, I naturally have a different take on Didion's tragic memoirSECOND READING: More than a decade after my first reading of THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING, I naturally have a different take on Didion's tragic memoir. Since then, I have lost a loved one, and I now recognize the grief that Didion writes about. Loss is hard and there are no right ways to grieve—or to write about that grief. Even after two readings, I can scarcely imagine losing a spouse of 40 years, especially a relationship as close and constant as Didion's and Dunne's. And now, in what seems like dramatic irony, I know that roughly six months after this book was published, Didion lost her only daughter, the one who suffered so many tragic health issues in this book. I cannot fathom how Didion got through that. I am clueless though on how/why/who chose the word "magical" for this title. Maybe Didion felt getting through the year after her husband's death took a fair bit of magic, or maybe the publisher thought that's the only way it would sell. Regardless, this is a sad, heart-wrenching tale of loss. Raising my rating to FOUR STARS.FIRST READING: I had high hopes for such a book by such an insightful author. While it was very moving and sad, I never felt like she touched bone with her emotional descriptions. Perhaps she was so devastated she couldn't dig that deeply, or perhaps she is so private that she didn't want to reveal her innermost tear-jerking moments. In any case, I liked the book, she is a beautiful writer, but it seemed coldly factual....more
